('54', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('54', 0, 2, 3, 70) LONDON, October 13, 1931 I do not want to be aggressive.
('54', 0, 2, 4, 127) I maintain that the failure to discover a solution for the communal question is largely due to want of knowledge about the new constitution and also tot he unre presentative character of delegates.
('54', 0, 2, 5, 325) The Government know only too well that the Congress is the only body which can deliver the goods.
('54', 0, 2, 6, 423) What then is the use of their pretending that the Congress is one among different groups, namely, Hindus, Depressed, Classes, Christians, landlords, zamindars?
('54', 0, 2, 7, 583) When the struggle was in progress the Hindu Sabha was not different from the the Congress.
('54', 0, 2, 8, 674) I am certain that a referendum is held today, the Hindus and Depressed Classes will by overwhelming majority be found to be in sympathy with the Congress.
('54', 0, 2, 9, 829) I am certian that the Nationalist Muslims will render a good account of themselves.
('54', 0, 2, 10, 913) If I had my own way, I certainly would surrender to the Muslims, but it will be of no use for the Government to exaggerate the differences which are largely due to the composition of the delegation which is their own action.
('54', 0, 2, 11, 1138) If the Government is genuinely not in favour of framing a constitution prior to a communal settlement, I invite them to put their hand to the plough.
('54', 0, 2, 12, 1288) I am prepared to co operate with the Government on the minimum terms which the Congress is prepared to accept.
('54', 0, 2, 13, 1399) The Congress insists on the fullest control of the army, foreign policy and finance.
('54', 0, 2, 14, 1484) The Government have the choice to accept or reject the Congress demands.
('54', 0, 2, 15, 1557) I do not expect the the Government to solve the Indian question at this Conference, but an participating in it in the fulfilment of the promise that I gave Lord Irwin to discuss every issue and I value the contacts outside the Conference more.
('54', 0, 3, 16, 1801) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 15 10 1931
('54', 1, 0, 1, 1834) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 1, 1, 2, 1874) 2. SPEECH AT INDIAN STUDENTS’ MEETING 1
('54', 1, 2, 3, 1914) LONDON, October 13, 1931
('54', 1, 3, 4, 1939) Gandhiji, after reiterating India’s fundamental claims, said he knew before starting that these were not likely to be granted because no nation ever yet obtained its lost freedom by mere appeal to reason.
('54', 1, 3, 5, 2144) Something much more serious had always been required.
('54', 1, 3, 6, 2198) He did not suppose India would be an exception.
('54', 1, 3, 7, 2246) It was now plainer than ever that only through suffering would victory be won, but his hope was that the suffering already endured might have created a sufficient impression on the British mind favourable to reason and negotiation.
('54', 1, 3, 8, 2478) I must confess that, as I go on, I feel the task Herculean.
('54', 1, 3, 9, 2538) Probably nothing would come out of it, but being an optimist, I would not give up hope in its entirely until I find nothing more can be done.
('54', 1, 3, 10, 2680) Still I pray the seed being sown now will bear fruit in the conscience of this country and the Ministers will feel compelled to come to terms with the nation of sufferers.
('54', 1, 4, 11, 2852) It may be that the seed which is being sown now may result in softening the British spirit and that it may result in the preventing of the brutalization human beings.
('54', 1, 4, 12, 3019) I have known the English nature in its hideous form in the Punjab.
('54', 1, 4, 13, 3086) I have known it elsewhere also, during these fifteen years of experience and through history, I have known the same thing happening.
('54', 1, 4, 14, 3219) It is my purpose by every means at my command to prevent such a catastrophe occurring again.
('54', 1, 4, 15, 3312) I am more concerned in preventing the brutalization of human nature than in preventing the sufferings of my own people.
('54', 1, 4, 16, 3432) I have often gloated over the sufferings of my own people.
('54', 1, 4, 17, 3491) I know that people, who voluntarily undergo a course of suffering raise themselves and the whole of humanity, but I also know that people who become brutalized in their desperate efforts to get victory over their opponents or to exploit weaker nations or weaker men, not only drag down themselves but mankind also.
('54', 1, 4, 18, 3806) And it cannot be a matter of pleasure to me or anyone else to see human nature dragged in the mire.
('54', 1, 4, 19, 3906) If we are all sons of the same God and partake of the same
('54', 1, 5, 20, 3965) 1 The meeting took place in Gower Street Hostel, Bloomsbury.
('54', 1, 5, 21, 4026) Sir Ewart Greaves of the Indian Y.M.C.A. was in the chair.
('54', 1, 5, 22, 4085) 2 What follows is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “London Letter” in Young India.
('54', 2, 0, 1, 4166) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 3
('54', 2, 1, 2, 4210) divine essence, we must partake of the sin of every person whether he belongs to us or to another race.
('54', 2, 1, 3, 4314) You can understand how repugnant it must be to invoke the beast in any human being, how much more so in Englishmen, amongst whom I count numerous friends!
('54', 2, 1, 4, 4469) I invite you to give all the help you can in the endeavour that I am making.
('54', 2, 2, 5, 4546) To the Indian students my appeal is to study this question in all thoroughness and, if you really believe in the power of non violence and truth, then, for God’s sake express these two things in your daily life—not merely in the political field—and you will find that whatever you do in this direction will help me in the struggle.
('54', 2, 2, 6, 4878) It is possible that Englishmen and Englishwomen who come into close touch with you will assure the world that they have never seen students so good, so truthful, as Indian students.
('54', 2, 2, 7, 5060) Don’t you think that that would go a long way towards vindicating our nation?
('54', 2, 2, 8, 5138) The words “self purification” occurred in a Congress Resolution in 1920. From that moment the Congress realized that we were to purify ourselves.
('54', 2, 2, 9, 5284) We were by self sacrifice to purify ourselves so that we would deserve liberty and so that God would also be with us.
('54', 2, 2, 10, 5402) If that is the case, every Indian whose life bears testimony to the spirit of self sacrifice helps his country, without having to do anything more.
('54', 2, 2, 11, 5550) Such, in my opinion, is the strength of the means which the Congress adopted.
('54', 2, 2, 12, 5628) Therefore, in the battle for freedom, every student here need do nothing more than that he should purify himself and present a character above reproach and above suspicion.
('54', 2, 3, 13, 5801) Q. Lord Irwin is reported to have said in a speech at the Central Hall that he
('54', 2, 4, 14, 5880) knew you would not insist on Complete Independence.
('54', 2, 4, 15, 5932) Is this true?
('54', 2, 4, 16, 5946) A. Well : In the first instance, I do not know that Lord Irwin made the speech which is imputed to him.
('54', 2, 4, 17, 6050) Secondly, I must not speak for Lord Irwin.
('54', 2, 4, 18, 6093) That would be a question well addressed to him.
('54', 2, 4, 19, 6141) But I never told Lord Irwin that I would not press for Complete Independence.
('54', 2, 4, 20, 6219) On the contrary, so far as my memory serves me right, I told him that I would press for Complete Independence, and, for me that does not mean ruling India through deputies, i.e., Indian agents rather than English agents.
('54', 2, 4, 21, 6440) Complete independence to me means National Government.
('54', 3, 0, 1, 6495) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 3, 1, 2, 6535) Q. How do you reconcile Complete Independence with the retention of British troops.
('54', 3, 2, 3, 6619) A. British troops may remain in India and that would depend upon the arrangement that the partners came to.
('54', 3, 2, 4, 6727) This, for a limit ed period, would be to the interests of India because India has become emasculated and it is necessary to retain some portion of British troops or some portion of British officers under the National Government and in the employ of the National Government.
('54', 3, 2, 5, 7001) I shall defend the partnership and yet defend the retention of those troops.
('54', 3, 3, 6, 7078) Q. Do you envisage a Viceroy when you speak of an Independent India ?
('54', 3, 4, 7, 7148) A. Whether the Viceroy remains is a question to be decided by both the parties.
('54', 3, 4, 8, 7228) Speaking for myself, I cannot conceive a Viceroy remaning.
('54', 3, 4, 9, 7287) But I can conceive a British Agent remaining there because there would be so many interests which the British have brought into being there which I personally do not seek to destroy and, in order to represent those interests and if there is also an army consisting of British troops and officers, I could not possibly say, ‘No, there will not be a British Agent.’ And since there are also the Princes concerned I cannot vouchsafe for what the Princes will do and, therefore, I do not expect that under the scheme I have in mind there will be no British Agent there—whether he is called a Viceroy or a Governor General.
('54', 3, 4, 10, 7906) But I would defend it as a partnership having the condition that it is to be terminated at the will of either on terms of absolute equality.
('54', 3, 4, 11, 8047) I am writing on a slate from which I have to rub out many things.
('54', 3, 5, 12, 8113) Q. What are the common objects that such a partnership would advance ?
('54', 3, 6, 13, 8184) A. The common object that the partnership is going to advance is to cease the exploitation of the races of the earth.
('54', 3, 6, 14, 8302) If India becomes free from this curse of exploitation, under which she has groaned for so many years, it would be up to India to see that there is no further exploitation.
('54', 3, 6, 15, 8474) Real partnership would be of mutual benefit.
('54', 3, 6, 16, 8519) It would be a partnership between two races the one having been known for its manliness, bravery, courage and its unrivalled powers of organization, and the other an ancient race possessing a culture perhaps second to none, a continent in itself.
('54', 3, 6, 17, 8766) A partnership between these two peoples cannot but result in mutual good and be to the benefit of mankind.
('54', 3, 7, 18, 8873) 1 What follows is from The Hindu.
('54', 4, 0, 1, 8907) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 5
('54', 4, 1, 2, 8951) Dealing lengthily with the communal problem, he said he was incapable of bargaining away the rights of minorities and insisted again that the Congress was predominantly representative of the dumb millions.
('54', 4, 1, 3, 9157) The golden rule is : Believe just the contrary of what the newspapers say on such matters.
('54', 4, 1, 4, 9248) What I have been trying to do is to persuade Hindus and Sikhs to give Muslims what they want and persuade Muslims to so frame their demands as to make them acceptable to other communities.
('54', 4, 2, 5, 9437) Regarding smaller minorities, he pointed out the part played by the Parsis in Bombay as an example of what numerically insignificant communities could do without special advantages and what great opportunities adult suffrage would provide all alike.
('54', 4, 3, 6, 9687) The most determined opposition to the claims of untouchables and other minorities except Muslims and Sikhs was expressed by Mr. Gandhi.
('54', 4, 3, 7, 9823) He said: I shall resist those claims at the cost of my life and I appeal to you to join me in shaming the delegates into withdrawing them.
('54', 4, 4, 8, 9962) He denied that he had offered to accept the demands of Mussalmans if they would join him in resisting the demands of untouchables.
('54', 4, 4, 9, 10093) He said he was forced to agree to Muslim and Sikh demands for historical reasons, but he would not agree to the grant of special representation to any other community in any circumstances.
('54', 4, 5, 10, 10282) The manifestations of goodwill by people in England had convinced him that the English people would never again tolerate repression in India.
('54', 4, 5, 11, 10424) If it became necessary for Indians to resume passive resistance and non co operation, he appealed to the students to behave themselves and win the respect of the English people.
('54', 4, 6, 12, 10602) The Hindu, 14 10 1931, and Young India, 29 10 1931

('54', 5, 5, 8, 11323) 4. STATEMENT TO “THE ISLAND” 1
('54', 5, 6, 9, 11354) LONDON, [On or before October 14, 1931] 2
('54', 5, 7, 10, 11396) The movement of artists and poets who are endeavouring to free themselves from the shackles of commercial and industrial influences of this age is a most laudable venture if only they have strength enough to do it.
('54', 5, 7, 11, 11611) Religion is the proper and eternal ally of art.
('54', 5, 7, 12, 11659) What religion teaches people the artist brings near to them in form on the plastic plane.
('54', 5, 7, 13, 11749) I hate “art for art’s sake”, which I think is a lamentable aberration of the human mind.
('54', 5, 7, 14, 11838) Art has a profound similarity with religion inasmuch as the fundamental experience in both of them belongs to the domain of man’s relationship with God.
('54', 5, 7, 15, 11991) Indian art symbolizes this relationship and at the same time expresses the ritual of religious worship.
('54', 5, 7, 16, 12095) If an artist who thinks he is surrounded by people without any religious sentiment chooses to become a scoffer, he will inevitably frustrate his own vocation.
('54', 5, 7, 17, 12254) On the other hand if he feels that his is a mission, then a poet or artist has a right to oppose the prevalent creed or lack of creed and he will be justified by the greater value of his own revelation.
('54', 5, 7, 18, 12457) I do not pretend to know anything about art, but I believe firmly that both religion and art have to serve the identical aims of moral and spiritual elevation.
('54', 5, 7, 19, 12617) The central experience of life will for ever remain the relationship which man has to God and it will never be superseded or replaced by anything else, just as human bodies will never free themselves from the law of gravitation.
('54', 5, 7, 20, 12846) In this relationship of man to God it is the

('54', 5, 8, 22, 12967) The latter made a record of it and submitted the script for Gandhiji’s approval.
('54', 5, 8, 23, 13048) Gandhiji approved it, except for the last paragraph which read: “Both the priestlike and the artistic human beings aspire to what is sacred and, when the vulgar mind pities them for the sacrifices they make, they forget that for both of them a sacrifice retains the joyous meaning of its origin—the road towards the sacred.” 2 The Island gave the date line October 14.

('54', 6, 3, 5, 13743) 5. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('54', 6, 4, 6, 13769) LONDON, October 14, 1931 Though it is a matter for deep sorrow that the negotiations for a communal settlement failed, I have not given up hope of success.
('54', 6, 4, 7, 13925) In spite of the Premier’s energetic disclaimer, I still hold that the causes of the failure were inherent in the composition of the Conference.
('54', 6, 4, 8, 14069) I am more than ever convinced that the framing of a constitution should not depend on the previous settlement of the communal question.
('54', 6, 4, 9, 14205) It was, therefore, wrong for the Premier to suggest that further progress in constitution making largely depended on the communal settlement.
('54', 6, 4, 10, 14347) In judging events here the Indian public will do well to bear in mind these two defects in Government procedure; they will then not become nervours each time there is failure.
('54', 6, 4, 11, 14523) I have had several protracted conversations with the Muslim Delegation, but we could not come to a final conclusion.
('54', 6, 4, 12, 14640) I have felt the absence of Dr. Ansari a severe handicap, but he will be of no real use unless the Muslim Delegation desires or approves of his selection as a delegate.
('54', 6, 4, 13, 14808) The position I have taken up is of a double character.
('54', 6, 4, 14, 14863) In an individual capacity I have retained my original position, namely, to concede all to all parties, but, as a Congress delegate,I have endeavoured to act as an intermediary, up to now without success.
('54', 6, 4, 15, 15067) I have made it clear I should have to receive the sanction of the Working Committee before I accept any scheme.
('54', 6, 4, 16, 15179) I have made no reference to the Working Committee, as I have nothing definite before me.
('54', 6, 4, 17, 15268) At the same time I am keeping myself in touch with all parties.
('54', 6, 4, 18, 15332) The moment I have anything on which I have to take action, I shall ask for instructions.
('54', 6, 4, 19, 15421) Meanwhile, I would warm the public against being affected or agitated by newspaper reports.
('54', 6, 4, 20, 15513) The Hindu , 15 10 1931

('54', 7, 1, 2, 15576) 6. SPEECH AT FEDERAL STRUCTURE COMMITTEE MEETING
('54', 7, 2, 3, 15625) LONDON, October 14, 1931
('54', 7, 3, 4, 15650) MY LORD CHANCELLOR AND FRIENDS, I have to tender my apology for intervening in the debate.
('54', 7, 3, 5, 15741) It was my intention to request you to give me a few minutes at the end of this discussion for making a few brief remarks, but, as I listened to the discussion yesterday, I thought I might be able to make a suggestion which might remove the difficulty with which this Committee had to contend.
('54', 7, 3, 6, 16034) I became more convinced than ever of this when Mr. Jinnah presented his difficulty, and therefore, it was that I requested you, Lord Chancellor, with apologies to Dr. Shafa’at Ahmad, to let me intervene and make a few remarks.
('54', 7, 3, 7, 16261) I want to do so with a view to saving time if possible.
('54', 7, 3, 8, 16317) Before I proceed with my suggestion, I should like to tender my congratulations to Lord Peel’s Subcommittee upon their labours and upon the exhaustive reprot they have given to us.
('54', 7, 3, 9, 16498) I feel, however, that the Sub committee aimed too hight, and hence, quite unconsciously, threw an apple of discord in our midst.
('54', 7, 3, 10, 16627) The reference is clearly to examine and report upon the general principles upon which the finan cial resources and obligations of India should be apportioned between the federation, etc.
('54', 7, 3, 11, 16814) Well, in my humble opinion, if the Sub committee had not aimed too high, it could have presented us with a definite scheme.
('54', 7, 3, 12, 16938) I sympathize with Mr. Jinnah's objection; but at the root of his objection is, I believe, a misunderstanding of Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru's presentation of his case—this is to say, if I have understood him correctly.
('54', 7, 3, 13, 17151) Mr. Jinnah's objection is that, unless there was some sort of a scheme, there could be no Federation whatsoever.
('54', 7, 3, 14, 17264) I think that that would be a fatal objection if it was true.
('54', 7, 3, 15, 17325) If I have understood Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru's contention correctly, it is that there should be a scheme, but that there might be, or should be, an Expert Committee to be brought into being by the Federal Government, if it ever comes into being, which could examine the whole question de novo, and present that Government with an exhaustive report.
('54', 7, 3, 16, 17672) Naturally, that report could be shelved, could be torn to pieces, examined by all the parties and, if it commended itself to them, it could be then adopted by the Federal Government.
('54', 7, 3, 17, 17855) There was no question of embodying
('54', 8, 0, 1, 17890) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 9
('54', 8, 1, 2, 17934) that report in any constitution.
('54', 8, 1, 3, 17967) The constiution would have been framed before the Federal Government came into being.
('54', 8, 1, 4, 18053) I personally confess that I do not envisage a constitution, to be framed by the greatest Parliament of the world, that would make us riskproof and difficulties proof.
('54', 8, 1, 5, 18220) I believe that this Federal Government, if it comes into being would be faced even in the very beginning with many difficulties with which it would have manfully to struggle; but I feel that it is not beyond the power of this Sub committee to give us an elementary scheme about which all parties are agreed.
('54', 8, 1, 6, 18528) I do not mind how humble that scheme is, but it should be a scheme which would commend itself to the States.
('54', 8, 1, 7, 18637) Let the States themselves decide, in consultation with the other members of this Conference, as to how far they are willing to go.
('54', 8, 1, 8, 18768) Let me illustrate what I am saying.Here, as they have started with a mention of the natural difficulties that they have to contend against, the whole of this Report is a tentative Report and for its finality it depneds upon these two Expert Committees which have been suggested by the Sub committee.
('54', 8, 1, 9, 19068) What I feel is that, just as they have said in paragraph 10 that so many heads are marked "Federal", if they could sit again, and if this Report was referred back to them, they would then come, not with a tentative suggestion, but with an agreed suggestion that so many items of revenue would be federal.
('54', 8, 1, 10, 19373) Even if there was an Expert Committee appointed, we would certainly not get absolutely accurate figures.
('54', 8, 1, 11, 19478) Absolutely accurate figures can only be had after the event has happened—after the revenues have been collected—but we should have something to go by.
('54', 8, 1, 12, 19629) I venture to suggest that such a thing is not necessary for our purose before we can come to an agreement as to what items shall be or shall not be considered to be Federal; and so I simply take up these items and I say, let them concentrate upon these items to the exclusion of everything else and say definitely,‘Yes, External Customs, including Export duties, shall be Federal’ or ‘shall not be Federal’.
('54', 8, 1, 13, 20037) Then they would know immediately what are the sources of revenue.
('54', 8, 1, 14, 20103) Similarly, let them sit together and say‘These will be the obligations that shall be Federal’, and let the States decide for themselves.
('54', 8, 1, 15, 20240) After all, it is they who are invited to come, or who have volunteered to come.
('54', 8, 1, 16, 20320) I welcome gratefully the assurance given by His Highness of Bhopal, as also by His Highness of Bikaner.
('54', 8, 1, 17, 20424) My sympathies are entirely with Sir Akbar Hydari when he says that he cannot possibly, either on behalf of Hyderabad or on behalf of the States' Delegation, take a leap
('54', 9, 0, 1, 20593) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 9, 1, 2, 20634) in the dark.
('54', 9, 1, 3, 20647) Let there, therefore, be no leap in the dark; and, in order to avoid such a catastrophe, let there be just now a very humble scheme of participation, and let us launch that humble scheme.
('54', 9, 1, 4, 20835) Then it would be open to the Federal Government—and there should be sufficient elasticity, for which His Higheness of Bhopal pleaded, in the consti tution itself to eanable the Federal Government and the Federal Parliament—to take on what burdens they chose to take on.
('54', 9, 1, 5, 21105) We do not want a castiron constitution, out of which we can never get, or to which we may never make any addition or amendment.
('54', 9, 1, 6, 21233) If we have an elastic constitution, then it will be open to the Federal Government, as it gains experience, to appoint, not one Expert Committee, but ten Expert Committees to examine many things; and then the Federal Government, as it begins its march, will shoulder further responsibi lities, and as it proceeds to shoulder resonsibilites, it will also have further avenues of revenue to be derived from various sources.
('54', 9, 1, 7, 21655) If one the thing is launched, I anticipate no difficulty and no trouble of any kind whatsoever.
('54', 9, 1, 8, 21751) Therefore my concrete suggestion, if it commends itself to you, is that we refer this Report back to the Sub committee with thanks, and ask the Sub committee, with the material at its disposal, to give us a minimum scheme to which the States agree; and that we accept that scheme as a scheme to start with, without any encum brance in the shape of Expert Committees.
('54', 9, 1, 9, 22118) I we do that, we meet entirely Mr. Jinnah's objection, I think.
('54', 9, 1, 10, 22182) We meet also the legitimate fears of Sir Akbar Hydari; and, what is more to the point for a man like me, we waste no more time even on a matter which is of importance.
('54', 9, 1, 11, 22350) I must confess to you that I dread a committee which might report in twelve months' time or even in three months' time or even in one month's time or three weeks' time.
('54', 9, 1, 12, 22519) I think that this Conference has been called upon to shoulder a particular burden.
('54', 9, 1, 13, 22602) It should manfully shoulder that burden and not throw responsibilities upon any further committees.
('54', 9, 1, 14, 22702) Whatever we can hammer into shape we should present to His Majesty's Government, to the Partliament, and to the people of India also; but I think that, unless we approach the task in this manner, so far as I can see, we shall certainly never see light out of what appears to me to be impenetrable darkness at the present moment.
('54', 9, 1, 15, 23031) That really is the reason why I have intervened.
('54', 9, 1, 16, 23080) I think that I
('54', 10, 0, 1, 23095) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 11
('54', 10, 1, 2, 23140) have sufficiently explained the suggestion that I have ventured to place beore this Committee.

('54', 10, 10, 16, 23919) PANNALAL,
('54', 10, 11, 17, 23929) I am happy that you have gone to Khurshedbehn.

('54', 11, 3, 4, 24341) SIR MANECKJEE DADABHOY: My Lord, the Mahatma goes further and
('54', 11, 4, 5, 24403) says that his concrete suggestion is, if it commends itself to the meeting, to
('54', 11, 5, 6, 24482) refer this Report back to the Sub committee with thanks, and ask the Sub committee,

('54', 11, 12, 13, 24940) however, a graver constitutional objection.
('54', 11, 12, 14, 24984) If you are going to put the Federation

('54', 12, 1, 2, 25924) 10. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’MEETING 1
('54', 12, 2, 3, 25957) LONDON, [October 15, 1931] 2
('54', 12, 3, 4, 25986) FELLOW STUDENTS, I have been speaking to people on all sorts of things, but principally on the mission that has brought me here and by this time you know by heart what I have to say in connection with my mission.
('54', 12, 3, 5, 26199) I had not intended to speak to you on any special subject.
('54', 12, 3, 6, 26258) So I said to myself: Perhaps I shall best utilize our time in answering questions instead of wasting it by a set address.
('54', 12, 3, 7, 26380) You may put me any question you like.
('54', 12, 3, 8, 26418) If I do not know the subject on which you ask me, I shall frankly confess my ignorance.
('54', 12, 3, 9, 26506) Barring that, you will not embarrass.
('54', 12, 3, 10, 26544) It will be an act of courtesy on your part if you are frank towards me.
('54', 12, 3, 11, 26616) I have addressed you as "Fellow Students".
('54', 12, 3, 12, 26659) It is not a formula.
('54', 12, 3, 13, 26680) I regard mysel essentially as a student and if you are wise, as I am (Laughter), in after life you will regard yourselves as students.
('54', 12, 3, 14, 26815) Throughout my varied experiences of life, I have come to the conclusion that our student life commences after we leave our Colleges and Universities and Law Chambers where we are supposed to be studying tied down to our studies with the key to our knowledge and, when we leave these premises, we practi cally forget all that we have learnt.
('54', 12, 3, 15, 27156) It is really in after life that we have to unlearn many things.
('54', 12, 3, 16, 27220) The so called student's life is merely a preparation or real life of a student.
('54', 12, 3, 17, 27300) When you are in college or anywhere else, you have got set subjects.
('54', 12, 3, 18, 27369) Even in optional subjects you have to learn them in a particular fashion because you are definitely bound down.
('54', 12, 3, 19, 27481) 3 But after that stage is over, you are free like a bird with wings to soar high and, the higher you soar, the stronger you become.
('54', 12, 3, 20, 27613) So I am still a student who has not graduated in the world.
('54', 12, 3, 21, 27673) When you are buffetted about and thrown on your resources, it becomes a tough job.
('54', 12, 3, 22, 27756) If you give yourselves to study, if you dedicate
('54', 12, 4, 23, 27805) 1 The meeting was held at the International Students' Movement House, Russell Square.
('54', 12, 4, 24, 27891) About 200 students hailing from all parts of the world were present.
('54', 12, 4, 25, 27960) 2 The date is according to Mahadev Desai's Diary.
('54', 12, 4, 26, 28010) 3 The source has "hide bound".
('54', 13, 0, 1, 28041) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 13, 1, 2, 28082) yourselves to study, to eternal research, there is no limit to joy, there is no limit to pleasure that you derive from that study.
('54', 13, 1, 3, 28213) My study consistently has been the search after Truth.
('54', 13, 1, 4, 28268) During the early days of my study and search I could not consistently find Truth unless I invited injury against myself and not against others.
('54', 13, 1, 5, 28412) I could find Truth only when I eschewed all feeling of causing injury to others, but, when necessary, inflicting it on myself.
('54', 13, 1, 6, 28539) Becuase, as you must be knowing, Truth and violence are opposed to each other: Violence hides Truth and, if you try to find Truth by violence, you will betray horrible ignorance in the search of Truth and, thereore, non violence without any exception whatsover.
('54', 13, 1, 7, 28801) I have come to realize the essence of life, that is ahimsa.
('54', 13, 1, 8, 28861) With this brief introduction I leave myself at your disposal.
('54', 13, 1, 9, 28923) You are at liberty to put me all kinds of questions.
('54', 13, 2, 10, 28976) A NEGRO STUDENT FROM GOLD COAST : On your way to Dandi, you advised the police and headmen to resign—policemen bound by allegiance to Government.
('54', 13, 2, 11, 29122) You also asked Gurkhas to disobey orders.
('54', 13, 2, 12, 29164) It is not contrary to non violance?
('54', 13, 3, 13, 29200) GANDHIJI: Interesting question, but shows superficial know ledge.
('54', 13, 3, 14, 29266) But that cannot be helped because this philosophy could not be studied from books.
('54', 13, 3, 15, 29349) No contradiction.
('54', 13, 3, 16, 29367) In the first instance, I asked the village headman to resign if it is assumed that he knew that he was serving a Government which was doing wrong.
('54', 13, 3, 17, 29514) And there cannot be a vow or promise or determination to do wrong.
('54', 13, 3, 18, 29581) It is like the vow or determination of a man or woman to smoke 50 cigars a day or drink 2 bottles of whisky per day or before taking his meal to take one hu man life—it cannot be a vow.
('54', 13, 3, 19, 29767) If a policeman enlists himself in service of a Government which does wrong, it is his bounden duty to leave the service; so I undertook to preach to the people that they were doing violence to themselves and to their country and doing disservice to the Government themselves.
('54', 13, 3, 20, 30043) The consequence was imprisonment which they should put up with without murmur.
('54', 13, 3, 21, 30122) There was in this no breach of truth or non violence.
('54', 13, 3, 22, 30176) It was a good thing on their part and on my part.
('54', 13, 3, 23, 30226) I now leave the village headmen and Dandi policemen and go to the Punjab.
('54', 13, 3, 24, 30300) The Garhwali soldiers received orders from their superiors.
('54', 13, 3, 25, 30360) I have never condemned that as an act of violence.
('54', 13, 3, 26, 30411) That too was a patriotic act.
('54', 13, 3, 27, 30441) They got imprisonment which was worse.
('54', 13, 3, 28, 30480) It was breach of discipline and sme of them were sentenced under Martial Law.
('54', 13, 3, 29, 30558) While I admire them for having refused to shoot their
('54', 14, 0, 1, 30612) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 15
('54', 14, 1, 2, 30657) countrymen and still suffering, I shall have to ask for mercy which, as a Civil Resister, I cannot do.
('54', 14, 1, 3, 30760) If the reins of Government were given in charge of the Congress, the Congress would discharge them tomorrow.
('54', 14, 1, 4, 30869) As there is no law in the reason, there is not contradiction.
('54', 14, 1, 5, 30931) He who knows the whole histroy can fling in my face the whole settlement.
('54', 14, 1, 6, 31005) They did so.
('54', 14, 1, 7, 31018) Some countrymen thoughtlessly asked me to get these men discharged.
('54', 14, 1, 8, 31086) But I said ‘No’.
('54', 14, 1, 9, 31103) It was no part of the Congress campaign that such soldiers should commit breach of discipline.
('54', 14, 1, 10, 31198) The Congress had issued no such instructions.
('54', 14, 1, 11, 31244) They were not civil resisters and remember every patriotic man is not a civil resister necessarily, nor every resister is a patriotic man.
('54', 14, 2, 12, 31383) A RUSSIAN STUDENT: If you were less religious, would you not have come to an agreement quicker?
('54', 14, 3, 13, 31479) G. Oh, I understand your question.
('54', 14, 3, 14, 31514) You want to suggest that I should make a promise and break it (Laughter).
('54', 14, 3, 15, 31588) It is a very good definition of politicians (Laughter).
('54', 14, 3, 16, 31644) I can now tell you why I entered politics.
('54', 14, 3, 17, 31687) I entered politics to free politics from the reproach.
('54', 14, 3, 18, 31742) As a rule the politician is free from any law suit.
('54', 14, 3, 19, 31794) But I thought that would not do.
('54', 14, 3, 20, 31827) Politics like a snake’s coil surrounds, crushes you and seeing that I am in the midst of it, I realize my helpless plight, and I endea vour to control politics.
('54', 14, 3, 21, 31988) I am supposed to be managing somehow or other the largest organization of the world—the Indian National Congress.
('54', 14, 3, 22, 32102) It represents today millions of human beings who respond to its call.
('54', 14, 3, 23, 32172) If the Congress really and truly carries out the political work on [the lines of] non violence and truth, politicians will come to the conclusion that it is not necessary to make false promises and that politics becomes corrupted when you resort to any such means.
('54', 14, 3, 24, 32437) Because some religious men are bad, it is a wrong deduction to say that religion is bad.
('54', 14, 3, 25, 32526) That is a hopelessly false position to take and, because politicians resort to ways that are crooked, it is wrong to say that politics cannot be improved.
('54', 14, 3, 26, 32681) Mr. Keir Hardie felt out of fatigue that the House of Commons was not a good place or a true Christian because the majority of the House were bad: but that is wrong.
('54', 14, 3, 27, 32847) We must stand up for forlorn causes and we will be wholly justified in being in the House of Commons for fighting for them.
('54', 14, 3, 28, 32971) It is not given to human beings to command success, but it is given to every one of us to command effort.
('54', 14, 3, 29, 33077) At the same time do not forget it is arrogance to pretend to do
('54', 15, 0, 1, 33141) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 15, 1, 2, 33182) everything by your own effort alone, because you cannot bend even a blade of grass.
('54', 15, 1, 3, 33266) Before you do that, your hand may become paralysed as life is so uncertain.
('54', 15, 1, 4, 33342) We are at the mercy of God.
('54', 15, 1, 5, 33370) We should give up all ambition.
('54', 15, 1, 6, 33402) Be truthful at any cost and make efforts, and leave the results to God.
('54', 15, 2, 7, 33474) A KOREAN STUDENT: Why are you [not] opposed to police, or State or army on ground of non violence?
('54', 15, 3, 8, 33573) G. I admit the inconsistency.
('54', 15, 3, 9, 33603) If I said that army was essential for a State, it would be inconsistent.
('54', 15, 3, 10, 33676) Whilst I can invite all States to do without police or army, I have not yet been able to bring myself to believe that you can preserve a society without police.
('54', 15, 3, 11, 33837) If we would suffer thieves or robbers to go about in society, I can conceive a society without police.
('54', 15, 3, 12, 33940) Tolstoy has conceived of Dukhobors.
('54', 15, 3, 13, 33976) There are people all over the world not needing police protection.
('54', 15, 3, 14, 34043) But they should admit that they would not even lead that life unless they were in ordered surroundings.
('54', 15, 3, 15, 34147) This is not out of my scheme, but I am at present hooked on to my limited work.
('54', 15, 3, 16, 34227) You can thus say that my toleration of police is a limitation of non violence.
('54', 15, 3, 17, 34306) Army is opposed to non violence.
('54', 15, 3, 18, 34339) In one case it is my want of courage, in the other it is my inability to convince my people to do without an army.
('54', 15, 3, 19, 34454) I have not mustered sufficient strength to pit non violence against thieves and scoundrels and cutthroats but I can ask people to pit non violence against hordes of the army.
('54', 15, 3, 20, 34629) If perchance India wins her deliverance through non violence, we may perhaps show to the world that it is not necessary to have an army State—I do not regard it Utopian to think of a State without an army, but it requires a higher degree of courage and purity.
('54', 15, 4, 21, 34890) AN ENGLISH STUDENT: Your people live on land, Our people live on work.
('54', 15, 4, 22, 34961) They cannot carry on strikes indefinitely.
('54', 15, 4, 23, 35004) What is your remedy?
('54', 15, 4, 24, 35025) G. This is truly an embarrassing question.

('54', 15, 4, 26, 35116) I am a perfect stranger in this country, not knowing her circumstances.
('54', 15, 4, 27, 35188) But as we are fellow students, we can have exchange of views.
('54', 15, 4, 28, 35250) I shall place my own views.
('54', 15, 4, 29, 35278) I assure you, your distress distresses me too.
('54', 15, 4, 30, 35325) If God gave me courage to put an end to it, I would willingly do it.
('54', 15, 4, 31, 35394) Well, I have conducted strikes.
('54', 15, 4, 32, 35426) I claim for myself that I am an expert in conducting strikes fairly successfully.
('54', 15, 4, 33, 35508) But one indispensable condition was that strikes must not live on charity, but they should live on their labour.
('54', 15, 4, 34, 35621) Among those who
('54', 16, 0, 1, 35637) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 17

('54', 16, 1, 3, 35854) On another occasion I was in jail, but my people gave the strikers enough work in hand spinning and weaving and paid them wages for the work more than what they got in the market.

('54', 16, 1, 17, 37012) But later in life, he lost all, could not see anyone and ultimately drank a bowl of poison.
('54', 16, 1, 18, 37104) such a noble good friend is lost today due to the ever increasing wants.
('54', 16, 1, 19, 37177) In order to adopt my method, you have to revise your mode of life, particularly you of the English race.
('54', 16, 1, 20, 37282) You are a race of exploiters.

('54', 16, 1, 25, 37603) No wonder you are one of the richest countries.
('54', 16, 1, 26, 37651) But where did you get your money from?
('54', 16, 1, 27, 37690) Not in this soil .
('54', 16, 1, 28, 37709) It came from all parts of the Empire.

('54', 16, 1, 32, 37929) Don’t wait till you are compelled to do so.
('54', 16, 1, 33, 37973) I have given you what is agitating my mind.

('54', 17, 4, 6, 38345) 11. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('54', 17, 5, 7, 38372) LONDON, [Before October 16, 1931] 2
('54', 17, 6, 8, 38408) Q. If the Communal problem should not predominate over all the rest, why should you yourself have said, at one stage, that you would not think of going to the Round Table Conference, unless the Communal question was settled ?
('54', 17, 6, 9, 38634) A. You are right.
('54', 17, 6, 10, 38652) But you forget that I was borne down by the extreme pressure of English and other friends in india who said that it was imperative that I should go.
('54', 17, 6, 11, 38801) I was also persuaded that, if only to keep my word of honour with Lord Irwin, I should go.
('54', 17, 6, 12, 38892) Now, here I find myself face to face with men who are not nationalists, and who were selected only because they were communalists.
('54', 17, 6, 13, 39023) Therefore, though I said that it was a matter of humiliation for us all not to have been able to come to a decision, the principal cause was the very composition of the committee itself.
('54', 17, 6, 14, 39210) It is too unreal for words.
('54', 17, 6, 15, 39238) There are men who claim to represent communities which, if they were in India, and if a referendum were to be taken, would disown them.
('54', 17, 7, 16, 39374) Q. What about the untouchables?
('54', 17, 7, 17, 39406) Dr. Ambedkar was very severe on you and said that the Congress had no right to claim to represent the untouchables.
('54', 17, 7, 18, 39522) A. I am glad you have asked the question.
('54', 17, 7, 19, 39564) I do not mind Dr. Ambedkar.
('54', 17, 7, 20, 39592) He has a right even to spit upon me, as every untouchable has, and I would keep on smiling if they did so.
('54', 17, 7, 21, 39699) But I may inform you that Dr. Ambedkar speaks for that particular part of the country where he comes from.
('54', 17, 7, 22, 39806) He cannot speak for the rest of India and I have numerous telegrams from the so called ‘untouchables’ in various parts of India assuring me that they have the fullest faith in the Congress and disowning Dr. Ambedkar.
('54', 17, 7, 23, 40023) And this confidence has a reason.
('54', 17, 7, 24, 40057) They know the work that the Congress is
('54', 17, 8, 25, 40097) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “London Letter”.
('54', 17, 8, 26, 40147) Desai says it is “not one talk, but bits from various talks.” 2 Elsewhere in "London Letter", Mahadev Desai says: “As I am writing this, the time is drawing near for a conference with temperance workers.
('54', 17, 8, 27, 40351) .” This conference took place on October 16.
('54', 18, 0, 1, 40396) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 19
('54', 18, 1, 2, 40441) doing for them and they know that, if they cannot succeed in making their voice felt, I would be prepared to lead a campaign of civil resistance on their behalf and paralyse the Hindu orthodox opposition, if there were such an opposition against them.
('54', 18, 1, 3, 40693) On the other hand, if they were to be given special electorates, as Dr. Ambedkar persists in demanding, it would do that very community immense harm.
('54', 18, 1, 4, 40843) It would divide the Hindu community into armed camps and provoke needless opposition.
('54', 18, 2, 5, 40929) Q. I see your point, and I have no doubt that you can legitimately speak for the untouchables.
('54', 18, 2, 6, 41024) But you seem to ignore the fact that communities all the world over insist on being represented by their own people.
('54', 18, 2, 7, 41141) The devoted Liberals of the north would truly represent the working men, but they would have their representatives from amongst themselves, and the great stubborn fact against you is that you are not an untouchable.
('54', 18, 2, 8, 41357) A. I know it very well.
('54', 18, 2, 9, 41381) But the fact that I claim to represent them does not mean that I should think of representing them on the legislatures.
('54', 18, 2, 10, 41501) By no means.
('54', 18, 2, 11, 41514) I should have their own representatives drawn from their own class on the legislatures, and if they are left out, I should provide for their statutory co option by the elected members.
('54', 18, 2, 12, 41699) But when I am talking of representing them, I am talking of the representation on the Round Table Conference and I can assure you that, if anyone in India challenged our claim, I should gladly face a referendum and successfully.
('54', 18, 3, 13, 41928) Q. From this point of view it would be interesting to hear you about the
('54', 18, 4, 14, 42001) Mussalmans too.
('54', 18, 4, 15, 42017) You do not say that the Mussalmans here do not represent their
('54', 18, 5, 16, 42080) community?
('54', 18, 5, 17, 42091) A. Well, they are not duly elected, and I may tell you that I asked so many of the real nationalist Mussalmans to stay away.
('54', 18, 5, 18, 42216) There is a vast majority of the younger leaders—Mr. Khwaja, Mr. Sherwani, to name only two whom I came to know only through the friends who are today ranged against the Congress, and who are opposed to any Communal solution of the problem.
('54', 18, 5, 19, 42456) Personally, I would give the Mussalmans all that they want and I have been waking up late after midnight in persuading the Hindus and the Sikhs to go with me, but I have failed.
('54', 18, 5, 20, 42634) Do you think I would have failed if the Sikhs were elected by the Sikhs and not nominated by Government ?
('54', 18, 5, 21, 42740) Master Tara Singh 1 would have been
('54', 18, 6, 22, 42776) 1 Sikh leader
('54', 19, 0, 1, 42790) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 19, 1, 2, 42831) I know his views and he has his 17 points to pit against Mr. Jinnah's 14, but I am quite sure I could bear him down, as he is after all a comrade in arms.
('54', 19, 1, 3, 42986) Is it surprising then that we should fail to achieve a settlement in the present atmosphere?
('54', 19, 1, 4, 43079) It is, therefore, I said, that having already handicapped us, do not handicap us more by saying that the solution of the communal problem must precede any decision on the Constitutional question.
('54', 19, 1, 5, 43275) I tell them let us know what we are going to get, so that on that basis I might endeavour to bring about unity even in the present ill assorted group.
('54', 19, 1, 6, 43426) Let us for God's sake have something tangible.
('54', 19, 1, 7, 43473) It would be another string to the bow and help us to arrive at a solution.
('54', 19, 1, 8, 43548) For I could tell them that they were dashing a precious thing to pieces.
('54', 19, 1, 9, 43621) But, today, I have nothing to present them with.
('54', 19, 1, 10, 43670) And even if there were no solution, I have suggested various ways—private arbitration, judicial tribunal, etc.
('54', 19, 1, 11, 43781) That is the situation.
('54', 19, 1, 12, 43804) I am a slave to my friends, and it is because I honour Lord Irwin as a friend that I came.
('54', 19, 1, 13, 43895) But I now see that it is an impossible situation.
('54', 19, 2, 14, 43945) Q. Is it quite impossible?
('54', 19, 2, 15, 43972) You think you should not have come?
('54', 19, 3, 16, 44008) A. Not quite, and I am not going to give up my efforts until the last.
('54', 19, 3, 17, 44079) As for my visit I do not at all feel sorry for having come, for I know that indirectly, our of the Conference, the work that I am doing is wholly satisfactory and I am establishing contacts which I shall treasure.
('54', 19, 4, 18, 44293) Q. May I take it then that you do not attach much importance to the communal
('54', 19, 5, 19, 44370) question?
('54', 19, 6, 20, 44380) A. I have never said so.
('54', 19, 6, 21, 44405) I say that the question has been allowed to overshadow the main thing,which needs to be specially emphasized.
('54', 19, 6, 22, 44515) Young India, 29 10 1931
('54', 20, 0, 1, 44539) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 21
('54', 20, 1, 2, 44584) 12. INTERVIEW TO CALLENDER 1
('54', 20, 2, 3, 44613) LONDON, [October 16, 1931]
('54', 20, 3, 4, 44640) Q. Do you feel, Gandhiji, that mass production will raise the standard of living of the people?
('54', 20, 4, 5, 44736) A. I do not believe in it at all.
('54', 20, 4, 6, 44770) There is a tremendous fallacy behind Mr Ford’s reasoning.
('54', 20, 4, 7, 44828) 2 Without simultaneous distribution on an equally mass scale, the production can result only in a great world tragedy.
('54', 20, 4, 8, 44947) Take Mr. Ford’s cars.
('54', 20, 4, 9, 44969) The saturation point is bound to be reached soon or later.
('54', 20, 4, 10, 45028) Beyond that point the production of cars cannot be pushed.
('54', 20, 4, 11, 45087) What will happen then?
('54', 20, 4, 12, 45110) Mass production takes no note of the real requirement of the consumer.
('54', 20, 4, 13, 45181) If mass production were in itself a virtue, it should be capable of indefinite multiplication.
('54', 20, 4, 14, 45276) But it can be definitely shown that mass production carries within it its own limitations.
('54', 20, 4, 15, 45367) If all countries adopted the system of mass production, there would not be a big en ough market for their products.
('54', 20, 4, 16, 45483) Mass production must then come to a stop.
('54', 20, 5, 17, 45525) Q. I wonder whether you feel that this saturation point has already arrived in the Western world.
('54', 20, 5, 18, 45623) Mr. Ford says that there never can be too many articles of quality, that the needs of the world are constantly increasingly that, therefore, while there might be saturation in the market for a given commodity, the general saturation would never be reached.
('54', 20, 5, 19, 45880) A. Without entering upon an elaborate argument, I would categorically state my conviction that the mania for mass production is responsible for the world crisis.
('54', 20, 5, 20, 46042) Granting for the moment that machinery may supply all the needs of humanity, still, it would concentrate production in particular areas, so that you would have to go in a round about way to regulate distribution, whereas, if there is production and distribution both in the respec tive areas where things are required, it is automatically regulated, and there is less chance for fraud, none for speculation.
('54', 20, 6, 21, 46450) 1 An American Press correspondent.
('54', 20, 6, 22, 46485) Pyarelal Nayar, from whose article "Mass Production versus Production by the Masses", this has been extracted does not mention the name.
('54', 20, 6, 23, 46622) This and the date of the interview have been taken from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai's Diary, 1931. 2 The interviewer had earlier met Ford in America, who had put forward the view that demand for cheaper things would stimulate mass production.
('54', 21, 0, 1, 46869) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 21, 1, 2, 46910) The American friend mentioned Mr. Ford's favourite plan of decentralization of industry by the use of electric power conveyed on wires to the remotest corner, instead of coal and steam, as a possible remedy, and drew up the picture of hundreds and thousands of small, neat, smokeless villages, dotted with factories, run by village communities.
('54', 21, 1, 3, 47255) “Assuming all that to be possible”, he finally asked Gandhiji, “how far will it meet your obejction?” A. My objection won't be met by that, because, while it is true that you will be producing things in innumerable areas, the power will come from one selected centre.
('54', 21, 1, 4, 47523) That, in the end, I think, would be found to be disastrous.
('54', 21, 1, 5, 47583) It would place such a limitless power in one human agency that I dread to think of it.
('54', 21, 1, 6, 47670) The consequence, for instance, of such a control of power would be that I would be dependent on that power for light, water, even air, and so on.
('54', 21, 1, 7, 47816) That, I think, would be terrible.
('54', 21, 2, 8, 47850) have you any idea as to what Europe and America should do to solve the problem presented by too much machinery?
('54', 21, 3, 9, 47962) A. You see that these nations are able to exploit the so called weaker or unorganized races of the world.
('54', 21, 3, 10, 48068) Once those races gain this elementary knowledge and decide that they are no more going to be exploited, they will simply be satisfied with what they can provide themselves.
('54', 21, 3, 11, 48241) Mass production, then, at least where the vital necessities are concerned, will disappear.
('54', 21, 4, 12, 48332) Q. As a world organization.
('54', 21, 4, 13, 48360) A. Yes.
('54', 21, 5, 14, 48368) Q. But even these races will require more and more goods as their needs multiply.
('54', 21, 5, 15, 48450) A. They will then produce for themselves.
('54', 21, 5, 16, 48492) And when that happens, mass production, in the technical sense in which it is understood in the West, ceases.
('54', 21, 6, 17, 48602) Q. You mean to say it becomes local.
('54', 21, 7, 18, 48639) A. When production and consumption both become locali zed, the temptation to speed up production, indefinitely and at any price, disappears.
('54', 21, 7, 19, 48780) All the endless difficulties and problems that our present day economic system presents, too, would then come to an end.
('54', 21, 7, 20, 48901) Take a concrete instance.
('54', 21, 7, 21, 48927) England today is the cloth shop of the world.
('54', 21, 7, 22, 48973) It, therefore, needs to holda world in bondage to se cure its market.
('54', 21, 7, 23, 49043) But under the change that I have envisaged, she would limit her production to the actual needsof her 45 millions of population.
('54', 21, 7, 24, 49171) When that need is satisfied, the production
('54', 22, 0, 1, 49215) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 23
('54', 22, 1, 2, 49260) will necessarily stop.
('54', 22, 1, 3, 49283) It won't be continued for the sake of bringing in more gold irrespective of the needs of a people and at the risk of their impoverishment.
('54', 22, 1, 4, 49422) There would be no unnatural accumulation of hoards in the pockets of the few, and want in the midst of plenty in regard to the rest, as is happening today, for instance, in America.
('54', 22, 1, 5, 49604) America is today able to hold the world in fee by selling all kinds of trinklets, or by selling her unrivalled skill, whcih she has a right to do.
('54', 22, 1, 6, 49751) She has reached the acme of mass production, and yet she has not been able to abolish unemployment or want.
('54', 22, 1, 7, 49859) There are still thousands, perhaps millions of people in America who live in misery, in site of the phenomenal riches of the few.
('54', 22, 1, 8, 49989) The whole of the American nation is not benefited by the mass production.
('54', 22, 2, 9, 50063) Q. There the fault lies in distribution.
('54', 22, 2, 10, 50104) It means that, whilst our system of production has reached a high pitch of perfection, the distribution is still defective.
('54', 22, 2, 11, 50228) If distribution could be equalized, would not mass production be sterilized of its evils?
('54', 22, 3, 12, 50318) A. No, the evil is inherent in the system.
('54', 22, 3, 13, 50361) Distribution can be equalized when production is localized; in other words, when the distribution is simultaneous with production.
('54', 22, 3, 14, 50492) Distribution will never be equal so long as you want to tap other markets of the world to dispose of your goods.
('54', 22, 3, 15, 50605) That does not mean that the world has not use for the marvellous advances in science and organization that the Western nations have made.
('54', 22, 3, 16, 50743) It only means that the Western nations have to use their skill.
('54', 22, 3, 17, 50807) If they want to use their skill abroad, from philanthropic motives, America would say, 'Well, we know how make bridges, we won’t keep keep it a secret, but we say to the whole world, we will teach you how to make bridges and we will charge you nothing.’ America says, ‘Where other nations can grow one blade of wheat, we can grow two thousand.’ Then, America should teach that art free of charge to those who will learn it, but not aspire to grow wheat for the whole world, which would spell a sorry day for the world indeed.
('54', 22, 4, 18, 51333) The American friend next asked Gandhiji, referring to Russia, whether it was not a country that had developed mass production without exploiting, in Gandhiji's sense, the less industrialized nations, or without falling into the pit of unequal distribution.
('54', 22, 4, 19, 51590) A. In other words, you want me to express opinion on State controlled industry, i.e., an economic order in whcih both pro duction and distribution are controlled and regulated by the State as is being today done in Soviet Russia.
('54', 22, 4, 20, 51820) Well, it is a new
('54', 23, 0, 1, 51838) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 23, 1, 2, 51879) experiment.
('54', 23, 1, 3, 51891) How far it will ultimately succeed, I do not know.
('54', 23, 1, 4, 51942) If it were not based on force, I would dote on it.
('54', 23, 1, 5, 51993) But today, since it is based on force, I do not know how far and where it will take us.
('54', 23, 2, 6, 52081) Q. Then, you do not envisage mass production as an ideal future of India?
('54', 23, 3, 7, 52155) A. Oh yes, mass production, certainly, but not based on force.
('54', 23, 3, 8, 52218) After all, the message of the spinning wheel is that.
('54', 23, 3, 9, 52272) It is mass production, but mass production in people's own homes.
('54', 23, 3, 10, 52338) If you multiply individual production to millions of times, would it not give you mass production on a tremendous scale?
('54', 23, 3, 11, 52459) But I quite understand that your ‘mass production’ is a technical term for production by the fewest possible number through the aid of highly complicated machinery.
('54', 23, 3, 12, 52624) I have said to myself that that is wrong.
('54', 23, 3, 13, 52666) My machinery must be of the most elementary type which I can put in the homes of the millions.
('54', 23, 3, 14, 52761) Under my system, again, it is labour which is the current coin, not metal.
('54', 23, 3, 15, 52836) Any person who can use his labour has that coin, has wealth.
('54', 23, 3, 16, 52897) He converts his labour into cloth, he converts his labour into grain.
('54', 23, 3, 17, 52967) If he wants paraffin oil, whcih he cannot himself produce, he used his surplus grain for getting the oil.
('54', 23, 3, 18, 53073) It is exchange of labour on free, fair and equal terms—hence it is no robbery.
('54', 23, 3, 19, 53152) You may object that this is a reversion to the primitive system of barter.
('54', 23, 3, 20, 53227) But is not all international trade based on the barter system?
('54', 23, 3, 21, 53290) Look, again, at another advantage, that this system affords.
('54', 23, 3, 22, 53351) You can multiply it to any extent.
('54', 23, 3, 23, 53386) But concentration of production ad infinitum can only lead to unemployment.
('54', 23, 3, 24, 53462) You may say that workers thrown out of work by the introduction of improved machinery will find occupation in other jobs.
('54', 23, 3, 25, 53584) But in an organized country where there are only fixed and limited avenues of employment, where the worker has become highly skilled in the use of one particular kind of machinery, you know from your own experience that this is hardly possible.
('54', 23, 3, 26, 53829) Are there not over three millions unemployed in England today?
('54', 23, 3, 27, 53892) A question was put to me only the other day: "What are we doing today with these three million unemployed?" They cannot shift from factory to field in a day.
('54', 23, 3, 28, 54050) It is a tremendous problem.
('54', 23, 3, 29, 54078) Q. Would not machine agriculture make a great difference to India, as it has done to America and Canada?
('54', 23, 3, 30, 54183) A. Probably.
('54', 23, 3, 31, 54196) But that is a question I do not consider myself fit to answer.
('54', 23, 3, 32, 54259) We in India have not been able to use much complicated machinery in agriculture with profit so far.
('54', 23, 3, 33, 54359) We do not exclude machinery.
('54', 23, 3, 34, 54388) We are making cautious experiments.
('54', 23, 3, 35, 54424) But we have not found power driven agricultural machinery to be necessary.
('54', 24, 0, 1, 54499) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 25
('54', 24, 1, 2, 54544) Q. Some people have the impression that you are opposed to machinery in general.
('54', 24, 1, 3, 54625) This is not true, I believe.
('54', 24, 2, 4, 54654) A. That is quite wrong.
('54', 24, 2, 5, 54678) The spinning wheel is also machinery.
('54', 24, 2, 6, 54716) It is a beautiful work of art.
('54', 24, 2, 7, 54747) It typifies the use of machinery on a universal scale.
('54', 24, 2, 8, 54802) It is machinery reduced to the terms of the masses.
('54', 24, 3, 9, 54854) Q. So, you are opposed to machinery, only because and when it concentrates
('54', 24, 4, 10, 54929) production and distribution in the hands of the few?
('54', 24, 5, 11, 54982) A. You are right.
('54', 24, 5, 12, 55000) I hate privilege and monopoly.
('54', 24, 5, 13, 55031) Whatever cannot be shared with the masses is taboo to me.
('54', 24, 5, 14, 55089) That is all.

('54', 24, 8, 18, 55173) Q. Are you hopeful of a successful outcome?
('54', 24, 9, 19, 55217) A. Being an optimist, I never lose hope, but I can say that I am no nearer a solution than I was in Bombay.
('54', 24, 9, 20, 55325) There are numerous difficulties.
('54', 24, 9, 21, 55358) I know that the Congress demand appears a little too high in the atmosphere that is found to exist here, though I think that is none too high.
('54', 24, 10, 22, 55501) Q. Is there no way out of the difficulty?
('54', 24, 10, 23, 55543) A. There are many ways, but whether they will be adopted by the parties concerned, I do not know.
('54', 24, 10, 24, 55641) We have been told that the solution of the constitutional question depends on the solution of the communal question.
('54', 24, 10, 25, 55758) It is not true, and I am afraid, it is the very presentation of the question in this inverted form that has made the question more difficult and given it an altogether artificial importance, and because it has been made the fulcrum, the parties concerned feel that they can pitch their demands as high as possible.
('54', 24, 10, 26, 56073) And thus, we are
('54', 24, 11, 27, 56090) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “London Letter”.
('54', 24, 11, 28, 56140) The questions were asked at a luncheon given by American Journalists at Savoy Hotel.

('54', 25, 1, 3, 56855) But I, for the life of me, see no vital connection at all between the two questions.
('54', 25, 1, 4, 56940) India will have freedom whether the communal question is solved or not solved.
('54', 25, 1, 5, 57019) No doubt we would have difficult times after the attainment of freedom, but freedom itself cannot be held up by the question, for we can get freedom as soon as we are worthy of it, and being worthy of it means suffering enough for it, paying a rich price for the rich prize of freedom.

('54', 25, 2, 9, 57851) Q. Does not the General Election make your work difficult?
('54', 25, 2, 10, 57910) A. It need not.
('54', 25, 2, 11, 57926) If British statesmen realized that the financial situation would be more difficult if there were a war between England and India, however non violent, they would not allow the General Election to hamper the solution of our problem.

('54', 25, 2, 13, 58389) On the contrary, if there is an honourable partnership, Great Britain would be more free to mend her own affairs.
('54', 25, 2, 14, 58503) But there is another very great difficulty in our way.
('54', 25, 2, 15, 58558) So long as India is held by the bayonet, the British ministers will continue to cast their hungry eyes on the famishing masses of India and forging fresh means of draining the last ounce of silver and gold from India not necessarily by a malicious design, but forced by the necessity of the case, for when there is unemployment and want stalking the land and there is a chance of relief from some direction, no matter whether it is by exploiting another country, you cannot expect the statesmen to weigh everything in golden scales, and model their conduct on a strictly ethical code.
('54', 25, 2, 16, 59143) It will drive them to desperate measures like manipulating India's currency.
('54', 25, 2, 17, 59220) That may for a time put off the agony, but the ultimate doom cannot long be delayed.

('54', 26, 1, 2, 59374) 14. EXTRACT FROM PROCEEDINGS OF THE FEDERAL STRUCTURE COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('54', 26, 2, 3, 59448) LONDON, October 16, 1931
('54', 26, 3, 4, 59473) MR GANDHI: My Lord Chancellor, in view of the impending conversations between Their Highnesses or their representatives and Delegates on this side of the table, perhaps it is unnecessary for me to say anything in defence of the suggestion which I had the privilege of making before this Committee; but I would be unjust to Lord Peel and unjust to Sir Akbar Hydari (and I have listened with all the respect and attention which anything that Lord Peel or Sir Akbar Hydari might say deserves) if I did not confess that I am unconvinced and that I remain unrepentant.
('54', 26, 3, 5, 60037) It may be that I am too obtuse to realize those difficulties; it may be that I am too impatient to see something concrete before us to see those difficulties; but I also know that I have confidence enought in myself and my countrymen to believe that we are well able to bear the burden and the responsibilities that self government would impose upon us , and therefore I am not baffled by difficulties, real or imaginary.
('54', 26, 4, 6, 60459) But I want to apply my very simple mind to this question of apportionment of the revenue and the expenditure of the Government of India.
('54', 26, 4, 7, 60596) We have been talking about principles.
('54', 26, 4, 8, 60635) Well, I have really failed to see many principles in connections with the work before us.
('54', 26, 4, 9, 60725) There is certainly one principle, namely, on what standard are we going to apportion the revenues and the expenditure?
('54', 26, 4, 10, 60844) There certainly we shall have to come to some rough and ready principle on which we should decide; and that principle, as I visualize if before myself, is whether the British Indian part of India is to shoulder any additional burden beyond what it shoulders today by reason of Federation, and likewise whether, the states are to do so,or whether, in entering upon Federation, each party will refuse, say, for the time being, to take over any futher burdens.
('54', 26, 4, 11, 61302) That, to my mind, would be the principle that would guide us in coming to an apportionment of revenue and expenditure.
('54', 26, 5, 12, 61421) 1 The Committee continued consideration of Head 4: Distribution of Financial Resources between the Federation and its Units.
('54', 27, 0, 1, 61546) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 27, 1, 2, 61587) The difficulty, therefore, really, that has appeared to me as a result of having listened to all these discourses, is one not of principle, but rather, if I may respectfully put it, of disinclination.
('54', 27, 1, 3, 61788) If we have got the determination that we want Federation, that we want Federation at any cost consistently with the self respect of each party, or each partner—if we have that determination I, again, as I say, as a simple man, a layman, can see no difficulty whatsoever.
('54', 27, 1, 4, 62059) All we have to do is to find out those heads of revenue which we can easily understand without any complication, and we set about saying, “These are the heads of the revenue which we shall hold jointly.
('54', 27, 1, 5, 62262) The balance will go either to the Federal Government or to the Provinces.” That distribution can, in my opinion, easily be made.
('54', 27, 1, 6, 62391) Today the greatest difficulty lies in bringing the States’ and the other Delegates together and coming to a conclusion.
('54', 27, 1, 7, 62511) If we lay down the principle that neither party is just now to bear any fresh burdens, we shall devide the heads accordingly; or if there is going to be a little give and take, each taking a little more responsibility,we shall arrive at a conclusion in accordance with that Principle.
('54', 27, 1, 8, 62796) Nor do I see any difficulty in finding what items of expenditure we are going to hold in common.
('54', 27, 1, 9, 62893) If we have come to the conclusion that, at the present moment, we are going to have A, B and C sources of revenue, we know today, so far as our information permits us, that from these three sources we shall get so much revenue.
('54', 27, 1, 10, 63121) Then we shall take such heads of expenditure as will balance that revenue.
('54', 27, 1, 11, 63196) I know that our estimate may prove to be wrong; it will be time enough for the Federal Government to decide how it would adjust the difference.
('54', 27, 1, 12, 63340) If there is a surplus, there should be no difficulty; if a deficit, naturally there would be some difficulty, but not one of us expects that the Federal Government will, when it is launched out on the stormy ocean of responsibility, meet no difficulty whatsoever.
('54', 27, 1, 13, 63604) I see that there is a kind of fear regarding decisions by the Federal Government, seeing that, in the Federal Government, up to now, we have pictured to ourselves a majority of those on the Bri tish Indian side; so that the fate of the States might be in the hands of the majority.
('54', 27, 1, 14, 63886) If there is any such fear, we need not have have any reservation whatsoever, or we might have some such reservation as I can just now think of, namely, that, unless there is an agreement between a two thirds majority of the Princes on the one side and a similar majority on the other, there will be no deci sion taken binding on both sides.
('54', 27, 1, 15, 64227) It ake that by way of illus
('54', 28, 0, 1, 64255) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 29
('54', 28, 1, 2, 64300) tration as it comes into my mind whilst I am speaking.
('54', 28, 1, 3, 64355) I simply say that difficulties of this kind need not baffle us, and I feel that we ought to get rid of this incubus of expert opinion at every point.
('54', 28, 1, 4, 64505) We are, after all, a poor country, and we are not going to get the assistance of experts at every turn.
('54', 28, 1, 5, 64609) I think that, in India, we have intelligence enough to understands roughly what we want without having the guidance of experts; and in, my humble experience of things of the world, I have seen that, when you go to experts, sometimes you founder, because one expert says one thing, another expert says another.
('54', 28, 1, 6, 64919) And when you come to matters of finance, which are ordinarily too deep for humble folk, these folk do not know which expert's opinion to take; so that they cast lots and trust to the future, saying that they are not going to be buffeted about by these experts.
('54', 28, 1, 7, 65180) You find the same thing in law, with all deference to the Lord Chancellor.
('54', 28, 2, 8, 65255) H.H. THE MAHARAJA OF BIKANER : You are a distinguished lawyer yourself.
('54', 28, 3, 9, 65327) MR.GANDHI : That is why I speak from bitter experience.
('54', 28, 3, 10, 65383) The same is true of medicine.
('54', 28, 3, 11, 65413) Heaven help us from medical men!
('54', 28, 3, 12, 65446) Let us get rid of these difficulties that experts cast for us.
('54', 28, 3, 13, 65509) After all, if we make any mistake,we ourselves will be the sufferers.
('54', 28, 3, 14, 65579) But if we tread upon this ground with fear lurking in our breast, we shall not be able to evolve a scheme consistent with the dignity of the great and ancient country that we are.
('54', 28, 3, 15, 65759) I have therefore simply explained my position as a very simple man before this Committee, so that, when we have these informal conversations, we may approach the question with fresh minds and not with minds full of dread.
('54', 28, 3, 16, 65981) May I, as I conclude, respectfully suggest to the Princes that they have come here with their experts also.
('54', 28, 3, 17, 66089) They have brought their best men here.
('54', 28, 3, 18, 66128) I will trust myself to those experts, and use my common sense judgment also if they dare to mislead me.
('54', 28, 3, 19, 66232) But I shall be entirely satisfied, and in a few hours come to a definite conclusion as to what I want and what I do not want.
('54', 28, 3, 20, 66358) Hence I remain absolutely convinced that we should either send this thing to Lord Peel's Sub committee, putting the burden on them to come with a definite conclusion, or, instead of worrying that Sub committee, some of us should sit together and produce a very humble agreed scheme with which we can start the financial part of the Federation.

('54', 29, 1, 2, 66876) 15. SPEECH AT TEMPERANCE WORKERS' MEETING 1
('54', 29, 2, 3, 66920) LONDON, October 16, 1931
('54', 29, 3, 4, 66945) The Speaker .
('54', 29, 3, 5, 66959) lost no time in plunging in thoroughly business like fashion into his subject.
('54', 29, 3, 6, 67038) The first half of the hour at his disposal he devoted to what proved to be a clear, concise and convincing statement of the position in India with regard to the traffic in drink and drugs.
('54', 29, 3, 7, 67227) The rest of the time, by his own request, we devoted to answering questions which, he said, was “the best way to establish contact with his hearers”.
('54', 29, 3, 8, 67377) And of questions there were not a few—regular fusillade, in fact— all of which were clearly and courteously replied to.
('54', 29, 4, 9, 67497) Drink, we learned, was not the fashion in India as it is with us, in U.S.A. and on the continent, In fact, it is ‘taboo’ in good society there.
('54', 29, 4, 10, 67641) India, seeks to rid herself of the traffic in it, the revenue from which, alas!
('54', 29, 4, 11, 67721) goes to the Provincial Governments and is a main source of support for education.
('54', 29, 4, 12, 67803) Indians, despairing of any help from the Government, had sought in recent years to reduce the evils resulting from the trade in intoxicants by peaceful picketing of the liquor shops, a work (involving much self sacrificing efforts on their part) heroically undertaken by Indian women, some of them of high degree.
('54', 29, 4, 13, 68117) And Lord Irwin, with whom he had discussed the subject at length, had admitted the right of Indians to adopt that course of action in pursuing their campaign against “these two sinful traffics” as Gandhi with emphasis called them.
('54', 29, 4, 14, 68348) Such were some of the things we learned from the lips of this strange, asceticlooking leader of men who only twice showed any emotion or fire in his narrative; once when an interrogator suggested that if the Indians were really earnest in desiring to end the traffic, it would surely not be difficult for their representatives on the Legislative Councils to suggest alternative methods of revenue raising (e.g., by a light tax on salt or other article in general use) .
('54', 29, 4, 15, 68818) This suggestion Gandhi promptly and scornfully rejected.
('54', 29, 4, 16, 68875) He would be no party, he said, to laying any greater burden on the people than they were already bearing.
('54', 29, 4, 17, 68981) Reduction of the unnecessary expenditure on the standing army in India and of the excessive cost of the Indian Civil Service were his alternative methods.
('54', 29, 4, 18, 69136) An inquiry respecting the payment of compensation to dispossessed licence holders provoked amazement on his part that anyone should think of compensating them.
('54', 29, 4, 19, 69296) It was the victims of the traffic, not those who conducted it, who, in his view, should be compensated.

('54', 31, 5, 14, 71626) 18. SPEECH AT NOTTINGHAM UNIVERSITY COLLEGE
('54', 31, 6, 15, 71670) NOTTINGHAM, October 17, 1931
('54', 31, 7, 16, 71699) Gandhi said the Indian Congress demanded complete independence in the fullest sense of that term.
('54', 31, 7, 17, 71797) India sought for power to control the defence forces, external affairs and finance.
('54', 31, 7, 18, 71881) I have used the term demand.
('54', 31, 7, 19, 71910) As a matter of fact, no nation has ever secured independence by demanding it.
('54', 31, 7, 20, 71988) Indepen dence has to be earned by sacrifice and self suffering.
('54', 31, 7, 21, 72052) So far as history teaches, nations have come to freedom through rivers of blood.
('54', 31, 7, 22, 72133) They have beaten back the intruder, oppressor or exploiter, but in the process they have suffered a big share of the beating.
('54', 31, 8, 23, 72259) 1 It read: “I am coming to London the Monday next for two or three days—and I wondered if you had half an hour or an hour free on Wednesday morning 21. You might have cared to have another talk at Eaton Square.
