('54', 32, 2, 9, 73369) 19. INTERVIEW TO EVELYN WRENCH 1
('54', 32, 3, 10, 73402) LONDON, [On or after October 17,1931] 2
('54', 32, 4, 11, 73442) WRENCH : I am very glad to have this opportunity of having a talk with you, Mr.Gandhi, for the benefit of the readers of The Spectator.
('54', 32, 5, 12, 73578) GANDHIJI: One of the things I wanted to do while in England was to talk to the Editor of The Spectator, because we in India appreciate very much the part The Spectator has played in enlightening the people of Great Britain on Indian problems.
('54', 32, 5, 13, 73821) I know that you may not necessarily agree with all the views I hold, but I recognize that you have repeatedly stated in the columns of The Spectator that the only satisfactory basis for the future relations of Great Britain and India is one of friendship, absolute equality and a recognition of the fact that the people of India must be the final arbiters of their destiny.
('54', 32, 6, 14, 74195) Q. Let’s see; when were you last in England, Mr.Gandhi ?
('54', 32, 6, 15, 74252) It was some time before the War, wasn't it ?
('54', 32, 7, 16, 74297) A. Yes, I visited England in 1909 and I was here again just two days after the outbreak of War 3. On that occasion I assisted in the organization of a Red Cross unit, but unfortunately I fell ill and a severe attack of pleurisy prevented my doing what I wanted to do before I returned to India at the end of November that year.
('54', 32, 8, 17, 74625) 1 Editor of The Spectator.
('54', 32, 8, 18, 74652) The account has been extracted from Wrench’s report “An Evening with Mr.Gandhi.” The interview took place at Wrench's residence between 8 and 11 p.m.
('54', 32, 8, 19, 74802) 2 The source does not mention the date of the interview, but merely says it took place “last week”.
('54', 32, 8, 20, 74902) 3 The first World War, in August 1914. 4 Gandhiji sailed for home on December 19, 1914 and reached Bombay actually on January 9, 1915.
('54', 33, 0, 1, 75037) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 33, 1, 2, 75078) Q. What is your chief impression as regards the British understanding of the Indian problem today ?
('54', 33, 1, 3, 75178) Do you find that public opinion has changed much ?
('54', 33, 2, 4, 75229) A. Yes, I find a vast change in the attitude of the man in the street, and I have made a special point of talking with all sections of the British people.
('54', 33, 2, 5, 75384) I am very happy in London and I have received wonderful signs of affection from your ordinary folk.
('54', 33, 2, 6, 75484) In the East End I have been greatly touched by the friendliness displayed.
('54', 33, 2, 7, 75559) People come out of their houses and shake hands with me and wish me well.
('54', 33, 2, 8, 75633) I was much gratified by the reception I received in Lancashire, where the people seemed to me to understand my position; and despite the fact that my policy in India was reported to have affected Lancashire so grievously, no grudge was borne me and I found genuine friendship both from operatives and employers alike.
('54', 33, 3, 9, 75951) Q. What about the so called upper and official classes?
('54', 33, 3, 10, 76007) Do you think their opinion has changed and are they ready to give India what it wants?
('54', 33, 4, 11, 76094) A. I fear thay still do not understand the position and are ready to give the freedom that we claim as our right.
('54', 33, 4, 12, 76208) They think that India is not ready today to control her own affairs, and I fear not may of them would be prepared to admit our right to the same freedom that Great Britain possesses, that is, the right to control our armed forces, our finances and our external affairs.
('54', 33, 5, 13, 76478) Q. As you know, Mr. Gandhi, The Spectator has always been a great believer
('54', 33, 6, 14, 76553) in what is called Dominion Status.
('54', 33, 6, 15, 76588) We think it has achieved the apparently impossible task of reconciling two apparent opposites, co operation and independence.
('54', 33, 6, 16, 76714) Would India be satisfied, do you think, with the same status that South Africa has as a Dominion within the British Commonwealth?
('54', 33, 7, 17, 76844) A.I regard the status of India as unique.
('54', 33, 7, 18, 76886) After all, we re present a fifth the human race.
('54', 33, 7, 19, 76935) I do not think, thereore, that a political status which might suit other Dominions of the British Commonwealth would necessarily suit us.
('54', 33, 7, 20, 77073) You must remember that India has been a subject nation for a very long time.
('54', 33, 7, 21, 77150) If Great Britain approaches the question of the future relations between our peoples in a spirit of friendship with no reservations, she will not find India behindhand in coming to meet her proffered hand.
('54', 33, 7, 22, 77356) We would be quite ready, once our right to independence has been recognized, to enter into an alliance or partnership on equal temrs which would place the relations of Great Britain and India on a satisfactory basis.
('54', 34, 0, 1, 77573) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 35
('54', 34, 1, 2, 77618) Q. Once Great Britain has stated finally and once for all that the peoples of India have the same right to control their own destiny that we have, do you think that India would still want to employ, on terms within India's means, British officials, British soldiers, British technicians, and to draw upon our experience in building up the Indian State of the future?
('54', 34, 2, 3, 77985) A. Yes, most certainly.
('54', 34, 2, 4, 78009) Once Great Britain recognizes what we consider our just claims, I certainly would not wish to remove all the British officials in India.
('54', 34, 2, 5, 78146) I want to avail myself of all the experience you have gained.
('54', 34, 2, 6, 78208) I believe that we could make mutually satisfactory arrangements once there is no dictation on your side.
('54', 34, 3, 7, 78313) Q. Is it true, as some of my more extreme nationalist friends have said, that India when she wants European advisers would rather turn to Continental Europeans such as Germans, French, Swedes, Dutch, in place of British?
('54', 34, 4, 8, 78534) A. No, I do not think this is true in general.
('54', 34, 4, 9, 78581) We would certainly need advice and guidance from Europe in several things.
('54', 34, 4, 10, 78656) If we could get these from Great Britain on terms that we can afford, we would welcome them.
('54', 34, 4, 11, 78749) The only thing that would make us turn away from Great Britain would be if Great Britain refuses to grant what we consider our just demand.
('54', 34, 4, 12, 78889) If you will play the same with us and recognize our right to control our own defence, we should confer with your experts and ascertain what is considered the minimum number of British troops necessary for our needs.
('54', 34, 4, 13, 79105) I would regard the British Commander in Chief in India as my technical adviser on military matters, but the British Army in India would, of course, have to be under the Indian National Government.
('54', 34, 5, 14, 79302) Q. What about the statement that it would be undignified for British subjects to place themselves in the position of mercenaries to the Indian Government?
('54', 34, 6, 15, 79457) A. I have heard the argument, but I cannot appreciate it.
('54', 34, 6, 16, 79515) Behind the objection is the lurking belief that partnership is to be partnership in name only and that in reality we are to remain a subject nation.
('54', 34, 6, 17, 79664) Or else, how can British soldiers serving a partner nation be considered mercenaries?
('54', 34, 6, 18, 79750) But if British soldiers will not serve the National Government, we must do without them.
('54', 34, 7, 19, 79839) Q. In terms of self interest, therefore, from the British standpoint, you think that a friendly India in close alliance and partnership with Great Britain would be an asset to us.
('54', 34, 8, 20, 80019) A. You should be the best judges.
('54', 34, 8, 21, 80053) In my opinion, the solution
('54', 35, 0, 1, 80081) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 35, 1, 2, 80122) of the Indian problem in a manner satisfactory to Indian aspirations would largely help Great Britain to solve her own economic question.
('54', 35, 1, 3, 80260) It would be good for Great Britain, India, and the world.
('54', 35, 1, 4, 80318) If Great Britain enters into a free will partnership with India, that is to say, a partnership of equals, she will have a friendly nation to trade with and all the boycotting of British trade would naturally cease, apart, of course, from cloth.
('54', 35, 1, 5, 80563) I fear Lancashire cannot get much help as we are determined to make our own cloth, but there are many others goods required which we shall have to import from abroad.
('54', 35, 1, 6, 80730) for instance, I think India imports eighteen crores worth of sugar and seven crores worth of hardware, and so on.
('54', 35, 1, 7, 80844) We shall certainly not be able to manufacture all our own requirements for a long time to come.
('54', 35, 2, 8, 80940) Q. Then, Mr. Gandhi, I understand you to mean that you want India’s right to control her own destiny recognized now once for all.
('54', 35, 2, 9, 81070) If this were done, you think that the whole atmosphere would change and that Great Britain would then find the India that you represent only too ready to work out the details of co operation?
('54', 35, 2, 10, 81262) Rather than that the Round Table Conference should fail, you think that the principle of India’s complete control of her destiny should be acknowledged and that such problems as the communal question should be left over to arbitration?
('54', 35, 3, 11, 81498) A. Yes, that is so.
('54', 35, 3, 12, 81518) I think that once the British Government proclaimed to the world that India had as much right to freedom as Great Britain, we should be quite ready to accept the principle of arbitration on the difficult communal question.
('54', 35, 3, 13, 81741) I do not think, however, that all the time which has been spent at the Round Table will be found to have been wasted.
('54', 35, 3, 14, 81859) Believe me, Congress is not obstructive.
('54', 35, 3, 15, 81900) Sir Geoffrey Corbett's scheme has emerged from it.
('54', 35, 3, 16, 81951) Sir Hubert Carr's scheme, which practically gives to the Moslems what they want in the Lower Chamber and to the Sikhs what they want in the Upper Chamber, also deserves very careful consideration.
('54', 35, 3, 17, 82148) But, as I have said, I think much the best method would perhaps be to leave the question of the adjustment of seats and separate or joint electorates to an impartial judicial tribunal which would only be called into being in the case of non settlement.
('54', 35, 4, 18, 82401) Q. What about the untouchables?
('54', 35, 4, 19, 82433) I know it is thought in some quarters that they ought to have separate electorates and that you are not qualified to speak for them.
('54', 35, 4, 20, 82566) A. I am glad you have dealt with this subject.
('54', 35, 4, 21, 82613) I do not hesitate to say that, if the untouchables in all parts of India would record their votes, I should be their representative.
('54', 35, 4, 22, 82746) Dr. Ambedkar is
('54', 36, 0, 1, 82762) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 37
('54', 36, 1, 2, 82807) undoubtedly clever and enthusiastic.
('54', 36, 1, 3, 82844) He has every reason to be bitter.
('54', 36, 1, 4, 82878) I have spent the best part of my life in championing their cause, I have mixed with them east, west, north and south in India, I have my of them in my own Ashram, I adopted an untouchable girl.
('54', 36, 1, 5, 83072) My Congressmen think as I do and realize how serious is the untouchable problem.
('54', 36, 1, 6, 83153) In the interests of the untouchables themselves I think it would be fatal for them to have a special electorate, or to have reservation of seats.
('54', 36, 1, 7, 83299) If this were attempted, it would create opposition to them.
('54', 36, 1, 8, 83359) I think their interests would be best safeguarded by their coming "through the open door", to let them have the same voting rights as the ordinary Hindu.
('54', 36, 1, 9, 83513) They will find that the leaders of Indian opinion are determined to improve their social status and give them the right to enter into temples and are ready to remove those other terrible disabilities under which they have suffered in the past.
('54', 36, 2, 10, 83757) Q. Readers of Miss Mayo’s book 1 have never been able to understand the Indian treatment of animals.
('54', 36, 2, 11, 83858) They know that the Hindu thinks it is wrong to take life, but they cannot understand a system whch allows wretched animals in a diseased condition to be left to die on the roadside and not put out of their misery.
('54', 36, 2, 12, 84072) What have you got to say on that subject?
('54', 36, 3, 13, 84114) A. You have dealt with one of the problems which reformers in India hope to rectify in time.
('54', 36, 3, 14, 84207) In my Ashram, we had a dying calf.
('54', 36, 3, 15, 84242) 2 He had stinking sores and was lame.
('54', 36, 3, 16, 84280) I put an end to his earthly existence by painless injections.
('54', 36, 3, 17, 84342) I was bitterly attacked by some of my fellow countrymen, who in my view have yet to learn that ahimsa never meant that suffering which could be terminated should be permitted.
('54', 36, 3, 18, 84518) I think that much of the animal suffering in India today is due to this travesty of what ahimsa meant.
('54', 36, 4, 19, 84621) Q. To move on to another subject.
('54', 36, 4, 20, 84655) I would be interested to know some thing of your religious beliefs.
('54', 36, 4, 21, 84723) Have you ever had religious doubts and when did you first firmly believe in God and since then have you ever been through dark nights of the soul?
('54', 36, 5, 22, 84870) A. When I was quite young I did go through a period of complete disbelief, I was an atheist in fact.
('54', 36, 5, 23, 84971) This was when I was about fourteen.
('54', 36, 5, 24, 85007) Since then, however, I have always believed in God.
('54', 36, 6, 25, 85059) 1 Mother India; or Gandhiji’s comments on the book, vide “Drain Inspector’s Report” 2 Vide “The Fiery Ordeal”
('54', 37, 0, 1, 85169) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 37, 1, 2, 85210) Q. Do you then believe in the personal immortality of the soul?
('54', 37, 2, 3, 85274) A. Yes, I believe in the immortality of the soul.
('54', 37, 2, 4, 85324) I would like to give you the analogy of the ocean.
('54', 37, 2, 5, 85375) The ocean is composed of drops of water, each drop is an entity and yet it is part of the whole, 'the one and the many'.
('54', 37, 2, 6, 85496) In this ocean of life we are all little drops.
('54', 37, 2, 7, 85543) My doctrine means that I must identify myself with life, with everything that lives, that I must share the majesty of life in the presence of God.
('54', 37, 2, 8, 85690) The sum total of this life is God.
('54', 37, 3, 9, 85725) Q. Did any book ever affect you supremely and was there any turning point in your life?
('54', 37, 4, 10, 85813) A. Yes, the book that affected me more than any other was Unto This Last by Ruskin.
('54', 37, 4, 11, 85897) I was living in South Africa then.
('54', 37, 4, 12, 85932) It was the reading of Unto This Last on a railway journey to Durban in 1904 when I was thirty five, they made me decide to change my whole outward life.
('54', 37, 4, 13, 86085) 1 There is no other word for it, Ruskin’s words captivated me.
('54', 37, 4, 14, 86148) I read the book in one go and lay awake all the following night and I there and then decided to change my whole plan of life.
('54', 37, 4, 15, 86274) Tolstoy I had read much earlier.
('54', 37, 4, 16, 86307) He affected the inner being.
('54', 37, 5, 17, 86336) Q. You were a fairly successful lawyer then, weren't you Mr. Gandhi?
('54', 37, 5, 18, 86405) Did your conversion mean then that you came to the conclusion it was wrong to enjoy the good things of this life?
('54', 37, 5, 19, 86519) What income were you making then?
('54', 37, 6, 20, 86553) A. As far as I recollect, I was making something like 3,000 a year by my legal practice.
('54', 37, 6, 21, 86642) My “conversion”, as you call it, decided for me that in future I would dedicate all my earnings to causes that I felt were for the benefit of my fellows, that in the future I would live simply and by physical labour, and imperfectly as I have tried to carry out that aim, I know that it is only be living thus that one achieves complete peace of mind.
('54', 37, 7, 22, 86994) Q. I have been very much struck with your wonderful vitality.
('54', 37, 7, 23, 87056) Few men of
('54', 37, 8, 24, 87067) sixty two can be so full of energy.
('54', 37, 8, 25, 87103) I have read in the papers some of the things about
('54', 37, 9, 26, 87154) your diet.
('54', 37, 9, 27, 87165) Would you tell me just what your daily bill of fare is?
('54', 37, 10, 28, 87221) A Certainly.
('54', 37, 10, 29, 87234) I am sure that most people eat much too much.
('54', 37, 10, 30, 87280) I have never felt better than I do on my present regimen and I have a horror of drugs and medicines.
('54', 37, 10, 31, 87381) This is my daily bill of fare: For my breakfast at 8 o'clock I have sixteen ounces of goat's milk and four oranges, for my luncheon at 1 o'clock I again have sixteen ounces of
('54', 37, 11, 32, 87557) 1 Vide ”An Autobiography”
('54', 38, 0, 1, 87583) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 39
('54', 38, 1, 2, 87628) milk, grapes, pears or other fruit.
('54', 38, 1, 3, 87664) My evening meal is between 5 and 6 o’clock.
('54', 38, 1, 4, 87708) I eat a teaspoonful of almond paste, twenty or thirty dates, several tomatoes and a lettuce or other salad.
('54', 38, 1, 5, 87816) This avoids indigestion.
('54', 38, 1, 6, 87841) As you will note, I eat no starch and no cereals.
('54', 38, 2, 7, 87891) Q. To sum up, Mr. Gandhi, if the Conference breaks down, do you think the
('54', 38, 3, 8, 87965) people of India will be satisfied with partial Home Rule, with the possibility of a
('54', 38, 4, 9, 88049) further conference in ten or twenty years when the British Parliament considers that
('54', 38, 5, 10, 88134) India is in a position to control her own destiny?
('54', 38, 6, 11, 88185) A. I am sure you know what my answer will be.
('54', 38, 6, 12, 88231) I have tried while I have been in England not to say anything provocative, but those of us who are giving our lives to India will never be satisfied with half measures.
('54', 38, 6, 13, 88400) If the people of India after this Conference become convinced that Great Britain is not genuine in her desire to give them immediate self government, all the forces at their disposal will be used.
('54', 38, 7, 14, 88597) Q. What is your final word to the readers of The Spectator?
('54', 38, 8, 15, 88657) A. My final word to your readers is that they should use all the influence at their disposal to get their friends to see our point of view, that they should work for the great cause of a real partnership between our countries on a basis of equality.
('54', 38, 8, 16, 88907) I think that a free association of our two nations or groups of nations, can be utilized for the solving of many world problems, not merely for the good of the greatest number, but for the good of all.
('54', 38, 8, 17, 89109) The Spectator, 24 10 1931

('54', 39, 2, 3, 89208) LONDON, October 18, 1931
('54', 39, 3, 4, 89233) DEAR FRIEND, I was delighted to have your beautiful letter sent through Sundaram.
('54', 39, 3, 5, 89315) It is a great consolation to me that the work I am doing finds favour in your sight.
('54', 39, 3, 6, 89400) I do indeed wish that we could meet face to face and that too in India at my Ashram.

('54', 42, 1, 2, 94008) 24. SPEECH AT BIRMINGHAM MEETING 1
('54', 42, 2, 3, 94043) SELLY OAK,
('54', 42, 3, 4, 94054) BIRMINGHAM, October 18, 1931
('54', 42, 4, 5, 94083) Whereas to other places I have gone as a matter of business, to deliver my message, I have come here as a matter of pilgrimage because this Settlement it was that spared and sent Mr. Horace Alexander to us at a time 2 when we were in need of a friend.
('54', 42, 4, 6, 94335) It was a time when news of satyagraha could not be transmitted from India, everything that was sent was censored, the principal men were all in jail.
('54', 42, 4, 7, 94485) It was then that the friends came to the conclusion that a mission ought to be sent to India and Mr. Alexander was chosen for the purpose.
('54', 42, 4, 8, 94624) Not only were you able to spare him but his wife, a cripple, spared him.
('54', 42, 4, 9, 94697) Now you will understand why it is a pilgrimage for me to come here.
('54', 42, 4, 10, 94765) With regard to the work before me, I did not think I should take your time to describe it to you now.
('54', 42, 4, 11, 94867) The vast majority of the people now know what the Indian National Congress claims for the nation.
('54', 42, 4, 12, 94965) You know what means we have adopted, perhaps, for the first time in history, to achieve our independence.
('54', 42, 4, 13, 95071) And you also know how far the nation during the last year was able to live up to its creed.
('54', 42, 4, 14, 95163) I would like to emphasize upon you the fact that, if the work that is now being done at the Round Table Conference is to bear fruit, it will do so only if the pressure of intelligent public opinion is brought to bear upon it.
('54', 42, 4, 15, 95389) I have often remarked that my true work in England lies outside the Conference, not in the Conference.
('54', 42, 4, 16, 95492) In my few public speeches I have not hesitated to throw out a hint that no work was being done in the Conference, that it was marking time and that the precious time of those who had come from India and those who were representing British interests in the Conference was being wasted.
('54', 42, 4, 17, 95777) That being my
('54', 42, 5, 18, 95791) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s account: “The Birmingham Visit”.

('54', 43, 1, 2, 96266) opinion, I cannot be too insistent that responsible leaders of public opinion in the British Isles should inform themselves of the true nature of the struggle that Indians are carrying on against heavy odds.
('54', 43, 1, 3, 96474) For, unless you understand the true nature and the 1 inner meaning of this struggle, you will not be able to bring effective pressure to bear on those who are conducting the affairs of the State here.
('54', 43, 1, 4, 96675) I know enough of the composition of this meeting to know that you are all earnest seekers after truth and anxious to do the right, not only especially with regard to this, but any cause that deserves the assistance of human beings.
('54', 43, 1, 5, 96907) And if you will approach this question from this standpoint, it is just likely that the deliberations of the Round Table Conference might prove fruitful.
('54', 43, 2, 6, 97061) One of the questions that were put to Gandhiji at the end of his speech was whether settlement was not made impossible by Indian representatives not agreeing among themselves on the communal question.
('54', 43, 2, 7, 97262) Gandhiji, while emphatically repudiating the suggestion, said: I know you have been taught to think like that.
('54', 43, 2, 8, 97373) You cannot shake off the spell of that hypnotic suggestion.
('54', 43, 2, 9, 97433) My case is that alien rulers have ruled India on the principle of “Divide and Rule”.
('54', 43, 2, 10, 97518) No alien Imperial rule could go on in India unless the rulers now conquetted with one and then with the other party.
('54', 43, 2, 11, 97635) We will continue to be divided so long as the wedge of foreign rule remains there, and sinks deeper and deeper.
('54', 43, 2, 12, 97747) That is the way of the wedge.
('54', 43, 2, 13, 97777) But take out the wedge and the split parts will instantly come together and unite.
('54', 43, 2, 14, 97860) Again, the attainment of unity has been rendered a task of Herculean difficulty by the composition of the Conference itself, as all the Delegates here are nominated, none of them is duly elected.
('54', 43, 2, 15, 98056) If, for instance, the Nationalist Muslims had been asked to elect their representative, it would have been Dr. Ansari.
('54', 43, 2, 16, 98175) Lastly, we should not forget that even if the present Delegates had been elected, they would have acted with a better sense of responsibility.
('54', 43, 2, 17, 98318) We, on the other hand, are here on the sufferance of the British Prime Minister.
('54', 43, 2, 18, 98399) We are responsible to nobody, we have no constituency to appeal to.
('54', 43, 2, 19, 98467) Again, we are reminded that unless we agree among ourselves on the communal issue no progess is possible.
('54', 43, 2, 20, 98573) In the very nature of the things, therefore, each pulls it a different way and to exact the utmost he can.
('54', 43, 2, 21, 98680) Again while the Delegates are called upon to present an
('54', 43, 3, 22, 98736) 1 The source has “its”.
('54', 44, 0, 1, 98760) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 45
('54', 44, 1, 2, 98805) agreed communal solution, they are not told what they would get if they agree and so the incentive that could have made agreement beforehand possible is killed at the very start, rendering agreement very nearly impossible.
('54', 44, 1, 3, 99028) Let the Government declare that they are going to withdraw from India whether Indians agreed or not and you will see that we shall then soon agree.
('54', 44, 1, 4, 99176) The fact of the matter is that no one feels that he is going to get real live liberty.
('54', 44, 1, 5, 99263) What is offered is simply a share in the power of the bureaucracy to exploit India and this sets up an apple of discord in our midst.
('54', 44, 1, 6, 99397) Further, the Government having made constitution making dependent upon the solution of the communal question, every party is tempted to pitch its demand as high as possible.
('54', 44, 1, 7, 99571) If the Government at all means business, it would unhesitatingly accept my suggestion, viz., to appoint a judicial tribunal to decide the communal question at issue.
('54', 44, 1, 8, 99737) If this is done, there is every possibility of an agreed solution being reached without the intervention of the judicial tribunal.
('54', 44, 2, 9, 99868) In reply to a further question asking what would happen in India during the transition period if the British Government abdicated its function, Gandhiji said: Alien rule is like foreign matter in an organic body.
('54', 44, 2, 10, 100081) Remove the poison and body will at once start recuperating.
('54', 44, 2, 11, 100141) It is preposterous to suggest that the British Government would be abdicating its funciton if it withdraws from India.
('54', 44, 2, 12, 100260) The only function that it is fulfilling today is of exploiting India.
('54', 44, 2, 13, 100330) Let Britain cease to exploit India and India will immediately revive economically.
('54', 44, 3, 14, 100413) Q. Have the people of India themselves come to an agreement on fundamentals?
('54', 44, 3, 15, 100490) The Congress has come with an agreed scheme of comm unal settlement, but it is not accepted.
('54', 44, 3, 16, 100583) Here at the Conference the Congress is only one of the many parties that are said to be represented here.
('54', 44, 3, 17, 100689) The organic fact, however, is that it is the only representative body speaking for the vast masses in India.
('54', 44, 3, 18, 100798) It is the one live, organic and independent organization that has been functio ning for close upon fifty years.
('54', 44, 3, 19, 100910) It is the only organization that has stood the test of untold suffering.
('54', 44, 3, 20, 100983) It is the Congress which arri ved at a Settlement with the Government, and say what you will, it is the only organization that will one day replace the present Government.
('54', 44, 3, 21, 101155) My claim is that the scheme that is produced through a representative committee of one Sikh, one Muslim and one Hindu member of its Cabinet would stand the test of any judicial tribunal so far as fairness and justness is concerned.
('54', 45, 0, 1, 101387) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 45, 1, 2, 101428) One member of the audience asked the question whether the Round Table Conference had broken down and whether India should wait for swaraj until another conference.
('54', 45, 1, 3, 101592) Gandhiji replied: I am not giving up all hope till I have severed all connection with the Round Table Conference.
('54', 45, 1, 4, 101706) Apparently, thereore, I still entertain some hope though, I may say, I have little data to build on .
('54', 45, 1, 5, 101808) But it is against my nature to violently break away from an organization with which I have been co operating.
('54', 45, 1, 6, 101918) I do not know whether, the next time when the solution comes, there will be another Round Table Conference or not, but this much I know that if the Round Table Conference breaks down, a solution will not be reached before India has passed through a fiery ordeal much more severe than the one it passed through last year.
('54', 45, 2, 7, 102239) Q. You talk of the impoverishment of India as being the result of British exploitation, but is it not a fact that the real cause of the agriculturists misery is the rapacity of the Bania and extravagance of expenditure on the occasion of marriages and funerals?
('54', 45, 2, 8, 102501) Finally, you chare the British Government with extravagance.
('54', 45, 2, 9, 102562) But what have you to say to the extravagance of the Indian Princes?
('54', 45, 3, 10, 102630) A. The Indian Bania is not a patch upon the English Bania and, if we were acting violently, the Indian Bania would deserve to be shot.
('54', 45, 3, 11, 102765) But then, the British Bania would deserve to be shot a hundered times.
('54', 45, 3, 12, 102836) The rate of interest charged by the Indian Bania is nothing compared to the loot carried on by the British Bania through the jugglery of currency and merciless exactions of Land Revenue.
('54', 45, 3, 13, 103023) I do not know of another instance in history of such an organized exploitation of so unorganized and gentle a race.
('54', 45, 3, 14, 103139) As for the profligacy of the Indian Princes, while I would have little hesitation, if I had the power, in dispossessing them of their insolent palaces, I would have infinitely less in depriving the British Government of New Delhi.
('54', 45, 3, 15, 103370) The extravagance of the Princes was nothing compared to the heartless squandering of crores of rupees on New Delhi to satisfy the whim of a Viceroy in order to reproudce England in India, when masses of people were dying of hunger.
('54', 45, 4, 16, 103602) An amusing question was asked by a friend who quoted a letter from The Manchester Guardian in which the correspondent questioned Gandhiji’s
('54', 45, 5, 17, 103742) authority to speak for the untouchables, as he belonged to the priestly class which
('54', 45, 6, 18, 103826) had kept that community depressed so far, and asked whether Gandhiji himself was
('54', 45, 7, 19, 103907) not a great hindrance in the way of a settlement.
('54', 46, 0, 1, 103957) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 47
('54', 46, 1, 2, 104002) I never knew that I was a Brahmin, but I do happen to be a Bania, which is certainly regarded as a term of painful reproach.
('54', 46, 1, 3, 104127) But let me inform the audience that my community excommunicated me when I came to English shores 40 years ago and the work that I have been doing entitles me to be called a farmer, weaver and untouchable.
('54', 46, 1, 4, 104332) I was wedded to the work for the extinction of untouchability long before I was wedded to my wife.
('54', 46, 1, 5, 104431) There were two occasions in our joint life when there was a choice between working for the untouchables and remaining with my wife and I would have preferred the first.
('54', 46, 1, 6, 104600) But thanks to my good wife, the crisis was averted.
('54', 46, 1, 7, 104652) In my Ashram, which is my family, I have several untouchables and a sweet but naughty girl living as my own daughter.
('54', 46, 1, 8, 104770) As to whether I am acting as a hindrance to a settlement.
('54', 46, 1, 9, 104828) I confess, I am for the simple reason that I would not be satisfied with any compromise short of real complete independence for India.
('54', 46, 2, 10, 104963) Q. Sometimes we have found it difficult to reconcile the special form of
('54', 46, 3, 11, 105036) united protest that you have evolved, with an appeal to reason.
('54', 46, 3, 12, 105100) What is it that makes
('54', 46, 4, 13, 105122) you sometimes feel that appeal to reason should be put aside in favour of more drastic
('54', 46, 5, 14, 105209) action?
('54', 46, 6, 15, 105217) A. Up to the year 1906 I simply relied on appeal to reason.
('54', 46, 6, 16, 105277) I was a very industrious reformer.
('54', 46, 6, 17, 105312) I was a good draftsman, as I always had a close grip of facts which in its turn was the necessary result of my meticulous regard for truth.
('54', 46, 6, 18, 105452) But I found that reason failed to produce an impression when the critical moment arrived in South Africa.
('54', 46, 6, 19, 105558) My people were excited—even a worm will and does sometimes turn—and there was talk of wreaking vengeance.
('54', 46, 6, 20, 105664) I had then to choose between allying myself to violence or finding out some other method of meeing the crisis and stopping the rot, and it came to me that we should refuse to obey legislation that was degrading and let them put us in jail if they liked.
('54', 46, 6, 21, 105918) Thus came into being the moral equivalent of war.
('54', 46, 6, 22, 105968) I was then a loyalist, becuase I implicity believed that the sum total of the activities of the British Empire was good for India and for ‘humanity’.
('54', 46, 6, 23, 106118) Arriving in England soon after the outbreak of the War, I plunged into it and later, when I was forced to go to India as a result of the pleurisy that I had developed, I led a recruiting campaign at the risk of my life, and to the horror of some of my friends.
('54', 46, 6, 24, 106379) The disillusionment came in 1919 after the passage of
('54', 47, 0, 1, 106433) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 47, 1, 2, 106474) the Black Rowlatt Act and the refusal of the Government to give the simple elementary redress of proved wrongs 1 that we had asked for.
('54', 47, 1, 3, 106610) And so, in 1920, I became a rebel.
('54', 47, 1, 4, 106645) Since then the conviction has been growing upon me, that things of fundamental importance to the people are not secured by reason alone, but have to be purchased with their suffering.
('54', 47, 1, 5, 106829) Suffering is the law of human beings; war is the law of the jungle.
('54', 47, 1, 6, 106897) But suffering is infinitely more powerful than the law of the jungle for converting the opponent and opening his ears, which are otherwise shut, to the voice of reason.
('54', 47, 1, 7, 107066) Nobody has probably drawn up more petitions or espoused more forlorn causes than I, and I have come to this fundamental conclusion that, if you want something really important to be done, you must not merely satisfy the reason, you must move the heart also.
('54', 47, 1, 8, 107324) The appeal of reason is more to the head, but the penetration of the heart comes from suffering.
('54', 47, 1, 9, 107421) It opens up the inner understanding in man.
('54', 47, 1, 10, 107465) Suffering is the badge of the human race, not the sword.
('54', 47, 2, 11, 107522) Young India, 5 11 1931

('54', 47, 5, 15, 107738) A. I have compared the British rule to a wedge and no sooner the wedge is removed than the divided parts will unite.
('54', 47, 5, 16, 107855) But even if we continue to fight, I should think it a godsend.
('54', 47, 5, 17, 107918) A man who broods on evil is as bad as a man who does evil, if he is no worse, and so, if we are prevented from running at one another's throats simply because of the superimposed force of alien rule, the sooner that force is removed the better.
('54', 47, 5, 18, 108163) We should fight harder for a time, but we should unite better ultimately.
('54', 47, 6, 19, 108237) Q. Are you quite sure that, if you had the elected representatives of the people on the Conference, you would be united at once?

('54', 49, 4, 7, 110994) 27. LETTER TO MRS.

('54', 49, 6, 10, 111043) DEAR MATER,
('54', 49, 7, 11, 111055) You are naughty.
('54', 49, 7, 12, 111072) You will not write because I cannot write.
('54', 49, 7, 13, 111115) I think of you often but get no time to write letters.
('54', 49, 7, 14, 111170) I am obliged even to neglect the Indian mail.
('54', 49, 7, 15, 111216) Maud reminds me that you are expecting to hear from me in accordance with my message sent to you.
('54', 49, 7, 16, 111314) I have a few moments today during my silence.
('54', 49, 7, 17, 111360) I have had interesting accounts of your condition and I was pleased to know that you were bearing your years so well.

('54', 52, 11, 15, 117311) 29. SPEECH AT CHATHAM HOUSE MEETING 1
('54', 52, 12, 16, 117349) LONDON, October 20, 1931 You were good enough to say that I have spared from my busy time a few moments to address a gathering under the auspices of this Institute.
('54', 52, 12, 17, 117514) I must confess that I seize every opportunity I can of coming into touch with British public opinion and putting before them the purpose of my mission.
('54', 52, 12, 18, 117666) I have therefore come before you quite selfishly, and I hope that the words I speak to you this evening will find a lodgment in your hearts.
('54', 52, 12, 19, 117807) At the end of what I have to say I should like you to cross examine me and ask me any questions you may like to put.
('54', 52, 12, 20, 117924) I have found by experience that that is the only way of removing the mists of misunderstanding.
('54', 52, 12, 21, 118020) I have noticed that the greatest stumbling block in my way is the hopeless ignorance of the true facts of the situation, through no fault of yours; you belong to one of the busiest nations in the world, you have your own problems, and at the present moment this great island of yours is going through a crisis such as you have never had to face within
('54', 52, 13, 22, 118372) 1 Held under the auspices of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, the meeting was attended by influential Englishmen and Englishwomen drawn from all parts of England.
('54', 52, 13, 23, 118548) Lord Lothian presided.
('54', 53, 0, 1, 118571) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 53, 1, 2, 118612) living memory.
('54', 53, 1, 3, 118627) My whole heart goes out to you in your troubles, and I hope that you will soon be able, with your marvellous energy, to cut a way out of them.
('54', 53, 1, 4, 118770) No wonder, however, that, preoccupied as you are, you find no time to study the problems that affect a distant land like India.
('54', 53, 1, 5, 118898) It is therefore a matter of keen pleasure to me that so many of you have found time to come here and listen to what I may have to say.
('54', 53, 1, 6, 119033) I only feel grieved that many of you who are listening to my voice are unable to find accommodation in this room.
('54', 53, 1, 7, 119147) With these preliminary words, I plunge into my subject.
('54', 53, 1, 8, 119203) In order to give you a description of the future of India as I conceive it, I shall tell you in as few words as possible what India is at present.
('54', 53, 1, 9, 119350) India is a sub continent by itself, nineteen hundred miles long, fifteen hundred miles wide, with a population of roughly 350 millions.
('54', 53, 1, 10, 119486) Of these about 210 millions are Hindus, 70 millions are Mussalmans, 3 millions are Sikhs; there is also a fairly large Indian Christian population, and a very small European or, more correclty speaking, English population.
('54', 53, 1, 11, 119709) Numerically it is insignificant, but, as you know, it enjoys a position of privilege and influence unsurpassed, belonging as it does to the ruling race.
('54', 53, 1, 12, 119862) We have within this population our own Hindu Muslim—Sikh problem, or, as it is called, the problem of minorities.
('54', 53, 1, 13, 119976) I will not go into the problem as it affects other minorities, nor will I take up your time by airing my views with regard to these minorities, but one minority I may not omit, the unhappy untouchables, a word which is a standing reproach to the Hindus of India who form the majority of the population .
('54', 53, 1, 14, 120280) Untouchability is a curse upon Hinduism, and I have no hesitation in saying that, if untouchability is not rooted out of Hinduism, Hinduism must perish.
('54', 53, 1, 15, 120433) The time has come when any system, no matter how hoary and ancient it may be, must stand the light of day, must be able to stand fierce criticism, and if Hinduism harbours untouchability, it has no place on this earth.
('54', 53, 1, 16, 120652) I am glad to tell you that Congress has made the removal of untouchability an integral part of its programme, and under the inspiration of Congress there are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of young Hindu reformers who have dedicated their lives to the removal of this blot upon Hinduism and upon India.
('54', 53, 1, 17, 120953) These young men and women are reaching a hand to these untouchables in a variety of ways.
('54', 53, 1, 18, 121043) we are digging wells for them, opening schools for them, building new temples for them and opening up old temples for them.
('54', 54, 0, 1, 121167) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 55
('54', 54, 1, 2, 121212) giving to twenty five thousand untouchable women, if not more, work in their own homes.
('54', 54, 1, 3, 121300) We have introduced them to spinnng wheels.
('54', 54, 1, 4, 121343) We have found for several thousand untouchables their old occupation of rough weaving, which had died out owing to the competition of modern manufactured cloth.
('54', 54, 1, 5, 121504) This meant that they had taken either to scavenging or to some other occupation, because of their inability to earn their livelihood rom this noble hereditary occupation of weaving.
('54', 54, 1, 6, 121686) Thanks to God and to the efforts of these young reformers, several thousand untouchables have thus recovered their old occupation of rough weaving.
('54', 54, 1, 7, 121834) There are several families who were heavily indebted and who now are not only free from debts but have laid by a decent sum.
('54', 54, 1, 8, 121959) One family I can recollect has laid by what in India a very respectable sum for a poor family— two thousand rupees.
('54', 54, 1, 9, 122075) This family is in demand all over India as teachers, because both husband and wife are accomplished weavers and conscientious and skilled workers.
('54', 54, 1, 10, 122222) You can imagine how much self respect they must have gained, owing to their being wanted as teachers and not as scavengers and treated almost as a plague.
('54', 54, 1, 11, 122377) That is a very important minority, important in the sense that it deserves all the sympathy and all the aid that can be given to it.
('54', 54, 1, 12, 122510) I have not a shadow of doubt that this untouchability is going very fast, and if, through God’s grace, India comes to her own as a result of the deliberations of the Round Table Conference or otherwise, you will find that untouchability has gone for ever.
('54', 54, 1, 13, 122766) But I have not yet finished my description of India as it is.
('54', 54, 1, 14, 122828) What is this 350 million population doing?
('54', 54, 1, 15, 122871) More than eighty five per cent of this population is engaged in agriculture and is living in seven hundred thousand villages, dotted over the vast surface that I have described.
('54', 54, 1, 16, 123049) There are some villages in India which I have population of not more than a hundred souls; there are, again, villages which have a population of as many as five thousand.
('54', 54, 1, 17, 123220) Now Indian agriculture depends very largely—it has to—upon its precarious rainfall.
('54', 54, 1, 18, 123304) In parts of that subcontinent, like Cherapunji, you have a deluge of rain, as much as 600 inches.
('54', 54, 1, 19, 123402) In other parts, like Sind and Central India, for examle you have hardly 5 inches.
('54', 54, 1, 20, 123484) And then, often, it is not equally distributed.
('54', 54, 1, 21, 123532) Agricultural holdings are anything between one acre, or three quarters of an acre, and two and a half acres.
('54', 54, 1, 22, 123641) I think, taking province by province, in no province are the holdings, on the average, more
('54', 55, 0, 1, 123733) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 55, 1, 2, 123774) than two and a half or three acres per head.
('54', 55, 1, 3, 123819) I am open to correction, but I think I am not far out, and there are thousands upon thousands who have less than one acre, and again tens of thousands who are absolutely landless, and who are therefore living in India as serfs, one might almost say as slaves.
('54', 55, 1, 4, 124079) It cannot be called a state of legal slavery, but it is really a state bordering on slavery.
('54', 55, 1, 5, 124172) This population, because all the rainfall is concentrated within two, three, four or five months at the outside, lives wihout any continuous occupation for nearly six months of the year.
('54', 55, 1, 6, 124359) In some places where there are double crops, the absence of occupation extends over a period of four months, but, roughly speaking, you may say that these agriculturists of India are without any constant occupation for half the year.
('54', 55, 1, 7, 124593) That being so, there is deep and ever deepening poverty among the masses.
('54', 55, 1, 8, 124667) The average income of the people for the whole of India is two pence per day.
('54', 55, 1, 9, 124745) If the average income of these 350 million people is two pence a day—and in calculating this average the wealth of a few millionaires is included—you will have no difficulty in understanding that there are tens of thousands of poeple who do not even earn two pence per day.
('54', 55, 1, 10, 125019) The result is that nearly one tenth of the popultion is living in a condition of semi starvation.
('54', 55, 1, 11, 125117) They have no more than one meal per day, consisting of stale chapati and a pinch of dirty salt.
('54', 55, 1, 12, 125213) There is no such thing as bread.
('54', 55, 1, 13, 125246) They do not know from year’s end to year’s end what milk is, or even skimmed milk; they do not know what butter is; they do not know what oil is; they never get green vegetables.
('54', 55, 1, 14, 125425) That is the condition of the vast mass of sunken humanity in India.
('54', 55, 1, 15, 125493) I have now to tell you what should be, and, if the Congress had its way, would be the future state of India.
('54', 55, 1, 16, 125602) I have not filled in the picture with the cities because the cities do not make India; it is the villages which make India.
('54', 55, 1, 17, 125726) Nor have I put in the Princes; the Princes also have a portion of these villages, and the life of the villagers in British India.
('54', 55, 1, 18, 125856) If there is any difference, and there is some, it is a dffierence of degree and in no sense a differ ence of kind.
('54', 55, 1, 19, 125971) Princes will come and Princes will go, empires will come and empires will go, but this India living in her villages will remain just as it is.
('54', 55, 1, 20, 126114) Sir Henry Maine has left a monograph.
('54', 55, 1, 21, 126152) The Village Communities of India, in which you will find the author saying that all these villages were at one time, and are to a certain extent now, self contained “little republics”.
('54', 55, 1, 22, 126337) They have their own culture, mode of life, and method of protection themselves, their own village
('54', 56, 0, 1, 126435) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 57
('54', 56, 1, 2, 126480) schoolmaster, their own priest, carpenter, barber, in fact everything that a village could want.
('54', 56, 1, 3, 126577) There is certainly today no kind of government to be seen in the villages, but whatever their life is, these villages are self contained, and if you went there, you would find that there is a kind of agreement under which they are built.
('54', 56, 1, 4, 126815) From these villages has perhaps arisen what you call the iron rule of caste.
('54', 56, 1, 5, 126892) Caste has been a blight on India, but it has also acted as a sort of potecting shield for these masses.
('54', 56, 1, 6, 126996) But I must not take you into the intricacies of this caste system.
('54', 56, 1, 7, 127063) What I am trying to give you is as faithful a picture as possible of India as it is at present.
('54', 56, 1, 8, 127159) I must also not detain you with the impress that British rule has left on India, what that rule is today and what it accounts for.
('54', 56, 1, 9, 127290) I have dwelt upon that at other meetings and you have some of the literature; but you have no literature on the future of India.
('54', 56, 1, 10, 127419) I could not possibly have given you a picutre of the future unless I had given you this background.
('54', 56, 1, 11, 127519) If I tell you more about this peasantry of India, you will not now be surprised.
('54', 56, 1, 12, 127600) The Congress has made it an article of faith that the test of its work and its progress shall be the measure of its becoming a predominantly presant organization, and we have set for ourselves this rule, that we shall not consider any interest in India which is in conflict with the fundamental well being of this eighty per cent of the pupulation.
('54', 56, 1, 13, 127949) Then, what should the government of that population be?
('54', 56, 1, 14, 128005) The foremost thing that the future State of India would look after would be the economic welfare of these masses.
('54', 56, 1, 15, 128119) You will therefore have no difficulty in coming to the conclusion that, then, this Government is going to find some occupation or these idle six months of the year for the peasant.
('54', 56, 1, 16, 128300) That should really be the primary concern of any person who undertakes this gigantic task.
('54', 56, 1, 17, 128391) By a process of elimination we have come the conclusion that for this homogeneous population you must have one predominant occupation.You must have an easy occup ation; you must have tools for that occupation that can easily be made in the villages, and the product of the village industry must be capable of being consumed by the villagers.
('54', 56, 1, 18, 128733) I you can give some occ upation which will answer all these tests, you will have a process of production and distribution, self contained and without any other intermediary having to be resorted to.
('54', 56, 1, 19, 128932) Such an occupation was the ancient occupation of hand spinning and hand weaving.
('54', 56, 1, 20, 129013) I will not now take you through the histroy of how it was destroyed.
('54', 56, 1, 21, 129082) But you
('54', 57, 0, 1, 129090) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 57, 1, 2, 129131) find that, due to the Congress, the Spinners’ Association is penetrating as qucikly as it can the thousands of villages of India.
('54', 57, 1, 3, 129261) We have in this manner penetrated two thousand villages.
('54', 57, 1, 4, 129318) This occupaiton has nearly doubled the income of the villagers.
('54', 57, 1, 5, 129382) You will understand what two pence added to two pence means to a poor man; it means, I suggest, a fortune.
('54', 57, 1, 6, 129489) You will then take all the occupations necessary in connection with cotton, from hand sinning and hand weaving to printing, dyeing and washing.
('54', 57, 1, 7, 129633) When you take into considration all these occupations, it does govern the income of the people, and when we have done that, we have given these people a little bit of hope and courage and have put a little lustre into their eyes.
('54', 57, 1, 8, 129863) If you walked with me in the villages of Orissa, you would see walking death throughout the length and breadth of that thrice afficted land.
('54', 57, 1, 9, 130004) You see specimens of humanity, not voluntarily but compulsorily, mere skin and bone without any flesh on their limbs.
('54', 57, 1, 10, 130122) If we give them this occupation, we put into them new life and new hope.
('54', 57, 1, 11, 130195) But the activity of the new State will not stop there.
('54', 57, 1, 12, 130250) These people are living in utter ignorance of sanitation and we have to look after the hygienic conditions.
('54', 57, 1, 13, 130358) So we try to introduce the hygienic methods of Dr. Poor, who has wriitten a volume on village hygiene.
('54', 57, 1, 14, 130461) Briefly spea king, it consists of turning human excreta into manure.
('54', 57, 1, 15, 130530) The Chinese people are the greatest people of the earth in the knowledge of the use of these human excreta, and Dr. Poor says the Chinese were his teachers in discovering the economic treatment.
('54', 57, 1, 16, 130725) We are trying to do two things—to add to the wealth of the nation and to the health of the nation—and if we teach the people this method of treating human excreta, the result will be that we shall rid ourselves somewhat of the plauge of flies, and sterilize to some extent the poisonous mosquito not fully, I know, but it is in the right direction.
('54', 57, 1, 17, 131074) Then we must give them some medical assistance in his malaria ridden country.
('54', 57, 1, 18, 131152) India suffers from many diseases, but malaria is essentially a disease induced by want.
('54', 57, 1, 19, 131240) It is not to be driven away by simply giving the villagers packets of quinine.
('54', 57, 1, 20, 131319) Quinine is essential, but it is useless unless you can give them some milk of some fruit, as their digestive apparatus is not capable of taking anything else.
('54', 57, 1, 21, 131478) So we are trying to give them some simple medical aid where we can.
('54', 57, 1, 22, 131546) I am not trying to give you an idea that we have already done this, but I am talking of the future State, not as a visionary but as a practical man.
('54', 57, 1, 23, 131695) We have tried this on a small scale,
('54', 58, 0, 1, 131732) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 59
('54', 58, 1, 2, 131777) and if I can multiply this activity through the aid of the future State, you will understand what India can be without a vast outlay.
('54', 58, 1, 3, 131911) We give this medical aid, not through the very expensive methods that the Western doctors teach us, but we revive our own ancient treatment.
('54', 58, 1, 4, 132052) Every village once had its own medical man.
('54', 58, 1, 5, 132096) You may say he was a quack and that he was extremely ignorant of the elementary principles which govern this little body of ours; all which is very true.
('54', 58, 1, 6, 132250) But all the same he was a man who could give them some comfort, and, the occupation being hereditary, where he was not dishonest man, he really served an efficient purpose.
('54', 58, 1, 7, 132423) If you give him this elementary knowledge of hygiene, which is preventive medicine, and teach him this simple way of curing the people of malaria, you have gone a very long way.
('54', 58, 1, 8, 132601) What I am telling you today is a thing that was approved by the Surgeon General of the Bombay Presidency.
('54', 58, 1, 9, 132707) When he came to see me whilst I was lying in the Sassoon Hospital 1, he was discussing it with me, and I told him, “Your English methods are too expensive for this poor country, and if you want to treat a village through your method, it would take two or three centruries.” He agreed and said, “What would you do?” So I told him my plan.
('54', 58, 1, 10, 133045) That does not finish the picutre.
('54', 58, 1, 11, 133079) We have the education of this future State.
('54', 58, 1, 12, 133123) I say witout fear of my figures being challenged successully, that today India is more illiterate than it was fifty or a hundred years ago, and so is Burma, because the British adminis trations, when they came to India, instead of taking hold of things as they were, began to root them out.
('54', 58, 1, 13, 133414) They scratched the soil and began to look at the root, and left the root like that, and the beautiful tree perished.
('54', 58, 1, 14, 133531) The village schools were not good enough for the British administrator, so he came out with his programme.
('54', 58, 1, 15, 133638) Every school must have so much paraphernalia, building, and so forth.

('54', 60, 2, 15, 138567) Q. Would not Mr. Gandhi admit that within living memory the resisting power of the rural masses to the economic breakdown produced by a failure of crops had been enormously increased, and that the famine codes in India had been brought to a high degree of perfection at a time when the increased prosperity of the masses had rendered them unnecessary?
('54', 60, 3, 16, 138919) Mr. Gandhi replied that his experience was that the resisting power of the people had not increased, but that railway transport enabled people to get grain from other places which they had not formerly been able to obtain.

('54', 61, 1, 2, 139492) SIR PHILIP HARTOG: Would Mr. Gandhi explain why the literacy figure was fourteen per cent of the men and only two per cent of the women, and why illiteracy was higher to Kashmir and Hyderabad than in British India.

('54', 61, 1, 4, 139798) He could only conjecture, with regard to the figures for Kashmir, that if illiteracy was greater there, it was due to the negligence of the ruler or because the population was predominantly, Mohammedan, but he thought that, as a matter of fact, it was six of the one and half a dozen of the other.
('54', 61, 1, 5, 140096) Q. Were the Brahmins in Congress helping the untouchables?

('54', 61, 1, 11, 140837) The work of the Salvation Army and the missionaries was of a different character from that done by the Hindu reformers, and he did not wish to go into that issue on that occasion.
('54', 61, 1, 12, 141017) Q. What effect would the proposed reforms have on the population of India ?
('54', 61, 1, 13, 141093) If better hygiene was introduced, it would lower the death rate and increase the population, and if a better standard of living was attained through individual industry and economy of public expenditure, was there anything which would hold back the birth rate from again rising to keep the population hard up against subsistence level?
('54', 61, 1, 14, 141429) Was not permanent improvement prevented without restriction of the birth rate?
('54', 61, 1, 15, 141508) Mr. Gandhi replied that this problem was not a monopoly of India; it was a modern superstition.
('54', 61, 1, 16, 141604) He did not regard a normal increase in birth rate as an evil, and he would congratulate the Congress workers if they could show that, as a result of their hygienic and other reforms, the birth rate of India had increased.
('54', 61, 1, 17, 141826) He was not afraid of an increase of poverty if the birth rate did increase.
('54', 61, 1, 18, 141902) They were trying to inculcate among themselves the kind of life which regarded a normal increase in birth rate as one thing and animal indulgence resulting in birth rate as another, and there could not be too much stress laid upon education of that character.
('54', 61, 1, 19, 142162) He had undertaken a prayerful study of the question and was in correspondence with Western thinkers all over Europe and America on the subject, and he had come definitely to the conclusion that the methods of birth control suggested by modern reformers would be found upon experience to have been death traps.
('54', 62, 0, 1, 142472) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 63
('54', 62, 1, 2, 142517) Even though it might be proved that in England, Holland, France, other parts of Europe and some parts of America, this method of controlling birth rate might have done some good, it could only do immeasurable harm in India, where it was not possible to give these remedies to the people.
('54', 62, 1, 3, 142805) It was wicked for anybody to suggest these remedies for India when India could not understand these methods in any shape or form.
('54', 62, 1, 4, 142935) Q. Would Mr. Gandhi state briefly on what principle a strong, stable Executive could be framed for India ?
('54', 62, 1, 5, 143042) Mr. Gandhi replied that a strong, stable Executive Government could best be framed by getting strong, stable hearts, and there was no dearth of such hearts in India.
('54', 62, 1, 6, 143208) He had not dwelt on the political side, because the future of India as he had been picturing it, did not admit of much political treatment.
('54', 62, 1, 7, 143348) The cure of the disease of economic misery was economic, but he was dabbling in politics because it was impossible to deal wih economics unless he also dealt with politics.
('54', 62, 1, 8, 143521) He had given his political faith from many platforms, and had taken it for granted that the audience knew the principles which guided Congress, but he was willing to give his political faith again if desired.
('54', 62, 1, 9, 143730) He believed with Tolstoy that that country was best governed which was governed the least, and if Congress had its way, the politician would not be allowed to invade the privacy and sanctity of the home, but would be called upon to keep his place.

('54', 62, 1, 12, 144233) The harvest was ripe, but the labourers were undoubtedly few.

('54', 62, 1, 15, 144603) Either Hinduism would be broken to bits or untouchability would disappear before many years were past.

('54', 68, 7, 12, 158778) LORD PEEL: .
('54', 68, 7, 13, 158791) There should, first of all, be a small impartial committee which should investigate the questions connected with the States’ contributions, ceded territories, the position of the Maritime States, and so on.
('54', 68, 7, 14, 158998) Now, the question of the Maritime States need not necessarily be settled, I think, before the Bill becomes an Act; but the other matters—the question of the States’ contributions and the ceded territories—have to be gone into, and gone into carefully.
('54', 68, 7, 15, 159250) The first suggestion is, therefore, that this small impartial Committee shall deal with those problem and, of course report as quickly as possible.
('54', 68, 8, 16, 159398) The second Committee suggested to be set up is to some extent varied from the original proposal.
('54', 68, 8, 17, 159495) It was to be a Committee which should deal with the various problems submitted to it, and might have some freedom even to make alternative suggestions on matters of principle.
('54', 68, 8, 18, 159671) Well, there was a good deal of anxiety expressed in some quarters that that might, I will not say lead to the tearing up of the principles set out in the Finance Sub committee’s resport, but at least might give too much latitude to that Committee.

('54', 69, 2, 3, 160242) I hope that those suggestions will meet the views which have been expressed by the members of the Committee.
('54', 69, 2, 4, 160351) I can sum them up very shortly.
('54', 69, 3, 5, 160383) There is, first of all, the general acceptance, as a basis for drafting the Bill, of the principles laid down by the Finance Sub committee.
('54', 69, 3, 6, 160523) Then there are these two Committees to be set up, the one a small body dealing with the question of the States, and the other a fact finding Committee which can get to work rapidly and provide the material on which final decisions are taken.
('54', 69, 3, 7, 160765) Then, before the end of the Conference, the Government must states its proposals and make its own recommedations as to the best method of consulting the parties concerned on the few points which may be left over to be decided after these Committees have reported.

('54', 71, 0, 1, 165506) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('54', 74, 1, 2, 172157) 38. EXTRACTS FROM PROCEEDINGS OF THE FEDERAL STRUCTURE COMMITTEE MEETING
('54', 74, 2, 3, 172230) LONDON, October 23, 1931
('54', 74, 3, 4, 172255) MR. GANDHI : Lord Chancellor and fellow Delegates, I feel considerable hesitation in speaking on this subject 1 , which has been rendered so highly technical by the course that the discussion has taken; but I feel that I owe a duty to you and a duty to the Congress which I represent.
('54', 74, 3, 5, 172540) I know that the Congres hold some decided views on the question of the Federal Court—views which would be, I am afraid, very distasteful to a large number of the Delegates here.
('54', 74, 3, 6, 172718) Whatever they are, seeing that they are held by responsible body, It is, I suppose, necessary that I should at least present them to you.
('54', 74, 3, 7, 172856) I see that the discussions are based, if not upon utter distrust, upon considerable distrust of ourselves—that the National Govern ment will not be able to conduct its affairs in an impartial manner.
('54', 74, 3, 8, 173056) This communal tangle also is colouring the discussion.
('54', 74, 3, 9, 173111) The Congress, on the other hand, bases the whole of its policy on trust and on confidence that, when we have come to power, we shall also come to a sense of our responsibility, and all the communal bias will drop out.
('54', 74, 3, 10, 173329) But should it prove otherwise, then, too, the Congress would run the boldest risks imaginable because, without running those risks, we shall not be able to exercise real responsibility.
('54', 74, 3, 11, 173515) So long as we have the mental reservation that we have to rest upon some foreign power for our guidance and for conducting our affairs at a critical juncture, so long, in my opinion, there is no responsibility.One feels also embarrassed by the fact that we really are trying to discuss this thing without knowing where we shall be.
('54', 74, 3, 12, 173847) I should give one opinion if Defence was not under the control of the responsible to Government, and another opinion if Defence was under our own control.
('54', 74, 3, 13, 174002) I proceed upon the assumption that, if we are to enjoy responsibility in the real sense of the term, Defence will be under our control—under national control in every sense of the term.
('54', 74, 3, 14, 174188) I entirely sympathize with Dr. Ambedkar in the difficulty that he raised.
('54', 74, 3, 15, 174262) It is all very well to have a judgment of the highest tribunal; but if the writ of that tribunal does not run beyond the confines of its
('54', 74, 4, 16, 174399) 1 The Federal Court
('54', 75, 0, 1, 174419) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 75, 1, 2, 174460) own Court, that tribunal will be laughing stock of the nation and of the whole world.
('54', 75, 1, 3, 174546) What is then to be done in connection with that writ?
('54', 75, 1, 4, 174600) What Mr. Jinnah said, of course came home—that the military would be there; but it will be the Crown that will run the writ.
('54', 75, 1, 5, 174725) Then I would say, let the High Court also, or the Federal Court, be under the Crown.
('54', 75, 1, 6, 174810) In my opinion, the Supreme Court has to be, if we are responsible, under the responsible Government; and therefore the process of carrying out the writ has also to be made good by the responsible Government.
('54', 75, 1, 7, 175018) Personally, I do not share the fears that actuate Dr. Ambedkar; but I think that his objection is a very reasonable objection, and that a Court which gives judgments should also have perfect confidence that its judgements will be respected by those who are affected by its judgments.
('54', 75, 1, 8, 175302) Hence I would suggested that the Judges should have the power of framing rules in order to regulate matters in connection with those judgments.
('54', 75, 1, 9, 175446) Naturally the enforcement will not rest with the Court—the enforcement will rest with the executive authority; but the executive authority would have to conform to the rules that might be framed by the Court.
('54', 75, 1, 10, 175655) Somehow or other we fancy that this Consitution is going to give us every detail in connection with the composition of this Court.
('54', 75, 1, 11, 175786) I respectfully differ from that view in its entirety.
('54', 75, 1, 12, 175840) I think that this Constitution will give us the framework of the Federal Court and will define the jurisdiction of the Federal Court, but the rest will be left to the Federal Government to evolve.
('54', 75, 1, 13, 176037) I can not possibly understand that the Constitution is also going to tell us how many years the Judges are to serve, or whether they are to resign or retire at the age of 70 or 95 or 90 or 65. I think that these will be matters to be taken up by the Federal Court; hence I propose a drastic method, for what it may be worth, that the Constitution will give us, to start with, the Judges, and these Judges will serve for a fixed, definite period, so that the responsible Government might not have to shoulder the burden of a Federal Court or a Supreme Court, whatever we choose to call it, which may not answer the needs of the country.
('54', 75, 1, 14, 176673) We bring in the Crown at the end of almost every sentence.
('54', 75, 1, 15, 176732) I must confess that, according to the conception of the Congress, there is no question of the Crown.
('54', 75, 1, 16, 176833) India desires complete inde pendence; and if India enjoys complete independence, whoever the supreme authority there may be, that supreme authority will be responsible for the appointment of Judges and several other matters which today belong to the Crown.
('54', 76, 0, 1, 177090) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 77
('54', 76, 1, 2, 177135) It is a fundamental belief with the Congress that, whatever the course the Constitution takes, there should be our own Privy Council in India.
('54', 76, 1, 3, 177278) The Privy Council’s portals, if it is really to give relief to the poor people in matters of the highest importance, should be open to the poorest people in the land, and I think that is impossible if the English Privy Council is to decide our fate in matters of the greatest importance.
('54', 76, 1, 4, 177566) There, too, I would guide ourselves by implicit trust in the ability of our Judge to pronounce wise and absolutely impartial decisions.
('54', 76, 1, 5, 177702) I know that, in making great changes, we run always very great risks.
('54', 76, 1, 6, 177772) The Privy Council here is an ancient institution, and an institution which justly commands very great regard and respect; but, in spite of all the respect that I have for the Privy Council, I cannot bring myself to believe that we will not be able to have a Privy Council of our own which will command universal esteem.
('54', 76, 1, 7, 178092) Because England can boast of very fine institutions, I do not think that therefore we must be tied down to those institutions.
('54', 76, 1, 8, 178219) If we are to learn anything whatever from England, we should learn to erect those institutions ourselves.
('54', 76, 1, 9, 178325) Otherwise there is a poor chance for this nation whose representatives we claim to be.
('54', 76, 1, 10, 178412) Therefore, I would ask us all to have sufficient trust and confidence in ourselves at the present moment.
('54', 76, 1, 11, 178518) Our beginning may be very small, but if we have strong, true and honest hearts to give decisions, it does not matter in the slightest degree that we have not got the legal traditions which the Judges in England claim and very properly boast of before the whole world.
('54', 76, 1, 12, 178786) That being my view, I feel that this Federal Court should be a Court of the widest jurisdiction possible, and not decide cases only that arise from the administration of federal laws.
('54', 76, 1, 13, 178970) Federal laws, of course, will be there, but it should have the amplest jurisdiction to try all the cases that may come from the four corners of diction to try all the cases that may come from the four corners of India.
('54', 76, 1, 14, 179189) It is, then, a question where the subjects of the Princes will be and where they will come in.

('54', 76, 1, 16, 179658) If there is something in common between all of us, naturally the Supreme Court will be the guardian of the rights that we may consider to be common to all.
('54', 77, 0, 1, 179814) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 77, 1, 2, 179855) What those rights should be, I am totally unable to say.
('54', 77, 1, 3, 179912) It is entirely for the Princes to say what they can be and what they cannot be.
('54', 77, 1, 4, 179992) In view of the fact that they represent here not only their own Houses but have taken on themselves the tremendous responsibility of representing their subjects also at this Conference, I would certainly make a humble but fervent appeal to them that they would of their own accord come forth with some scheme whereby their subjects also may feel that, though they are not directly represented at this table, their voices will find adequate expression through these noble Princes themselves.
('54', 77, 1, 5, 180483) So far as the salary is concerned, you will laugh, naturally, but the Congress does believe that it is an impossible thing for the Congress,which represents a nation of dwarfs, to vie with the English nation, which represents today giants in wealth.
('54', 77, 1, 6, 180733) India, whose average income is 2d.
('54', 77, 1, 7, 180768) per day, can ill afford to pay the high salaries that are commanded here.
('54', 77, 1, 8, 180842) I feel that it is a thing which we will have to unlearn if we are going to have voluntary rule in India.
('54', 77, 1, 9, 180947) It is all very well, so long as the British bayonet is there, to squeeze out of these poor people salaries of Rs. 10,000 a month or salaries of Rs. 5,000 a month or salaries of Rs. 20,000 a month.
('54', 77, 1, 10, 181144) I do not consider, however, that my country has sunk to such an extent that it will not be able to produce sufficient men who will live somewhat in correspondence with the lives of the millions and still serve India nobly, truly and well.
('54', 77, 1, 11, 181383) I do not believe for one moment that legal talent has to be bought if it is to remain honest.
('54', 77, 1, 12, 181477) I recall the names of Motilal Nehru, C. R. Das, Manomohan Ghosh, Badruddin Tyabji and a host of others, who gave their legal talent absolutely free of charge and served their country faithfully and well.
('54', 77, 1, 13, 181681) The taunt may be flung in my face that they did so because they were able to charge princely fees in their own professional work.
('54', 77, 1, 14, 181811) I reject that argument, for the simple reason that I have known every one of them with the exception of Manomohan Ghosh.
('54', 77, 1, 15, 181932) It was not that they had plenty of money and therefore gave freely of their talent when India required it.

('54', 77, 1, 19, 182363) I have therefore absolute confidence that, when we come to conduct our own affairs and so on, we will do so in a patriotic spirit and taking account of the miserable state that the millions of India occupy.

('54', 77, 1, 21, 182605) Seeing that the Congress

('54', 78, 1, 2, 182675) holds the view that this Federal Court or Supreme Court—whichever you call it—will occupy the position of the highest tribunal beyond which no man who is an inhabitant of India can go, its jurisdiction in my opinion will be limitless.
('54', 78, 1, 3, 182910) It will have jurisdiction, so far as federal matters are concerned, to the extent that the Princes are also willing; but I cannot possibly imagine that we shall have two Supreme Courts—one in order to deal with merely federal law and another to deal with all the other matters that are not covered by the federal administration or the Federal Government.
('54', 78, 1, 4, 183265) because at the present moment, I suppose, as things go, the Federal Government will concern itself with the minimum subjects, matters of the highest moment will be extrafederal.
('54', 78, 1, 5, 183443) Who is to adjudicate upon these extrafederal matters if not this very Supreme Court?
('54', 78, 1, 6, 183528) Therefore, this Supreme Court or Federal Court will exercise double jurisdiction, if necessary treble jurisdiction.
('54', 78, 1, 7, 183644) The greater the power that we give to this Federal Court, I think, the greater the confidence we shall be able to inspire in the world and also in the nation itself.
('54', 78, 1, 8, 183810) I am sorry to have taken up these precious minutes of the time of the Conference, but I felt that, in spite of my great reluctance to speak to you on this Federal Court, I must give you the views that many of us in the Congress have been holding for a large number of years, and which we would, if we could, spread throughout the length and breadth of India.
('54', 78, 1, 9, 184169) I know the terrible handicap under which I am labouring.
('54', 78, 1, 10, 184226) All the most distinguished lwyers are arrayed against me; the Princes also probably arrayed against me so far as the salaries and jurisdiction of this Court are concerned.
('54', 78, 1, 11, 184398) But I would be guilty of neglect of duty to the Congress and to you if I did not give you the views that the Congress and I hold so strongly on the matter of the Federal Court.

('54', 78, 2, 13, 184687) We are here to exchange views and to hear arguments upon them; that is the object of the Conference.

('54', 78, 2, 15, 184931) The difficulty is to negotiate with a man who does not know what he wants.
