('54', 82, 2, 3, 192251) OXFORD, October 24, 1931
('54', 82, 3, 4, 192276) Muslims and Sikhs are all well organized.
('54', 82, 3, 5, 192318) The untouchables are not.
('54', 82, 3, 6, 192344) There is very little political consciousness among them and they are so horribly treated that I want to save them against themselves.
('54', 82, 3, 7, 192478) If they had separate electorates, their lives would be miserable in villages which are the strongholds of Hindu orthodoxy.
('54', 82, 3, 8, 192601) It is the superior class of Hindus who have to do penance for having neglected the untouchables for ages.
('54', 82, 3, 9, 192707) That penance can be done by active social reform and by making the lot of the untouchables more bearable by acts of service, but not by asking for separate electorates for them.
('54', 82, 3, 10, 192885) By giving them separate electorates you will throw the apple of discord between the untouchables and the orthodox.
('54', 82, 3, 11, 193000) You must understand I can tolerate the proposal for special representation of the Mussalmans and the Sikhs only as a necessary evil.
('54', 82, 3, 12, 193133) It would be a positive danger for the untouchables.
('54', 82, 3, 13, 193185) I am certain that the question of separate electorates for the untouchables is a modern manufacture of a Satanic Government.
('54', 82, 3, 14, 193310) The only thing needed is to put them on the voters’ list, and provided for fundamental rights for them in the Constitution.
('54', 82, 3, 15, 193434) In case they are unjustly treated and their representative is deliberately excluded they would have the right to special election triubunal which would give them complete protection.
('54', 82, 3, 16, 193617) It should be open to these tribunals to order the unseating of an elected candidate and election of the excluded man.
('54', 82, 3, 17, 193735) Separate electorates to the untouchables will ensure them bondage in perpetuity.
('54', 82, 3, 18, 193816) The Mussalmans will never cease to be Mussalmans by having separate electorates.
('54', 82, 3, 19, 193897) Do you want the untouchables to remain untouchables for ever?
('54', 82, 3, 20, 193959) Well, the sepa rate electorates would perpetaute the stigma.
('54', 82, 3, 21, 194020) What is needed is destruction of untouchability and when you have done it, the bar sinister which has been imposed by an insolent “superior” class upon an “inferior” class will be destroyed.
('54', 82, 3, 22, 194211) When you have destroy ed the bar sinister, to whom will you give the separate electorates?

('54', 83, 2, 17, 195670) Q.Do you still believe in the good faith of England?
('54', 83, 3, 18, 195723) A. I believe in the good faith of England to the extent that I believe in the good fait hof human nature.
('54', 83, 3, 19, 195829) I believe that the sum total of the energy of mankind is not to bring us down but to lift us up, and that is the result of the definite, if unconcious, working of the law of love.
('54', 83, 3, 20, 196009) The fact that mankind persists shows that the cohesive force is greater than the disruptive force, centripetal force greater than centrifugal.

('54', 83, 4, 24, 196650) Q.What is your view about the industrialization of India?

('54', 87, 1, 6, 204905) The key to self government is without doubt the control of the army.
('54', 87, 1, 7, 204974) As regards a united demand, I must say, what I have now said several times that you cannot have a united demand from a packed Conference.
('54', 87, 1, 8, 205112) It is my case that the Congress represents the largest number of Indians.
('54', 87, 1, 9, 205186) The British Ministers know it.
('54', 87, 1, 10, 205217) If they do not know it, I must go back to my country and have as overwhelming an opinion as possible.
('54', 87, 1, 11, 205319) We had a life and death struggle.
('54', 87, 1, 12, 205353) One of the noblest of Englishmen 1 tried us and did not find us wanting.
('54', 87, 1, 13, 205426) In consequence he opened the jail gates and appealed to the Congress to go to the Round Table Conference.
('54', 87, 1, 14, 205532) We had long talks and negotiations during which we exercised the greatest patience and there was a Settlement under which the Congress agreed to be represented on the Round Table Conference.
('54', 87, 1, 15, 205723) The Settlement was respected by Government more in its breach than its observance, and after much hesitation I agreed to come, if only to keep my word of honour given to that Englishman.
('54', 87, 1, 16, 205910) On coming here I find that I had miscalculated the forces arrayed against India and the Congress.
('54', 87, 1, 17, 206008) But that does not dismay me.
('54', 87, 1, 18, 206037) I must go and quality myself and prove by suffering that the whole country wants what it asks for .
('54', 87, 1, 19, 206137) Hunter has said that success on the battle field was the shortest cut to power.
('54', 87, 1, 20, 206217) Well, we worker for success on a different battle field.
('54', 87, 1, 21, 206274) I am trying to touch your heart instead of your body.
('54', 87, 1, 22, 206328) If I do not succeed this time, I shall succeed next time.

('54', 88, 0, 1, 206444) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 89
('54', 88, 1, 2, 206489) 43. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('54', 88, 2, 3, 206516) OXFORD, October 24, 1931
('54', 88, 3, 4, 206541) Q.How far would you cut India off from the Empire?
('54', 88, 4, 5, 206592) A. From the Empire entirely; from the British nation not at all, if I want India to gain and not to grieve.
('54', 88, 4, 6, 206700) The British Empire is an Empire only because of India.
('54', 88, 4, 7, 206755) That Emperorship must go and I should love to be equal partner with Britain, sharing her joys and sorrows and equal partner with all Dominions.
('54', 88, 4, 8, 206899) But it must be a partnership on equal terms.
('54', 88, 5, 9, 206944) Q.To what extent would India be prepared to share the sorrows of England?
('54', 88, 6, 10, 207018) A. To the fullest extent.
('54', 88, 7, 11, 207044) Q.Do you think India would unite her fortunes inextricably with England?
('54', 88, 8, 12, 207117) A. Yes, so long as she remains a partner.
('54', 88, 8, 13, 207159) But if she discovers that the partnership is lke one between a giant and a dwarf, or if it is utilized for exploitation of the other races of the earth, she would dissolve it.
('54', 88, 8, 14, 207335) The aim is the common good of all nations of the earth and, if it cannot be achieved, I have patience enough to wait for ages rather than patch up an unreal partnership.
('54', 88, 9, 15, 207505) Q.How would you distinguish exploitation from trading with a nation?
('54', 88, 10, 16, 207574) A. There are two tests: (1) The other nation must want our goods which should in no case be dumped on it against her will.
('54', 88, 10, 17, 207697) (2) The trade should not be backed by the navy.
('54', 88, 10, 18, 207745) And whilst in this connection I may say that, when you realize what wrong has been done by England to nations like us Indians, you will not sing Britannia rules the waves with any kind of pride.
('54', 88, 10, 19, 207940) Things, in English Readers, which are matter for pride today, will have to be matters for shame, and you will have to cease to take any pride over the defeat or humiliation of other nations.
('54', 88, 11, 20, 208131) Q.How far is the British attitude towards the communal question an obstacle in your path?
('54', 88, 12, 21, 208221) A. Largely, or I should say half and half.
('54', 88, 12, 22, 208264) There has been consciously or unconsciously that policy of divide and rule working
('54', 88, 13, 23, 208347) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report: “The Week end at Eton and Oxford: Among Future Empire Builders”.
('54', 88, 13, 24, 208453) The questions were put to Gandhiji at a meeting at the Raleigh Club.
('54', 89, 0, 1, 208522) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 89, 1, 2, 208563) here as in india.
('54', 89, 1, 3, 208581) The British officials have sometimes coquetted with one party, sometimes with another.
('54', 89, 1, 4, 208668) Of course, if I were a British officail, I would probably do the same and take advantage of dissensions to consolidate the rule.
('54', 89, 1, 5, 208797) Our share of responsibility lies in the fact that we fall easy victims to the game.
('54', 89, 2, 6, 208881) Q.You think the British Government should suggest a solution of the
('54', 89, 3, 7, 208949) communal question?
('54', 89, 4, 8, 208968) A. No, But I am the only party to say no.
('54', 89, 4, 9, 209010) It is a humiliating thing and neither the Congress nor I can be party to it.
('54', 89, 4, 10, 209087) But I have suggested a judicial tribunal.
('54', 89, 4, 11, 209129) There are some committals on the side of Government in Government of India and Provincial Government dispatches, though all Government solutions are tinged by political considerations.
('54', 89, 4, 12, 209314) As for us, each party, though talking of justice, fights shy of arbitration, which shows that there is a good deal of expediency and it is a question of degree who is wrong and who is right.
('54', 89, 4, 13, 209505) The judicial tribunal can certainly be trusted to adjudicate between the various claims.
('54', 89, 5, 14, 209594) Q.Could you tell us anything about the personnel?
('54', 89, 6, 15, 209644) A. They may be non Hindu and non Muslim judges of the Indian High Courts or judges from the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council.
('54', 89, 7, 16, 209777) Q.Would their decision be accepted?
('54', 89, 8, 17, 209813) A. There can be no question of accepting the decision of a Court.
('54', 89, 8, 18, 209879) I may confess that there is a trick at the back of the suggestion.
('54', 89, 8, 19, 209946) If Government will play the game and adopt my suggestion, the whole atmosphere will change and before the judicial Committee comes into being the communities will come out with a solution.
('54', 89, 8, 20, 210135) For, there is sufficient material in the advances already made to satisfy the politically minded and each one knows the flaws in his own claim.

('54', 90, 1, 2, 210348) 44. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('54', 90, 2, 3, 210375) [On or after October 24, 1931] 2
('54', 90, 3, 4, 210408) Q.Why do Hindus want joint electorates?
('54', 90, 4, 5, 210448) A. Because they are foolish.
('54', 90, 4, 6, 210477) They can take the wind out of the sails of Mussalmans by immediately giving them separate electorates and leaving them wondering whether there may not be after all something sinister in the separate electorates.
('54', 90, 5, 7, 210689) Q.Why are you so uncharitable to those who drink?
('54', 90, 6, 8, 210739) A. Because I am charitable to those who suffer from the effects of the curse.
('54', 90, 7, 9, 210817) Q.Do you ever suffer from nerves?
('54', 90, 8, 10, 210851) A. Ask Mrs. Gandhi.
('54', 90, 8, 11, 210871) She will tell you that I am on my best behaviour with the world but not with her.
('54', 90, 9, 12, 210953) Well, my husband is on his best behaviour with me.
('54', 90, 9, 13, 211004) Then I am sure that Mr. Miles has bribed you heavily.
('54', 90, 10, 14, 211058) Q.Is not the charkha a mediaeval device?
('54', 90, 11, 15, 211099) A. We were doing many things in the middle ages which were quite wise.
('54', 90, 11, 16, 211170) But if most of us have given them up, why accuse me of my wisdom?
('54', 90, 11, 17, 211236) However mediaeval the device may be, I am not ashamed of adding thereby fifty per cent to the income of my impoverished villagers.
('54', 90, 11, 18, 211367) During the War you produced potatoes and fashionable ladies of Lyceum Club invited men to stitch sleeping suits for the soldiers with plain needle and thread.
('54', 90, 11, 19, 211526) Was it not mediaeval?
('54', 90, 11, 20, 211548) Well, I learnt the mediaeval trick from the ladies of the Lyceum Club.
('54', 90, 12, 21, 211619) Q.What is the chief obstacle in the way swaraj?
('54', 90, 13, 22, 211667) A. It is the unwillingness of the British officials to part with power; or our incapacity to wrest power from unwilling hands.
('54', 90, 13, 23, 211794) Well, you feel sorry that I have not given you the expected reply.
('54', 90, 13, 24, 211861) I want you to understand that we can wrest power in spite of our disunion, and if the hands which have to yield power were willing, our disunion would soon disappear.
('54', 90, 13, 25, 212028) You say the British are impartial on lookers!
('54', 90, 13, 26, 212074) Well, I have had the audacity of accusing the Government of India of

('54', 93, 9, 17, 216760) 88 KNIGHTSBRIDGE, LONDON, W., October 27, 1931
('54', 93, 10, 18, 216807) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('54', 93, 10, 19, 216849) The friend who writes to you has evidently missed the mark.
('54', 93, 10, 20, 216909) The Congress is the Moderate Party.
('54', 93, 10, 21, 216945) There is no such thing as an extreme demand.
('54', 93, 10, 22, 216990) “Indepen dence” is not an extreme demand, but it is the only selfres pecting, logical and consistent demand.

('54', 94, 1, 2, 217229) undoubtedly a party in India which does not want independence because it fears it, but that is a constitutional disease.
('54', 94, 1, 3, 217350) Those who are not suffering from that disease naturally want their digestive apparatus craves for.
('54', 94, 1, 4, 217449) Nobody would call that an extreme craving, nor expect the man with a vigorous appetite to be satisfied with one [sic] who has all but lost it.
('54', 94, 1, 5, 217592) The friend is again wrong when he talks about meeting English sacrifice with Indian sacrifice.
('54', 94, 1, 6, 217687) I am reminded of a striking sentence of Dr. Chalmers: “Duty will be merit when debt becomes a donation.” I hold that it is the duty of England to return to India what she has taken away from her.
('54', 94, 1, 7, 217883) There is no sacrifice in the discharge of that obligation.
('54', 94, 1, 8, 217942) But so long as Englishmen believe that, whatever measure of freedom England grants means so much sacrifice on the part of England, so long will there be no meeting ground between the two countries, because England will not be able to come up to India’s credit balance against England.
('54', 94, 1, 9, 218227) I do not know whether I have made my meaning quite clear.
('54', 94, 1, 10, 218285) If I have not, you will please state difficulty and I shall endeavour to make it clear.

('54', 97, 0, 1, 221643) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 97, 1, 2, 221684) 55. SPEECH AT MONTESSORI TRAINING COLLEGE 1
('54', 97, 2, 3, 221728) LONDON, [October 28, 1931] 2
('54', 97, 3, 4, 221757) Madame, you have overwhelmed me with your words.
('54', 97, 3, 5, 221806) 3 It is perfectly true, I must admit it in all humility, that however indifferently it may be, I endeavour to represent love in every fibre of my being.
('54', 97, 3, 6, 221959) I am impatient to realize the presence of my Maker, Who to me embodies Truth, and in the early part of my career I discovered that if I was to realize Truth I must obey, even at the cost of my life, the law of love.
('54', 97, 3, 7, 222175) And having been blessed with children, I discovered that the law of Love could be best understood and learned through little children.
('54', 97, 3, 8, 222310) Were it not for us, their ignorant poor parents, our children would be perfectly innocent.
('54', 97, 3, 9, 222401) I believe implicitly that the child is not born mischievous in the bad sense of the term.
('54', 97, 3, 10, 222491) If parents would behave themselves whilst the child is growing, before it is born and after, it is a well known fact that the child would instinctively obey the law of Truth and the law of Love.
('54', 97, 3, 11, 222686) And when I understood this lesson in the early part of my life, I began a gradual but distinct change in life.
('54', 97, 3, 12, 222797) I do not propose to describe to you the several phases through which this stormy life of mine has passed, but I can only, in truth and in perfect humility, bear witness to the fact that to the extent that I have represented Love in my life, in thought, word and deed I have realized the “peace that passeth understanding”.
('54', 97, 3, 13, 223120) I have baffled many of my friends when they have noticed in me peace that they have envied, and they have asked me for the cause of that priceless possession.
('54', 97, 3, 14, 223279) I have not been able to explain the cause by saying that, if my friends found that peace in me, it was due to my attempt to obey this, the greatest law of our being.
('54', 97, 3, 15, 223445) It was in 1915 when I reached India, that I first became ac quainted with your activities.

('54', 98, 1, 13, 225957) We are conducting an experiment amongst the poorest of the children in India.
('54', 98, 1, 14, 226035) I do not know how far the experiment will go.
('54', 98, 1, 15, 226081) We have the problem of giving real vital eduction to these children of India’s hovels, and we have no material means.

('54', 99, 0, 1, 226643) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('54', 99, 1, 3, 226743) The greatest lessons in life if we would but stoop and humble ourselves, we would learn not from grown up learned men, but from the so called ignorant children.
('54', 99, 1, 4, 226904) Jesus never uttered a loftier or a grander truth than when he said that wisdom cometh out of the mouths of babes.
('54', 99, 1, 5, 227018) I believe it, I have noticed it in my own experience that, if we would approach babes in humility and in innocence, we would learn wisdom from them.

('54', 99, 1, 9, 227725) Therefore, I repeat that even as you, out of your love for children, are endeavouring to teach those children, through your numerous institutions, the best that can be brought out of them, even so I hope that it will be possible not only for the children of the wealthy and the well to do, but for the children of paupers to receive training of this nature.

('54', 100, 12, 19, 229591) By the nature of things it is impossible that we should all be of an equal stature, that we should all have the same colour of skin, the same degree of intelli gence; and consequently it is natural that some of us should be

('54', 101, 12, 24, 232928) A. My attitudes would be to convert the better off classes into trustees of what they already possessed.
('54', 101, 12, 25, 233033) That is to say, they would keep the money, but they would have to work for the benefit of the people who procured them their wealth.

('54', 102, 5, 23, 234517) For example, I shall ask the person who has a hundred rupees to keep fifty rupees and give the other fifty to the workers; but in the case of a person who has ten million rupees I shall ask him to retain, say, one per cent.

('54', 104, 1, 4, 238565) It would not have been consistent with the dignity of the Congress to demand the inclusion of anybody in a Conference in the making of which it had power.

('54', 104, 2, 6, 238924) Q.What do you mean by ‘machine’?
('54', 104, 2, 7, 238957) Is not the charkha a machine?
('54', 104, 2, 8, 238987) Is it that exploitation is not inherent in certain kinds of machines?

('54', 104, 3, 10, 239156) A. The charkha and similar instruments are clearly machines, and from this you can gather my definition of machines.
('54', 104, 3, 11, 239273) I am willing to admit that it is largely the abuse of the machine system which is responsible for the exploitation of the working class in the world.
('54', 104, 4, 12, 239423) Q.You speak of stopping the exploitation of the masses which implies the

('54', 104, 8, 18, 239838) I am convinced that the co ordination of capital and labour is perfectly possible.

('54', 105, 1, 2, 240841) Q. In a federal India, with the Princes as autonomous rulers, if the subjects demanded the same elementary political rights as the people of British India and had recourse to civil disobedience, with a popular uprising to enforce their demands, would the federal froces be called to help the Princes in suppressing the uprising?
('54', 105, 1, 3, 241170) And what would your attitude be in that case?
('54', 105, 2, 4, 241216) A. If I had the power I should never use it, or allow it to be used, for suppressing civil disobedience, no matter how or where it arose, for I hold civil disobedience to be a permanent law of our being entirely replacing violence, which is the law of the beast.
('54', 105, 3, 5, 241479) Q. Is it true that you withdrew your support from those popular movements which arose in the native, states, movements with the object of demanding from the Princes the same which you demand from the British in British India?
('54', 105, 4, 6, 241705) Gandhi looked at us in surprise and gave the lie to this report.
('54', 105, 5, 7, 241770) We asked him what, in his opinion, was the difference between “independence” and “equality of collaboration in Empire matters”.
('54', 105, 6, 8, 241898) A. There is, and there is not, a difference between the two.
('54', 105, 6, 9, 241959) That is to say, two independent states in an Empire can perfectly well be partners, collaborating in an imperial association.
('54', 105, 6, 10, 242085) But obviously India is not in such a situation.
('54', 105, 6, 11, 242133) Consequently, an association of India with Britain in the same Empire is a state, or rather a condition, which cannot be likened to independence, for a comparison can only take place between two things of the same kind.
('54', 105, 6, 12, 242353) In this case the things are not of the same kind Hence, if there is to be an association, on an equal footing, between Britain and India, the Empire must cease to exist.
('54', 105, 7, 13, 242523) At this, we retorted that the Lahore Congress made no mention of an association of equality within the limits of the Empire.
('54', 105, 8, 14, 242648) Gandhi replied that it was no use mentioning this in the Congress, but the question had been touched upon in the speeches.
('54', 105, 9, 15, 242771) Q.Does this equality of association envisage the withdrawal of the Viceroy?
('54', 105, 10, 16, 242847) A. The idea of “empire” must disappear entirely.
('54', 105, 10, 17, 242896) But it is impossible for me to say definitely whether the idea of royalty must also be absolished.
('54', 105, 10, 18, 242995) I am quite unable to say at present that the king of Great Britain will cease to be the king of India.
('54', 105, 11, 19, 243098) Q.Are you taking account of the fact that, since the time of the Lahore Congress, when the declaration of Independence displaced the compromise resolution adopted at Calcutta, the youth of India has believed that it was fighting for an independence India, in which there would no longer be a king?
('54', 105, 11, 20, 243396) Is it not bad politics to tell the youth of India now that royalty will remain?
('54', 106, 0, 1, 243476) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 107
('54', 106, 1, 2, 243522) Gandhi, quite unruffled, replied that there was no question of bad faith.
('54', 106, 1, 3, 243596) If the question had been put to him at Karachi, he would have given the same reply.
('54', 106, 2, 4, 243680) Q.Well, then, what difference is there between you and Malaviya,who was in the opposition at the Lahore Congress?
('54', 106, 3, 5, 243794) A. The difference is this, that Malaviya, still wished to give the Empire a chance, whereas I did not.
('54', 106, 4, 6, 243897) Q.Do you regard King George and his predecessors as usurpers in India?
('54', 106, 5, 7, 243968) A. I own that Great Britain and King George are usurpers of India.
('54', 106, 6, 8, 244035) We then asked him whether he thought it possible that a country which fought against exploitation could remain part of an Empire based on the exploitation of weaker races.
('54', 106, 7, 9, 244207) A. It is impossible, I would lend my heartiest support to the abolition of the British system of Government, as well as to the abolition of the capatalist system, but not to the abolition of capital and capitalists.
('54', 106, 7, 10, 244423) If the British Empire does not stop exploiting the weaker races, we shall refuse to collaborate with it.
('54', 106, 7, 11, 244528) Imperialist exploitation must disappear; collaboration will have to be free, and India at liberty, if she pleases, to sever the association.
('54', 106, 8, 12, 244669) Q.What were the reasons which led you to conclude a truce wih Lord Irwin?
('54', 106, 8, 13, 244743) Was it because, as we have been told, the Congress movement was only fighting on one wing, and if a truce were not arranged, it would be in grave danger of being strangled?
('54', 106, 8, 14, 244916) And does that mean that you and the Congress were afraid that you would be crushed by the violence of the British Government?
('54', 106, 8, 15, 245042) Would it not have been preferable, for the principle of “non violence”, that those of you who believe in the principle, should continue the fight and refuse to surrender to the violence of the British Government?
('54', 106, 8, 16, 245255) Even if the movement thereby suffered a set back, the reverse itself would have been its victory.
('54', 106, 8, 17, 245353) A. The suggestion of the impending collapse of our movement is entirely false.
('54', 106, 8, 18, 245432) The movement was showing no signs of slackening.

('54', 107, 4, 6, 246583) LONDON, October 30, 1931 I am grieved to hear of the attacks made on the lives of Mr. Villiers 1 and Mr. Durno 2 .
('54', 107, 4, 7, 246698) Ours is a difficult task and is rendered still more difficult by these senseless attacks.
('54', 107, 4, 8, 246788) I am convinced that these attacks do no good, but do create harm by increasing the vindictive spirit on both sides.

('54', 107, 4, 10, 247128) My point, however, is that you must preserve the spirit of non violence in spite of the greatest provocation.

('54', 121, 3, 4, 276752) The partnership has to be on equal terms.
('54', 121, 3, 5, 276794) It should not be ‘subjection’ in glorified language.
('54', 121, 3, 6, 276847) That means that the present relationship must be completely transformed though the connection may be retained, and that connection should be wholly and solely for the benefit of mankind.
('54', 121, 3, 7, 277034) India by herself has no capacity to exploit the nations of the earth, but with Great Britain’s assistance she can do it.
('54', 121, 3, 8, 277155) Now the partnership must mean that exploitation shall cease, and, if Great Britain should not desist from it, India should sever the connection.
('54', 121, 3, 9, 277300) All that is wanted is a fundamental change in the British policy of eploitation.
('54', 121, 3, 10, 277381) Britain cannot thereafter boast that she has a strong navy guarding the maritime highways and all her overseas commerce.
('54', 121, 3, 11, 277502) What about the South African possession?
('54', 121, 3, 12, 277543) I would not insist on a transformation of Britain’s relations with them, as a condition precedent to our partnership.
('54', 121, 3, 13, 277661) But I should certainly strive to work for the deliverance of those South African races which, I can say from experience, are ground down under exploitation.
('54', 121, 3, 14, 277818) Our deliverance must mean their deliverance.
('54', 121, 3, 15, 277863) But, if that cannot come about, I should have no interest in a partnership with Britain, even if it were of benefit to India.
('54', 121, 3, 16, 277989) Speaking for myself, I would say that a partnership, giving the promise of a world set free from exploitation, would be a proud privilege for my nation and I would maintain it for ever.
('54', 121, 3, 17, 278175) But India cannot reconcile herself in any shape or form to any policy of exploitation and, speaking for myself, I may say that, if ever the Congress should adopt an imperial policy, I should sever my connection with the Congress.
('54', 121, 3, 18, 278405) But would not the Congress be satisfied with a status equal to South Africa or Canada, for the time being at any rate?

('54', 131, 9, 14, 299978) DEAR PRIME MINISTER, It is with deep concern that we hear rumours to the effect that provincial autonomy will be introduced as a firt step in the political reconstruction of India, leaving federation and responsibility at the Centre to follow later.

('54', 131, 9, 16, 300340) The rumours, however, ar so strong and persistent that we must ask for leave to place our views before you beyond a possibility of doubt.
('54', 131, 9, 17, 300478) The needs of the present situation can be met only by a com plete and comprehensive scheme, of which responsibility at the federal Centre must be as integral a part as autonomy of the federating units.
('54', 131, 9, 18, 300680) To divide the scheme into parts and bring into immediate operation one of the parts and postpone the other is to arouse fears of uncertainty and suspicions of the intentions of the Government.

('54', 132, 4, 6, 301746) 75. INTERVIEW WITH GEORGE BERNARD SHAW 1
('54', 132, 5, 7, 301787) LONDON, [November 6, 1931] 2
('54', 132, 6, 8, 301816) Mr. Bernard Shaw had long been wanting to see Gandhiji, and it was not without considerable hesitation that he came.
('54', 132, 6, 9, 301933) He sat with Gandhiji for close on an hour, interrogating him on a bewildering variety of topics—ethno graphical, religious, social, political, economic,—and his talk was illumined by his sparkling wit and sardonic humour.
('54', 132, 6, 10, 302155) “I knew something about you and felt something in you of a kindred spirit.
('54', 132, 6, 11, 302230) We belong to a very small community on earth”.
('54', 132, 6, 12, 302277) said he.
('54', 132, 6, 13, 302286) Whilst his other questions were of universal importance, he could not help asking a question about the R.T.C. “Does not the Round Table Conference try your patience?” he asked, and Gandhiji had to confess with sorrow: It requires more than the patience of a Job.
('54', 132, 6, 14, 302549) The whole thing is a huge camouflage and the harangues that we are treated to are meant only to mark time.
('54', 132, 6, 15, 302656) Why not, I ask them, make a clean breast and announce your policy and let us make our choice?
('54', 132, 6, 16, 302750) But it does not seem to be in the English political nature to do so.
('54', 132, 6, 17, 302819) It must go by round about and tortuous ways!

('54', 133, 1, 2, 303070) 76. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
('54', 133, 2, 3, 303095) LONDON, November 6, 1931
('54', 133, 3, 4, 303120) Q.Why refuse special representation to the Depressed Classes if you are agreeable to surrender to the Muslims and Sikhs?
('54', 133, 3, 5, 303241) A. I would gladly resist Muslims and Sikhs also, but special representation for Muslims has been my [stand] since 1916. As a practical man, I realize it is impracticable to escape the legacy of the Lucknow Pact 1, but, as a sincere well wisher of the Depressed Classes as well of the Nation, I should be failing in my duty if I agreed to special representation to smaller minorities.
('54', 133, 3, 6, 303625) My offer to Muslims and Sikhs stands, but I certainly expect Muslims and Sikhs to agree to state that they are unable to escape seeking special protection, but that they feel any extension of special protection is undersirable.
('54', 133, 3, 7, 303853) This is especially so since adult suffrage, for which I stand, ensures the fullest opportunity to all sections who serve the community to enter legislatures.
('54', 133, 4, 8, 304011) Q.Since the need for swaraj is imperative, why not surrender to the Depressed Classes also?
('54', 133, 4, 9, 304103) A. Because that is not swaraj.
('54', 133, 4, 10, 304134) I consider it fundamental.
('54', 133, 4, 11, 304161) I am devoted to untouchables, but do not agree to the vivisection of the community.
('54', 133, 4, 12, 304245) I am not afraid of the failure of the conference.
('54', 133, 4, 13, 304295) As I feel it will fail, let us return to the country and seek other ways for swaraj.
('54', 133, 4, 14, 304380) The Hindustan Times, 9 11 1931

('54', 134, 1, 2, 304989) 78. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR” [Before November 7, 1931]
('54', 134, 2, 3, 305043) Gandhiji emphatically denied the suggestion that his supporters have been
('54', 134, 3, 4, 305117) clamouring for his return to India because of imminent revolutionary trouble.
('54', 134, 4, 5, 305195) contrary he proposed to remain in England until his mission to the Conference was
('54', 134, 5, 6, 305277) concluded.
('54', 134, 5, 7, 305288) Even then a whirlwind tour to European capitals might delay his return.
('54', 134, 6, 8, 305360) He said.
('54', 134, 6, 9, 305369) Reports of trouble and unrest have been greatly exaggerated and the Congress attitude misrepresented.
('54', 134, 6, 10, 305471) I don’t fear at the moment any likelihood of a return before the work is finished, but if my presence is desired, I shall of course go back.

('54', 136, 1, 2, 307523) 83. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('54', 136, 2, 3, 307552) LONDON, November 9, 1931 In anticipation of the Congress Working Committee’s decision I have already cancelled my Continental engagements.
('54', 136, 2, 4, 307691) My eye has constantly been on the events in India, but I feel it will be wrong on my part to leave England while the Round Table Conference work keeps me here.
('54', 136, 2, 5, 307851) I expect that I will be able to decide the date of my departure during this week.
('54', 136, 2, 6, 307933) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 10 11 1931
('54', 136, 3, 7, 307966) 84. SPEECH AT FRIENDS’ HOUSE 2
('54', 136, 4, 8, 307997) LONDON, November 9, 1931 You have asked me whether, though there was a voice cry ing in India for freedom, there were enough people ready to shoulder the responsibility of the country.
('54', 136, 4, 9, 308182) To me the question is quite reasonable.
('54', 136, 4, 10, 308222) I shall endeavour, as brielfy as I can, to answer this important question.
('54', 136, 4, 11, 308297) Let me tell you that the real point at issue is the Congress demand on the one hand and, if I can so put it, reluctance on the part of responsible men to respond to that demand on the other.
('54', 136, 4, 12, 308488) The Congress wants independence which in other words means it wants control over Defence, External Relations and Finance, i.e., partnership at will terminable by either party.
('54', 136, 4, 13, 308664) That is the substance of the Congress demand, because the Congress honestly believes that the country has got capable hands to take over charge from the foreign Government.
('54', 136, 4, 14, 308837) But on the part of responsible men I have been seeing nothing during my wanderings and talks.
('54', 136, 4, 15, 308931) On the other hand, I find they are raising considerable difficulties in conceding what is the legitimate claim of the Congress.
('54', 136, 4, 16, 309059) I shall tell you without any modesty that the Congress seeks and claims to represent the whole mass of India.
('54', 136, 5, 17, 309169) 1 It being his Silence Day, Gandhiji made the statement in writing at 11 a.m.
('54', 136, 5, 18, 309247) on his return from his visit to Oxford.
('54', 136, 5, 19, 309287) 2 The meeting, held in the evening, was organized by the Fellowship of Reconciliation.
('54', 136, 5, 20, 309374) The hall was filled to capacity and a large crowd had to go back disappointed.
('54', 137, 0, 1, 309453) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 137, 1, 2, 309495) claim cannot be disputed.
('54', 137, 1, 3, 309521) You know India is in villages and not in cities like Bombay, Calcutta or Madras.
('54', 137, 1, 4, 309602) The Congress claims to represent also even the Princes in spite of themselves.
('54', 137, 1, 5, 309681) Of course, it does not want to usurp their rights, but does justice to them also so long as their claims do not become inconsistent with those of the teeming millions.
('54', 137, 1, 6, 309849) At the same time, the Congress offers the least resistance to them because it engages itself in putting forth the claims on behalf of the masses.
('54', 137, 1, 7, 309995) As you are devoted to seeking avenues for peace, you should have no difficulty in recognizing the claim of the Congress.
('54', 137, 1, 8, 310116) The history of the past fifteen months before the Delhi Pact tells you that these masses were at war with Government, but it was a peaceful war for the simple reason that the masses had taken the pledge to win freedom without shedding a drop of blood.
('54', 137, 1, 9, 310368) In this struggle, thousands upon thousands of women and children received lathi blows.
('54', 137, 1, 10, 310455) Tens of thousands were sent to jail.
('54', 137, 1, 11, 310492) Women of India rose as if by magic.
('54', 137, 1, 12, 310528) There was a phenomenal awakening on their part.
('54', 137, 1, 13, 310576) Thousands of villages responded to the Congress message.
('54', 137, 1, 14, 310633) I myself do not know why and how I was not prepared for such a splendid response to me.
('54', 137, 1, 15, 310721) There must have been the hand of God behind.
('54', 137, 1, 16, 310766) These villages and villagers were all unarmed, because remember, there is compulsory disarmament in my country.
('54', 137, 1, 17, 310878) But those who wielded lathis and used bayonets did not realize that these women and villagers had with them an instrument which was not perishable and which was far more effective.
('54', 137, 1, 18, 311059) That instrument was in the form of love, non violence and truth against heir force of arms and other brutal methods.
('54', 137, 1, 19, 311176) Though the work ‘independence’ has a specific meaning in the English disctionary, to these masses it has also a larger and deeper meaning.
('54', 137, 1, 20, 311315) They do not understand what ‘Parliament’, ‘Responsible Government’, or ‘Councils’ mean, but the word ‘swaraj’ gives them the meaning in the twinkling of an eye.
('54', 137, 1, 21, 311476) Today they are paying the land revenue but they do not know why and how much is spent for the country’s purposes.
('54', 137, 1, 22, 311590) They do not even know that 55 crores are spent over the military.
('54', 137, 1, 23, 311656) At the same time, remember they have no fear from the frontiers, or the Afghans or any other place.
('54', 137, 1, 24, 311756) As a matter of fact, the invasions never bother Indian villagers because invasions in India did not begin with the East India Company.
('54', 137, 1, 25, 311891) We had them even before that period.
('54', 137, 1, 26, 311928) These invaders did not go beyond the cities.
('54', 137, 1, 27, 311973) They did not go beyond Delhi and, as you know from the geography
('54', 138, 0, 1, 312038) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 139
('54', 138, 1, 2, 312084) of India.
('54', 138, 1, 3, 312094) a vast number of its people living in villages were unaffected by the invasions.
('54', 138, 1, 4, 312175) Moreover, internal quarrels do not affect by the villagers.
('54', 138, 1, 5, 312235) They therefore need no protection.
('54', 138, 1, 6, 312270) Today the vast masses are living in abject starvation.
('54', 138, 1, 7, 312325) They do not know what it is to have two meals a day.
('54', 138, 1, 8, 312378) They have no bread and butter for themselves, nor a drop of milk for their children.
('54', 138, 1, 9, 312463) We have added dignity to their life and they have gained confidence that they will be able to make both ends meet and keep the wolf away from their doors.
('54', 138, 2, 10, 312618) The Congress has purified politics.
('54', 138, 2, 11, 312654) It has almost spiritualized it, though personally I do not like that word.
('54', 138, 2, 12, 312729) We are out to win freedom with non violence and truth, by removel of untouchability, and by recognition of every villager as a human being.
('54', 138, 2, 13, 312869) Our non co operation fight signifies that no man can possibly tyrannize over another.
('54', 138, 2, 14, 312955) Our whole movement is based on morality.
('54', 138, 2, 15, 312996) We do not believe in the theory of the sweet will of our rulers.
('54', 138, 2, 16, 313061) You know what we do in India.
('54', 138, 2, 17, 313091) When authorities say do this, which we know is a wrong order, we say, thank you, we will not do it.
('54', 138, 2, 18, 313191) We say we won’t do anything which injures our self respect, hurts our human dignity, and in such a struggle even millionaires have discarded their wealth and have ultimately become trustees of their wealth for the betterment of Indian villagers.
('54', 138, 2, 19, 313437) If British Ministers do not recognize my claim and want to keep the yoke on our neck, we may once again go through the fiery ordeal because, perhaps, we still need to suffer.
('54', 138, 2, 20, 313612) Your Government has brought no benefit to my country.
('54', 138, 2, 21, 313666) It has only emasculated it.
('54', 138, 2, 22, 313694) It is a shame that we are made incapable of defending ourselves against foreign yoke, and even in our internal affairs.
('54', 138, 2, 23, 313814) That is terribly disgraceful, but what have we done?
('54', 138, 2, 24, 313867) We have today created selfless workers in every village.
('54', 138, 2, 25, 313924) They are our civil servants and they will do anything that he Congress asks them to do.
('54', 138, 2, 26, 314012) They are capable of governing the country.
('54', 138, 2, 27, 314055) They know, as I do know, that we have already burnt our boats and are marching with our backs to the wall, because we are working for freedom of the teeming villagers.
('54', 138, 2, 28, 314223) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 11 1931
('54', 138, 3, 29, 314256) 1 Gandhiji here was referring to the work done by the All India Spinners’ Association.

('54', 139, 4, 10, 314937) LONDON, November 10, 1931 The main obstacle to my mission is—myself.
('54', 139, 4, 11, 315006) So many people tell me that the Congress demand is pitched too high.
('54', 139, 4, 12, 315075) When I come to grips, they begin to listen to me.
('54', 139, 4, 13, 315125) Those respon sible are equally guilty inasmuch as they are in no mood to listen.

('54', 139, 4, 15, 315283) Some of the best Englishmen and Englishwomen feel that something has got to be done to define freedom.
('54', 139, 4, 16, 315386) 3 I have come here out of prison; with me there were thousands.
('54', 139, 4, 17, 315450) The avowed object of the Settlement with the Viceroy was that Congress should be represented at the Round Table Conference.
('54', 139, 4, 18, 315574) I and many Congressmen were trying to negotiate this.
('54', 139, 4, 19, 315628) Generally at a round table people sit who are elected; who have got there is their own right.
('54', 139, 4, 20, 315722) I do not sit in my own right, I am there on sufferance: our of nominated members you do not expect brilliant results.
('54', 139, 4, 21, 315840) I have never known a conference with nominated members which has decided on principles.
('54', 139, 4, 22, 315928) We have set out to give our own blood.
('54', 139, 4, 23, 315967) But the attitude here [is]: ‘Look at these ungrateful fellows, they do not see the blessings of British rule.’ It is not only the official mind, but those capable of

('54', 141, 1, 3, 319187) Now British people make up the Government.
('54', 141, 2, 4, 319230) GANDHIJI : Man is superior to his method.
('54', 141, 2, 5, 319272) A man's method may be vile, and yet you may not aptly apply the adjective to the man himself.
('54', 141, 2, 6, 319366) .2 British system is Satanic.
('54', 141, 2, 7, 319396) But, in spite of British system being Satanic, I love the British like my brothers.
('54', 141, 2, 8, 319480) I have a boy who has rebelled against me.

('54', 141, 2, 10, 319578) I detest his methods and ways.
('54', 141, 2, 11, 319609) I have learnt from domestic law that, if I have humanity in me, I should love the Britisher whom God has made.
('54', 141, 2, 12, 319720) And yet I detest his method and am doing my best to destroy his method.
('54', 141, 2, 13, 319792) .3 In the war of non violence we walk in the fear of God, give no secret information, brook no treacherousness.

('54', 141, 4, 16, 319975) 87. LETTER TO JOHN HAYNES HOLMES 88 KNIGHTSBRIDGE,
('54', 141, 5, 17, 320026) LONDON, W., November 11, 1931
('54', 141, 6, 18, 320056) DEAR FRIEND, You have been most diligent in writing to me and to Mahadev and encouraging others to write to me about the much talked of visit of mine to America.
('54', 141, 6, 19, 320218) I do not know, however, wehther it was at all necessary for you to take all this trouble either for yourself or others.
('54', 141, 6, 20, 320338) I never entertained the slightest doubt about the wisdom of your judgment, and I have been absolutely clear in my state ments to every Pressman that I would not go to America until you had decided to bring me out there.
('54', 141, 6, 21, 320558) Having made up my mind to trust your judgment, was I not right in telling all and sundry that you were the keeper of my conscience in this matter ?
('54', 141, 6, 22, 320706) Of course, it has thrown a little more responsibility upon you, but your shoulders are broad enough to bear it and I am saved a lot of worry in arguing with importunate friends and reporters.
('54', 141, 6, 23, 320898) I met Mr. Bomanji fairly often during the few days that he was here.
('54', 141, 6, 24, 320967) He is now on his way to India.
('54', 141, 7, 25, 320998) Yours sincerely,
('54', 141, 8, 26, 321015) THE REVEREND JOHN HAYNES HOLMES, D.D.

('54', 143, 5, 7, 322913) 90. LETTER TO F. B. FISHER 88 KNIGHTSBRIDGE,
('54', 143, 6, 8, 322958) LONDON, W., November 11, 1931
('54', 143, 7, 9, 322988) DEAR FRIEND, I have been receiving your very warm letters.
('54', 143, 7, 10, 323047) I have time just to say this.
('54', 143, 7, 11, 323077) With reference to the American visit, my own instinct was that the time had not arrived to visit America.
('54', 143, 7, 12, 323183) That instinct still abides.
('54', 143, 7, 13, 323211) I had made up my mind when the visit was first talked about that I would do as Dr. Haynes 1 advised me.
('54', 143, 7, 14, 323315) This was about 3 years ago or more when the visit was first talked about.

('54', 144, 5, 10, 325121) 91. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('54', 144, 6, 11, 325148) LONDON, November 11, 1931 I do not think the Conference must fail.
('54', 144, 6, 12, 325215) If that were my conviction I should not stay here at all.
('54', 144, 6, 13, 325273) What I believe is that, unless something startling happens and unless all that is good in English life conspires together to bring about a satisfactory result, the Conference is likely to fail.
('54', 144, 7, 14, 325467) Q. If the Conferece were to fail, to whom would you apportion the blame ?
('54', 144, 8, 15, 325541) A. I should distribute the blame evenly between the Government and he whole of the Conference delegates.
('54', 144, 8, 16, 325646) I am not prepared to blame one party along, but I am convinced that, if the National Government really wills it, the Conference need not fail at all.
('54', 144, 9, 17, 325796) Q. How long do you think it will take you to be satisfied that such a will is manifest in the National Government?
('54', 144, 9, 18, 325911) A. I shall know in a week.
('54', 144, 9, 19, 325938) I shall continue to hope until I have positive evidence that nothing is to be gained from my further stay in England.
('54', 144, 9, 20, 326056) I am not going to think of civil disobedience as long as there is the slightest vestige of hope, and I can give my absolute assurance to all concerned that there will be no civil disobedience in connection with the Conference as long as there is a possibility of carrying on negotiations such as I am engaged in at the present moment.
('54', 144, 9, 21, 326391) I have come here with a fixed determination of making every effort humanly possible to achieve an honourable settlement— honourable both to Great Britain and to India.

('54', 147, 3, 14, 331823) The manipulation of the Exchange had been started before the time of Lord Curzon and through this policy 85 per cent of the population of India had suffered badly.
('54', 147, 3, 15, 331987) The fixing of the rupee to the pound at a fixed price of one shilling and six pence has meant that the Indian agriculturists have to sell at prices that will not even cover the cost of production.
('54', 147, 3, 16, 332184) Even the advisers of the India Office in this country have admitted that, if the rupee was set free, the agriculturists would profit.
('54', 147, 3, 17, 332318) The price of imports would certainly rise, but the mass of the Indian people is so little dependent upon imports that it would not be affected.
('54', 147, 3, 18, 332462) The difficulty is that the majority of Britishers have no knowledge of Indian conditions, and they draw the wrong comparisons.

('54', 148, 1, 2, 332804) The rupee has been sustained to make a greater scope for exports from this country to India.
('54', 148, 1, 3, 332897) Each time that the rupee has been fixed it has been against the advice of Indian experts.
('54', 148, 1, 4, 332987) The Government is the party that has benefited.
('54', 148, 1, 5, 333035) By fixing the rupee to the pound it has saved itself from insolvency.

('54', 148, 1, 7, 333285) India is an exporting country, and in nine out of every ten years her exports have exceeded her imports, but the balance of gain has been used either for Civil Service pensions or as capital for what I consider wild cat schemes such as Sukkur Barrage, etc.
('54', 148, 2, 8, 333542) Mahatma Gandhi then referred to the scanty Press space that has been given to the Government's acknowledgment of hopeless miscalculations over this scheme.
('54', 148, 2, 9, 333698) From a small corner in the Press he had seen that the actual cost of the irrigation scheme was twice of that estimated.
('54', 148, 2, 10, 333818) Mahatma Gandhi stated that he had no confidence in these large schemes which the Government put forward as they would not benefit the small agriculturists, but merely serve to strengthen and extend the capitalist system.
('54', 148, 3, 11, 334039) Mahatma Gandhi then reasserted the Congress demand or complete control of finance and fiscal policy.
('54', 148, 3, 12, 334140) He said, India must not be wrapped in cotton wool.
('54', 148, 3, 13, 334191) She must be given the chance even of making atrocious blunders.

('54', 148, 3, 15, 334456) He found himself baffled by the wall of ignorance around him in this country.

('54', 148, 3, 17, 334843) We shall treasure the knowledge of your frien dship, and be heartened by you as Emily Hobhouse heartened those who suffered in South Africa during the Boer War.

('54', 149, 2, 6, 335917) Mr. Horrabin then asked Mahatma Gandhi what particular sources of information would be available to the League in its work of spreading true information about India, and Mahatma Gandhi said that the resources of the Congress would always be at the disposal of the Leauge.

('54', 149, 2, 13, 336882) The policy of the Congress is to admit errors immediately and to expose every exaggeration of which its members have been guilty.
('54', 149, 3, 14, 337012) Miss Ellen Wilkinson asked Mahatma Gandhi if he thought it advisable to start a campaign about the political prisoners in India.
('54', 149, 3, 15, 337141) Mahatma Gandhi in reply pointed out that, before such a campaign could be successfully begun, detailed information was necessary, as each case stood on its own merits.
('54', 149, 3, 16, 337309) Just at present the attention of the authorities could not be sufficiently engaged, but later on, if the Conference broke down then would be the time to start such a campaign.
('54', 149, 3, 17, 337485) The Congress offices will always be ready to send all the information that is needed, and you must remember that it is an obstinate Government that you have to deal with.
('54', 149, 4, 18, 337656) Asked what he considered were the chief agencies responsible for the non success of the Conference, Mahatma Gandhi replied that he believed the fault to lie equally with the Indians for failing to reach a settlement over the communal question, and with the British Government for the wrong lead that it had given in the early stages of the Conference.
('54', 149, 4, 19, 338008) By making the communal question the central issue in the whole scheme, the Government had laid the
('54', 150, 0, 1, 338107) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 151
('54', 150, 1, 2, 338153) way open for Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims to pull their own ways.
('54', 150, 1, 3, 338216) In reality, the communal question was only one of many issues, and the Conference was not necessarily the instrument to bring about a communal settlement.
('54', 150, 1, 4, 338371) When the Government called together the Conference, it knew that the communal leaders had not come to an agreement and by bringing the communal question to the fore immediately the Government prepared the way for disunion, and for perpetuating that disunion.
('54', 150, 1, 5, 338630) Also one must remember that the Conference is a packed Conference of non responsible members.
('54', 150, 1, 6, 338724) What the British Government did not realize was that the Congress is the nation as far as swaraj is concerned.

('54', 150, 1, 9, 339084) As for myself, although I may not represent Sir Mahomed Shafi, I do claim to represent the Mussalmans; though I do not represent Dr. Ambedkar, I do represent the Depressed Classes; though not Dr. Dutta, but the Christians.
('54', 150, 1, 10, 339307) These people do not want separate representation.
('54', 150, 1, 11, 339357) I claim that 330 millions of the Indian people are represented by the Congress.
('54', 150, 1, 12, 339437) The interests of all classes must be subservient to the interests of the masses.
('54', 150, 1, 13, 339518) It is this representative character of the Congress that is not recognized by the Government and herein lies the chief blame.
('54', 150, 2, 14, 339644) When asked whether he did not think it was essential, should the Conference break down, that he should explain his position either at a public meeting or at least to a group people in this country, Mahatma Gandhi said that he was very anxious to have an opportunity for putting forward his reasons for action as he did, that he very much wished to speak to a group, but that his original promise not to hinder the Government would prevent his making any public declaration.
('54', 150, 3, 15, 340118) In discussing the question of the multiplicity of organizations in this country working for India, Mahatma Gandhi urged that every effort should be made at amalgamation of these organizations.
('54', 150, 3, 16, 340311) All energies must be concentrated, he added, into work or thorugh one channel, and that, in the main, the burden should fall upon English people who could act with Indian advice.
('54', 150, 3, 17, 340490) His advice to the Commonwealth of India League was to widen their organization as much as possible and to invite co operation from all possible quarters.

('54', 151, 7, 9, 340921) Q. I want to know, Mr. Gandhi, whether you are going to sign the request to the Prime Minister to arbitrate in the dispute between the Hindus and Muslims, which seems now almost certain to bring about the failure of the Round Table Conference.
('54', 151, 8, 10, 341165) A. I am afraid I cannot do so.
('54', 151, 8, 11, 341196) I should have no objection to Mr. MacDonald personally as arbitrator.
('54', 151, 8, 12, 341266) Do not mistake me there.
('54', 151, 8, 13, 341291) But to ask him, as Prime Minister, to arbitrate would be to petition the British Government to do so and that would be to put myself in a false position in respect of the Congress mandate.
('54', 151, 8, 14, 341480) The Government, on its side, would at once conceive itself to be in a position to bargain on matters in which, in my view, no bargain is possible—I have in mind, for example, the Army and Finance.
('54', 151, 9, 15, 341677) Mr. Gandhi went on to say that his refusal to sign the request did not mean that Mr. MacDonald need be prevented from arbitrating.
('54', 151, 9, 16, 341808) He continued: I myself would agree to any solution of the minorities problem accpeted by the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs.
('54', 151, 9, 17, 341936) But, for me, the minorities problem does not travel beyond the three communities, and if arbitration were contemplated with regard to the representation on the legislatures of the other minorities, I could not tolerate it.
('54', 151, 9, 18, 342159) In my view that would be the negation of responsible government.
('54', 151, 10, 19, 342224) I asked Mr. Gandhi whether, in view of the general feeling that the Conference was certian now to end in calamitous failure, he himself preserved any hope.
('54', 151, 11, 20, 342380) He answered that he was not yet altogether hopeless, although at the moment he saw little on the horizon to justify it.
('54', 151, 11, 21, 342500) He added:

('54', 152, 5, 18, 344744) Under my proposal the same statute will provide for provincial autonomy and complete responsibility at the Centre and will create the machinery for bringing into existence the Federal and Central structure.

('54', 154, 1, 2, 347446) arrive at an agreement.

('54', 154, 1, 4, 347713) I am quite certain that you did not convence this Round Table Conference and bring us all six thousand miles away from our homes and occupations to settle the communal question, but you convened us, you made deliberate declarations that we were invited to come here, to share the process of Constitution building, and that, before we went away from your hospitable shores, we should have the certain conviction that we had built up an honourable and a respectable framework for the freedom of India, and that it awaited only the imprimatur of the approval of the House of Commons and the House of Lords.
('54', 154, 1, 5, 348317) Now, at the present moment, we are face to face with a wholly different situation, namely, that, because there is no communal settlement agreed to by us, there is to be no building of the Constitution, and that, as a last resort and as the last touch, you will announce the policy of His Majesty's Government in connection with the Constitution and all the matters that may arise from it.
('54', 154, 1, 6, 348706) I cannot help feeling that it would be a sorry ending to a Conference which was brought into being with so much trumpeting and with so much hope excited in the minds and in the breasts of many people.
('54', 154, 1, 7, 348907) Coming to this document, I accept the thanks that have been given to me by Sir Hubert Carr.

('54', 154, 1, 9, 349406) I will not deprive Sir Hubert Carr and his associates of the feeling of satisfaction that evidently actuates them, but, in my opinion, what they have done is to sit by the carcass, and they have performed the laudable feat of dissecting that carcass.

('54', 155, 1, 2, 349962) world, that this scheme is not one designed to achieve responsible government, but is undoubtedly a scheme designed to share power with the bureaucracy.
('54', 155, 1, 3, 350115) If that is the intention—and it is the intention running through the whole of that document—I wish them well, and the Congress is entirely out of it.

('54', 159, 3, 9, 360334) 99. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('54', 159, 4, 10, 360361) LONDON, November 14, 1931
('54', 159, 5, 11, 360387) Q. What is your attitude towards the Prime Minister's request that all parties
('54', 159, 6, 12, 360466) should agree to his arbitration ?
('54', 159, 7, 13, 360500) A. I am unable to agree that a signed request should be made to the Premier to arbitrate, but I must explain that I am not opposed either to Mr. MacDonald personally or to the principle of arbitration.
('54', 159, 7, 14, 360702) On the contrary, I have always pleaded for parties agreeing to arbitration, but I must refuse to be a party to requesting the Premier to arbitrate because the Premier makes the suggestion not in his private capacity as Mr. MacDonald, but as the Premier where he is placed by the Cabinet.
('54', 159, 7, 15, 360990) He, therefore, speaks on behalf of the Government and I cannot be a party to the Government deciding this issue.
('54', 159, 7, 16, 361103) It is because I have a high sense of honour that I refuse to seek the obligation of the Government hand.
('54', 159, 7, 17, 361208) I cannot compromise as regards the Congress political demands.
('54', 159, 7, 18, 361271) I can accept only such adjustments as are manifestly in the interest of India.
('54', 159, 7, 19, 361350) Therefore, I will accept no obligation.
('54', 159, 8, 20, 361390) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “London Letter”.

('54', 160, 1, 2, 361530) Q. Does this mean that there can be no response to the Premier's request?
('54', 160, 2, 3, 361604) A. No, there can be.
('54', 160, 2, 4, 361625) In fact, friends are considering addressing a joint letter to the Premier leaving me out.
('54', 160, 2, 5, 361715) In fact, my consent to the Premier arbitrating is totally unnecessary since I represent the Congress and not any community.
('54', 160, 2, 6, 361839) Also because, in terms of the Congress solution, I am bound to accept any settlement acceptable to Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims.
('54', 160, 2, 7, 361965) Therefore, if Premier MacDonald arbitrates and Sikhs, Hindus and Muslims accept it, I am bound to accept the same.

('54', 160, 4, 16, 362907) I am prepared to provide through convention or co option, but would not agree to separate electorates or special reservation.

('54', 160, 10, 23, 363436) A. Certainly.
('54', 160, 10, 24, 363450) I am sure to reach an agreement in India, though I have no concrete plans just now.
('54', 160, 11, 25, 363534) Q. Whose scheme is this to introduce provincial autonomy into the provincial legislatures electing Constituent Assembly?
('54', 160, 12, 26, 363655) A. It is correct to say that the scheme was discussed in
('54', 161, 0, 1, 363712) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 161, 1, 2, 363754) A. It is correct to say that the scheme was discussed in Government circles with me and also other delegates.
('54', 161, 1, 3, 363864) I am unable to say whether it is Government 's scheme, but it is not proposed by any delegate.
('54', 161, 2, 4, 363959) Q. Is it true that you are agreeable to the scheme with slight modifications?

('54', 161, 3, 6, 364125) The only difference between others and myself is, they refused to discuss this scheme, while I dared to discuss the scheme.
('54', 161, 4, 7, 364249) Q. What are the conditions attached to your scheme?
('54', 161, 5, 8, 364301) A. Firstly, the statute which embodies provincial autonomy must also embody responsibility at the Centre.
('54', 161, 5, 9, 364407) Secondly, it must also fix a time limit within which the Federal Constitution with responsibility at the Centre will come into operation.
('54', 161, 5, 10, 364545) I suggested six months.
('54', 161, 5, 11, 364569) Thirdly, the provinces must enjoy practically sovereign rights.
('54', 161, 6, 12, 364633) Q. What is then left for the Constituent Assembly to decide?
('54', 161, 7, 13, 364694) A. It can be reserved for the Constituent Assembly to discuss whether it is through single or bicameral legislature and what the strength of the Federal Legislature should be.
('54', 161, 7, 14, 364870) But I have left no doubt in anybody's mind that the decision must be reached here and now as regards responsibility at the Centre, especially, the control of Finance, Army and Foreign Affairs.
('54', 161, 8, 15, 365063) Q. Have you given up all hopes of reaching a settlement?
('54', 161, 9, 16, 365120) A. No, I am sparing no endeavour to explore all avenues for a settlement.
('54', 161, 9, 17, 365194) I would not be surprised if a settlement were reached even at twelfth hour.
('54', 161, 10, 18, 365270) Mahatma Gandhi was asked if the Conference failed to reach a settlement, what effects would it have on India.
('54', 161, 11, 19, 365380) Mahatmaji answered if the Congress failed to reach a settlement here and now, it must inevitably result in the revival immediately of civil disobedience with all its consequences, because the failure of the Conference means that Indian reformers who are wedded to responsibility at the Centre must not hope to expect the Government to meet them for an indefinite time.
('54', 161, 11, 20, 365749) The civil disobedience is bound to start immediately once it is clear that the Conference has failed.

('54', 162, 3, 4, 366023) DEAR PRIME MINISTER,
('54', 162, 4, 5, 366044) I know that letters signed by delegates are being sent to you inviting you to settle the Hindu Muslim Sikh question.

('54', 162, 5, 8, 366412) I should have no hesitation in putting my signature to a letter appointing you sole arbitrator in your individual capacity to settle the communal question, so far as the Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs are concerned, but you will appreciate my hesitation in consenting to your appointment as arbitrator in your capacity as Prime Minister, for the simple reason that if I did so, I should feel embarrassed in presenting the Congress claim on the constitutional issue.
('54', 162, 5, 9, 366873) But my reluctance does not mean that the Congress will in any way resist your award; in fact Congress cannot do so, for it is bound by a resolution to approve of any solution that is acceptable to the three parties concerned, and if those claiming to represent the three communities refer the matter for your decison, the Congress cannot object to your award.

('54', 162, 6, 11, 367290) You know the position taken up on behalf of the Congress.
('54', 162, 6, 12, 367348) As I reiterated at the last meeting of the Minorities Committee, in my opinion they should be satisfied with complete protection of their civic and reli gious rights and of all their legitimate interests.
('54', 162, 6, 13, 367553) There are many extra legal ways that can be suggested for ensuring the election of deser ving candidates from all the other minorities through the ordinary electorate, and I feel that that is the only proper and legitimate course.
('54', 163, 0, 1, 367784) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 163, 1, 2, 367826) In any case, the Congress will never be reconciled to any further extension of the principle of separate electorate or special statutory reservation.

('54', 164, 2, 5, 369410) 103. EXTRACT FROM PROCEEDINGS OF THE FEDERAL STRUCTURE COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('54', 164, 3, 6, 369485) LONDON, November 17, 1931
('54', 164, 4, 7, 369511) MR. GANDHI: Lord Chancellor and fellow Delegates, I know that a tremendous responsibility rests upon my shoulders in having to give the Congress view on this most important question.
('54', 164, 4, 8, 369694) I have been sent here with the deliberate intention of exloring every possible avenue to achieve an honourable settlement, whether by open discussion at this table or by private conferences with Ministers and public men who influene public opinion here, and with all those who are interested in questions vitally affecting India.
('54', 164, 4, 9, 370024) Therefore, I am under obli gation not to leave a single stone unturned in order to arrive at a settle ment, if only because the Congress is wedded to a policy which is known to you all.
('54', 164, 4, 10, 370210) The Congress is intent upon reaching its goal at the earliest possible moment, and holds also very decided views upon all these matters.
('54', 164, 4, 11, 370347) What is more to the purpose, it is today, or considers itself today, capable of shouldering all the responsibilities that flow from responsible self government.
('54', 164, 4, 12, 370508) That being the case, I thought that I could not possibly allow the discussion on this most important matter to close without placing, as humbly as I could, and as briefly as I could, the Congress view on the question.
('54', 164, 4, 13, 370726) As you are all aware, the Congress case is that there should be complete responsibility transferred to India.
('54', 164, 4, 14, 370836) That means, and it has been there stated, that there should be complete control over Defence and over External Affairs; but it also contemplates adjustments.
('54', 164, 4, 15, 370994) I feel that we ought not to deceive ourselves, deceive the world, into thinking that we would be getting responsible government although we may not ask for responsibility in this vital matter.
('54', 164, 4, 16, 371187) I think that a
('54', 164, 5, 17, 371202) 1 The subject being considered by the Committee was Defence.
('54', 165, 0, 1, 371263) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 165, 1, 2, 371305) nation that has no control over her own defence forces and over her external policy is hardly a responsible nation.
('54', 165, 1, 3, 371421) Defence, its Army, is to a nation the very essence of its existence, and if a nation's defence is controlled by an outside agency, no matter how friendly it is, then that nation is certainly not resopnsibly governed.
('54', 165, 1, 4, 371638) This is what our English teachers have taught us times without number, and thereore some Englishmen twitted me also when they heard the talk that we would have responsible government, but we would not have or would not claim control over our own defence forces.
('54', 165, 1, 5, 371900) Hence I am here very respectfully to claim, on behalf of the Congress, complete control over the Army, over the Defence forces and over External Affairs.
('54', 165, 1, 6, 372054) I put in this also so as to avoid having to speak on it when Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru speaks on that tsubject.
('54', 165, 1, 7, 372162) To this conclusion we have come with the greatest deliberation.
('54', 165, 1, 8, 372226) If we do not get this control at the time of embarking upon responsibility, I cannot conceive a time when, because we are enjoying responsibility in other matters, we would be suddenly found fit to control our own defence forces.
('54', 165, 1, 9, 372456) I would like this Committee for just a few brief moments to understand what this Army at the present moment means.
('54', 165, 1, 10, 372571) This Army, in my opinion, whether it is Indian or whether it is British, is really an army of occupation.
('54', 165, 1, 11, 372677) It does not matter to us, at any rate to me, a bit—I speak from experience—that they are Sikhs or that they are Gurkhas or that they are pathans or that they are men from Madras or that they are Rajputs; not matter who they are, they are foreigners to me whilst they are in the Army, controlled by an alien government.
('54', 165, 1, 12, 372996) I cannot speak to them.
('54', 165, 1, 13, 373020) Soldiers have come to me stealthily, and have been afraid even of speaking to me, because they felt that they might be reported.
('54', 165, 1, 14, 373149) It is not possible for us ordinarily to go to the places where the soldiers are kept.
('54', 165, 1, 15, 373235) They are also taught to regard us not as their countrymen.
('54', 165, 1, 16, 373294) Unlike any other country in the world, there is absolutely no correspondence between them and the ordinary civil population.
('54', 165, 1, 17, 373419) This I give as my evidence before this Committee as a man who has endeavoured to come into touch with every part of Indian life, with all those with whom it was possible for me to come into touch and this is not my own personal experience alone, but it is the experience of hundreds and thousands of Congressmen that there is an absolute wall between them and us.
('54', 165, 1, 18, 373783) I am therefore quite aware that it is a tremendous thing for us at once to shoulder that responsibility and to have control of this Army,
('54', 166, 0, 1, 373921) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 167
('54', 166, 1, 2, 373967) say, less the British soldiers.
('54', 166, 1, 3, 373999) That is our unfortunate, unhappy position, created for us, I am sorry to have to say, by our rulers.
('54', 166, 1, 4, 374100) Then there is the British section of the Indian Army.
('54', 166, 1, 5, 374154) What is the purpose of this British Army?
('54', 166, 1, 6, 374196) Every Indian child knows that that British Army is there, including the Indian Army, for the defence of British interests and for avoiding or resisting foreign aggression.
('54', 166, 1, 7, 374368) I am sorry to have to make these remarks, but that is precisely what I have learned and have experienced, and it would be unjust even to my British friends if I did not give expression to the truth as I have given it and as I hold it.
('54', 166, 1, 8, 374603) Thirdly, it is an Army intended to suppress rebellion against constituted authority.
('54', 166, 1, 9, 374688) These, then, are the main functions of that Army, and hence it does not surprise me that Englishmen should take the view they do.
('54', 166, 1, 10, 374818) If I were an Englishman, and had also the ambition to rule another nation, I would do precisely the same thing.
('54', 166, 1, 11, 374930) I would take hold of Indians and train them as soldiers, and I would train them to be loyal to me, so loyal that they would at my command, shoot anybody I desired them to shoot.
('54', 166, 1, 12, 375108) Who was it that shoot people at Jallianwala Bagh, if it was not their own countrymen?
('54', 166, 1, 13, 375194) It is therefore not a matter of surprise to me, but it is a fact which stares me in the face.
('54', 166, 1, 14, 375288) The existence of the Birtish troops there is also intended to serve this very purpose; it holds the balance between these dif ferent Indian soldiers evenly.
('54', 166, 1, 15, 375445) It undoubtedly protects, as it must, the British officers, and it protects British lives.
('54', 166, 1, 16, 375535) Again I do not make any complaint, if I would assume the premise that it was right for Great Britain to occupy India, and that it is right for Great Britain to hold India today and to continue to hold India, no matter under what altered conditions.
('54', 166, 1, 17, 375784) That being so, I have no difficulty in answering the question which Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru would not face and which Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya also would not face.
('54', 166, 1, 18, 375948) Both of them said that, not being experts, they were not able to say to what extent this Army could be or should be reduced.
('54', 166, 1, 19, 376073) I, however, have no such difficulty.
('54', 166, 1, 20, 376110) I have no difficulty in saying what should happen to this Army; that is to say, I would say emphatically that the whole of this Army should be disbanded, if it does not pass under my control, before I could possibly shoulder the burden of running the government of India under the terrible handicaps under which we are labouring as a legacy of alien rule.
('54', 167, 0, 1, 376466) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 167, 1, 2, 376508) Therefore, that being my fundamental position, I would say that if you British Ministers and British people really wish well by India, if you will transfer power now to us, then regard this as a vital condition, that they Army should pass under our control in its entirety.
('54', 167, 1, 3, 376782) But then I have told you that, I know the risk that is attendant upon it.
('54', 167, 1, 4, 376856) That Army will not accept my command.
('54', 167, 1, 5, 376894) I know that very well.
('54', 167, 1, 6, 376917) I know that the British Commander in Chief will not accept my command; nor would the Sikhs, nor the proud Rajputs—none of them would accept my command.
('54', 167, 1, 7, 377069) But I expect, even so, to exercise that command with the goodwill of the British people, that they will be there at the time of transferring the command to teach a new lesson to these very soldiers, and to tell them that they are after all serving their own countrymen if they do so.
('54', 167, 1, 8, 377353) British troops may also be told; 'Now is the time for you not to remain here to protect British interests and British lives, but you are here to protect India against foreign aggression, even against internal insurrection, as if you were defending and serving your own countrymen.
('54', 167, 1, 9, 377634) That is my dream.
('54', 167, 1, 10, 377652) I know that I shall not realize that dream here.
('54', 167, 1, 11, 377701) That is what I feel; the evidence that is before me, the evidence of my senses, tells me that I am not going to realize that dream today and here as a reuslt of the deliberations of this Conference.
('54', 167, 1, 12, 377900) But I should still che rish that dream.
('54', 167, 1, 13, 377940) It is the dream I should like to cherish up to the end of my time.
('54', 167, 1, 14, 378007) But, seeing the atmosphere here, I know that I cannot possibly infect British statesmen or the British public with the idea or with the ideal that this should be also their cherished mission.
('54', 167, 1, 15, 378199) That is how I would interpret the Prime Minister’s declaration; that is how I would interpret Lord Irwin's wishes.
