('54', 167, 1, 17, 378450) Having clipped our wings, it is their duty to give us wings whereby we can fly, even as they fly.
('54', 167, 1, 18, 378548) That is really my ambition , and therefore I say I would wait till eternity if I cannot get control of Defence.
('54', 167, 1, 19, 378660) I refuse to deceive myself that I am going to embark upon responsible government although I cannot control my Defence.
('54', 167, 1, 20, 378779) After all, India is not a nation which has never known how to defend herself.
('54', 167, 1, 21, 378857) There is all the material there.
('54', 167, 1, 22, 378890) There are the Mohammedans, standing in no dread of foreign invasion.
('54', 167, 1, 23, 378959) The Sikhs will refuse to think that they can be conquered by anybody.
('54', 167, 1, 24, 379029) The Gurkha, immediately he develops the national mind, will say: 'I alone can defend India.' Then there are the Rajputs , who are supposed to
('54', 168, 0, 1, 379171) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 169
('54', 168, 1, 2, 379217) be responsible for a thousand Thermopylaes, and not one little Thermopylae [as] in Greece.
('54', 168, 1, 3, 379308) That is what the Englishman, Colonel Tod, told us.
('54', 168, 1, 4, 379359) Colonel Tod has taught us to believe that every pass in Rajputana is a Thermopylae.
('54', 168, 1, 5, 379443) Do these people stand in need of learning the art of defence?
('54', 168, 1, 6, 379505) I assume that, if I shoulder the burden of responsibility, all these people are going to join hands.
('54', 168, 1, 7, 379606) I am here writhing in agony to see that we have not yet come to terms on the communal question; but whenever the communal settlement comes, it must presuppose that we are going to trust each other.
('54', 168, 1, 8, 379804) Whether the rule is predominantly Mohammedan or Sikh or Hindu, they will not rule as Hindus or Mohammedans or Sikhs, but they will rule as Indians.
('54', 168, 1, 9, 379952) If we have distrust of one another, then we want British people there if we do not want to be killed by one another.
('54', 168, 1, 10, 380069) But then let us not talk of responsible government.
('54', 168, 1, 11, 380121) I at least cannot possibly think that we have got responsible government without control of the Army, and therefore I feel deep down at the bottom of my heart that if we are to have responsible government—and the Congress wants responsible government, the Congress has faith in itself, in the masses of the people, and in all those brave military races, and what is more, the Congress has faith also in Englishmen some day doing their duty and transferring complete control to us—we must infect the British with that love for India which would enable her to stand on her own feet.
('54', 168, 1, 12, 380702) If the British people think that we shall require a century before that can be done, then for that century the Congress will wander in the wilderness, and the Congress must go through that terrible fiery ordeal, it must go through a storm of distress, misrepresentation and—if it becomes necessary and if it is God's will—a shower of bullets.
('54', 168, 1, 13, 381045) If this happens, it will be because we cannot trust one another, because Englishmen and Indians have different angles of vision.
('54', 168, 1, 14, 381174) That is my fundamental position.
('54', 168, 1, 15, 381207) I do not want to go into it in detail.
('54', 168, 1, 16, 381246) I have put this case as forcibly as I am capable of putting it.
('54', 168, 1, 17, 381310) But if this one thing is admitted, I am resourceful enough to submit and frame safeguard after safeguard which will commend themselves to any unbiased mind, provided that it is common cause that those safeguards must be in the interests of India.
('54', 168, 1, 18, 381557) But I want to go further and endorse what Lord Irwin said, that although the safeguards in the Pact are stated to be in the interests of India, they must be
('54', 169, 0, 1, 381714) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 169, 1, 2, 381756) considered—I believe Lord Irwin used my name, and said that Gandhi also said they must be considered—as in the mutual interests of India and England.
('54', 169, 1, 3, 381906) I endorse that.
('54', 169, 1, 4, 381922) I do not conceive a single safeguard that will be only in the interests of India, not a single safeguard that will not be also in the interests of Great Britain, provided that we contemplate a partnership, a partnership at will, and a partnership on absolutely equal terms.
('54', 169, 1, 5, 382196) The very reasons that I have given you today for demanding complete control for the Army are also reasons for pleading for, for demanding, control over our External Affairs.
('54', 169, 1, 6, 382370) Not being well versed in what is really meant by External Affairs and having to plead my ignorance of what is stated in these Reports of the Round Table Conference on the subject, I asked my friends Mr. Iyengar and Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru to give me a first lesson in what is meant by external affairs and foreign relations.
('54', 169, 1, 7, 382693) I have got their reply before me.

('54', 169, 1, 14, 383816) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya has sketched the safeguards.

('54', 169, 1, 16, 383977) If Englishmen and Indians put their heads together, sailing in the same direction with no mental reservation whatsoever, it is possible, I submit with every confidence, that we would bring into being safeguards which will be honourable alike to India and to England, and which would be a guarantee for the safety of every British life and the safety of every British interest to which India pledges her honour.

('54', 174, 9, 13, 394281) MR.GANDHI : Lord Chancellor and friends, I would like to tender my congratulations to Mr.Benthall on his very temperate statement, and I wish that he could have seen his way not to spoil that admirable statement by importing two sentiments.
('54', 174, 9, 14, 394522) One sentiment expressed by him was practically that Europeans or Britishers claimed what they are claiming because of their having conferred certain benefits on India.
('54', 174, 9, 15, 394690) I wish that he could have omitted this opinion, but having expressed it, there should have been no surprise expressed, as was expressed by Lord Reading, that there was a courteous retort from Sir Purushottamdas Thakurdas, and now, as we have heard, reinforced by Sir Phiroze Sethna.

('54', 184, 1, 16, 420533) To me the Federal Court is the Supreme Court; it is the final Court of Appeal beyond which there would be no appeal whatsoever; it is my Privy Council and it is the Palladium of Liberty.
('54', 184, 1, 17, 420720) It is the Court to which every person who is at all aggrieved can go.
('54', 184, 1, 18, 420790) A great jurist in the Transvaal—and the Transvaal and South Africa generally have undoubtedly produced very great jurists—to whom I used to go for assistance when I was a youngster, once said to me, in regard to a very difficult case, “Although there may be no hope just now, I tell you that I have guided myself by one thing, or else I should not be a lawyer; the law
('54', 185, 0, 1, 421159) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 185, 1, 2, 421201) teaches us lawyers that there is absolutely no wrong for which there is no remedy to be found in court of law, and if judges say there is no remedy, then those Judges should be immediately unseated.” I say that with all deference to you, Lord Chancellor.
('54', 185, 1, 3, 421456) I therefore think that our European friends may rest assured that the future Federal Court will not send them away empty handed, as we expect to go away empty handed if we do not have the favour of the Minister who are the present advisers of His Majesty.
('54', 185, 1, 4, 421712) I am still hoping that we shall have their ear and get round their better side, and then we may hope to go away with something substantial in our pockets, but, whether we go away with anything substantial in our pockets or not, I hope that, if the Federal Court of my dreams comes into being, then the Europeans and evrybody—all the minorities— may rest assured that that court will not fail them, though a puny individual like myself may fail them.
('54', 185, 2, 5, 422162) CHAIRMAN: We are very much obliged to Mr. Gandhi or that speech.
('54', 185, 2, 6, 422227) If you will allow me to say so, everybody must be impressed by the earnestness and sincerity with which he advocates his ideals, and I thank him very much indeed.
('54', 185, 2, 7, 422390) perhaps he will be good enough to give me those two formulae.
('54', 185, 3, 8, 422452) SIR TEJ BAHADUR SAPRU: I should like to ask Mahatma Gandhi to explain one part of his speech, in regard to which there is some doubt in my mind.
('54', 185, 3, 9, 422597) Does he propose that the National Government of the future should examine and investigate the title to property of everyone, and if so, would it be any title acquired within a certain period of time or not?
('54', 185, 3, 10, 422804) What is the machinery he proposes to bring into existence for the examination of that title and does he propose to give any compensation at all, or that the National Government should simply expropriate property which, according to his view o the majority, seeemed to have been wrongfully acquired?
('54', 185, 4, 11, 423103) MR. GANDHI: If you will give me permission, I will certainly answer those questions, which are very legitimate questions.
('54', 185, 4, 12, 423225) I have really given my view.
('54', 185, 4, 13, 423254) So far as I understand, it is not intended that the administration should do the things; everything that is done will be above board.
('54', 185, 4, 14, 423388) It will be done by legal machinery.
('54', 185, 4, 15, 423424) All these claims—
('54', 185, 5, 16, 423442) SIR TEJ BAHADUR SAPRU: That is what I want to know.
('54', 185, 5, 17, 423494) What is the legal machinery to be?
('54', 185, 6, 18, 423529) MR. GANDHI : I have not at the present moment thought of any limitation .
('54', 185, 6, 19, 423603) I think that there is no limitation running against a wrong.
('54', 185, 7, 20, 423664) SIR TEJ BAHADUR SAPRU : Under your National Government, therefore, no title in India is safe ?
('54', 186, 0, 1, 423759) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 187
('54', 186, 1, 2, 423805) MR. GANDHI : Under our National Government the Court will decide these things, and if there is any undue fear about these things, I think it is possible to satisfy every legitimate doubt.
('54', 186, 1, 3, 423993) I have no hesitation in saying that generally speaking this is a formula which should be accepted.
('54', 186, 1, 4, 424092) Where complaints are made that there are illegitimate rights acquired, it should be open to the courts of law to examine those rights.
('54', 186, 1, 5, 424227) I am not going to say today in taking over the Government that I shall examine no rights whatsoever, no titles that have been acquired.
('54', 186, 2, 6, 424363) CHAIRMAN : I think each of you will consider most carefully what the other has said and we will consider what both of you have said.
('54', 186, 3, 7, 424496) PANDIT M. M. MALAVIYA : After the very exhaustive speech of the Mahatama Gandhi, I do not propose to detain the Committee very long .
('54', 186, 3, 8, 424630) I wish to make a few points quite plain.
('54', 186, 3, 9, 424671) We are all agreed that there shall be no discrimination against Europeans trading in India and no wrong done to them.
('54', 186, 3, 10, 424789) They shall be dealt with justly and fairly.
('54', 186, 3, 11, 424833) On that point there is general agreement.
('54', 186, 4, 12, 424875) CHAIRMAN : Would you rather continue at our next meeting ?

('54', 187, 1, 2, 425624) 110. SPEECH AT MEETING OF LONDON VEGETARIAN SOCIETY LONDON, November 20,1931 When I received the invitation to be present at this meeting , I need not tell you how pleased I was, because it received old memories and recollections of pleasant friendship formed with vegetarians.
('54', 187, 1, 3, 425902) I feel especially honoured to find on my right Mr. Henry Salt.
('54', 187, 1, 4, 425965) I was Mr. Salt's book, A Plea for Vegetarianism, which showed my why, apart from a hereditary habit, and apart from my adherence to a vow administered to me by my mother , it was right to be a vegetarian.
('54', 187, 1, 5, 426170) He showed me why it was a moral duty incumbent on vegetarians not to live upon fellow animals.
('54', 187, 1, 6, 426265) It is, therefore, a matter of additional plea sure to me that I find Mr. Salt in our midst.
('54', 187, 1, 7, 426357) I do not propose to take up your time be giving you my various experiences of vegetarianism, nor do I want to tell you something of the great difficulty that faced me in London itself in remaining staunch to vegetarianism, but I would like to share with you some of the thoughts that have developed in me in connection with vege tarianism.
('54', 187, 1, 8, 426697) Forty years ago I used to mix freely with vegetarians.
('54', 187, 1, 9, 426752) There was at that time hardly a vegetarian restaurant in London that I had not visited.
('54', 187, 1, 10, 426840) I made it a point, out of curiosity, and to study the poss ibilities of vegetarian restaurants in London, to visit every one of them.
('54', 187, 1, 11, 426974) Naturally, therefore, I came into close contact with many vegetarians.
('54', 187, 1, 12, 427045) I found at the tables that largely the conversation turned upon food and disease.
('54', 187, 1, 13, 427127) I found also that the vegetarians who were strugg ling to stick to their vegetarianism were finding it difficult from hea lth point of view.
('54', 187, 1, 14, 427268) I do not know whether, nowadays, you have those debates, but I used at that time to attend debates that were held between vegetarians and vegetarians, and between vegetarians and non vegetarians.
('54', 187, 1, 15, 427464) I remember one such debates, between Dr. Densmore and the late Dr. T. R. Allinson.
('54', 187, 1, 16, 427547) Then vegetarians had a habit of talking of nothing but food and nothing but disease.
('54', 187, 1, 17, 427632) I feel that is the worst way of going about the business.
('54', 187, 1, 18, 427690) I notice also that it is those persons who become vegetarians because they are suffering from some disease or other—that is, from purely the health point of view it is those persons who largely fall back .
('54', 187, 1, 19, 427896) I discovered that for remaining staunch to vegetarianism a man requires a moral basis.
('54', 188, 0, 1, 427983) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 189
('54', 188, 1, 2, 428029) For me that was a great discovery in my search after truth.
('54', 188, 1, 3, 428089) At an early age, in the course of my experiments, I found that a selfish basis would not serve the purpose of taking a man higher and higher along the paths of evolution.
('54', 188, 1, 4, 428260) What was required was an altruistic purpose.
('54', 188, 1, 5, 428305) I found also that health was by no means the monopoly of vegetarians.
('54', 188, 1, 6, 428375) I found many people having no bias one way or the other, and that non vegetarians were able to show, generally speaking, good health.
('54', 188, 1, 7, 428509) I found also the several vegetarian found it impossible to remain vegetarians because they had made food a fetish and because they thought that by becoming vegetarians they could eat as much lentils, haricot beans, and cheese as they liked.
('54', 188, 1, 8, 428750) Of course, those people could not possibly keep their health.
('54', 188, 1, 9, 428812) Observing along these lines, I saw that a man should eat sparingly and now and then fast.
('54', 188, 1, 10, 428902) No man or woman really ate sparingly consumed just that quantity which the body requires and no more.
('54', 188, 1, 11, 429004) We easily fall a prey to the temptations of the palate, and, therefore, when a thing tastes delicious,we do not mind taking a morsel or two more.
('54', 188, 1, 12, 429150) But you cannot keep health under thsose circumstances.
('54', 188, 1, 13, 429205) Therefore, I discovered that in order to keep health, no matter what you ate, it was necessary to cut down the quantity of your food and reduce the number of meals.
('54', 188, 1, 14, 429370) Become moderate; err on the side of less, rather than on the side of more.
('54', 188, 1, 15, 429445) When I invite friends to share their meals with me, I never press them to take anything except only what they require.
('54', 188, 1, 16, 429564) On the contrary, I tell them not to take a thing if they do not want it.
('54', 188, 1, 17, 429637) What I want to bring to your notice is that vegetarians need to be tolerant if they want to convert others to vegetarianism.
('54', 188, 1, 18, 429762) Adopt a little humility.
('54', 188, 1, 19, 429787) We should appeal to the moral sense of the people who do not see eye to eye with us.
('54', 188, 1, 20, 429872) If a vegetarian became ill, and a doctor prescribed beef tea, then I would not call him a vegetarian.
('54', 188, 1, 21, 429974) A vegetarian is made of sterner stuff.
('54', 188, 1, 22, 430013) Be cause it is for the building of the spirit and not of the body.
('54', 188, 1, 23, 430080) Man is more that meat.
('54', 188, 1, 24, 430103) It is the spirit in man for which we are concerned.
('54', 188, 1, 25, 430155) Therefore, vegetarians should have that moral basis—that a man was not born a carnivorous animal, but born to live on the fruits and herbs that the earth gorws.
('54', 188, 1, 26, 430316) I know we must all err.
('54', 188, 1, 27, 430340) I would give up milk if I could but I cannot.
('54', 188, 1, 28, 430386) I have made that experiment times without number.
('54', 188, 1, 29, 430436) I could not , after a serious illness, regain my strength unless I went back to milk.
('54', 188, 1, 30, 430522) That has been the tragedy of my life.
('54', 188, 1, 31, 430560) But the basis of my vegetarianism is not physical, but moral.
('54', 188, 1, 32, 430622) If anybody said that I should die if I did not take beef tea or mutton, even under medical advice, I would prefer death.
('54', 188, 1, 33, 430743) That is the basis of my vegetarianism.
('54', 188, 1, 34, 430782) I would love to think that all of us who called ourselves
('54', 189, 0, 1, 430840) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 189, 1, 2, 430882) vegetarians should have that basis.
('54', 189, 1, 3, 430918) There were thousands of meat eaters who did not stay meat eaters.
('54', 189, 1, 4, 430984) There must be a definite reason for our making that change in our lives, for our adopting habits and customs different from society, even though sometimes that change may offend those nearest and dearest to us.
('54', 189, 1, 5, 431195) Not for the world should you sacrifice a moral principle.
('54', 189, 1, 6, 431253) Therefore the only basis for having a vegetarian society and proclaiming a vegetarian principle is, and must be, a moral one.
('54', 189, 1, 7, 431379) I am not to tell you, as I see and wander about the world, that vegetarians, on the whole, enjoy much better health than meat eaters.
('54', 189, 1, 8, 431513) I belong to a country which is predominantly vegetarian by habit or necessity.
('54', 189, 1, 9, 431592) Therefore, I cannot testify that that shows much greater endurance, much greater courage, or much greater exemption from disease.
('54', 189, 1, 10, 431722) Because it is a peculiar, personal thing.
('54', 189, 1, 11, 431764) It requires obedience, and scrupulous obedience, to all the laws of hygiene.
('54', 189, 1, 12, 431841) Therefore, I think that what vegetarians should do is not to emphasize the physical consequences of vegetarianism, but to explore the moral consequences.
('54', 189, 1, 13, 431995) While we have not yet forgotten that we share many things in common with the beast, we do not sufficiently realize that there are certain things which differentiate us from the beast.
('54', 189, 1, 14, 432179) Of course, we have vegetarians in the cow and the bull—which are better vegetarians than we are—but there is something much higher which calls us of vegetarianism.
('54', 189, 1, 15, 432343) Therefore I thought that during the few minutes which I give myself the privilege of addressing you, I would just emphasize the moral basis of vegetarianism.
('54', 189, 1, 16, 432501) And I would say that I have found from my own experience, and the experience of thousands of friends and compa nions, that they find satisfaction, so far as vegetarianism is concerned, from the moral basis they have chosen for sustaining vegetarianism.
('54', 189, 1, 17, 432754) In conclusion, I thank you all for coming here and allowing me to see vegetarians face to face.
('54', 189, 1, 18, 432850) I cannot say I used to meet you forty or forty two years ago.
('54', 189, 1, 19, 432912) I suppose the faces of the London Vegetarian Society have changed.
('54', 189, 1, 20, 432979) There are very few members who, like Mr. Salt, can claim association with the Society extending over forty years.
('54', 189, 1, 21, 433093) Lastly, I would like you, if you want to, to ask me any questions, for I am at your disposal for a few minutes.
('54', 189, 1, 22, 433205) Mr. Gandhi was then asked to give his reasons for limiting his daily diet to five articles only, and he replied: That has no connection with vegetarianism.
('54', 189, 1, 23, 433361) There was another reason.
('54', 189, 1, 24, 433387) I had been a pampered child of nature.
('54', 189, 1, 25, 433426) I had acquired then that notoriety that when I was invited by friends, they placed before me ample dishes of food.
('54', 189, 1, 26, 433541) I told them, I had come there to serve, and personally, I should find myself dying by inches if I allowed myself to be pampered like that.
('54', 189, 1, 27, 433680) So, in limiting myself to five
('54', 190, 0, 1, 433711) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 191
('54', 190, 1, 2, 433757) ingredients of food, I served a double purpose.
('54', 190, 1, 3, 433805) And I must finish all my eating before sundown.
('54', 190, 1, 4, 433853) I have been saved many pitfalls by that.
('54', 190, 1, 5, 433894) There are many discoveries about that in regard to health reaosns.
('54', 190, 1, 6, 433961) Dietists are saying that we are more and more tending towards simplifying diet, and that, if one must live for health one must have one thing at a time and avoid harmful combinations.
('54', 190, 1, 7, 434145) I like the process of exclusion better than that of inclusion because no two doctors have the same opinion.
('54', 190, 1, 8, 434253) Then I think the restriction to five articles of food has helped me morally and materially—materially because, in a poor country like India, it is not always possible to procure goat's milk, and it is a hard thing to produce fruit and grapes.
('54', 190, 1, 9, 434496) Then, I go to visit poor people, and if I expected hothouse grapes, they would banish me.
('54', 190, 1, 10, 434586) So, by restricting myself to five articles of food, it also serves the law of economy.
('54', 190, 1, 11, 434673) Harijan, 20 2 1949

('54', 192, 6, 8, 438075) Q. Is the Conference certainly doomed to failure ?
('54', 192, 7, 9, 438126) A. It is ungrateful to say so.
('54', 192, 7, 10, 438157) But I see very little warrant for success.
('54', 192, 8, 11, 438200) Q. Don't you think the Government having allowed the discussion will now do
('54', 192, 9, 12, 438276) something?

('54', 192, 10, 14, 438342) A. I expected them to do certainly better, but I do not know that they have made up their minds to transfer power.
('54', 192, 10, 15, 438457) As regards the two parties, I think for India it is 'six of the one and half a do zen of the other'.
('54', 192, 10, 16, 438558) In fact, I am rather glad that I have to do with an overwhelmingly large Conservative majority.
('54', 192, 10, 17, 438654) For I do not want to steal anything from here.
('54', 192, 10, 18, 438701) I want something large and good which poor people can easily see and un derstand and so it is best that I have to fight a strong party and win what I want from a str ong party.
('54', 192, 10, 19, 438878) What I want is a lasting thing.
('54', 192, 10, 20, 438910) I do not want to dissolve the tie, but to transform it.
('54', 192, 10, 21, 438966) The relationship between India and England, the basis of equal partnership, can exist only if each does the common thing out of a consciousness of strength and not of weakness.
('54', 192, 10, 22, 439143) And, therefore, I would love to feel that during the Conservative regime we were able to convince the Conservatives that we were not unworthy opponents nor unworthy partners.

('54', 194, 10, 14, 441692) 117. INTERVIEW TO "NEW LEADER"
('54', 194, 11, 15, 441723) LONDON, [November 25, 1931] 4
('54', 194, 12, 16, 441753) Q. Is it possible for you to speak about what developments are likely in India
('54', 194, 13, 17, 441832) if the Conference breaks down ?
('54', 194, 14, 18, 441864) A. Not in detail.
('54', 194, 14, 19, 441882) As I sense the future now, there will be a revival of trouble in its intensest form.
('54', 194, 15, 20, 441967) Q. But do you think you will be able to renew the psychology of resistance?
('54', 194, 16, 21, 442043) When a movement is called off, is it not always more difficult to renew it?
('54', 194, 17, 22, 442119) A. I have no doubt whatever about it.
('54', 194, 17, 23, 442157) I have never found it diffi cult to renew a movement which I have called off.
('54', 194, 17, 24, 442235) But I must feel the strength within.
('54', 194, 17, 25, 442272) My friends were nervous when we finished at

('54', 195, 1, 2, 442800) Bardoli in 1922, and then renewed the struggle in 1930. But it was just the right time.
('54', 195, 1, 3, 442888) And the suspension proved to be good.
('54', 195, 1, 4, 442926) During the intervening years we were not idle.
('54', 195, 1, 5, 442973) The people were imbibing our ideas.
('54', 195, 1, 6, 443009) Our constructive work went on, and it told on the masses who assimilated the meaning and spirit of the movement, and there was a very wonderful response.
('54', 195, 2, 7, 443163) Q. I see that Jawaharlal Nehru is saying that it is difficult to keep back the people now.
('54', 195, 3, 8, 443254) A. That is all to the good.
('54', 195, 3, 9, 443282) I can say in the plainest possible manner that I should not like to start the struggle if there were no spontaneous feeling among the people.
('54', 195, 3, 10, 443424) But even at this distance, I am conscious that the people are absolutely ready.
('54', 195, 3, 11, 443504) They are only waiting for the signal.
('54', 195, 4, 12, 443542) Q. Is that the case with the peasants as well as with the population in the towns?
('54', 195, 4, 13, 443625) A. Yes.
('54', 195, 4, 14, 443633) I have to depend more and more on the peasants.
('54', 195, 5, 15, 443681) Q. Do they take part in the movement principally from economic or political motives?
('54', 195, 6, 16, 443766) A. Their economic difficulties have given them a grasp of the political situation.
('54', 195, 6, 17, 443849) They understand that their economic position will not be better until the present political system is destroyed, root and branch.
('54', 195, 6, 18, 443979) The Government in India has become the protector of the rich.
('54', 195, 6, 19, 444041) There seems to be a conspiracy of the rich behind the Gover nment to get every pice they can from the poor.
('54', 195, 6, 20, 444149) The position of the peasants cannot be improved until the cruel burden of taxation which they have to bear is removed.
('54', 195, 7, 21, 444268) Q. In the struggle at the beginning of this year, South India seemed to be weak.
('54', 195, 7, 22, 444349) Do you think you can count on South India this time?
('54', 195, 7, 23, 444402) A. South India gave its share steadily in the last struggle, and was coming forward splendidly when the civil disobedience campaign was suspended.
('54', 195, 7, 24, 444549) It will come forward again when the struggle is renewed.
('54', 195, 7, 25, 444606) South India is like that.
('54', 195, 7, 26, 444632) It moves more slowly, but it is sound.
('54', 195, 7, 27, 444671) I did not lose faith in the South before.
('54', 195, 7, 28, 444713) In the making of khaddar the South has done the best, and its work among the untouchables has been solid...
('54', 195, 7, 29, 444821) But I cannot say which province will be best this time.
('54', 195, 7, 30, 444877) I have faith in all the provinces.
('54', 195, 8, 31, 444912) Q. Have you any fear that the impatience in India may prevent you from maintaining the movement on non violent lines?
('54', 195, 9, 32, 445030) A. No, I think not.
('54', 195, 9, 33, 445050) If the people continue to respond and the
('54', 196, 0, 1, 445092) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 197
('54', 196, 1, 2, 445138) mass character of the movement is maintained, violence will play no part.
('54', 196, 2, 3, 445212) Q. I don't want to embarrass you, but I cannot escape the conviction that some of the Muslims at the Round Table Conference have been more concerned about their communal claims than about Indian self government.
('54', 196, 3, 4, 445424) A. I would not say that.
('54', 196, 3, 5, 445449) I would say that their predominant concern is the guarding of what they consider to be the rights of Islam in India.
('54', 196, 3, 6, 445566) That certainly occupies a very important place in their minds.
('54', 196, 3, 7, 445629) But one has to say the same of the communal claims of the three sections; the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs.
('54', 196, 4, 8, 445742) Q. Do you regard the communal "representatives" at the Conference as in fact representative, or would you say that the larger part of their communities are behind Congress?
('54', 196, 4, 9, 445915) A. Undoubtedly they are behind Congress.
('54', 196, 4, 10, 445956) Otherwise, Congress could not do its work.
('54', 196, 4, 11, 445999) We have had the hearty support of both Sikhs and Muslims.
('54', 196, 4, 12, 446057) There are five Muslims on the Congress Working Committee.
('54', 196, 4, 13, 446115) And they are not non entities.
('54', 196, 4, 14, 446146) They are really representative Muslim leaders.
('54', 196, 5, 15, 446193) Q. Would you say that the National Muslim Party (which supports Congress) is more representative than most of the Muslim "leaders" at the Conference?
('54', 196, 6, 16, 446343) A. Certainly.
('54', 196, 6, 17, 446357) That is what Dr. Ansari, who is on our Working Committee, is always claiming.
('54', 196, 6, 18, 446435) It may not be so true, perhaps, as Dr. Ansari thinks, but it is becoming truer day by day.
('54', 196, 6, 19, 446526) There is no doubt whatever that it is true of the younger generation, which is turning from sectarianism.
('54', 196, 7, 20, 446632) Q. Is this tendency in the younger generation a revolt against sectarianism only, or is it a revolt against religion itself?
('54', 196, 8, 21, 446757) A. It is difficult to say.
('54', 196, 8, 22, 446784) I am not able to say that they are agnostics and atheists.
('54', 196, 8, 23, 446843) I can only say that they have developed the spirit of toleration.
('54', 196, 8, 24, 446909) Whether that signifies less appreciation of Islam and a waning of the religious instinct, I do not know.
('54', 196, 9, 25, 447014) Q. If the Round Table Conference breaks down on the issue of responsible government at the Centre, do you think there will be a repetition of the united opposition, which was given to the Simon Commission?
('54', 196, 10, 26, 447220) A. Yes, I think so.
('54', 196, 10, 27, 447240) The Liberals and Moderates will not join the direct action movement, but their opinions will be entirely on the Congress side.
('54', 196, 11, 28, 447367) Q. Do you see any possibility of agreement with the British Government on
('54', 197, 0, 1, 447441) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 197, 1, 2, 447483) the basis of self government in the Provinces?
('54', 197, 1, 3, 447530) I suggested a formula, but the British Government would not accept it.
('54', 197, 1, 4, 447601) There might be a possibility of agreement if the Provinces were given real control immediately and if an absolute guarantee were given of early Central responsibility.
('54', 197, 1, 5, 447769) I would accept an interval in point of time, but not in legislation.
('54', 197, 1, 6, 447838) The same legislation must deal with the two things.
('54', 197, 1, 7, 447890) Indian Nationalists will not look at Provincial autonomy without the certainty of Central responsibility.
('54', 197, 1, 8, 447996) They say they have waited a long time for complete independence, and they can wait a little longer rather than accept a compromise which withholds Central responsibility.
('54', 197, 2, 9, 448167) Q. What is your view of Mr. Brailsford's suggestion of complete Provincial autonomy, with provision for a national constituent assembly to settle the issue of the form of Central Government.
('54', 197, 2, 10, 448358) A. Only a guarantee of responsible government under statutory provision would do.
('54', 197, 2, 11, 448440) We must have responsible government.

('54', 197, 3, 13, 448509) 118. SPEECH AT FEDERAL STRUCTURE COMMITTEE MEETING
('54', 197, 4, 14, 448560) LONDON, November 25, 1931 My Lord Chancellor, I tender my congratulations to Mr. Lees Smith for being responsible for this debate, and I tender my congratulations to you, My Lord Chancellor, for having allowed this debate.
('54', 197, 4, 15, 448783) I think that Mr. Lees Smith has shown amazing optim ism in intiating this debate.
('54', 197, 4, 16, 448865) He has come as a physician with an oxy gen pump and he is trying to pump oxygen into a dying body.
('54', 197, 4, 17, 448964) I do not say that we are a dying body because of this rum our or threat of Provincial autonomy divorced from Central responsibility.
('54', 197, 4, 18, 449097) In my own humble manner, almost from the commencement of these proceedings, I have been uttering words of warning and I was oppressed, and I said so in so many words, with a sense of unreality which dawned upon Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru only yesterday, or as I happen to know, has been dawning upon him for the last few days, because he has given me the privilege of taking me into his confidence in common with his other friends and com rades, if I can also bracket myself as one of his comrades.
('54', 197, 4, 19, 449591) Out of his ripe experience of administrative affairs, having held high offices in
('54', 198, 0, 1, 449673) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 199
('54', 198, 1, 2, 449719) the Government, he has warned us of the danger of Provincial autonomy so called.
('54', 198, 1, 3, 449800) I am very often an unrepentant sinner.
('54', 198, 1, 4, 449839) He had reasons for issuing this warning, especially in connection with me, because I had dared to discuss the question of Provincial autonomy with many English friends who are responsible public men in this country, and he had heard of it, and so he gave me ample warning.
('54', 198, 1, 5, 450112) It was for that reason that you find me as one of the co signatories not to the document that has been placed before you, My Lord Chancellor, but to another similar document that was issued to the Press about ten days ago and was addressed to the prime Minister.
('54', 198, 1, 6, 450375) I told him, as I say here, that both he and the others who have spoken after him and I reached the same goal through different routes.
('54', 198, 1, 7, 450510) Fools walk in where angels fear to tread.
('54', 198, 1, 8, 450552) Not having had any experience of administration actually, I felt that, if Provincial autonomy was the Provincial autonomy of my conception, I for one would not mind handling the fruit, feeling the thing and seeing whether it really answered my purpose.
('54', 198, 1, 9, 450805) I love to meet friends, who may be opponents in policy, on their own platform and find out their difficulties, and find out also whether what they are offering is likely to lead one to the same place, and in that spirit and in that sense I ventured to discuss Provincial autonomy, but I found at once on discussion that what they meant was certainly not the Provincial autonomy that I meant, and so I told my friends also that I would be quite safe if they left me alone, that I was not going to sell the interests of country out of a foolish conception of Provincial autonomy, or out of impatience to get som ething for the country.
('54', 198, 1, 10, 451439) What I am anxious to do is, having come all these miles with the greatest diffidence, having come here to tender my whole hearted co operation to the Government and to this Conference, without the slightest mental reservation, and having applied that spirit of co operation in thought, word and deed, to leave nothing undone, I have not hesitated even to go into the danger zone, and hence I have dared to talk about and discuss Provincial autonomy.
('54', 198, 1, 11, 451889) But I have come to the conclusion that you, or the British Ministers, do not contemplate giving India that measure of Provincial autonomy which would satisfy a man of my mentality, which would satisfy the Congress, and which would reconcile the Congress to taking up Provincial auto nomy although there may be delay in getting responsibility at the Centre.
('54', 198, 1, 12, 452246) At the risk of taking up a little of the time of this meeting, let me
('54', 199, 0, 1, 452316) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 199, 1, 2, 452358) make my meaning clear, because here too I am adopting a somewhat different line of argument, and I am most anxious not to be misunderstood.
('54', 199, 1, 3, 452498) Let me take, therefore, one illustration.
('54', 199, 1, 4, 452540) I want to take for my illustration Bengal, because it is one of the Provinces today in India which is deeply affected.
('54', 199, 1, 5, 452659) I know that there is a terrorist school active in Bengal.
('54', 199, 1, 6, 452717) Everybody ought to realize by this time that I can have no manner of sympathy with that terrorist school in any shape or form.
('54', 199, 1, 7, 452844) I am as convinced as I have ever been that terrorism is the worst kind of action that any reformer can take up.
('54', 199, 1, 8, 452956) Terrorism is the very worst thing for India in a special manner, because India is a foreign soil for terrorism to flourish in.
('54', 199, 1, 9, 453083) I am convinced that those young Indians who are giving their lives for what they consider to be a good cause are simply throwing away their lives, and that they are not bringing the country by one inch nearer to the goal which is common, I hope, to us all.
('54', 199, 1, 10, 453340) I am convinced of all these things, but, having been convinced of them, supposing that Bengal had Provincial autonomy today, what would Bengal do?
('54', 199, 1, 11, 453487) Bengal would set free every one of the detenus.
('54', 199, 1, 12, 453535) Bengal would not hunt down the terrorists—an autonomous Bengal, I mean—but Bengal would try to reach these terrorists and convert these terrorists, and I should approach them with every confidence and wipe out terrorism from Bengal.
('54', 199, 1, 13, 453768) But let me go a little step further, in order to drive home the truth that is in me.
('54', 199, 1, 14, 453853) If Bengal was autonomous, that autonomy itself would really remove terrorism from Bengal , because these terrorists foolishly consider that their action is the shortest cut to freedom; but, having attained that freedom, the terrorism would cease.
('54', 199, 1, 15, 454100) Today there are a thousand young men, some of whom, I would dare swear, have absolutely nothing in common with the school of terrorism, a thousand young men who have not been tried and who have not been convicted; they have all, every one of them, been arrested on suspicion.
('54', 199, 1, 16, 454376) So far as Chittagong is concerned, Mr. Sen Gupta, who was Lord Mayor of Calcutta, who was member of Bengal Legislative Council, and who was also President of the Provincial Congress Committee in Bengal, is here today.
('54', 199, 1, 17, 454594) He has brought to me a report signed by members of all the parties in Bengal in connection with Chittagong, and it is sad reading.
('54', 199, 1, 18, 454725) It is painful to read this report, but the substance of this
('54', 200, 0, 1, 454786) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 201
('54', 200, 1, 2, 454832) report is that there has been an inferior edition of the Black and Tans in Chittagong—and Chittagong is not a place of no importance on the map of India.
('54', 200, 1, 3, 454986) We now see there has been a flag showing ceremony, and in making this demonstration all the military forces have been concen trated togehter in Calcutta, and these demonstrations have gone through ten streets of Calcutta.
('54', 200, 1, 4, 455208) At whose expense, and what will it do?
('54', 200, 1, 5, 455247) Will it frighten the terrorists?
('54', 200, 1, 6, 455280) I promise you it will not frighten the terrorists.
('54', 200, 1, 7, 455331) Will it then wean the Congresmen from civil disobedience?
('54', 200, 1, 8, 455389) It will not do so.
('54', 200, 1, 9, 455408) The Congressmen are pledged to this thing.
('54', 200, 1, 10, 455451) Suffering is the badge of their tribe.
('54', 200, 1, 11, 455490) They have determined to go through every form of suffering.
('54', 200, 1, 12, 455550) It cannot, therefore, frighten them.
('54', 200, 1, 13, 455587) Our children would laugh at this show, and it is our purpose to show the children that they must not be terrified, they must not be frightened by this display of artillery, guns, air force, and so on.
('54', 200, 1, 14, 455788) So you see what is my conception of Provincial autonomy.
('54', 200, 1, 15, 455845) All these things would be impossible; I would not allow a single soldier to enter the Province of Bengal; I would not pay a simple farthing for the upkeep of an army which I may not command.
('54', 200, 1, 16, 456036) In such Provincial autonomy you do not contemplate a state in Bengal whereby I can set free all these detenus and I can remove from the statute book the Bengal Regulation III.
('54', 200, 1, 17, 456212) If it is Provincial autonomy, then it is inde pendence for Bengal precisely in the same manner as that responsible Government.
('54', 200, 1, 18, 456339) I have seen growing up in Natal.
('54', 200, 1, 19, 456372) That is a little colony, but it had its own independent existence; it had its own volunteer force and so on.
('54', 200, 1, 20, 456481) You do not contemplate that thing for Bengal or any of these Provinces.
('54', 200, 1, 21, 456553) It will be the Centre still dictating, still ruling, still doing all these things.
('54', 200, 1, 22, 456636) That is not the Provincial autonomy of my conception.
('54', 200, 1, 23, 456690) That was why I said, if you present me with that live Provincial autonomy.
('54', 200, 1, 24, 456765) I shall be preapred to consider that propositon; but I am also convinced that that autonomy is not coming.
('54', 200, 1, 25, 456872) If that autonomy was coming, we would not see all these protracted proceedings that have taken place here; then we would have managed our own affairs in an entirely different manner.
('54', 200, 1, 26, 457055) But what really grieves me still more is this: We have all been brought here with one single purpose.

('54', 201, 1, 2, 457402) safeguards undoubtedly—safeguards in the interests of India.
('54', 201, 1, 3, 457463) I have said in season and out of season that I would consider every safeguard that is necessary.
('54', 201, 1, 4, 457560) I personally do not really consider, with Mr. Lees Smith or anybody, that all this Constitution building should take all these long years—three years.
('54', 201, 1, 5, 457711) He thinks of Provincial autonomy in eighteen months.
('54', 201, 1, 6, 457764) My folly tells me that all this time is not necessary.
('54', 201, 1, 7, 457819) Where the people have made up their minds, the Parliament has made up its mind, the Ministers have made up their minds and the public opinion here is ready, then these things do not take time.
('54', 201, 1, 8, 458012) I have seen them not taking time where there has been one mind applied; but I do not know that there is not one mind applied, but there are many minds, all following their own course and all perhaps with a disruptive tendency.
('54', 201, 1, 9, 458239) That being so, I feel convinced that, in spite of this debate, not only is there going to be no responsibility at the Centre, but no tangible result coming out of this Conference.

('54', 202, 1, 21, 461997) I want that responsibility at the Centre that will give me, as you all know, control of the Army and Finance.

('54', 202, 1, 23, 462381) What I have been saying to friends in private sitting rooms with reference to Provincial autonomy I have now said openly at this table, and I have told you what I mean by Provincial autonomy and what would really satisfy me.

('54', 203, 1, 2, 462732) and I feel convinced that real Provincial autonomy is an impossibility unless there is responsibility at the Centre, or unless you are prepared to so weaken the Centre that the Provinces will be able to dictate to the Centre.
('54', 203, 1, 3, 462958) I know that you are not prepared today to do this.
('54', 203, 1, 4, 463009) I know that this Conference does not conceive a weak Centre when this Federal Government is brought into being, but that is conceives a strong Centre.
('54', 203, 1, 5, 463160) A strong Centre governed and administered by an alien authority, and a strong autonomy , are a contradiciton in terms.
('54', 203, 1, 6, 463279) Hence I feel that Provincial autonomy and Central responsibility have really speaking to go together.

('54', 203, 4, 11, 463769) LONDON, November 25, 1931 My Lord 1, I followed your speech yesterday on this very important subject with the greatest attention and with all the respect that is undoubtedly your due, and in conneciton with that speech I read the paragraphs on Finance in the Federal Structure Committee's Report of last year, I think it is pragraphs 18, 19 and 20, and I regret to have to record my opinion that I cannot endorse the restrictions that have been suggested in these paragraphs.
('54', 203, 4, 12, 464245) My position, and, I think the position of all of us, must be very difficult when we do not know exactly what are the financial burdens.

('54', 204, 1, 3, 465076) The third examiner or member of the Committee is Professor Shah 1, for a long time Professor in the Unviersity of Bombay, a man having an all India reputation and author of valuable works on Indian economics.
('54', 204, 1, 4, 465285) The fourth member of the Committee is Mr. Kumarappa 2, who holds European degrees and whose opinions on Finance command considerable acceptance and influence.
('54', 204, 1, 5, 465444) These four gentlemen have submitted an elaborate Report in which they, as I hold, make out a conclusive case for an impartial enquiry, and they show that many of the obligations do not really belong to India.
('54', 204, 1, 6, 465653) In this connection, I want very resepctfully to say that the Congress has never suggested, as it has been viciously suggested against it, that one single farthing of national obligations should ever be repudiated by the Congress.
('54', 204, 1, 7, 465883) What the Congress has, however, suggested is that some of the obligations which are supposed to belong to India ought not to be saddled upon India and should be taken over by Great Britain.
('54', 204, 1, 8, 466073) You will find in these volumes a critical examination of all these obligations.
('54', 204, 1, 9, 466153) I do not propose to weary this Committee with a recital of these things.

('54', 204, 1, 11, 466446) That being the case, I feel that if one knew exactly where one was, it would be possible to give a decisive opinion, but subject to that, I venture to suggest, that the restrictions, or the so called safeguards, that have been suggested in paragraph 18, 19 and 20 of this Report of the Federal Structure Sub committee will, instead of helping India on her course, hinder her progress at every step.

('54', 205, 1, 10, 469304) I, therefore, do not propose to go into any details; but I cannot help saying one thing in connection with this increase in the ratio.

('54', 206, 0, 1, 469803) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 207
('54', 206, 1, 2, 469849) was really subordinated to foreign interest.
('54', 206, 1, 3, 469894) It does not require an expert to know that a depreciated rupee is always, or as a rule would be, in the interest of the cultivators.
('54', 206, 1, 4, 470027) I was very much str uck by an admission made by two financiers here that, if the rupee, instead of being linked to sterling, had been left to itself, at least for the time being, it would have been of great advantage to the cultivators.
('54', 206, 1, 5, 470264) They were going to the last extreme and thinking of some catastrophe that might befall India if the rupee left to itself went down to the intrinsic value, namely 6d.
('54', 206, 1, 6, 470430) Personally, I have not even then been able to see that really the Indian cultivator would be in any shape or form damaged.
('54', 206, 2, 7, 470553) Now, that being the case, I cannot possibly endorse safeguards that would interfere with the full discharge of his responsibility by the Indian Finance Minister, and that responsibility conceived predominantly in the interests of the ryots.
('54', 206, 3, 8, 470794) But I want to draw the attention of this Committee to one thing more.
('54', 206, 3, 9, 470864) In spite of the caution uttered by the Lord Chancellor and you, My Lord, I feel somehow or other that if Indian Finance was properly managed entirely in the interests of India, we should not be subject to fluctuations as seriously as we are today in the foreign market, the fluctuations in London.
('54', 206, 3, 10, 471162) I want to give you my reason for it.
('54', 206, 3, 11, 471199) When I first became acquainted with the writing of Sir Daniel Hamilton, I approached him with considerable diffidence and hesitation.
('54', 206, 3, 12, 471333) I knew nothing practically of Indian Finance, I was absolutely new to the subject, but he with his zeal insisted upon my studying the papers that he continued to send me.
('54', 206, 3, 13, 471504) As we all know, he has large interests in India, he has himself held offices of importance and is himself an able financier.
('54', 206, 3, 14, 471629) He is today making experiments himself along the lines he has suggested, but this is the one striking thought that he has placed before all who would care to understand his mode of looking at Indian finance, and he says that India does not need to look to the gold standard or to the silver standard or to any metallic standard.
('54', 206, 3, 15, 471958) India has metal all its own, and he says that that consists in her innumerable, countless millions of labourers.
('54', 206, 3, 16, 472071) It is true that the British Government has not declared itself insolvent in connection with Indian Finance, that it has been, up to now, able to pay its way; but at what cost?
('54', 206, 3, 17, 472247) It has been, in my humble opinion, at the cost of the cultivator, the money has been squeezed
('54', 207, 0, 1, 472341) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 207, 1, 2, 472383) from the cultivator.
('54', 207, 1, 3, 472404) Instead of thinking in terms of rupees, if the authorities had consulted and thought of finance in terms of these masses, they could have managed the affairs of India, in my humble opinion, infinitely better than they have hitherto done, they would not then have been obliged to fall back upon foreign market.
('54', 207, 1, 4, 472714) Everybody recognizes, British financiers have told us, that for nine years out of ten India has always a favourable balance.
('54', 207, 1, 5, 472839) That is to say, whenever India has what may be called an eight anna or ten anna year,eight annas is really enough to give her a favourable balance.
('54', 207, 1, 6, 472987) Then India produces through boun tiful Nature, from Mother Earth, more than enough to pay for all her obligations, and more than for all the imports that she may ever require.
('54', 207, 1, 7, 473163) If it is true, and I hold that it is true, a country like India does not really need to fall back upon the foreign capitalist.
('54', 207, 1, 8, 473290) She has been made to fall back upon the foreign capitalist because of the enormous drain that has taken place from India in order to pay what are called the home charges, in order to pay terrific charges for India's Defence.
('54', 207, 1, 9, 473515) She is utterly unable to discharge these obligations, and yet they have been met a revenue policy which has been condemned in unmeasured terms by one of the officiating commissioners, the late Romesh Chandra Duttt.
('54', 207, 1, 10, 473730) I know he engaged in a contoversy with the late Lord Curzon on this very topic, and we Indians came to the conclusion that the right was on the side of the late Romesh Chandra Dutt.

('54', 207, 1, 12, 473945) It is known that these millions of cultivators remain idle for six months in the year.
('54', 207, 1, 13, 474032) If the British Government saw to it that these men would not remain idle for six months in the year, imagine the wealth that they would produce.
('54', 207, 1, 14, 474177) Why would we then need ever to fall back upon the foreign market?
('54', 207, 1, 15, 474243) That is how the whole idea of finance appears before me, a layman— a man who continually thinks of these masses and wants to feel as they would feel.
('54', 207, 1, 16, 474393) They would say: 'We have all the labour; we do not want, therefore, to fall back upon any foreign capital.' So long as we labour, the whole world would want the products of our labour.
('54', 207, 1, 17, 474578) And it is true the world today wants the products of our labour.
('54', 207, 1, 18, 474643) We would be able to produce those things that the world would voluntarily and willingly take from us.
('54', 207, 1, 19, 474745) That has been the condition of India for ages past.
('54', 207, 1, 20, 474797) Therefore, I really do not feel the fear that you, My Lord, have expressed in connection with Indian Finance.
('54', 207, 1, 21, 474907) Having these views, I do not really share the fear that Indian Finance would be in jeopardy if
('54', 208, 0, 1, 475002) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 209
('54', 208, 1, 2, 475048) we whispered something that need not be said now, or if a man like me said today that I would want complete control of Indian Finance if India is to have responsibility at the Centre.
('54', 208, 1, 3, 475232) In my opinion, unless we have control over our own door keepers and over our own purse absolutely unrestricted, we shall not be able to shoulder the resonsibility, and it will not be a responsibility worth the name.
('54', 208, 1, 4, 475448) Holding thie view, I feel that the safeguards that I would suggest are of a totally different character; but I am not in a position at the present moment to suggest any safeguard at all—not until I know that the nation is to have complete responsibility, complete control over her Army, over the Civil Service, that the nation will be at perfect liberty to take over so many of the Civilians as the nation would want, so many of the soldiers as the nation would want and on terms that would be suitable for a poor nation like India.

('54', 208, 1, 12, 477210) We would avoid all the quarrels, and we, not having any imperialistic ambition, would not go to war with the Afghans or any other nation, but we would cultivate friendly relations, and they would have nothing to fear from us.

('54', 214, 2, 3, 487084) If the Round Table Conference fails the effects on British trade will be disastrous, for the boycott will increase.
('54', 214, 2, 4, 487200) One would think, therefore, it is to Britain’s own interests to see that the Conference does not fail.

('54', 214, 4, 9, 487624) A.I should have to consider what was offered.
('54', 214, 4, 10, 487670) It is not likely that I can get all I want.

('54', 214, 4, 17, 488094) But I would not do so.

('54', 214, 9, 28, 488868) If I were to be deported from India many evil things might happen, but I feel that even in my absence my influence for peace will last; though I may be for away

('54', 215, 2, 10, 489639) Passing to another topic Gandhi remarked : Machinery is a grand yet awful invention.
('54', 215, 2, 11, 489724) It is possible to visulalize a stage at which the machines invented by man may finally engulf civilization .
('54', 215, 2, 12, 489833) If man controls the machines, then they will not; but should man lose his control over the machines and allow them to control him, then they will certainly engulf civilization and everything.
('54', 215, 3, 13, 490025) Q. What are your impressions of the West ?
('54', 215, 3, 14, 490068) Do you condemn Western civili zation ?

('54', 218, 6, 7, 495157) 131. SPEECH AT PLENARY SESSION OF ROUND TABLE CONFERENCE
('54', 218, 7, 8, 495214) LONDON, December 1, 1931 1
('54', 218, 8, 9, 495241) PRIME MINISTER AND FRIENDS, I wish that I could have done without having to speak to you, but I felt that I would not have been just to you or just to my principles if I did not put in what may be the last word on behalf of the Congress.
('54', 218, 8, 10, 495479) I live under no illusion.
('54', 218, 8, 11, 495505) I do not think that anything that I can say this evening can possibly influene the decision of the Cabinet.
('54', 218, 8, 12, 495613) Probably the decision has been already taken.
('54', 218, 8, 13, 495659) Matters of the liberty of practically a whole continent can hardly be decided by mere argumentation, even nego tiation.
('54', 218, 8, 14, 495779) Negotiation has its purpose and has its play, but only under certain conditions.
('54', 218, 8, 15, 495860) Without those conditions negotiations are a fruitless task.
('54', 218, 8, 16, 495920) But I do not want to go into all these matters.
('54', 218, 8, 17, 495968) I want as far as possible to confine myself within the four corners of the conditions that you, Prime Minister, read to this Con ference at its opening meeting.
('54', 218, 8, 18, 496129) I would, therefore, first of all, say a few words in connection with the Reports that have been submitted to this Conference.
('54', 218, 8, 19, 496255) You will find in these Reports that generally it has been stated that so and so is the opi nion of a large majority, some, however, have expressed an opinion to the contrary, and so on.
('54', 218, 8, 20, 496441) Parties who have dissented have not been stated.
('54', 218, 8, 21, 496490) I had heard when I was in India, and I was told when I came here, that no decision or no decisions will be taken by the ordinary rule of majority, and I do not want to mention this fact here by way of complaint that the Reports have been so framed as if the proceedigns were governed by the test
('54', 218, 9, 22, 496786) 1 The session began on November 30 and, after adjourning at 11.50 p.m., was resumed at 12.5 a.m.
('54', 219, 0, 1, 496883) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 219, 1, 2, 496925) of majority.
('54', 219, 1, 3, 496938) But it was necessary for me to mention this fact, because to most of these Reports you will find that there is a dissenting opinion, and in most of the cases that dissent unfortunately happens to belong to me.
('54', 219, 1, 4, 497148) It was not a matter of joy to have to dissent from fellow Delegates, but I felt that I could not truly represent the Congress unless I notified that dissent.
('54', 219, 1, 5, 497306) There is another thing which I want to bring to the notice of this Conference, namely: what is the meaning of the dissent of the Congress?
('54', 219, 1, 6, 497445) I said at one of the preliminary meetings of the Federal Structure Committee that the Congress claimed to represent over 85 per cent of the population of India, that is to say, the dumb, toiling, semi starved millions.
('54', 219, 1, 7, 497664) But I went further: that the Congress claimed also by right of service to represent even the Princes, if they would pardon my putting forth that claim, and the landed gentry, the educated class.
('54', 219, 1, 8, 497859) I wish to repeat that claim and I wish this evening to emphasize that claim.
('54', 219, 1, 9, 497936) All the other parties at this meeting represent sectional interests.
('54', 219, 1, 10, 498005) Congress alone claims to represent the whole of India, all interests.
('54', 219, 1, 11, 498075) It is no communal organization; it is a determined enemy of commun alism in any shape of form.
('54', 219, 1, 12, 498170) Congress knows no distinction of race, colour or creed; its platform is universal.
('54', 219, 1, 13, 498253) It may not always have lived up to the creed.
('54', 219, 1, 14, 498299) I do not know a single human organization that lives up to its creed.
('54', 219, 1, 15, 498369) Congress has failed very often to my knowledge.
('54', 219, 1, 16, 498417) It may have failed more often to the knowledge of its critics.
('54', 219, 1, 17, 498480) But the worst critic will have to recognize, as it has been recognized, that the National Congress of India is a daily growing organization, that its message penetrates the remotest village of India; that on given occasions the Congress has been able to demonstrate its influence over and among these masses who inhabit 700,000 villages.
('54', 219, 1, 18, 498818) And yet here I see that the Congress is treated as one of the Parties.
('54', 219, 1, 19, 498889) I do not mind it; I do not regard it as a calamity for the Con gress; but I do regard it as a calamity for the purpose of doing the work for which we have gathered together here.
('54', 219, 1, 20, 499068) I wish I could convince all the British public men, the British Ministers, that the Congress is capable of delivering the goods.
('54', 219, 1, 21, 499197) The Congress is the only all India wide national organization, bereft of any communal basis; that it does represent all the minorities which have lodged their claims here and which, or the signatories on their behalf, claim I hold unjustifiably to represent 46 per cent of the population of India.
('54', 219, 1, 22, 499495) The Congress, I say, claims to represent all these minorities.
('54', 220, 0, 1, 499558) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 221
('54', 220, 1, 2, 499604) What a great difference it would be today if this claim on behalf of the Congress was recognized.
('54', 220, 1, 3, 499702) I feel that I have to state this claim with some degree of emphasis on behalf of peace, for the sake of achieving the purpose which is common to all of us, to you Englishmen who sit at this table, and to us the Indian men and women who also sit at this table.
('54', 220, 1, 4, 499962) I say so for this reason.
('54', 220, 1, 5, 499988) Congress is a powerful organization; Congress is an organization which has been accused of running or desiring to run a parallel Government; and in a way I have endorsed the charge.
('54', 220, 1, 6, 500170) If you could understand the working of the Congress, you would welcome an organization which could run a parallel Government and show that it is possible for an organization, voluntary, without any force at its command, to run the machinery of Government even under adverse circumstances.
('54', 220, 1, 7, 500459) But no.
('54', 220, 1, 8, 500467) Although you have invited the Congress, you distrust the Congress.
('54', 220, 1, 9, 500534) Althought you have invited the Congress, you reject its claim to represent the whole of India.
('54', 220, 1, 10, 500629) Of course it is possible at this end of the world to dispute that claim, and it is not possible for me to prove this claim; but, all the same, if you find me asserting that claim, I do so because a tremendous responsibility rests upon my shoulders.
('54', 220, 1, 11, 500878) The Congress represents the spirit of rebellion.
('54', 220, 1, 12, 500927) I know that the word ‘rebellion’ must not be whispered at a Conference which has been summoned in order to arrive at an agreed solution of India’s troubles through negotiation.
('54', 220, 1, 13, 501104) Speaker after speaker has got up and said that India should achieve her liberty through negotiation, by argument, and that it will be the greatest glory of Great Britian if Great Britain yields to India’s demands by argument.
('54', 220, 1, 14, 501330) But the Congress does not hold that view, quite.
('54', 220, 1, 15, 501379) The Congress has an alternative which is unpleasant to you.
('54', 220, 1, 16, 501439) I heard several speakers—and let me say I have endeavoured not to miss a single sitting; I have tried to follow every speaker with the utmost attention and with all the respect that I could possibly give to these speakers—saying what a dire calamity it would be if India was fired with the spirit of lawlessness, rebellion, terrorism and so on.
('54', 220, 1, 17, 501784) I do not pretend to have read histroy, but as a schoolboy I had to pass a paper in history also, and I read that the page of history is soiled red with the blood of those who have fought for freedom.
('54', 220, 1, 18, 501984) I do not know an instance in which nations have attained to their own without having to go through an incre dible measure of travail.
('54', 220, 1, 19, 502118) The dagger of the assassin, the poison bowl, the bullet of the rifleman, the spear and all these weapons and methods of destruction have been up to now used
('54', 221, 0, 1, 502275) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 221, 1, 2, 502317) by what I consider blind lovers of liberty and freedom, and the historian has not condemned him.
('54', 221, 1, 3, 502414) I hold no brief for the terrorists.
('54', 221, 1, 4, 502450) Mr. Ghuznavi brought in the terrorists and he brought in the Calcutta Corporation.
('54', 221, 1, 5, 502533) I felt hurt when he mentioned an incident that took place at the Calcutta Corporation.
('54', 221, 1, 6, 502620) He forgot to mention that the Mayor of that Corporation made handsome reparation for the error into which he himself was betrayed and the error into which the Calcutta Corporation was betrayed through the instrumentality of those members of the Corporation who were Congressmen.
('54', 221, 1, 7, 502899) I hold no brief for Congressmen who directly on indirectly would encourage terrorism.
('54', 221, 1, 8, 502985) As soon as this incident was brought to the notice of the Congress, the Congress set about putting it in order.
('54', 221, 1, 9, 503097) It immediately called upon the Mayor of the Calcutta Corporation to give an account of what was done and the Mayor, the gentleman that he is, immediately admitted his mis take and made all the reparation that it was then legally possible to make.
('54', 221, 1, 10, 503344) I must not detain this Assembly over this incident for any length of time.
('54', 221, 1, 11, 503419) He mentioned also a verse which the children of the forty schools conduc ted by the Calcutta Corporation are supposed to have recited.
('54', 221, 1, 12, 503554) There were many other mis statements in that speech which I could dwell upon, but I have no desire to do so.
('54', 221, 1, 13, 503663) It is only out of regard for the great Calcutta Corporation and out of regard for truth and on behalf of those who are not here tonight to put in their defence that I mention these two glaring instances.
('54', 221, 1, 14, 503867) I do not for one moment believe that this was taught in the Calcutta Corporation schools with the knowledge of the Calcutta Corporation.
('54', 221, 1, 15, 504004) I do know that in those terrible days of last year, several things were done for which we have regret, for which we have made reparation.
('54', 221, 1, 16, 504142) If our boys in Calcutta were taught these verses which Mr. Ghuznavi has recited, I am here to tender an apology on their behalf, but I should want it proved that the boys were taught by the schoolmasters of these schools with the knowledge and encouragement of the Corporation.
('54', 221, 1, 17, 504420) Charges of this nature have been brought against the Congress times without number, and times without number these charges have also been refuted, but I have mentioned these things at this juncture.
('54', 221, 1, 18, 504619) It is again to show that for the sake of liberty people have fought, people have lost their lives, people have killed and have sought death at the hands of those whom they have sought to oust.
('54', 221, 1, 19, 504812) The Congress then comes upon the scene and devises a new method not known to history, namely, that of civil disobedience, and the
('54', 222, 0, 1, 504942) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 223
('54', 222, 1, 2, 504988) Congress has been following that method up.
('54', 222, 1, 3, 505032) But again I am up against a stone wall and I am told that that is a method that no Govenment in the world will tolerate.
('54', 222, 1, 4, 505153) Well, of course, the government may has not tolerate, no government has tolerated open rebellion.
('54', 222, 1, 5, 505251) No governmentmaytoleratecivildisobedience, but governments have to succumb even to these forces, as the British Government has done before now, even as the great Dutch Gover nment after eight years of trial had to yield to the logic of facts.
('54', 222, 1, 6, 505494) General Smuts is a brave General, a great statesman, and a very hard taskmaster also, but he himself recoiled with horror from even the contemplation of doing to death innocent men and women who were merely fighting for the preservation of their self respect and the things which he had vowed he would never yield in the year 1908, rein forced as he was by General Botha, he had to do in the year 1914, after having tried these civil resisters through and through.
('54', 222, 1, 7, 505959) And in India Lord Chelmsford had to do the same thing; the Governor of Bombay had to do the same thing in Borsad and Bardoli.
('54', 222, 1, 8, 506085) I suggest to you, Prime Minister, it is too late today to resist this, and it is this thing which weighs me down, this choice that lies before them, the parting of the ways probably.
('54', 222, 1, 9, 506268) I shall hope against hope, I shall strain every nerve to achieve an honourable settlement for my country if I can do so without having to put the millions of my countrymen and countrywomen and even children through this ordeal of fire.
('54', 222, 1, 10, 506504) It can be a matter of no joy and comfort to me to lead them on again to a fight of that character, but if a further ordeal of fire has to be our lot.
('54', 222, 1, 11, 506654) I shall appraoch that with the greatest joy and with the greatest consolation that I was doing what I felt to be right, the country was doing what it felt to be right, and the country will have the additional satisfaction of knowing that it was not at least taking lives, it was giving lives; it was not making the British people directly suffer, it was suffering.
('54', 222, 1, 12, 507019) Professor Gilbert Muray told me I shall never forget that I am paraphrasing his inimitable language.
('54', 222, 1, 13, 507120) He said: You do not consider for one moment that the Englishmen do not suffer when thousands of your countrymen suffer, that we are so heartless?
('54', 222, 1, 14, 507266) I do not think so.
('54', 222, 1, 15, 507285) I do not know that you will suffer; but I want you to suffer because I want to touch your hearts; and when your hearts have been touched will come the psychological moment for negotiation.
('54', 222, 1, 16, 507474) Negotiation there always will be; and if this time I have travelled all these miles in order to enter upon negotiation, I thought that your countryman, Lord Irwin, had sufficiently tried us through his ordi nances, that he had sufficient evidence that thousands of men and women of India and that thousands of children had suffered; and that, ordinance or no ordinance, lathis or no lathis, nothing would
('54', 223, 0, 1, 507879) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 223, 1, 2, 507921) avail to stem the tide that was onrushing and to stem the passions that were rising in the breasts of the men and women of India who were thirsting for liberty.
('54', 223, 1, 3, 508082) Whilst there is yet a little sand left in the glass, I want you to understand what this Congress stands for.
('54', 223, 1, 4, 508191) My life is at your disposal.
('54', 223, 1, 5, 508220) The lives of all the members of the Working Committee, the All India Congress Committee, are at your disposal.
('54', 223, 1, 6, 508331) But remember that you have at your disposal the lives of all these dumb millions.
('54', 223, 1, 7, 508413) I do not want to sacrifice those lives if I can possibly help it.
('54', 223, 1, 8, 508479) Therefore please remember that I will count no sacrifice too great if by chance I can pull through an honourable settlement.
('54', 223, 1, 9, 508604) You will find me always having the greatest spirit of compromise if I can but fire you with the spirit that is working in the Congress, namely, that India must have real liberty.
('54', 223, 1, 10, 508783) Call it by any name you like; a rose will smell as sweet by any other name, but it must be the rose of liberty that I want and not the artificial product.
('54', 223, 1, 11, 508938) If your mind and the Congress mind, the mind of this Conference and the mind of the British people, mean the same thing by the same word, then you will find the amplest room for compromise, and will find the Congress itself always in a Compromising spirit.
('54', 223, 1, 12, 509195) But so long as there is not that one mind, that one definition, not one implication for the same word that you and I and we may be using, so long there is no compromise possible.

('54', 233, 7, 18, 533994) CHAIRMAN: ...
('54', 233, 7, 19, 534008) At the beginning of the year I made a declaration of the policy of the then Government, and I am authorized by the present one to give you and India a specific assurance that it remains their policy.
('54', 233, 7, 20, 534208) I shall repeat the salient sentences of that declaration:
('54', 233, 8, 21, 534266) "The view of His Majesty’s Government is that responsibility for the government of India should be placed upon Legislatures, Central and Provincial, with such provisions as may be necessary to guarantee, during a period of transition, the observance of certain obligations and to meet other special circumstances, and also with such guarantees as are required by Minorities to protect their political liberties and rights.
('54', 233, 9, 22, 534689) "In such statutory safeguards as may be made for meeting the needs of the transitional period, it will be a primary concern of His Majesty’s Government to see that the reserved powers are so framed and exercised as not to prejudice the advance of India through the new Constitution to full responsibility for her own government."
('54', 233, 10, 23, 535019) With regards to the Central Government, I made it plain that, subject to defined conditins, His Majesty’s late Government were prepared to recognize the principle of the responsibility of the Executive to the Legislature, if both were constituted on an all India Federal basis.
('54', 233, 10, 24, 535297) The principle of responsibility was to be
('54', 234, 0, 1, 535339) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 235
('54', 234, 1, 2, 535385) subject to the qualification that, in existing circumstances, Defence and External Affairs must be reserved to the Governor General, and that, in regard to Finance such conditions must apply as would ensure the fulfilment of the obligations incurred under the authority of the Secretary of State, and the maintenance unimpaired of the financial stability and credit of India.
('54', 234, 2, 3, 535761) Finally, it was our view that the Governor General must be granted the necessary powers to enable him to fulfil his responsibility for securing the obser vance of the constitutional rights of Minorities, and for ultimately maintaining the transquillity of the State.
('54', 234, 3, 4, 536028) These were, in broad outline, the features of the new Constitution for India as contemplated by His Majesty’s Government at the end of the last Conference.

('54', 237, 24, 32, 545178) 134. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('54', 237, 25, 33, 545206) LONDON, December 1, 1931 It is not so much the Premier’s statement or what happened at the Conference that is worrying me as what is happening in India at the present moment.
('54', 237, 25, 34, 545381) You have an English saying which is appropriate: “Coming events cast their shadow before.” Well, the situation in India, especially in Bengal, is very ugly, leaving little room for hope that anything big will come out of the Conference.
('54', 237, 25, 35, 545618) I refer to the
('54', 237, 26, 36, 545633) 1 The Conference terminated at 12.33 p.m.
