('54', 238, 1, 2, 545721) Ordinance just passed in Bengal giving extra ordinary powers to the Government to deal with what has been called terrorism and to a certain extent rightly so called, but past experience tells me that the Government has become panicky as it is wont when European life is taken or is attempted.
('54', 238, 1, 3, 546014) I detest such a crime, but I am quite clear in my mind that the powers taken are altogether out of all proportion to the possibilities of the spread of terrorism.
('54', 238, 1, 4, 546177) If it is let to me, it shall be dealt with under ordinary law.
('54', 238, 1, 5, 546240) I must say the executive in authority has very wide powers even under the ordinary law, and after all is said and done, if one were to examine the mere arithmetic in connection with terrorism, I do not think Bengal would come out the worst.
('54', 238, 1, 6, 546481) Then, instead of dealing with the root cause, the Government of India, rather the Government of Bengal, assisted by the Government of India and the Secretary of State here have merely dealt with the symptom and not the disease.
('54', 238, 1, 7, 546709) Terrorists, everybody admits, do not resort to terrorism for the sake of it.
('54', 238, 1, 8, 546786) Nobody throws away his life without some motive behind and it is, I think, admitted by all that the terrorists resort to their method in the hope of thereby securing freedom for their country.
('54', 238, 1, 9, 546979) If that freedom comes, there surely may be no terrorism, certainly no attempts on European life or the life of officials whether they are Europeans or others.
('54', 238, 1, 10, 547138) If I had my way, therefore, I would certainly utilize all the ordinary legal powers to put down crime and at the same time find out what the terrorists mean by freedom and if, as a result of enquiry, I found their demands just, I would straight away concede their demands and there would be no terrorism in the land.
('54', 238, 1, 11, 547455) The late Mr. C.R. Das and many other public men of his time advised the Government to adopt this method, but their advice went unheeded or was not accepted in the fullest extent.
('54', 238, 1, 12, 547634) But it is never too late to retrace one’s steps in a matter of this character and I fear very much that, unless full freedom for which the nation is hungering comes, terrorism will not be rooted out.
('54', 238, 1, 13, 547834) The Congress has adopted a method whereby terrorism can entirely be replaced by means of civil resistance and all it means, and I am certain the Congress method has, in a very large degree, kept the terrorist crime under check.
('54', 238, 1, 14, 548062) But I make no larger claim for the Congress method just yet.
('54', 238, 1, 15, 548123) I hope, however, whether the Government regains sanity or not, the Congress will pursue its course and some day effectively stamp out terrorism.
('54', 238, 1, 16, 548268) But I confess that the progress is slow as all methods of conversion are likely to be.
('54', 238, 1, 17, 548355) The relevance, however, of what I have said is that these extra ordinary powers of repression with which the Bengal Government has
('54', 239, 0, 1, 548486) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 239, 1, 2, 548528) armed itself seem to me wholly inconsistent with the desire expressed here to part with power, and give India the real freedom she wants.
('54', 239, 1, 3, 548666) Apart, therefore, from the meaning which the Premier’s declaration bears, this Ordinance and the other things that, I know, are happening in India, fill me with the greatest misgiving and may leave the Congress no choice in the matter of tendering further co operation.

('54', 240, 1, 2, 550285) 136. INTERVIEW TO SIR PHILIP HARTOG 1
('54', 240, 2, 3, 550323) LONDON, December 2, 1931
('54', 240, 3, 4, 550348) In my last letter to Mr. Gandhi relating to his statement at the Royal
('54', 240, 4, 5, 550419) Institute of International Affairs on October 20 that literacy in India had
('54', 240, 5, 6, 550495) diminished during the last 50 or 100 years, 2 I had asked him for an inter 
('54', 240, 6, 7, 550571) I went to see Mr. Gandhi at 88 Knightsbridge at 4 p.m.
('54', 240, 7, 8, 550626) stayed till five.
('54', 240, 7, 9, 550644) He was lying on a sofa, covered with his shawl, in front of a big fire,
('54', 240, 8, 10, 550716) obviously tired, though he insisted on rising both when I came and when I went.
('54', 240, 9, 11, 550796) told me that he had thought his strength was equal to anything, but that he was now
('54', 240, 10, 12, 550880) saturated.
('54', 240, 10, 13, 550891) I suggested that he might be too tired to discuss matters, but he said that it
('54', 240, 11, 14, 550970) was a pleasure to meet me and he apologized sincerely for not having written to over
('54', 240, 12, 15, 551055) me an appointment.
('54', 240, 13, 16, 551074) He admitted at once that he had at present no facts to subtantiate his statements and did not attempt to answer my argument that the articles in Young India
('54', 240, 14, 17, 551231) for December 8 and 29, 1920 by Daulat Ram Gupta, of which he had furnished me with typed copies, contained no literacy figures and that the most recent official report on them, Dr. G. W. Leitner’s History of Indigenous Education in the Punjab, was written
('54', 240, 15, 18, 551487) in 1882 and could therefore furnish no evidence with regard to the progress or decline of literacy in India during the last 50 years.
('54', 240, 15, 19, 551621) He told me that Mr. Mahadev Desai (who was present) had been investigating the matter in the British Museum.
('54', 240, 15, 20, 551730) Mr. Desai admitted that he had found nothing fresh up to the present.
('54', 240, 15, 21, 551800) Mr. Gandhi said that he would question the writer of the articles in Young India and that on his return he
('54', 240, 16, 22, 551907) would get competent friends at his Ashram to investigate the matter for him over there and that he would send me a cablegram with regard to the result, and that in it he would say whether he had found material that would convince me that he was right, or that he would apologize handsomely for his mistake, and he would make his withdrawl in such a way as to reach a much wider audience than his original statement.
('54', 240, 17, 23, 552323) I showed him Leinter’s book and pointed out the statement on 3 in which Leitner pointed out that the Punjab was not typical, but far behind the Central Provinces and Lower Bengal in the proportion of pupils to population, a statement not referred to by Mr. Gupta, though he had quoted figures in regard to Hushiarpur from p.
('54', 240, 17, 24, 552648) 2.I told Mr. Gandhi that the population of British India in 1882 was roughly speaking 210 millions, and that it had increased in 1931 to about 270 millions i.e., about 30 per cent in round figures, and that during that period the number of pupils
('54', 240, 18, 25, 552895) 1 Extracted from Sir Philip Hartog’s notes of the interview.
('54', 240, 18, 26, 552956) 2 Vide “Speech at Chatham House Meeting”, 20 10 1931
('54', 241, 0, 1, 553009) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 241, 1, 2, 553051) under instruction in British India had increased from about 2 1/3 millions to over 11 millions, i.e., more than 4 times, and that it would be surprising, therefore, if literacy had diminished during these 50 years.
('54', 241, 1, 3, 553266) I also pointed out that it was impossible to draw any accurate conclusions, on the other hand, in regard to literacy from the numbers of pupils under instruction.
('54', 241, 1, 4, 553429) Howell in his Education in British India had pointed out that for many reasons,
('54', 241, 2, 5, 553509) including the early age at which the children are withdrawn, the schools in the early 19th century were almost worthless.
('54', 241, 2, 6, 553631) I also mentioned that during the years 1917 1927 in Bengal with an increased enrolment of over 300,000 pupils (the actual figure is about 370,000) there had been a decline of about 30,000 pupils in number that reached class IV where, under present conditions, literacy was first attained.
('54', 241, 3, 7, 553920) I also showed Mr. Gandhi certain figures of literacy for Bengal from Adam’s Report on Vernacular Education of 1835 38 and compared them with the census figure for 1921, Vol. 5, p.302. I further showed him census figures for 1911 and 1901 taken from the same volume p.
('54', 241, 3, 8, 554188) 285, showing considerable increases in literacy in Burma, Bengal and Madras, though the Punjab, Bihar, Bombay and United Provinces had made little or no progress during those years.
('54', 241, 3, 9, 554370) Mr Gandhi said, “I know very little about these things” in a tone of apology, to which I rejoined that he had no doubt many other things to occupy his attention.
('54', 241, 4, 10, 554532) Towards the end of the interview, I said that I hoped that he was now on the side of peace.
('54', 241, 4, 11, 554624) He replied that he had meant exactly what he had said on the previous day, that he would read the Prime Minister’s declaration over again and again, and that he felt the immense personal responsibility that rested on his shoulders in advising Congress.
('54', 241, 4, 12, 554877) He said that he had postponed his departure in order to see Sir Samuel Hoare on the following Friday as Sir Samuel had said that he would have no free time during the debate in Parliament (on Wednesday and Thursday).
('54', 241, 4, 13, 555094) I said: “I am sure you must be convinced that Englishmen are in earnest in wishing to give India everything possible at the present moment.” He said: Yes, but there is one thing that the English sincrely believe, but which I cannot understand.
('54', 241, 4, 14, 555338) They think us incapable of managing our own affairs even with the help of experts.
('54', 241, 4, 15, 555421) When I was a young man and my father was Prime Minister of an Indian State, I knew the Prime Minsiter of another Indian State (Junagadh), who could hardly sign his own name but who was a very remarkable man and managed the State wonderfully.

('54', 242, 4, 8, 556957) Mr. Gandhi then asked me if I thought that primary education would be of much use unless the children went on to middle schools.

('54', 242, 4, 10, 557322) I said that I was sorry that Bengal despised vernacular middle schools and insisted on English teaching middle schools.

('54', 242, 5, 12, 557601) Mr. Gandhi said that he entirely agreed, but he asked himself whether primary education would make girls better mothers.

('54', 242, 7, 15, 557847) 137. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS LONDON, December 3, 1931
('54', 242, 8, 16, 557900) Squatting before a fire in a small room in his Knightsbridge office, Mahatma Gandhi shortly before midnight received some 40 Press representatives, seated on the floor round him.
('54', 242, 8, 17, 558079) He told them that he was unable to give his decisive view either on the Premier’s statement or on the Commons debate, but assured them that, before reaching any conclusion, he proposed to exhaust all resources at his disposal in order to understand both the statement and the debate.
('54', 242, 8, 18, 558363) Mahatma Gandhi added that any conclusion he might reach would have no weight until it had been submitted to the Congress Working Committee and accepted by it.
('54', 242, 9, 19, 558522) Mahatma Gandhi repeated his declaration regarding civil disobedience and reaffirmed his tentative opinion that the statement meant a parting of the ways, but he had not yet studied it as he had promised.
('54', 242, 9, 20, 558726) Mahatma Gandhi said that it was a tremendous responsibility for any man to call upon a nation to go through the fiery
('54', 243, 0, 1, 558844) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 243, 1, 2, 558886) ordeal again.
('54', 243, 1, 3, 558900) Therefore , he was not likely light heartedly to advise the resumption of civil disobedience, but resistence in the policy of repression envisaged by the Bengal Ordinance might upset all calculations and precipitate any day civil disobedience on a national scale.
('54', 243, 1, 4, 559164) Mahatma Gandhi declared that there was no justification for the Ordinance and continued: I am no more pessimistic than when I left India.
('54', 243, 1, 5, 559302) I never believed that we would get anything more than what our own internal strength entitled.
('54', 243, 1, 6, 559397) The Round Table Conference negotiations have been a method of finding out the measure of our strength compared with those with whom power at present resides.

('54', 243, 1, 8, 559581) The Congress, therefore, must refill the battery so that it will be powerful enough to do its work.

('54', 248, 4, 20, 572782) LONDON, [Before December 5, 1931] 2
('54', 248, 5, 21, 572818) Q. I thought you were the sworn enemy of all machines.
('54', 248, 5, 22, 572873) How does it happen that you use a watch?
('54', 248, 6, 23, 572914) A. I must know what time it is, consequently, I must use a watch.
('54', 248, 6, 24, 572980) Moreover, I am doing nothing against my principles.
('54', 248, 6, 25, 573032) I am an enemy not of mechanism but of organized mechanism.
('54', 248, 6, 26, 573091) I consider this system, which has become the basis of your civilization, as the greatest danger which could menace man.
('54', 248, 6, 27, 573211) If I use a watch, that does not mean that I am its slave.
('54', 248, 6, 28, 573269) But when it is a question of the machine organized, man becomes its slave and loses all of the values with which the Lord endowed him.
('54', 248, 7, 29, 573404) Q. Excuse me, if I interrupt you.
('54', 248, 7, 30, 573438) You speak of God.
('54', 248, 7, 31, 573456) Your God is not mine.
('54', 248, 8, 32, 573478) A. But your God is also mine for I believe in your God, in spite of the fact that you do not believe in mine.

('54', 249, 1, 4, 573929) One is able to understand as soon as one believes in man.
('54', 249, 1, 5, 573987) The difference between us consists in the divergence of opinions as to man and his destinty.
('54', 249, 1, 6, 574080) You say, you Europeans, that man is born without being either good or bad, and that it is the place, the institutions, and a dozen other factors which determine the road which he is going to follow.
('54', 249, 1, 7, 574279) I affirm, to the contrary, that man is always good and that it is the only bad institutions which turn him from the straight road.

('54', 250, 2, 8, 576723) 140. A MANIFESTO 1
('54', 250, 3, 9, 576742) [On or before December 5, 1931] The Congress demands Complete Independence, including full control of defence forces, External Affairs and Finance, not excluding equal partnership with Britain determinable at the instance of either party, subject to the discharge or adjustment of mutual obligtions.
('54', 250, 4, 10, 577042) SAFEGUARDS The Congress will accept safeguards necessary in the interests of India and is willing to take over all legitimate obligations, subject to examination by an impartial tribunal.
('54', 250, 4, 11, 577230) The Congress is committed to a purely national solution of the question of minorities but will, if necessary, accept the principle of special reservation of seats in legislature for Muslims and Sikhs as a necessary evil for historical reasons.
('54', 250, 5, 12, 577474) UNTOUCHABLES The cause of untouchables will be the special care of the Congress and it would be unjust to treat them separately and thus give untouchablity a legal status when every attempt is being made to abolish the evil altogether.

('54', 256, 2, 3, 587369) December 5, 1931
('54', 256, 3, 4, 587386) I first came to Paris in 1890 at the time of the Exhibition at which the Eiffel Tower the “chief attraction”.
('54', 256, 3, 5, 587496) At once I fell in love with many things in the city: The Cathedral, of which the memory is still fresh in my mind .
('54', 256, 3, 6, 587612) 2 In my spare time I tried to read works concerning France.
('54', 256, 3, 7, 587672) I read, in parts, Rousseau and Voltaire.
('54', 256, 3, 8, 587713) I tried to understand, more comprehensively, your great revolution.
('54', 256, 3, 9, 587781) From all this I came to the conclusion that if you choose you can give to the world a message even more grand than that proclaimed by your great countrymen.
('54', 256, 3, 10, 587938) As it seems to me, the world is tired of sanguinary wars; the world is disgusted with the falsehoods, hypocrisy and deceit that are the necessary concomitants of the way of violence; and it has begun to understand (albeit only vaguely as yet) the disastrous consequences of questionable economics.
('54', 256, 3, 11, 588236) I am convinced that the economic crisis which has gripped the countries of the world, including the United States, is a consequence of the World War, which we very mistakenly, call the “Great War”.
('54', 256, 3, 12, 588434) Thus it seems to me that India’s struggle for independence is a movement in which every Frenchman and everyFrenchwoman should take a direct interest.
('54', 256, 3, 13, 588584) That nation, comprising 350 million inhabitants and representing one fifth of mankind, has been trying to secure its liberty by methods wholly devoid of violence.
('54', 256, 3, 14, 588747) Falsehoods, duplicity, hypocrisy and deceit have no place in the method we are practising in India.
('54', 256, 3, 15, 588847) Everything is open and above board.
('54', 256, 3, 16, 588883) Once you have grasped the secret, that is, Truth, you will then be more open, more truthful.
('54', 256, 3, 17, 588976) In the dictionary of the man who bases his life on truth and non violence there is no place for fear and despair.
('54', 256, 3, 18, 589090) This movement is not passive; it is essentially active.
('54', 256, 3, 19, 589146) It is more active than any campaign involving lethal weapons can be.
('54', 256, 3, 20, 589215) Truth and non violence are perhaps the most active forces in the world.

('54', 257, 1, 20, 591917) Our parents are moving forward with such energy, such confidence, such ardour, that participation of the children is spontaneously brought about and the authority of the parents cannot stop them.

('54', 264, 1, 2, 605110) 153. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('54', 264, 2, 3, 605138) LAUSANNE, December 8, 1931
('54', 264, 3, 4, 605165) Q. How can East and West be brought together to work for peace?
('54', 264, 4, 5, 605229) A. This question was asked me some 5 years ago.
('54', 264, 4, 6, 605277) And this was my answer: I, who belong to a subject nation, did not know how I could work for peace except by working for freedom, and if India could be help ed to win freedom through peaceful means, it would be a very good com bination for peace.
('54', 264, 4, 7, 605524) I have said this after having attempted the deliverance of my country through absolutely non violent and truthful means.
('54', 264, 5, 8, 605645) Q. Must we admit that, parallel to the use of non violence in India, there
('54', 264, 6, 9, 605720) should be a movement here also for use of non violence for political ends?
('54', 264, 7, 10, 605795) A. If you are convinced that the means adopted in India are day by day bringing about the results we desire, and if you are convinced that India is doing so through spiritual means, then do so here too.
('54', 264, 7, 11, 605998) Though there is greater difference in Europe.
('54', 264, 7, 12, 606044) Friends have told me there were special difficulties in Europe to adopt non violent means.
('54', 264, 7, 13, 606135) Europe consists of martial races unlike India.
('54', 264, 7, 14, 606182) Here all know how to wield arms.
('54', 264, 7, 15, 606215) All the male population has at one time or another wielded arms.
('54', 264, 7, 16, 606280) It is difficult for you to understand the efficacy and beauty of non retaliation.
('54', 264, 7, 17, 606362) Why not punish the wrong doer—and in an exemplary manner?—that is what is asked everywhere here.
('54', 264, 7, 18, 606459) Thus non violence is quite foreign to Europe.
('54', 264, 7, 19, 606505) For people belonging to such a country it is difficult to strike out a new path.
('54', 264, 7, 20, 606586) Your economic life is so constructed that it is not possible, generally speaking, for an ordinary man to get out of the ordinary rut unless he faces poverty.
('54', 264, 7, 21, 606744) And the fourth difficulty is that in Catholic Europe the iron discipline allows very little free play to the intellect.
('54', 264, 7, 22, 606864) These are the four difficulties we have not to face in India which you have to face.
('54', 264, 7, 23, 606949) If India becomes free through non violent means, it won’t enter upon war.
('54', 264, 7, 24, 607023) But if she does, God will give me strength to fight India single handed.
('54', 264, 8, 25, 607096) 1 Although the source does not mention the occasion of the questions, these were presumably put at the very first meeting Gandhiji addressed at Lausanne.
('54', 265, 0, 1, 607250) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 265, 1, 2, 607292) Q. What do you think of Einstein’s call to military people not to take part in war?
('54', 265, 2, 3, 607376) A. My answer can only be one.
('54', 265, 2, 4, 607406) That, if Europe can take up this method enthusiastically like me, I can only say Einstein has stolen the method from me.
('54', 265, 2, 5, 607527) But if you want me to elaborate the thing, I would like to elaborate the method a little deeper.
('54', 265, 2, 6, 607624) To refuse to render military service when a particular individual’s time comes is to do the thing after all the time for combating the evil is practically gone.
('54', 265, 2, 7, 607785) The disease is deeper.
('54', 265, 2, 8, 607808) I suggest to you that those who are not on the Register for military service are equally participating in the crime.
('54', 265, 2, 9, 607925) He or she, therefore, who supports a State so organized is, whether directly or indirectly, participating in the sin.
('54', 265, 2, 10, 608043) It is fraught with immediate danger.
('54', 265, 2, 11, 608080) Seeing that each man, old or young, takes part in this sin by contributing to the State (by paying the tax to the State) I said so long as I ate wheat supplied by the Navy, whilst I was doing everything short of being a soldier, it was best for me to be shot; otherwise I should go to the mountains and eat food grown by nature.
('54', 265, 2, 12, 608409) Similarly, all those who want to stop military service can do so by withdrawing all military co operation.
('54', 265, 2, 13, 608516) Refusal of military service is much more superficial than non co operation with a whole system which supports the State.
('54', 265, 2, 14, 608637) But then your opportunity becomes so swift and so effective that you run the risk of not only being marched to jail, but of being thrown on the street.
('54', 265, 2, 15, 608789) This was the position of Tolstoy.
('54', 265, 3, 16, 608823) Q. Are we not allowed to accept the State?
('54', 265, 3, 17, 608866) Should we even refuse local self government (including public works, schools, etc.)?
('54', 265, 4, 18, 608951) A. Now you have touched the tenderest spot in human nature.
('54', 265, 4, 19, 609011) This question touched me as author of non co operation in the initial stage.
('54', 265, 4, 20, 609088) And before I could make up my mind, I said to myself: I co operate with the State in two ways.
('54', 265, 4, 21, 609183) There is no State, run either by Nero or Mussolini, which has no good points about it.
('54', 265, 4, 22, 609270) We have in India what is called the Grand Trunk Road.
('54', 265, 4, 23, 609324) It provides facility for millions of travellers; well equipped hospitals, grand palaces built for schools.
('54', 265, 4, 24, 609431) These we may consider to be good points.
('54', 265, 4, 25, 609472) But I said, if the whole thing crushes the nation, I should not have anything to do with them.
('54', 265, 4, 26, 609567) They are like the snake with a jewel but with poison fangs.
('54', 265, 4, 27, 609627) So I came to the conclusion that British rule in India had stunted the nation and so I denied myself all the privileges.
('54', 265, 4, 28, 609748) The gentlemanly way was to deny them.
('54', 266, 0, 1, 609786) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 267
('54', 266, 1, 2, 609832) The plea of self defence is a wretched plea.
('54', 266, 1, 3, 609877) You organize your country and society to prey upon ill organized communities and nations.
('54', 266, 1, 4, 609967) It is a bad thing.
('54', 266, 1, 5, 609986) 1 What Einstein has said would occur only once in a year and only with a very few people.

('54', 266, 7, 24, 611085) 154. SPEECH AT MEETING IN LAUSANNE 2
('54', 266, 8, 25, 611122) December 8, 1931
('54', 266, 9, 26, 611139) FRIENDS, Let me say how overwhelmed I have felt by the kindness of which I have been the recipient ever since I have been in your beautiful city.
('54', 266, 9, 27, 611285) If earthly beauty can make a paradise, you are indeed living in a paradise.
('54', 266, 9, 28, 611361) I come from a land where God has showered His choicest gift in the shape of earthly beauty.
('54', 266, 9, 29, 611453) There is nothing grander you can find in all the earth than the beauty you can find in the uttermost extremity of India—Travancore—and yet as the train was slowly gliding by your beautiful lake and as we passed the villages so beautifully clean, I could not but be entranced by the sublimity of the
('54', 266, 10, 30, 611752) 1 Some words here are not clear in the source.

('54', 266, 10, 33, 612060) The speech and the answers to questions that followed were translated by Edmond Privat and Prof.
('54', 267, 0, 1, 612157) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 267, 1, 2, 612199) beauty.
('54', 267, 1, 3, 612207) And when I came here, I enjoyed and drank deep the beauty of your affection.
('54', 267, 1, 4, 612284) I could trace your affection in the many searching and relevant questions put to me, where I had heart to heart talks and, now to crown all in this house of God, you have commenced your bombardment by a question which has been occupying me—the whole of my being—for nearly 50 years.
('54', 267, 1, 5, 612567) You have asked me why I consider that God is Truth.
('54', 267, 1, 6, 612619) In my early childhood or youth, I was taught to repeat what in Hindu scriptures is one thousand names of God.
('54', 267, 1, 7, 612729) Among the several little things one of the religious teachers my family had was a little pamphlet which contained these thousand names of God.
('54', 267, 1, 8, 612872) But these thousand names of God were by no means an exhaustive list.
('54', 267, 1, 9, 612941) We believe—and I think it is the truth—that God has as many names as there are creatures and, therefore, we also say that God is nameless and since God has many forms we also consider him formless, and since he speaks to me through many tongues we consider him to be speechless and so on.
('54', 267, 1, 10, 613230) And so when I came to study Islam, I found that Islam too had many names, but I had not come to recognize God for my personal satisfaction as Truth.
('54', 267, 1, 11, 613379) I would say for those who say God is love, God is love.
('54', 267, 1, 12, 613435) But deep down in me I say God may be love, but God is Truth.
('54', 267, 1, 13, 613496) I it is possible for the human tongue to give the fullest description of God, for myself I have come to the conclusion that God is Truth.
('54', 267, 1, 14, 613634) But two years ago I went a step further and said Truth is God.
('54', 267, 1, 15, 613697) You will see the fine distinction between the two statements: God is Truth and Truth is God.
('54', 267, 1, 16, 613790) And that conclusion I came to after a continuous, relentless search after Truth which began so many years ago.
('54', 267, 1, 17, 613901) I found that the nearest approach to Truth is through love.
('54', 267, 1, 18, 613961) But I found also that love has many meanings, in the English language at least, and human love in the sense of passion becomes a degrading thing also.
('54', 267, 1, 19, 614112) I found too that love in the sense of ahimsa an non violence has only limited number of votaries in the world.
('54', 267, 1, 20, 614223) And as I made progress in my search, I made no dispute with “God is love”.
('54', 267, 1, 21, 614298) It is very difficult to understand “God is love” (because of a variety of meanings of love) but I never found a double meaning in connection with Truth and not even atheists have denied the necessity or power of Truth.
('54', 267, 1, 22, 614517) Not only so.
('54', 267, 1, 23, 614530) In their passion for discovering Truth, they have not hesitated even to deny the very existence of God— from their own point of view rightly.
('54', 267, 1, 24, 614672) And it was because of their reasoning that I saw that I was not going to say “God is Truth”, but “Truth is God”.
('54', 267, 1, 25, 614785) Therefore I recall the name of Charles Bradlaugh—a
('54', 268, 0, 1, 614836) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 269
('54', 268, 1, 2, 614882) great Englishman who lived 50 years ago.
('54', 268, 1, 3, 614923) He delighted to call himself an atheist.
('54', 268, 1, 4, 614964) But knowing as I do something of his life.
('54', 268, 1, 5, 615007) I never considered him an atheist.
('54', 268, 1, 6, 615042) I would call him a godfearing man although he would reject the claim, and I know his face would redden.
('54', 268, 1, 7, 615146) I would say: No Mr. Bradlaugh, you are a truth fearing man, not a god fearing man, and I would disarm his criticisms by saying “Truth is God” as I have disarmed criticisms of many a young man.
('54', 268, 1, 8, 615339) Add to this the great difficulty that millions have taken the name of God and have committed nameless atrocities in the name of God.
('54', 268, 1, 9, 615472) Not that scientists do not very often commit cruelties in the name of Truth.
('54', 268, 1, 10, 615549) I know today in the name of Truth and science inhuman cruelties are perpetrated on animals when men perform vivisection.

('54', 277, 4, 14, 637381) 157. SPEECH AT INTERNATIONAL SANATORIUM
('54', 277, 5, 15, 637421) VILLENEUVE, GENEVA, December 9, 1931 It is a matter of joy to me that I am able to make this hurried visit.
('54', 277, 5, 16, 637529) That you are in a beautiful building situated in pleasant surroundings must be a matter of recreation for you.
('54', 277, 5, 17, 637640) As you have very properly remarked, this sanatorium should not be for merely healing the body but for promotion of international friendship.
('54', 277, 5, 18, 637781) After all one finds that healing of the body plays a subordinate part in human experience.
('54', 277, 5, 19, 637872) One may live down injury to the body but not the injury to the soul.
('54', 277, 5, 20, 637941) And so it is a matter of keen joy to me that you are looking after things of the spirit also.
('54', 277, 5, 21, 638035) I wish you many years of service, complete restoration to health and life of the inmates and useful international service thereafter.
('54', 277, 6, 22, 638169) Q. Does psychological influence promote healing?
('54', 277, 7, 23, 638218) A. I am afraid illness will remain with mankind so long as mankind exists.
('54', 277, 7, 24, 638293) But I do believe that at present we are making a fetish of illness.
('54', 277, 7, 25, 638361) If I had my way, I would reduce medical treatment to a minimum.
('54', 277, 7, 26, 638425) I have enforced that rule not only in my life, but in the lives of hundreds of my companions.
('54', 277, 7, 27, 638519) I believe that most of the illnesses we suffer from yield to hygienic treatment and I think that in life, which is beset with dangers, we should count with grave dangers also.
('54', 277, 7, 28, 638695) And this has given us much consolation in illness.
('54', 277, 7, 29, 638746) The rule is: let us not think of having services which millions in all parts of the earth cannot command.
('54', 277, 7, 30, 638852) For instance, the favoured students and professors of medicine can have access to this, but not the millions
('54', 278, 0, 1, 638961) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 279
('54', 278, 1, 2, 639007) who are suffering like you.
('54', 278, 1, 3, 639035) I do not want to say this by way of criticism of the sanatorium, but I do want to say that I am not personally in love with sanatoria like these.
('54', 278, 1, 4, 639181) Therefore I know full well that if millionaires of the earth emptied their wealth it would not be enough to build millions of sanatoria for people needing them.
('54', 278, 1, 5, 639342) In reducing hygienic laws we should reduce them to such proportions that the poorest may observe them in their own lives and their own health.
('54', 278, 1, 6, 639485) That brings us to psychological influence which promotes healing.
('54', 278, 1, 7, 639551) I believe in this to a great extent.
('54', 278, 1, 8, 639588) I believe a healthy mind presupposes a healthy body and, if you are to analyse medical students as you are illnesses that the flesh is heir to, you will find that most are avoidable and mind has a great part to play in creating illness and promoting it.
('54', 278, 1, 9, 639842) Whereas, instead of pampering ourselves, if we were tolerant, we might be able to shed these illnesses.
('54', 278, 1, 10, 639946) This is a subject which, as some of you know, I have been studying or experimenting in as a quack for 35 years.
('54', 278, 1, 11, 640058) I could therefore keep you engaged for hours in reciting my experiences.
('54', 278, 2, 12, 640131) Q. What is the moral significance of manual work?
('54', 278, 2, 13, 640181) A. I think so much of it that in institutions I have founded manual work is a sacred obligation for the inmates and he who does not do manu al work steals food.
('54', 278, 2, 14, 640342) He is not entitled to eat his portion of food, unless he has done sufficient manual work and I have not the slightest shadow of a doubt that when man shirks manual work, he stunts his moral growth.
('54', 278, 2, 15, 640540) I have no doubt that, if we recognize the significance of manual work, many of the monstrosities would die a natural death.
('54', 278, 2, 16, 640664) The law of bread labour was that that man was entitled to bread who worked for it.
('54', 278, 2, 17, 640747) You find that law enunciated by Jesus when he said: thou shalt earn thy bread by the sweat of thy brow; and if this was literally followed, there would be very little illness on earth and little of hideous surroundings on earth.
('54', 278, 3, 18, 640976) Q. Is it not possible to live in Europe without compromise in accordance with your ideas?
('54', 278, 3, 19, 641066) A. Not impossible but difficult.
('54', 278, 3, 20, 641099) But, however difficult the thing may be, it is necessary to make a heroic effort in order to translate the ideal into practice.

('54', 279, 9, 22, 642407) GENEVA, December 10, 1931 I have heard a great deal of the magnificent scenery of your country, but seeing surpasses my expectations and the affection I have received has added to the joy of seeing the scenery of your country.
('54', 279, 9, 23, 642634) I wish I had more time at my disposal to make the ac quaintance of individuals and to see the beautiful spots of this country of yours.
('54', 279, 9, 24, 642770) But I must not detain you by inviting you to share my joy.
('54', 279, 9, 25, 642829) I know that all of you who have come to this meeting have
('54', 279, 10, 26, 642887) 1 From the contents it appears that this letter was written after the death of Abdul Kadir Bawazeer on December 9, 1931. 2 The meeting, which was held during the lunch hour in the Victoria Hall under the auspices of the International Women’s League for Peace and Freedom, was attended by about 2,000 people.

('54', 280, 1, 3, 643355) I want to talk to you about that to which my life is dedicated and that particularly is being tried on a scale not tried on this earth before.
('54', 280, 1, 4, 643498) I refer to the means adopted in India for attaining independence.
('54', 280, 1, 5, 643564) History shows that when a people have been subjugated and desire to get rid of the subjection, they have rebelled and resorted to use of arms.
('54', 280, 1, 6, 643707) In India, on the other hand, we have resorted to means that are scrupulously non violent and peaceful and strangers have testified and I am here to give my testimony that in a great measure we seem to have succeeded in attaining our goal.
('54', 280, 1, 7, 643946) I know that it is still an experiment in making.

('54', 281, 2, 13, 647091) Q. Why did you make such a solemn protest because newspaers had reported you advising soldiers to shoot in the air?
('54', 281, 3, 14, 647207) A. Whether I made a solemn protest I do not know, but I made my position clear.
('54', 281, 3, 15, 647287) I do not want a single soldier, after having taken an oath to serve the army, to mislead the people by shooting in the air.
('54', 281, 3, 16, 647411) I regard myself as a soldier, as a soldier of peace.
('54', 281, 3, 17, 647464) I know the value of discipline and truth and I would consider it unmanly for a soldier who has taken an oath to deny himself the consequences when he defies the order by shooting in the air.
('54', 281, 3, 18, 647655) In my opinion, when a soldier comes to the conclusion that it is inhuman and beneath the dignity of man, he should lay down arms and pay the penalty of insubordination.
('54', 281, 4, 19, 647824) Q. How could workers obtain justice without violence?
('54', 281, 4, 20, 647878) If capitalists use force why should not workers use pressure?
('54', 281, 5, 21, 647940) A. This is the old law, the law of the jungle—blow against blow—and I have told you that I am endeavouring to make this experiment essentially to substitute the law of the jungle, which is foreign to man.
('54', 281, 5, 22, 648145) You may not know that I am supposed to be the chief adviser to a labour union in Ahmedabad, which has
('54', 282, 0, 1, 648247) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 283
('54', 282, 1, 2, 648293) commanded the testimony of labour experts.
('54', 282, 1, 3, 648336) Through this labour union we have been endeavouring to enforce methods of non violence for solving questions arising between the employers and the employed.
('54', 282, 1, 4, 648493) Therefore, what I am now about to tell you is based upon actual experience—in the very line about which the question has been asked.
('54', 282, 1, 5, 648626) In my humble opinion, labour can always vindicate itself provided it is united and self sacrificing.
('54', 282, 1, 6, 648727) No matter how oppressive capitalism may be, I am convinced that those who are connected with labour and guiding labour have no idea of the resources that labour can command and capitalism can never command.
('54', 282, 1, 7, 648934) If labour would only understand and recognize that capital is perfectly helpless without labour, labour would easily come to its own.
('54', 282, 1, 8, 649068) We have unfortunately come under the hypnotic suggestion and influence of capital that capital is all in all on earth.
('54', 282, 1, 9, 649187) But a moment’s thought would show that labour has at its disposal a capital that capitalists never possess.

('54', 282, 2, 22, 650707) 1 For details of the Champaran struggle for the abolition of forced labour on the indigo plantations,

('54', 283, 1, 5, 651126) But I tell you why labour so often fails.

('54', 283, 1, 7, 651358) And therefore the capitalist who is properly entrenched and organized, finding in labour a desire for the same objective, makes use of labour to suppress labour.

('54', 286, 3, 9, 658978) 160. DISCUSSION WITH ROMAIN ROLLAND [On or after December 10, 1931] 2
('54', 286, 4, 10, 659048) Q. Cruelty or wickedness in man is not caused by will, but by morbid taste.
('54', 286, 4, 11, 659124) What would non resistance do to preserve society from these half responsible people?
('54', 286, 5, 12, 659209) A. I do not need to use violence at all.
('54', 286, 5, 13, 659250) But I would need to keep them under restraint.
('54', 286, 5, 14, 659297) I would use some social force.
('54', 286, 5, 15, 659328) I would not call it violence.
('54', 286, 5, 16, 659358) My brother becomes a lunatic and I put irons on his hands.
('54', 286, 5, 17, 659417) There is no use of violence when the motive is lacking.
('54', 286, 5, 18, 659473) Nor would he feel the violence.
('54', 286, 5, 19, 659505) On the contrary, when he comes to his senses, he would thank me for it.
('54', 286, 5, 20, 659577) In his lunacy he would feel the violence, offer resistance to it.
('54', 286, 5, 21, 659643) I would not mind the resistance because my action would be dictated by unadulterated love; there is not even the selfishness of loving behind it.
('54', 286, 5, 22, 659789) If I am tying his hands, it is not in order to save myself from being hurt.
('54', 286, 5, 23, 659865) If I felt that I should hurt myself by trying to save him, I should subject myself to being hurt.
('54', 286, 5, 24, 659963) In the same way I should treat these half crazy men, treat them as sick men, put them in an infirmary and put them [not] under heartless jailors but under medical men who have studied their conditions and surround them by kind nurses.
('54', 286, 5, 25, 660198) That is only dealing with the system.
('54', 286, 6, 26, 660236) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('54', 286, 6, 27, 660282) Courtesy: Narayan Desai.
('54', 286, 7, 28, 660307) 1 St. Mark VIII, 35 and St. Luke IX.
('54', 286, 8, 29, 660344) 2 The source mentions no date, but this was recorded after the meeting in Geneva on December 10.

('54', 287, 1, 2, 660483) 161. INTERVIEW TO SUKHOTINA TOLSTOY 1
('54', 287, 2, 3, 660521) ROME, [December 13, 1931] 2
('54', 287, 3, 4, 660549) SUKHOTINA TOLSTOY: I have been long looking forward to an opportunity of meeting you.
('54', 287, 3, 5, 660635) If my father had been alive, he would have been delighted to hear of your non violent battle for freedom.
('54', 287, 4, 6, 660741) GANDHIJI: I am sure.
('54', 287, 4, 7, 660762) And are you the daughter who wrote that famous letter 3 of your father to me?
('54', 287, 5, 8, 660840) That was another daughter, a fact which led to inquiry about Tolstoy’s children.
('54', 287, 6, 9, 660921) S. T. Six of us are still living.
('54', 287, 6, 10, 660955) The two daughters accept my father’s principles, but the four sons do not.
('54', 287, 6, 11, 661030) You know my father allowed every one of us the fullest liberty of thought and action and, whilst these brothers of mine revered my father, they were not prepared to accept his principles.
('54', 287, 7, 12, 661218) I was a friend of Romain Rolland.
('54', 287, 7, 13, 661252) G. Why was?
('54', 287, 7, 14, 661264) Are you not a friend now?
('54', 287, 8, 15, 661290) S. T. No, I used to be a great friend of his until two years ago.
('54', 287, 8, 16, 661356) He wrote to me fairly frequently and I also used to write to him.
('54', 287, 8, 17, 661422) G. But now ?
('54', 287, 9, 18, 661435) S. T. But now I find that he is in sympathy with Bolshevism and Bolshevik methods.
('54', 287, 9, 19, 661518) I do not quarrel with their goal, but their doctrine that the end justifies the means seems to me to be frightful.
('54', 287, 9, 20, 661633) How can Romain Rolland, a believer in non violence, have any sympathy with them?
('54', 287, 9, 21, 661714) G. Supposing what you say is true, is it not all the more necessary that you should write to him and tell him what you feel about his views?
('54', 287, 9, 22, 661855) Don’t you as a friend of two years ago owe it to him to write freely and fully?
('54', 287, 9, 23, 661935) After all, he is the one true and honest man in Europe after Tolstoy.
('54', 287, 9, 24, 662005) Like your father he is old, worn out, and unhappy over the tendencies of the present age and he has your father’s childlike simplicity of never taking correction amiss, no matter whether it came from a wise man or a fool.
('54', 287, 10, 25, 662227) S. T. I know that he is all that.
('54', 287, 10, 26, 662261) In the War he was the only man who stood out bravely against it and he has the same bravery even now.
('54', 287, 10, 27, 662363) I also know that he has written the best book on my father that has ever been written.
('54', 287, 10, 28, 662450) But somehow I have hesitated, I actually wrote a letter, but never posted it.
('54', 287, 10, 29, 662528) If you like, I shall post it now.
('54', 287, 11, 30, 662562) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Letter from Europe”.
('54', 287, 11, 31, 662617) 2 According to an entry under this date in “Diary, 1931” 3 Vide “Tolstoy’s Letter to Gandhiji”, 7 10 1909
('54', 288, 0, 1, 662723) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 289
('54', 288, 1, 2, 662769) G. Do I want you to do so.
('54', 288, 2, 3, 662796) S. T. Then I will say that you asked me to do so.
('54', 288, 2, 4, 662846) G. Yes, you may.
('54', 288, 2, 5, 662863) I shall also write to him?
('54', 288, 4, 6, 662890) Young India, 14 1 1932
('54', 288, 5, 7, 662913) 162. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, ROME
('54', 288, 7, 8, 662950) [December 13, 1931]
('54', 288, 9, 9, 662970) The beauty of non violent war is that women can play the same
('54', 288, 10, 10, 663032) part in it as men.
('54', 288, 10, 11, 663051) In a violent war the women have no such part in it as men.
('54', 288, 10, 12, 663110) In a violent war the women have no such privilege, and the Indian women played a more effective part in our last non violent war than men.
('54', 288, 10, 13, 663249) The reason is simple.
('54', 288, 10, 14, 663271) Non Violent war calls into play suffering to the largest extent, and who can suffer more purely and nobly than women?
('54', 288, 10, 15, 663389) The women in India tore down the purdah and came forward to work for the nation.
('54', 288, 10, 16, 663470) They saw that the country demanded something more than their looking after their homes.
('54', 288, 10, 17, 663558) They manufactured contraband salt, they picketed foreign cloth shops and liquor shops, and tried to wean both the seller and the customer from both.
('54', 288, 10, 18, 663707) At late hours in the night, they pursued the drunkards to their dens with courage and charity in their hearts.
('54', 288, 10, 19, 663818) They marched to jails and they sustained lathi blows as few men did.
('54', 288, 10, 20, 663887) If the women of the West will try to vie with men in becoming brutes, they have no lesson to learn from the women of India.
('54', 288, 10, 21, 664011) They will have to cease to take de light in sending their husbands and sons to kill people and congrat ulate them on their valour.
('54', 288, 11, 22, 664142) Young India, 14 1 1932

('54', 290, 10, 12, 665970) 1 Sir Samuel Hoare, later Viscount Templewood, in his Nine Troubled Years (Collins, 1954), says that when he heard the report of “a fictitious interview” Gandhiji was said to have given to Gayda of Giornale d’ Italia, he was so “horrified and amazed” that he at once telegraphed for its confirmation.
('54', 290, 10, 13, 666271) “The answer came”, says Templewood, “from Gandhi himself, to the effect that he had made no such statement, and that the reported interview was a fake.” Presumably the answer in question was this cable.
('54', 290, 10, 14, 666474) The cable which had beeen sent to Gandhiji “from an authoritative quarter” according to a Times report was as follows: ‘Press reports state that, on embarkation, you issued to Giornale d’ Italia a statement which contained expressions such as following: (1) Round Table Conference marked definite rupture of relations between Indian nation and British Government.
('54', 290, 10, 15, 666838) (2) You are returning to India in order to restart at once struggle against England.
('54', 290, 10, 16, 666923) (3) Boycott would now prove powerful means of rendering more acute British crisis.
('54', 290, 10, 17, 667006) (4) We will not pay taxes, we will not work for England in any way, we will completely isolate British authorities, their politics and their institutions, and we will totally boycott all British goods.’ Some of your friends here think you must have been misreported and, if so , denial desirable.” Notwithstanding Gandhiji’s disclaimer, Gayda persisted in his claim that the interview was genuine.
('54', 290, 10, 18, 667404) Gandhiji repeated this disclaimer in 1934 when he was again asked about the interview.

('54', 292, 5, 11, 669255) 170. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('54', 292, 6, 12, 669297) WHILE NEARING ADEN, December 17, 1931
('54', 292, 7, 13, 669335) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I have been getting from you occasionally, not letters exactly, but little notes.
('54', 292, 7, 14, 669438) As I myself did not write often, I cannot blame you.
('54', 292, 7, 15, 669491) However, there were strong reasons for my not being able to write.
('54', 292, 7, 16, 669558) In London, I could neither sleep nor have regular meals.
('54', 292, 7, 17, 669615) I used to carry my tiffin with me and ate wherever I could.
('54', 292, 7, 18, 669675) This time I seldom wrote to anybody and, as for writing for Young India and Navajivan, I had to stop it altogether.
('54', 292, 7, 19, 669791) You had no excuse for not writing to me or writing only brief notes.
('54', 292, 7, 20, 669860) But the saying that habits die hard is true in your case.
('54', 292, 7, 21, 669918) There is, however, another saying which applies to people who are prepared to try hard: “A mere string can make a dent in a black, strong, stone.” What, then, cannot one achieve with effort ?
('54', 292, 7, 22, 670110) We entered the Red Sea today.
('54', 292, 7, 23, 670140) There are nine of us.
('54', 292, 7, 24, 670162) All of us are deck passengers.
('54', 292, 7, 25, 670193) Deck passengers get no amenities worth the name.
('54', 292, 7, 26, 670242) But we have everything we require and so need not worry.
('54', 292, 7, 27, 670299) I mention this merely to describe the conditions on the deck.
('54', 292, 7, 28, 670361) We shall reach Bombay on the 28th.
('54', 292, 7, 29, 670396) Let us see what happens when we arrive there.
('54', 292, 7, 30, 670442) If the struggle starts again, you need not think you have to come away immediately 1. First watch what form the struggle takes and then come.
('54', 292, 7, 31, 670584) Do not come until you have been able

('54', 295, 4, 8, 673678) 174. LETTER TO MADELEINE ROLLAND
('54', 295, 5, 9, 673711) S. S. “PILSNA”, December 20, 1931
('54', 295, 6, 10, 673745) DEAR SISTER,
('54', 295, 7, 11, 673758) what shall I say of you and your good brother’s affection for me?
('54', 295, 7, 12, 673824) The visit to Villeneuve was truly a pilgrimage for me.
('54', 295, 7, 13, 673879) I wish I could have stayed longer than I did.
('54', 295, 7, 14, 673925) However, the memory of the few days’ communion with you will be among my richest treasures.
('54', 295, 7, 15, 674017) Now one word about your brother’s health.
('54', 295, 7, 16, 674059) You must shed the fear of fresh air, no matter of what season it is.
('54', 295, 7, 17, 674128) If damp air is feared, a drier region has to be chosen.
('54', 295, 7, 18, 674184) The artificial drying does no good at all unless one uses most expensive machinery for continuous drying of continuously admitted fresh air.
('54', 295, 7, 19, 674325) They do this in the British House of Commons, I am told.
('54', 295, 7, 20, 674382) But I feel sure that if you keep the windows continually open in the unused part of the room, it can do no harm.
('54', 295, 7, 21, 674495) As it is, you are not getting the benefit of the magnificent air of Villeneuve.
('54', 295, 7, 22, 674575) I have now done.
('54', 295, 7, 23, 674592) You will pardon this writing prompted by love.
('54', 295, 7, 24, 674639) You will now write freely and fully whatever you feel.

('54', 296, 1, 2, 674883) 175. LETTER TO ROMAIN ROLLAND
('54', 296, 2, 3, 674913) S. S. "PILSNA", December 20, 1931
('54', 296, 3, 4, 674947) DEAR FRIEND AND BROTHER, I beg you to write to the daughter of Tolstoy and satisfy her curio sity concerning Bolshevism.
('54', 296, 3, 5, 675068) 1 The General and Mrs. Moris were extremely kind to us all.
('54', 296, 3, 6, 675128) We felt as if we were one of the family as soon as we entered the house.
('54', 296, 3, 7, 675201) Mussolini is a riddle to me.
('54', 296, 3, 8, 675230) Many of his reforms attract me.
('54', 296, 3, 9, 675262) He seems to have done much for the peasant class.
('54', 296, 3, 10, 675312) I admit an iron hand is there.
('54', 296, 3, 11, 675343) But as violence is the basis of Western society, Mussolini’s refor ms deserve an impartial study.
('54', 296, 3, 12, 675441) His care of the poor, his opposition to super urbanization, his efforts to bring about co ordination between capital and labour, seem to me to demand special attention.
('54', 296, 3, 13, 675610) I would like you to enli ghten me on these matters.
('54', 296, 3, 14, 675662) My own fundamental objection is that these reforms are compulsory.
('54', 296, 3, 15, 675729) But it is the same in all democratic institutions.
('54', 296, 3, 16, 675780) What strikes me is that behind Mussolini’s implacability is a desire to serve is people.
('54', 296, 3, 17, 675869) Even behind his emphatic speeches there is a nucleus of sincerity and of passionate love for his people.
('54', 296, 3, 18, 675974) It also seems to me that the majority of Italian people love the iron government of Mussolini.
('54', 296, 3, 19, 676069) I do not wish that you should take the trouble of replying to me immediately.
('54', 296, 3, 20, 676147) Take your time, I beg of you.
('54', 296, 3, 21, 676177) It is not necessary to say that I do not propose to write publicly on this subject at this moment.
('54', 296, 3, 22, 676276) I have simply put these questions before you as before someone who knows infinitely more than I do about the subject, and now I think, if you come during the cold season between January and March, you can easily bear the climate and probably derive some good out of it.
('54', 296, 3, 23, 676546) You can certainly come by air, but I would rather you came by sea.
('54', 296, 3, 24, 676613) If you take up this proposition seriously, an eventual programme can be submitted to you.
('54', 296, 3, 25, 676703) With deep love, Yours,

('54', 297, 6, 8, 677186) 177. THE INDIAN ARMY [December 21, 1931 ] 1
('54', 297, 7, 9, 677230) However honest the Prime Minister’s declaration on the closing day of the Round Table Conference was, it fell far short of the national demand, and hence was utterly unacceptable if there was no room for expansion.
('54', 297, 7, 10, 677445) And yet the pity of it is that it represents the English mind.
('54', 297, 7, 11, 677508) The true test of responsibility is control of Defence and Finance .
('54', 297, 7, 12, 677576) The declaration is unequivocal about both these matters.
('54', 297, 7, 13, 677633) There is to be no Indian control, certainly not of Defence, and virtually not of Finance.
('54', 297, 7, 14, 677723) The reason for this extraordinary state of affairs is the great ignorance that prevails in England about India.
('54', 297, 7, 15, 677835) Many of the best Englishmen believe that we are incapable of defending ourselves or managing our Finance.
('54', 297, 7, 16, 677941) If this is so, we are certainly far away from the Complete Independence we want.
('54', 297, 7, 17, 678022) But I claim that we are quite able to look after our own Defence and Finance.
('54', 297, 7, 18, 678100) What is the army in India ?
('54', 297, 7, 19, 678128) Roughly, it consists of sixty thousand British soldiers and a hundred and sixty thousand Indian soldiers—all hirelings.
('54', 297, 7, 20, 678248) Indian soldiers are chosen for their being devoid of any national instinct whatever.
('54', 297, 7, 21, 678333) They are almost trained to regard themselves as foreigners who should look down upon the
('54', 297, 8, 22, 678422) 1 According to an entry in “Diary, 1931” Gandhiji wrote an article for The Indian News (Which, from 1932,changed to The India Review) on this date .
('54', 297, 8, 23, 678571) Presumably this was the article.
('54', 298, 0, 1, 678604) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 299
('54', 298, 1, 2, 678650) ordinary citizen with whom they have nothing in common.
('54', 298, 1, 3, 678706) The whole of this army is used for external aggression, and the protection of British interests and British lives within Indian borders.
('54', 298, 1, 4, 678843) This army I regard as a menace, within, to nationalism, and without, to the independence of India’s neighbours.
('54', 298, 1, 5, 678955) Surely India managed somehow to live and to preserve her culture before the British advent.
('54', 298, 1, 6, 679047) India’s defence lies in the cultivation of friendly relations with her neighbours and her ability to resist, through non violent non co operation, her exploitation by any nation.
('54', 298, 1, 7, 679226) The first act of a National Government should be to disband this menace, unless it were reduced to manageable proportions and the control handed honourably and peacefully to the National Govern ment by the British Government.
('54', 298, 1, 8, 679452) This is the least expiation the British Government owe to the people of India for having brought into being an army designed to crush their legitimate aspirations.
('54', 298, 1, 9, 679616) Should the British Government not see the obvious duty of doing this elementary thing, the Nationalist Party must continue to fight till hard experience had demonstrated the necessity.
('54', 298, 1, 10, 679801) The Indian Army of the future will not be mercenary but voluntary, and largely in the nature of police.
('54', 298, 1, 11, 679905) But the British people have been taught to think that the army in India is the crowning act of British rule for which India should be for ever thankful.
('54', 298, 1, 12, 680058) The Editor of The Indian Review has to dispel this colossal ignorance by hard study of facts and figures showing how the army is composed and how, from its conception, it has been used for the spoliation of India and her neighbours.
('54', 298, 1, 13, 680291) The India Review, 16 1 1932

('54', 299, 1, 2, 680657) You have said that the movement in India was not kept to the high level at which it was kept in South Africa.
('54', 299, 1, 3, 680767) My own experience and opinion are to the contrary.
('54', 299, 1, 4, 680818) You have instanced the consideration shown to the South Africa Government when it was in distress.
('54', 299, 1, 5, 680917) The instance is not to the point.
('54', 299, 1, 6, 680951) In South Africa there was no question of displacing the Government.
('54', 299, 1, 7, 681019) Therefore when European movement to displace the Government took place, as satyagrahis, Indians were bound not to join the insurgents.
('54', 299, 1, 8, 681154) In India the movement is to displace the Government.

('54', 301, 4, 12, 684691) 181. A RETROSPECT [December 23, 1931 ] 1
('54', 301, 5, 13, 684732) Never since taking up the editorship of Young India have I, though not being on a sickbed or in a prison, been unable to send something for Young India or Navajivan, as I was during my stay in London.
('54', 301, 5, 14, 684933) The uninterrupted series of engagements keeping me awake till over midnight made it physically impossible for me to write anything for these journals.
('54', 301, 5, 15, 685084) Fortunately, Mahadev Desai was with me and though he too was overworked, he was able to send a full weekly budget for Young India.
('54', 301, 5, 16, 685215) Nevertheless the reader will expect me to give my own impressions of the London visit.
('54', 301, 5, 17, 685302) Though I approached the visit in fear and trembling, I am not sorry for having gone there.
('54', 301, 5, 18, 685393) It brought me in touch with the responsible Englishmen and women as also with the man in the street.
('54', 301, 5, 19, 685494) This experience will be of inestimable value in future, whether we have to put up a fight again or not .
('54', 301, 5, 20, 685599) It is no small matter to know with whom you are fighting or dealing.
('54', 301, 5, 21, 685668) It was a good thing that Muriel Lester, the soul of Kingsley Hall settlement, invited me to stay at her settlement and that I was able to accept the invitation.
('54', 301, 5, 22, 685829) The choice lay between Kinglsey Hall and Mr. Birla’s Arya Bhavan.
('54', 301, 5, 23, 685895) I had no difficulty in making my choice nor had Mr. Birla.
('54', 301, 5, 24, 685954) But great pressure was put upon me by Indian friends, and that naturally, to stay at Arya Bhavan.
('54', 301, 5, 25, 686052) Experience
('54', 301, 6, 26, 686063) 1 The date is inferred from the entry under this date in “Diary,1931”.
('54', 302, 0, 1, 686134) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 303
('54', 302, 1, 2, 686180) showed that Kingsley Hall was an ideal choice.
('54', 302, 1, 3, 686227) It is situated among the poor of London and is dedicated purely to their service.
('54', 302, 1, 4, 686309) Several women and some men, under the inspiration of Muriel Lester, have dedicated themselves to such service.
('54', 302, 1, 5, 686420) Not a corner of the big building is used for any other purpose.
('54', 302, 1, 6, 686484) There is religious service, there are entertainments, there are lectures, billiards, reading room, etc., for the use of the poor.
('54', 302, 1, 7, 686614) The inmates live a life of severe simplicity.
('54', 302, 1, 8, 686660) There is no superfluous furniture to be found in all that settlement.
('54', 302, 1, 9, 686730) The inmates occupy tiny rooms called cells.
('54', 302, 1, 10, 686774) It was no joke to accommodate five of us in that settlement.
('54', 302, 1, 11, 686835) But love makes room where there is none.
('54', 302, 1, 12, 686876) Four settlers vacated their cells which were placed at our disposal.
('54', 302, 1, 13, 686945) Bedding, etc., had to be borrowed.
('54', 302, 1, 14, 686980) Fortunately,we had all armed ourselves with sufficient blankets and, being used to squat on the floor, most of the articles borrowed could be returned.
('54', 302, 1, 15, 687132) But, there was no doubt, my presence at the settlement put a severe tax on its times, space and other resources.
('54', 302, 1, 16, 687245) But the good people would not hear of my leaving it.
('54', 302, 1, 17, 687298) And to me it was a privilege to receive the loving, silent and unseen services of the members and a perennial joy to come in vital contact with the poor of the East End of London.
('54', 302, 1, 18, 687478) Needless to say I was able to live exactly s in India, and early morning walks through the streets of East London are a memory that can never be effaced.
('54', 302, 1, 19, 687632) During these walks I had most intimate talks with those members who joined me and others whom Muriel allowed.
('54', 302, 1, 20, 687742) For she was a vigilant guardian of my time whilst I was in the settlement .
('54', 302, 1, 21, 687818) And she would get easily angry if she heard that my time was being abused by people when she was not by me.
('54', 302, 1, 22, 687926) During my stay in East London, I saw the best side of human nature and was able to confirm my intuitive opinion that at bottom there was neither East nor West.
('54', 302, 1, 23, 688086) And as I received the smiling greetings of the East Enders, I knew that they had no malice in them and they wanted India to regain her independence.
('54', 302, 1, 24, 688235) This experience has brought me closer to England if such a thing was possible.
('54', 302, 1, 25, 688314) For me the fight is never with individuals, it is ever with their manners and their measures.
('54', 302, 1, 26, 688408) But this intimate contact with the simple poor people of the East End, including the little children, will put me still more on my guard against any hasty action.
('54', 302, 1, 27, 688571) I may not omit my all too brief experience of Lancashire and its operatives and employers whom, to my agreeable surprise, I found to be so free from prejudice and receptive of new facts and arguments drawn from them.
('54', 302, 1, 28, 688788) Here, of course, the ground was prepared for me by
('54', 303, 0, 1, 688839) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 303, 1, 2, 688881) Charlie Andrews.
('54', 303, 1, 3, 688898) I must mention too the never to be forgotten visit to Mr. C. P. Scott of the Manchester Guardian, the most impartial and the most honest paper in Great Britain.
('54', 303, 1, 4, 689059) A great British statesman told me the Guardian was the sanest and the most honest journal in the world.
('54', 303, 1, 5, 689163) Nor can I easily forget the communions at Canterbury, Chichester, Oxford, Cambridge and Eton.
('54', 303, 1, 6, 689257) They gave me an insight into the working of the British mind which I could have got through no other means.
('54', 303, 1, 7, 689365) These contacts have brought about friendships which will endure for ever.
('54', 303, 1, 8, 689439) I do not omit the two detectives and their companions and the many constables who were told off to look after me.
('54', 303, 1, 9, 689553) To me Sergeants Evans and Rogers, the two detectives, were no mere police officers.
('54', 303, 1, 10, 689637) They became my trusty guides and friends looking after my comforts with the punctilious care of loving nurses.
('54', 303, 1, 11, 689748) And it was a matter of great joy to me that they were permitted at my request to accompany me as far as Brindisi.
('54', 303, 1, 12, 689862) Last, but not least, was my pilgrimage to Romain Rolland, the sage of Villeneuve.
('54', 303, 1, 13, 689944) Could I have left India just to visit him and his inseparable sister Madeleine, his interpreter and friend, I would have undertaken the voyage.
('54', 303, 1, 14, 690088) But that could not be.

('54', 303, 1, 16, 690223) And I was able to see something of that great and ancient city and Mussolini, the un questioned dictator of Italy.

('54', 303, 1, 19, 690550) I saw there at once that nations like individuals could only be made through the agony of the Cross and in no other way.
('54', 303, 1, 20, 690671) Joy comes not out of infliction of pain on others, but out of pain voluntarily borne by oneself.
('54', 303, 1, 21, 690768) II I am, therefore, returning home not filled with disappointment but with hope enriched.
('54', 303, 1, 22, 690858) This hope is based on the fact that what I saw in England and on the Continent not only did not shake my faith in truth and non violence, but, on the contrary, strongly confirmed it.
('54', 303, 1, 23, 691041) I found, too, many more kindred spirits that I had expected.
('54', 303, 1, 24, 691102) Of the Round Table Conference there is nothing new I can report.
('54', 303, 1, 25, 691167) I spoke out plainly what I thought about its composition and its achievements.
('54', 303, 1, 26, 691246) One thing, however, I would like to say here.
('54', 303, 1, 27, 691292) It would be wrong to think that the British Ministers are humbugs and
('54', 304, 0, 1, 691362) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 305
('54', 304, 1, 2, 691408) that they do not mean what they say.
('54', 304, 1, 3, 691445) I have come away with the impression that they are honest in their professions but they are labouring under a heavy handicap.
('54', 304, 1, 4, 691571) The delegates, whilst seemingly unanimous over fundamentals, betrayed amazing differences on details of fundamental importance.
('54', 304, 1, 5, 691699) The minorities, question became a hopeless tangle, not wholly through the fault of the Ministers.
('54', 304, 1, 6, 691797) But, after all, this was a temporary handicap.
('54', 304, 1, 7, 691844) Their greatest handicap lay in their being spoonfed on one sided and often hopelessly false statements and anti nationalist opinions received by them from their agents in India ever since the commencement of the British Raj.
('54', 304, 1, 8, 692069) For the Ministers this information is generally gospel truth.
('54', 304, 1, 9, 692131) They, therefore, believe us to be incapable of handling our own Defence and Finance, they believe that the presence of British troops and British civilians is necessary for the well being of India.
('54', 304, 1, 10, 692329) Perhaps, there is no nation on earth equal to the British in the capacity for self deception.
('54', 304, 1, 11, 692423) In confirmation of what I am writing, I would commend to the reader the speech delivered by Sir Samuel Hoare at the House of Commons at the debate on the White Paper.
('54', 304, 1, 12, 692590) In spite of warnings to the contrary, each time I saw the Secretary of State for India I came away with a higher opinion of his honesty and frankness.
('54', 304, 1, 13, 692741) Of all the British Ministers If found him to be the most straightforward and frank.
('54', 304, 1, 14, 692825) He is also a strong man, but he is a hard man.
('54', 304, 1, 15, 692872) I believe him to be capable of advising or approving of ruthless repression and of hitting the hardest.
('54', 304, 1, 16, 692976) And he would honestly think that he was merciful even as a surgeon is merciful who applies the knife when he must with a steady and strong hand.
('54', 304, 1, 17, 693121) This Secretary of State is a hard working conscientious man who would slave away even though he might have a temperature.
('54', 304, 1, 18, 693243) He knows his mind at a given moment.
('54', 304, 1, 19, 693280) He has behind him all the British parties and the large majority known in modern British history.
('54', 304, 1, 20, 693378) His speech, therefore, is the best British type.
('54', 304, 1, 21, 693427) And yet it falls hopelessly short of the Congress demand and is based, as Congressmen would say, on utterly wrong data which unfortunately he believes in common with many honest British statesmen.
('54', 304, 1, 22, 693624) How can this British mentality be changed or, in other words, how can power be wrested from such unwilling hands?
('54', 304, 1, 23, 693738) No argument will carry conviction to these statesmen; they are all seasoned hard headed soldiers.
('54', 304, 1, 24, 693836) They like and appreciate facts, deeds.
('54', 304, 1, 25, 693875) They will understand an open rebellion and, if they cannot suppress it, they will at once admit that we are capable of defending ourselves and administering our own affairs.
('54', 304, 1, 26, 694049) And I have come away with my view
('54', 305, 0, 1, 694083) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 305, 1, 2, 694125) confirmed that they will also understand and perhaps more quickly appreciate a non violent rebellion.
('54', 305, 1, 3, 694227) But the unfortunate fact is that they do not believe in our cooporate non violence.
('54', 305, 1, 4, 694311) And, what is more, they believe that corporate non violence on a mass scale is impossible.
('54', 305, 1, 5, 694402) No argument can remove this disbelief.
('54', 305, 1, 6, 694441) Only actual experience can induce faith.
('54', 305, 1, 7, 694482) Nor do they believe that the Congress is really the party that can deliver the goods.
('54', 305, 1, 8, 694568) Even General Smuts could not convince them that the Congress was such a party.
('54', 305, 1, 9, 694647) How could he in the teeth of reports of the contrary from their agents in India?
('54', 305, 1, 10, 694728) Thus it appears to me that a further fiery ordeal is a necessity of the case.
('54', 305, 1, 11, 694806) The British mind is not ready for anything radically more than the Prime Minister’s declaration.
('54', 305, 1, 12, 694903) III But I can come to no hasty conclusion.
('54', 305, 1, 13, 694946) This is being written on 23rd December on s.s.
('54', 305, 1, 14, 694993) Pilsna in ignorance of the situtation in India.
('54', 305, 1, 15, 695041) I do not know what possibilities there still are for further negotiation.
('54', 305, 1, 16, 695115) Nor do I know how far the situation in Bengal, United Provinces, Gujarat, and the South permits of peaceful negotiations.
('54', 305, 1, 17, 695237) This much is clearer to me than ever before that our true battleground is not London, it is India.
('54', 305, 1, 18, 695336) We have to convert not the British Minister but the British civilians in India.
('54', 305, 1, 19, 695416) The strongest Secretary of State for India cannot move much beyond the advice of his local agents.
('54', 305, 1, 20, 695515) India Office is a clog on the wheel of India’s progress.
('54', 305, 1, 21, 695572) The real power resides in the 250 District Collectors, not even in the Viceroy.
('54', 305, 1, 22, 695652) These Collectors have powers nowhere enjoyed on earth even by real dictators.
('54', 305, 1, 23, 695730) The latter do not have behind them the machinery of a mighty Government which the Collectors can move at will.
('54', 305, 1, 24, 695841) But thus stated the problem becomes incredibly simple.
('54', 305, 1, 25, 695896) Each district has the key to the situation in its own hands.
('54', 305, 1, 26, 695957) We have to work out our own salvation in India by negotiation if at all possible, by direct action if it becomes imperatively necessary.
('54', 305, 1, 27, 696094) I know that I shall not light heartedly invite the nation to the ordeal, nor shall I hesitate, if I find no way out, to advise action.
('54', 305, 1, 28, 696229) I shall strain every nerve to discover a way out.
('54', 305, 2, 29, 696279) Young India, 31 12 1931

('54', 306, 15, 14, 696694) I have never been able to reconcile myself to the gaieties of the Christmas season.
('54', 306, 15, 15, 696778) They have appeared to me to be so inconsistent with the life and teaching of Jesus.
('54', 306, 15, 16, 696862) How I wish America could lead the way by devoting the season to a real moral stock taking and emphasizing consecration to the service of mankind for which Jesus lived and died on the Cross.
('54', 306, 16, 17, 697052) From a photostat: S.N. 18411
