('54', 307, 0, 1, 697503) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 307, 1, 2, 697545) 185. TALK ON BOARD s.s.“PILSNA” 1
('54', 307, 2, 3, 697579) December 25, 1931 I shall tell you how, to an outsider like me, the story of Christ, as told in the New Testament, has struck.
('54', 307, 2, 4, 697706) My acquain tance with the Bible began nearly forty five years ago, and that was through the New Testament.
('54', 307, 2, 5, 697813) I could not then take much interest in the Old Testament, which I had certainly read, if only to fulfil a promise I had made to a friend whom I happened to meet in a hotel.
('54', 307, 2, 6, 697986) But when I came to the New Testament and the Sermon on the Mount, I began to understand the Christian teaching, and the teaching of the Sermon on the Mount echoed something I had learnt in childhood nad something which seemed to be part of my being and which I felt was being acted up to in the daily life around me.
('54', 307, 2, 7, 698303) I say it seemed to be acted up to, meaning thereby that it was not necessary for my purpose that they were actually living the life.
('54', 307, 2, 8, 698436) This teaching was non retaliation, or non resistance to evil.
('54', 307, 2, 9, 698498) Of all the things I read what remained with me for ever was that Jesus came almost to give a new law—though He of course had said He had not come to give a new law, but tack something on to the Old Mosaic law.
('54', 307, 2, 10, 698708) Well, He changed it so that it became a new law—not an eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth, but to be ready to receive two blows when one was given, and to go two miles when you were asked to go one.
('54', 307, 2, 11, 698912) I said to myself, “This is what one learns in one’s childhood.
('54', 307, 2, 12, 698975) Surely this is not Christianity.” For, all I had then been given to understand was that to be a Christian was to have a brandy bottle in one hand and beef in the other.
('54', 307, 2, 13, 699144) The Sermon on the Mount, however, falsified the impression.
('54', 307, 2, 14, 699204) As my contact with real Christians, i.e., men living in fear of God, increased, I saw that the Sermon on the Mount was the whole of Christianity for him who wanted to live a Christian life.
('54', 307, 2, 15, 699394) It is that Sermon which has endeared Jesus to me.
('54', 307, 2, 16, 699444) I may say that I have never been interested in a historical Jesus.
('54', 307, 2, 17, 699511) I should not care if it was proved by someone that the man called Jesus never lived, and that what was narrated in the Gospels was a figment of the writer’s imagination.
('54', 307, 2, 18, 699681) For the Sermon on the Mount would still be true for me.
('54', 307, 3, 19, 699737) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report: “The Jesus I Love”.
('54', 307, 3, 20, 699798) The talk was given at 4.30 a.m.
('54', 307, 3, 21, 699830) Half a dozen persons attended.
('54', 308, 0, 1, 699861) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 309
('54', 308, 1, 2, 699907) Reading, therefore, the whole story in that light, it seems to me that Christianity has yet to be lived, unless one says that where there is boundless love and no idea of retaliation whatsoever, it is Christianity that lives.
('54', 308, 1, 3, 700133) But then it surmounts all boundaries and book teaching.
('54', 308, 1, 4, 700189) Then it is something indefinable, not capable of being preached to men, not capable of being transmitted from mouth to mouth, but from heart to heart.
('54', 308, 1, 5, 700340) But Christianity is not commonly understood in that way.
('54', 308, 1, 6, 700397) Somehow, in God’s providence, the Bible has been preserved from destruction by the Christians, so called.
('54', 308, 1, 7, 700503) The British and Foreign Bible Society has had it translated into many languages.
('54', 308, 1, 8, 700584) All that may serve a real purpose in the time to come.
('54', 308, 1, 9, 700639) Two thousand years in the life of a living faith may be nothing.
('54', 308, 1, 10, 700704) For though we sang, “All glory to God on high and on the earth be peace,” there seems to be today neither glory to God nor peace on earth.
('54', 308, 1, 11, 700843) As long as it remains a hunger still unsatisfied, as long as Christ is not yet born, we have to look forward to Him.
('54', 308, 1, 12, 700960) When real peace is established, we will not need demonstrations, but it will be echoed in our life, not only in individual life, but in corporate life.
('54', 308, 1, 13, 701112) Then we shall say Christ is born.
('54', 308, 1, 14, 701146) That to me is the real meaning of the verse we have sung.
('54', 308, 1, 15, 701204) 1 Then we will not think of a particular day in the year as that of the birth of Christ, but as an ever recurring event which can be enacted in every life.
('54', 308, 1, 16, 701360) And the more I think of fundamental religion, and the more I think of miraculous conceptions of so many teachers who have come down from age to age and clime to clime, the more I see that there is behind them the eternal truth that I have narrated.
('54', 308, 1, 17, 701609) That needs no label or declaration.
('54', 308, 1, 18, 701645) It consists in the living of life, never ceasing, ever progressing towards peace.
('54', 308, 1, 19, 701727) When, therefore, one wishes “A Happy Christmas” without the meaning behind it, it becomes nothing more than an empty formula.
('54', 308, 1, 20, 701853) And unless one wishes for peace for all life, one cannot wish for peace for oneself.
('54', 308, 1, 21, 701938) It is a self evident axiom, like the axioms of Euclid, that one cannot have peace unless there is in one an intense longing for peace all round.
('54', 308, 1, 22, 702083) You may certainly experience peace in the midst of strife, but that happens only when to remove strife you destroy your whole life, you crucify yourself.
('54', 308, 2, 23, 702237) 1 The proceedings had opened with the singing of a hymn celebrating Christ’s Nativity: “While shepherds watched their flocks by night.”
('54', 309, 0, 1, 702373) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 309, 1, 2, 702415) And so, as the miraculous birth is an eternal event, so is the Cross an eternal event in this stormy life.
('54', 309, 1, 3, 702522) Therefore, we dare not think of birth without death on the Cross.
('54', 309, 1, 4, 702588) Living Christ means a living Cross.
('54', 309, 1, 5, 702624) Without it life is a living death.
('54', 309, 1, 6, 702659) Young India, 31 12 1931
('54', 309, 2, 7, 702683) 186. NOTES
('54', 309, 3, 8, 702694) THE LATE IMAM SAHEB In the death of Imam Saheb Abdul Kadir Bawazeer, I have lost an old friend and co worker, Inida has lost a sincere worker and Islam a gem.
('54', 309, 3, 9, 702853) Who does not know of Imam Saheb’s courage and patriotism?
('54', 309, 3, 10, 702911) Despite his weak health, he was in the forefront of the assault at Dharasana and, despite his frail constitution, he made the pilgrimage of jail.
('54', 309, 3, 11, 703057) Imam Saheb was a devout Muslim; he never missed his namaz or roza.
('54', 309, 3, 12, 703124) He became known as Imam Saheb because he performed the function of a religious teacher in the Transvaal.
('54', 309, 3, 13, 703229) He became a fakir for the sake of his country.
('54', 309, 3, 14, 703276) After serving a term of imprisonment in the Transvaal, he came to live with me in Phoenix along with his family and began to live the life of a fakir.
('54', 309, 3, 15, 703427) When I returned to India, he too returned.
('54', 309, 3, 16, 703470) He brought with him his Malay wife too.
('54', 309, 3, 17, 703510) He lost one wife after another.
('54', 309, 3, 18, 703542) Later his elder daughter Fatima died, and now Imam Saheb himself has passed away.
('54', 309, 3, 19, 703624) He leaves behind his daughter Amina Begum and her husband Qureshi.
('54', 309, 3, 20, 703691) Both are engaged in serving the country.
('54', 309, 3, 21, 703732) Imam Saheb was one of the trustees of the Ashram: he took full interest in its affairs, he observed its rules and freely associated with everyone there.
('54', 309, 3, 22, 703885) To me this is a great loss and the fact that he passed away before I reached India adds further to my grief.
('54', 309, 3, 23, 703994) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 27 12 1931

('54', 310, 10, 13, 704595) Only this time the responsibility is a thousandfold greater.
('54', 310, 10, 14, 704656) I shall therefore take no hasty step.

('54', 311, 1, 2, 705580) 189. MESSAGE TO AMERICA [Before December 28, 1931] Tell America, as the exponent of that liberty we hunger for, not to forget our sad people in her prayers.
('54', 311, 2, 3, 705737) Home Department, Political, File No.
('54', 311, 2, 4, 705774) 141, pp 15 7, 1932. Courtesy: National Archives of India
('54', 311, 3, 5, 705831) 190. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('54', 311, 4, 6, 705875) S. S. “PILSNA”, [December 28, 1931] 1
('54', 311, 5, 7, 705913) Real disarmament cannot come unless the nations of the world cease to exploit one another.
('54', 311, 6, 8, 706004) Gandhiji added that without sanctions, the League of Nations could not keep peace among the nations, as was evident in the present Sino Japanese conflict in Manchuria.
('54', 311, 7, 9, 706172) Q. Do you think that the application of your principle of non violence would bring permanent peace?
('54', 311, 8, 10, 706272) A. Non violence would be futile unless the root cause is dealt with, and the root cause in this case is the greed of nations.
('54', 311, 8, 11, 706398) If there were no greed, there could be no occasion for armaments.
('54', 311, 8, 12, 706464) The principle of non violence necessitates complete abstention from exploitation in any form.
('54', 311, 8, 13, 706558) Immediately the spirit of exploitation is gone, armaments will be felt as a positive unbearable burden.
('54', 311, 9, 14, 706662) Gandhiji believed that Europe had advanced materially since his last visit fifteen years ago, but he doubted whether it had made much progress spiritually.
('54', 311, 9, 15, 706818) I think, however, that there is a greater longing for peace on the part of the poeple.
('54', 311, 9, 16, 706905) Deep down everywhere, I noticed intense dissatisfaction and unrest on the part of the people with things as they are.
('54', 311, 9, 17, 707023) That, to my mind, is not a dangerous, but a healthy sign.
('54', 311, 9, 18, 707081) Whether the Government of Europe will translate this unrest into real action in the right direction remains to be seen.
('54', 311, 10, 19, 707201) 1 According to the source, the interview was given just before Gandhiji landed in Bombay.
('54', 312, 0, 1, 707291) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 313
('54', 312, 1, 2, 707337) Q. As a result of that unrest, do you visualize during in the next score of years a gradual disappearance of monarchies for more democratic forms of Government, as evidenced by the recent change in Spain?
('54', 312, 1, 3, 707542) A. Sudden changes such as those in Spain offer no material for a reasonable forecast.
('54', 312, 1, 4, 707628) By habit, too, I am not given to peeping into the future.
('54', 312, 2, 5, 707686) The Indian National leader said it was indisputable that England had failed as a first class power, but he had faith enough in the English people to feel that they would turn their present economic distress to good account and become an example to other nations in spiritual progress.
('54', 312, 2, 6, 707971) For England’s sake and for the sake of the world, I hope, England will not regain the material supremacy she enjoyed before the war, because that supremacy might be used to oppress other nations.
('54', 312, 3, 7, 708167) The Mahatma saw the British Empire disintegrating and ultimately becoming a series of separate independent units, like Canada, Australia, South Africa, New Zealand and India, but he also hoped that these units would be united voluntarily for the good of mankind.
('54', 312, 4, 8, 708430) But this opinion may be due to the wish being father to the thought.
('54', 312, 5, 9, 708499) Gandhiji said that the strongest impression he carried away from Europe is that Europe cannot for any length of time sustain the artificial life its peoples are living today, because that life, he asserted, is too materialistic and too complicated.
('54', 312, 5, 10, 708748) There must be a return to simplicity and proper proportions.
('54', 312, 5, 11, 708809) The flesh has taken precedence over the spirit.
('54', 312, 5, 12, 708857) The machine age is ruining Western civilization.
('54', 312, 5, 13, 708906) Over production and lack of means of proper distribution may finally spell the doom of capitalistic society.
('54', 312, 5, 14, 709015) The only solution I see is a return to hand industry and the emancipation of the individual from factory slavery.
('54', 312, 6, 15, 709129) Q. Would you recommend great industrial countries like England and the United States to adopt the spinning wheel?
('54', 312, 6, 16, 709243) A. I think it would be an eventful day in the life of those countries if they adopted the spinning wheel.
('54', 312, 7, 17, 709349) Q. Is the world growing better or worse?
('54', 312, 7, 18, 709390) A. So long as I believe in a benevolent God, I must believe that the world is getting better even though I see evidence to the contrary.
('54', 312, 7, 19, 709527) The Hindu, 1 1 1932

('54', 313, 5, 11, 710056) 192. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('54', 313, 6, 12, 710084) BOMBAY, December 28, 1931
('54', 313, 7, 13, 710110) In a brief conversation with pressmen, Gandhiji stated that he had closely studied the Premier’s statement and the India debate.
('54', 313, 7, 14, 710239) He would deal with that subject at the public meeting tonight.
('54', 313, 7, 15, 710302) One thought of the Government’s latest action in arresting Pandit Jawaharlal and Mr. Sherwani and Abdul Ghaffar Khan as a challenge to the Congress, but it was for the Congress President to state that those Government activities amounted to a breach of the Delhi Pact.
('54', 313, 8, 16, 710571) Questioned about his attitude towards the Subcommittees set up by His Majesty’s Government to carry on the Conference work, Gandhiji said that it was too early to state his attitude.
('54', 313, 8, 17, 710754) All the material was not before him.
('54', 313, 8, 18, 710791) It was for the Government to consider how the Committees could work if the atmosphere was uncongenial.
('54', 313, 9, 19, 710894) Gandhiji considered the Round Table Conference a debating society.
('54', 313, 9, 20, 710961) It was not representative in the sense it was claimed to be.
('54', 313, 9, 21, 711022) It was not a ‘Round Table’ in the right sense.
('54', 313, 9, 22, 711069) Asked whether he was convinced now that the signing of the truce was a great blunder, he said, “No”, and added that it was an act of statesmanship.
('54', 313, 9, 23, 711217) He agreed that the recent developments in Bengal, U.P. and the Frontier were a challenge to the Congress, but the reserved action till the decision of the Congress Working Committee.
('54', 313, 9, 24, 711400) He added the Round Table Conference was a debating society.
('54', 313, 9, 25, 711460) Asked if he believed that the Delhi Pact was dead he said it was for the Congress President to say.

('54', 314, 0, 1, 711619) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 315
('54', 314, 1, 2, 711665) 193. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('54', 314, 2, 3, 711695) BOMBAY, December 28, 1931
('54', 314, 3, 4, 711721) Mahatma Gandhi denied the rumour that he was seeking an interview with the Viceroy and discussing with him the situation in the country.
('54', 314, 4, 5, 711858) The Mahatma pleaded that he had had no time to study the recent developments in the country and what he had heard from his colleagues till then was only ‘titbits’.
('54', 314, 4, 6, 712022) He, therefore, declined to pass any opinion on the subject.
('54', 314, 4, 7, 712082) But when asked if, when the Ordinances were in force in the country, it would not be difficult for the Committees of the Round Table Conference to function in India, he vouchsafed the remark: Well, it is very difficult.
('54', 314, 4, 8, 712302) But it is for the Government to consider how the Committees shall work and function.
('54', 314, 5, 9, 712387) A pressman asked Gandhiji if he did not see a gloomy future for India if she had to go through another fight to which Gandhiji replied promptly: Even if India has got to go through another fiery ordeal, I would not consider that a gloomy prospect in any sense of the term.
('54', 314, 6, 10, 712660) SIR PRABHASHANKAR PATTANI: But you will try your utmost to prevent another fiery ordeal?
('54', 314, 7, 11, 712749) GANDHIJI: I will strain every nerve to avoid a fiery ordeal naturally enough.
('54', 314, 7, 12, 712827) But if it bccomes unavoidable, it is unbecoming of a warrior to draw a long face when death is in front of him.
('54', 314, 7, 13, 712939) To me it may be imprisonment or a lathi charge.
('54', 314, 8, 14, 712987) A VOICE: Or deportation.
('54', 314, 9, 15, 713012) GANDHIJI: To me imprisonment and deportation are convertible terms.
('54', 314, 9, 16, 713080) They make no difference.
('54', 314, 10, 17, 713105) SARDAR VALLABHBHAI: There may be a difference in climate.
('54', 314, 11, 18, 713163) GANDHIJI: Climatic difference I do not mind.
('54', 314, 11, 19, 713208) (Laughter)
('54', 314, 12, 20, 713219) Gandhiji informed the Pressmen that he had given the most careful consideration to the statement of the Premier and had crossed its I’s and dotted its I’s.
('54', 314, 12, 21, 713375) But he deferred the statement on it till the Azad Maidan meeting.
('54', 314, 13, 22, 713441) To a pressman who doubted the wisdom of the Congress in declaring Truce,
('54', 314, 14, 23, 713514) 1 The interview took place at Mani Bhawan.
('54', 314, 14, 24, 713557) Vallabhbhai Patel, Subhas Chandra Bose and Prabhashankar Pattani were present.
('54', 315, 0, 1, 713636) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 315, 1, 2, 713678) Mahatma Gandhi retorted: It was an act of statesmanship to have signed the Delhi Truce.
('54', 315, 2, 3, 713766) The pressman argued that the Government taking cover under the white flag had flung thousands of the youths of the country into the prisons.
('54', 315, 2, 4, 713907) This evoked the reply from the Mahatma: More young men today are out than in the jail.
('54', 315, 2, 5, 713994) I am unable to subscribe to your formula.
('54', 315, 3, 6, 714036) Several questions that followed were ruled out by Gandhiji on the ground that the Congress President in his official capacity was the proper man to answer them: My opinion does not count.
('54', 315, 3, 7, 714224) It is the opinion of an individual.
('54', 315, 4, 8, 714260) SOMEBODY: But the President has been asking the country all these days to wait for you.
('54', 315, 4, 9, 714348) It shows that your opinion is final.
('54', 315, 5, 10, 714385) GANDHIJI: It may be final with the President.
('54', 315, 6, 11, 714431) Q. Why don’t you go to Bengal.

('54', 315, 7, 13, 714507) GANDHIJI: It may be quite advisable.
('54', 315, 7, 14, 714544) But I am a representative and not a free lance like you.
('54', 315, 7, 15, 714601) (Laughter) My wishes should be dominated in this instance by Bengal.
('54', 315, 7, 16, 714670) Subhas Babu is here to advise me on the subject.
('54', 315, 7, 17, 714719) But you have not yet given him a chance to address me.
('54', 315, 8, 18, 714774) Asked if Mr. M. R. Jayakar was right in his surmise, uttered at a recent meeting in Bombay that it would have been better if Gandhiji had accepted the offer of Lord Irwin to take 14 other Congress representatives with him to London, Gandhiji said: I am convinced after having had this experience that it was a wise decision that the Congress could have come to in sending me alone.
('54', 315, 8, 19, 715156) It would have been a first calls tragedy, if 14 or 15 good servants of the nation had been sent out instead of keeping them here.
('54', 315, 8, 20, 715286) In other respects also it was a good thing to have sent only one delegate.
('54', 315, 8, 21, 715361) When the mandate was so absolutely clear, there was no occasion for sending more than one agent unless, of course, the Congress had distrusted its agent.
('54', 315, 8, 22, 715515) They did the wisest thing in sending one man and, at that, such a wise man like me.
('54', 315, 8, 23, 715599) (Laughter)

('54', 324, 1, 13, 736622) The Congress is undoubtedly ready to take over charge of Defence of Finance and also of the obligations you might consider India is liable for.
('54', 324, 1, 14, 736766) But only in a truly businesslike way they should get all the obligations examined by an impartial examiner.
('54', 324, 1, 15, 736874) Unless the Congress tries its hand at these matters, how can it learn and thrive ?” So what is there disloyal or seditious in organizations trying to run parallel Governments, based on the goodwill of the poeple whom the organization claims to serve.
('54', 324, 1, 16, 737125) It was the very foundation of the Congress to be able one day to replace the present Government.
('54', 324, 1, 17, 737222) It has been laid down by such eminent persons like Dadabhai Naoroji and many other Englishmen and Indians.
('54', 324, 1, 18, 737329) So after its life of more than half a century, if it is not able to run a parallel Government, I would say we should all be ashamed of it.
('54', 324, 1, 19, 737468) The Congress has done nothing immoral nothing ungentle manly.
('54', 324, 1, 20, 737530) It is not a secret organization.
('54', 324, 1, 21, 737563) It always spreads out its cards on the table.
('54', 324, 1, 22, 737609) And if still the Government should mistrust it as they seem to, then all I can say is that we will have to make our power felt or allow ourselves to perish in doing so.
('54', 324, 1, 23, 737778) I would request you, members of the Welfare of India League, to direct me in this matter.
('54', 324, 1, 24, 737868) I have placed before you, so to say,
('54', 325, 0, 1, 737905) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 325, 1, 2, 737947) my puzzle.
('54', 325, 1, 3, 737958) If the Congress is not trusted, how can it give coope ration?
('54', 325, 1, 4, 738020) The welfare of India is a common interest between you and me and the Congress.
('54', 325, 1, 5, 738099) The Congress does not live for anything else than the welfare of India and I have myself no other aim in living this life.
('54', 325, 1, 6, 738222) It may be that I and the Congress are going the wrong way about it.
('54', 325, 1, 7, 738290) I am open to correction and conviction.
('54', 325, 1, 8, 738330) So I would request you all to study the situation in the light of my speech and shall be glad to answer any questions that you may put to me based on my speech for better understanding and for my own guidance.
('54', 325, 1, 9, 738540) Q. Will you co operate with the working of the various R.T.C. Commit tees, which would commence work in India soon if all the Ordinances are withdrawn ?
('54', 325, 1, 10, 738693) A. I have already explained that the Ordinances block the way.
('54', 325, 1, 11, 738756) Firstly, the Ordinances must go.
('54', 325, 1, 12, 738789) Secondly, the Congress must be satisfied that its goal can be reached through co operation with the Committees.
('54', 325, 1, 13, 738901) I can hold out no hope of the Congress reducing its demands.
('54', 325, 1, 14, 738962) But if the Congress is satisfied that the door is open for argument and negotiation in regard to its demands, I would advise the Congress to tender its co operation in the work of the Committees.
('54', 325, 2, 15, 739158) Q. Before condemning these Ordinances as you have done,why don’t you please proceed to the Provinces where these Ordinances are in force and study the conditions there personally and see if they are not justified?
('54', 325, 2, 16, 739372) A. I would be most glad to do so if the Government permitt ed me to do so.
('54', 325, 2, 17, 739447) I hsve tried several times to go to the Frontier Province.
('54', 325, 2, 18, 739506) But on all these occasions the Government have stood in the way, at least the Government have not shown any encouragement for this move of co operation.
('54', 325, 2, 19, 739659) I am divulging no official secret to you when I say that when the Delhi Pact was signed, Ghaffar Khan was on the brain of the Executive I requested Lord Irwin to allow me to go to the Frontier.
('54', 325, 2, 20, 739853) But Lord Irwin, after consultation with the Commissioner of the Frontier, came to the conclusion that it was a dangerous thing to send me there.
('54', 325, 2, 21, 739998) (Laughter) I was told that I would create ferment there and whatever I might say would be misinterpreted to the tribesmen.
('54', 325, 2, 22, 740121) (Laughter) I tried another time in Simla with Lord Willingdon with no better success.
('54', 325, 2, 23, 740207) I could have proceeded without taking permission, but I did not want to emba rass the Government.
('54', 325, 2, 24, 740305) If the Government would permit me to proceed to the Frontier tomorrow, I shall rush to that place.
('54', 325, 2, 25, 740404) So, if those of you here who have got the ear of the Government can procure for me this permission, I shall directly start for the Frontier, I would love to go there tomorrow itself.
('54', 326, 0, 1, 740587) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 327
('54', 326, 1, 2, 740633) Q. Will you not agree to go to the Frontier and Bengal on Government’s terms?
('54', 326, 1, 3, 740711) A. No, I cannot, If Government will allow me to serve them, it must be on my own terms.
('54', 326, 1, 4, 740799) I cannot go to the brave Abdul Ghaffar Khan and tell him that it is wrong to long for independence for the Frontier or for India.
('54', 326, 1, 5, 740929) If you want a bird to fly, you must not clip its wings and then say: you can fly now.
('54', 326, 1, 6, 741015) That is what the Government want to do.
('54', 326, 1, 7, 741055) They clip my wings and then want me to fly.
('54', 326, 1, 8, 741099) The Government must let me grow in strength, if they will let me serve them.
('54', 326, 1, 9, 741176) I can really make things easy.
('54', 326, 1, 10, 741207) The Government knows that Abdul Ghaffar Khan would pay heed to my words.
('54', 326, 1, 11, 741280) I have lived with the Pathans and moved with them.
('54', 326, 1, 12, 741331) I have also been assaulted by them and that has ever been a link between they and me.
('54', 326, 1, 13, 741417) (Laughter) So long as he (Ghaffar Khan) is satisfied that I have not betrayed the cause, he would certainly abide by my advice.
('54', 326, 1, 14, 741545) It was on my advice that he went and saw the Commissioner some time ago.
('54', 326, 1, 15, 741618) But the Government will not accept my services.
('54', 326, 1, 16, 741666) I also intend to visit Bengal.
('54', 326, 1, 17, 741697) The situation is different in regard to Bengal.
('54', 326, 1, 18, 741745) I need not ask for permission to go to Bengal.
('54', 326, 1, 19, 741792) But once I go to Bengal, I will write to the Government and place my co operation at their service as I will at the service of the people of Bengal.
('54', 326, 1, 20, 741941) It will be for the Government to accept my service or not.
('54', 326, 1, 21, 742000) But I will not go to Chittagong or Hijli without asking the Bengal Government if I may do so without embarrassment to them.
('54', 326, 1, 22, 742124) I can go to the Frontier.
('54', 326, 1, 23, 742150) I can go to Chittagong and to Hijli, whether the Government will it or not.
('54', 326, 1, 24, 742226) I can practise civil disobedience if the authorities issue prohibitory orders.
('54', 326, 1, 25, 742305) But I will not go to the Frontier, Chittagong or Hijli, at the cost of practising civil disobedience.
('54', 326, 1, 26, 742407) If I do so, I will be embarrassing the Government greatly which is what I do not want to do.
('54', 326, 1, 27, 742500) If I decide to offer civil disobedience, I shall choose, as a satyagrahi, a ground that offers to the Government the minimum embarrassment and puts the Government in the wrong.
('54', 326, 2, 28, 742677) Q. If you are satisfied that there is a seditious organization existing in Bengal, would you ask for the repeal of the Ordinances?
('54', 326, 2, 29, 742808) A. The word ‘sedition’ is a very elastic term.
('54', 326, 2, 30, 742855) But I under stand the spirit of the question.
('54', 326, 2, 31, 742901) If these organizaitons are trying to subvert law and oder and trying to usurp the powers of the Government, it is certainly the duty of the Government to deal with
('54', 327, 0, 1, 743065) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 327, 1, 2, 743107) such activities.
('54', 327, 1, 3, 743124) But all the difference lies in the method of dealing with the same.
('54', 327, 1, 4, 743192) The same question was put to me in England; “How would you deal with terrorism if the Congress were running the Government” I then replied: “Give me the power and I shall show that.” I would deal with an organizaiton of that character in the most sympathetic manner.
('54', 327, 1, 5, 743459) There is the ordinary law which could alone deal with any kind of crime.
('54', 327, 1, 6, 743532) Then why have recourse to Ordinances, which only help to estrange the feelings of the people on whom it operates.
('54', 327, 1, 7, 743646) I yield to none in my condemnation of crimes, but these Ordinances instead of weaning away people from terrorism only accentuate it.
('54', 327, 1, 8, 743779) No society would tolerate the taking of innocent lives as was done by the Bengal youths.
('54', 327, 1, 9, 743868) But why punish 50,000 for the crime of five?
('54', 327, 1, 10, 743913) If I were the Secretary of State or the Governor General, I would ask the Bengal Governor to resign his place when he asked for the promulgation of an Ordinance.
('54', 327, 1, 11, 744075) But I would not rest there.
('54', 327, 1, 12, 744103) I would dive into the root cause of this discontent and try to cure that first.
('54', 327, 1, 13, 744183) The Governor should invite the prominent leaders into his secret chamber and take them into his confidence and discuss the question thread bare and find out the means to check and stop such crime.
('54', 327, 1, 14, 744380) Mutual trust is what he wants.
('54', 327, 1, 15, 744411) The Archbishop of Canterbury told me that he had understood what was at the back of the Indian problem and he had understood it well when he said that it is mutual trust we want.
('54', 327, 1, 16, 744590) Bengal has its grievances.
('54', 327, 1, 17, 744617) The Bengal youths are courageous, emotional and patriotic and so speeches like those delivered in the House of Commons decrying the bravery of Bengal drive them to extremes.
('54', 327, 1, 18, 744791) As I said before, I yield to none, not even Englishmen, in my condemnation of crime.
('54', 327, 1, 19, 744876) But it should be dealt within the ordinary course of law.
('54', 327, 1, 20, 744934) The Congress creed of non violence has done a great deal to check terrorism.
('54', 327, 1, 21, 745011) But the methods of General Dyer would not do.
('54', 327, 1, 22, 745057) I have no enmity or irritation against General Dyer.
('54', 327, 1, 23, 745110) I know he was an honest man who believed in what he was doing and who justified his actions in India.
('54', 327, 1, 24, 745212) But the Dyer method is wrong.
('54', 327, 1, 25, 745242) English lives in India must not be saved by Dyer methods.
('54', 327, 1, 26, 745300) The atmosphere created by the Ordinances is certainly not conducive to hammering out a Constitution for the country as it is
('54', 328, 0, 1, 745425) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 329
('54', 328, 1, 2, 745471) proposed to do.
('54', 328, 1, 3, 745487) If you think young India will look at any Constitution evolved in the atmosphere of the Ordinances, it is a forlorn hope.
('54', 328, 1, 4, 745609) It is no use saying that Indian loyalists say ‘yes’ to Government in support of these methods.
('54', 328, 1, 5, 745704) I tell you even these loyalists when they say ‘yes’ to the Government, they say at the back of their minds ‘no’.
('54', 328, 1, 6, 745817) As one who is of the people, who lives amongst them, who lives for them, I claim to know the reaction of the Indian mind to these Ordinances better than the Governor General who issues these Ordinances living in Simla or Delhi, better than all his advisers put together.
('54', 328, 2, 7, 746088) Q. Would you not try to stamp out the terrorist movement to the exclusion
('54', 328, 3, 8, 746162) of all your other activities?
('54', 328, 3, 9, 746192) A. The Congress campaign of non violence, I firmly believe, has done a great deal to check terrorism.
('54', 328, 3, 10, 746294) I am speaking with evidence.
('54', 328, 3, 11, 746323) I know of any number of cases in which the Congress message has won to the cause of non violence ex revolutionaries.
('54', 328, 3, 12, 746440) Today, I can vouch for their non violence as I can vouch for my own.
('54', 328, 3, 13, 746509) These patriotic young men are engaged in constructive work.
('54', 328, 4, 14, 746569) Q. If you were in power, would you allow another organization to run a
('54', 328, 5, 15, 746640) parallel Government and usurp your place?
('54', 328, 5, 16, 746682) A. When I said that I did not see any harm in organizations running parallel Governments, I did not mean usurpation.
('54', 328, 5, 17, 746799) My friend has put a word into my mouth which I never used.
('54', 328, 5, 18, 746858) If these organizations run a parallel Government for the good of the people, I would certainly give them all encouragement.
('54', 328, 5, 19, 746982) See what Dictator Mussolini is doing in Italy.
('54', 328, 5, 20, 747029) He never interferes with voluntary activities for the betterment of the country.
('54', 328, 5, 21, 747110) I am dying for co operation and shall not rest till I have explored all avenues.
('54', 328, 5, 22, 747191) I appeal to you, Englishmen and women, to ponder over the facts I have placed before you tonight and do your bit for creating an atmosphere of love and peace in this country.

('54', 329, 18, 23, 748389) 2 The result of this would be that we
('54', 329, 19, 24, 748427) 1 For the Viceroy’s reply dated December 31, vide “Telegram fro Private Secretary to Viceroy”, 31 12 1931 2The position of Indians in South Africa was regulated by the Cape Town Agreement of 1927 which fell due for re examination in 1932. But in 1931, an ordinance called the Licences (Control) Ordinance was passed by the Transvaal Provincial Council which repealed the existing General Dealers (Control) Ordinance, 1926, and gave the Transvaal municipalities complete control over the issue of Trading Licences to Indian without specifying the grounds on which the licence could be refused.
('54', 329, 19, 25, 749020) This greatly perturbed the Indian community.
('54', 329, 19, 26, 749065) Accordingly, the Government of India sent a delegation to South Africa, led by the addressee who was a member of the Governor General’s Executive Council, to settle the various issues.

('54', 330, 1, 2, 749296) would have to waive the right to further facilities.

('54', 330, 1, 4, 749538) It is likely that if our people can be satisfied with such a guarantee the Union Government may protect existing businesses.

('54', 340, 3, 12, 766646) 200. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('54', 340, 4, 13, 766679) [1931] 2
('54', 340, 5, 14, 766688) CHHAGANLAL, Go on with your work there without worrying.
('54', 340, 5, 15, 766745) Find a washer man there if possible.
('54', 340, 5, 16, 766782) It will be good if all processes (of khadi) are as far as possible carried out there.
('54', 340, 5, 17, 766868) I have talked to Ghanshyamdasji about the disposal of your khadi.
('54', 340, 5, 18, 766934) Hence, instead of spending twice on railway freight, you may send it directly to Calcutta or wherever else he suggests.
('54', 340, 5, 19, 767054) It would be better still if some types of garments could be got made by a tailor from that khadi.
('54', 340, 5, 20, 767152) But all this may have to be carefully considered.
('54', 340, 5, 21, 767202) Wherever you feel helpless, you may leave the subsequent processes on the manufactured khadi.
('54', 340, 5, 22, 767296) After the rolls are ready I would be willing to lift even the unbleached stock.
('54', 340, 5, 23, 767376) If you can you may try and introduce new spinning wheels gradually.
('54', 340, 5, 24, 767444) If you do not have enough self confidence, do it after Krishnadas returns.
('54', 340, 5, 25, 767519) Proceed slowly.
('54', 340, 5, 26, 767535) Try and find customers for khadi there.
('54', 340, 5, 27, 767575) The matter regarding Gangabehn must have been settled by now.
('54', 340, 6, 28, 767637) Blessings from BAPU Silence Day I have your letter.
('54', 340, 6, 29, 767689) What you write about the tannery is right.
('54', 340, 6, 30, 767732) I have written to the Ashram about it.
('54', 340, 7, 31, 767771) From a copy of the Gujarati: Chhanganlal Gandhi Papers.
('54', 340, 7, 32, 767827) Courtesy: Sabarmati Sangrahalaya
('54', 340, 8, 33, 767860) 1 Vide “Telegram to Private Secreary to Viceroy”, 1 1 1932
('54', 340, 9, 34, 767919) 2 This and the following two letters have been placed in 1931, as in the sources.
('54', 340, 9, 35, 768001) From the contents too it appears that they belong to this period.
('54', 340, 9, 36, 768067) 3 The land on which the Vijapur Ashram stood, and which was in Gangabehn’s name, was to be transferred to the Ashram Trust.
('54', 341, 0, 1, 768191) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 342
('54', 341, 1, 2, 768233) 201. LETTER TO CHANDRAKANTA
('54', 341, 2, 3, 768261) Y. M., Silence Day [1931]
('54', 341, 3, 4, 768287) KANTA, I have your letter.
('54', 341, 3, 5, 768314) Keep writing to your parents.

('54', 342, 4, 16, 770563) 203. RESOLUTION OF THE CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE 1
('54', 342, 5, 17, 770615) BOMBAY [January 1, 1932] The Working Committee has heard Mahatma Gandhi’s account of his visit to the West and considered the situation created by the extra ordinray Ordinances promulgated in Bengal, the United.
('54', 342, 5, 18, 770827) Provinces and the Frontier Province and by the actions of the authorities including the numerous arrests made among those of Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, Mr. Sherwani and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and by the the shootings in the Frontier Province of innocent men resulting in many deaths and many more being injured.
('54', 342, 5, 19, 771138) The Working Committee has also seen the telegram from His Excellency the Viceroy in reply to the telegram sent by Mahatma Gandhi to him.
('54', 342, 5, 20, 771275) The Working Committee is of opinion that these several acts and others of lesser gravity that have taken place in some other Provinces and the telegram from His Excellency seem to make further co operation with the Government on the part of the Con gress utterly impossible unless the Government policy is radically chang ed.
('54', 342, 5, 21, 771601) These acts and the telegram betray no intention of the part of bureau cracy
('54', 342, 6, 22, 771677) 1 This was drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Talk with Welfare of India League Deputation”, 2 1 1932 and “Diary, 1931”, entry under December 31. The text of this was telegraphed to the Viceroy along with the following item.
('54', 343, 0, 1, 771894) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('54', 343, 1, 2, 771936) to hand power to the people and are calculated to demoralize the na tion.
('54', 343, 1, 3, 772010) They also betray want of faith in the Congress from which co ope ration is expected by the Government.
('54', 343, 1, 4, 772113) The Working Committee yields to no one in its abhorrence of terrorism on any account whatsoever resorted to by individuals such as was recently in witnessed in Bengal, but it condemns with equal force terrorism practised [by the Government] by its recent Acts and Ordinances.
('54', 343, 1, 5, 772389) The Working Committee marks the deep natio nal humiliation over the assassination committed by two girls in Comil la and is firmly convinced that such crime does great harm to the nation especially when through its greatest political mouth piece the Congress it is pledged to non violence for achieving swaraj.
('54', 343, 1, 6, 772700) But the Working Committee can see no justification whatsoever for the Bengal Ordinance which seeks to punish a whole people for the crime of a few.
('54', 343, 1, 7, 772848) The real remedy lies in dealing with the known cause that prompts such crime.
('54', 343, 1, 8, 772926) If Bengal Ordinance has no justification for its existence the Ordinances in the United Provinces and the Frontier Province have still less.
('54', 343, 1, 9, 773067) The Working Committee is of opinion that the measures taken by the Congress in the United Provinces for obtaining agrarian relief are and can be shown to be justified.
('54', 343, 1, 10, 773235) The Working Committee holds that it is the unquestionable right of all people suffering from gave economic distress, as the tenantry of the United Provinces is admittedly suffering, to withhold payment of taxes if they fail, as in the United Provinces they have failed, to obtain redress by other constitutional methods.
('54', 343, 1, 11, 773556) In the arrest and imprisonment of Mr. Sherwani, the President of the United Provinces Congress Committee, and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, the Working General Secretary of the Congress, who were proceeding to Bombay to confer with Mahatma Gandhi and to take part in the meeting of the Working Committee, the Government have gone even beyond the limits contemplated by their Ordinance in that there was no question whatsoever of these gentlemen taking part in Bomby in a non tax campaign in the United Provinces.
('54', 343, 1, 12, 774064) So far as the Frontier Province is concerned on the Government’s own showing there appears to be no warrant for either the promulgation of the Ordinance or the arrest and imprisonment without trial of Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan and his co workers.
('54', 343, 1, 13, 774309) The Working Committee regrads the shootings in that Province of innocent and unarmed men to be wanton and inhuman and congratulates the brave men of the Frontier Province upon their courage and endurance, and the Working Committee has no doubt
('54', 344, 0, 1, 774553) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 345
('54', 344, 1, 2, 774599) that, if the brave people of the Frontier Province retain their non violent spirit in spite of the gravest provocations, their blood and their sufferings would advance the cause of India’s independence.
('54', 344, 1, 3, 774802) The Working Committee calls upon the Government of India to institute a public and impartial enquiry into the events that have led up to the passing of these Ordinances, the necessity of superseding the ordinary courts of law and legislative machinery, and the necessity of several acts committed thereunder.
('54', 344, 1, 4, 775111) And thereafter, if a proper enquiry is set up and all facilities are given to the Working Committee for the producition of evidence, it will be prepared to assist the enquiry by leading evidence before it.
('54', 344, 1, 5, 775317) The Working Committee has considered the declaration of the Prime Minister made before the Round Table Conference and the debates in the Houses of Parliament and regards the declaration as wholly unsatisfactory and inadequate in terms of the Congress demand and place on record its opinion that nothing short of Complete Independence, carrying full control over the Defence and External Affairs and Finance with such safeguards as may be demonstrably necessary in the interests of the nation, can be regarded by the Congress as satisfactory.
('54', 344, 1, 6, 775859) The Working Committee notes that the British Government was not prepared at the Round Table Conference to regard the Congress as representing and entitled to speak and act on behalf of the nation as a whole without disti nction of caste, creed or colour.
('54', 344, 1, 7, 776114) At the same time, the Committee recog nizes with sorrow that communal harmony could not be attained at the said Conference.
('54', 344, 1, 8, 776238) The Working Committee invites the nation, therefore, to make ceaseless effort to demonstrate the capacity of the Congress to represent the nation as a whole and promote an atmosphere that would make a Constitution framed on a purely national basis acceptable to the various communities composing the nation.
('54', 344, 1, 9, 776546) Meanwhile, the Working Committee is prepared to tender co operation to the Government provided His Excellency the Viceroy reconsiders his telegram and adequate relief is granted in respect of the Ordinances and its recent Acts, free scope is left to the Congress in any future negotiations and consultations to prosecute the Congress claim for Complete Independence, and the administration of the country is carried on in consultation with popular representatives pending the attainment of such independence.
('54', 344, 1, 10, 777055) The absence of any satisfactory response from the Government in terms of the foregoing paragraph the Working Committee will regard as an indication on the part of the Government that it has reduced to nullity the Delhi Pact.
('54', 345, 0, 1, 777280) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 346
('54', 345, 1, 2, 777322) the event of a satisfactory response not forthcoming, the Working Committee calls upon the nation to resume civil disobedience including non payment of taxes under the following conditions and illustrative heads: (1) No Province or district or tahsil or village is bound to take up civil disobedience unless the people thereof understand the non violent nature of the struggle with all its implications and are ready to undergo sufferings involving loss of life and property.
('54', 345, 1, 3, 777798) (2) Non violence must be observed in thought, word and deed in the face of the gravest provocation, it being understood that the campaign is not one of seeking revenge or inflicting injuries on the oppressor, but it is one of converting him through self suffering and self purification.
('54', 345, 1, 4, 778085) (3) Social boycott with the intention of inflicting injury on Government officers, police or anti nationalists should not be undertaken and is wholly inconsistent with the spirit of non violence.
('54', 345, 1, 5, 778281) (4) It should be borne in mind that non violent campaigns are independent of pecuniary assistance; therefore, there should be no hired volunteers, but their bare maintenance and maintenance of the dependents of poor men and women who might have been imprisoned or killed is permissible wherever it is possible.
('54', 345, 1, 6, 778592) The Working Committee, however, expects workers in the cause to continue the struggle even though they might have to suffer privations.
('54', 345, 1, 7, 778728) (5) Boycott of all foreign cloth whether British or of other countries is obligatory under all circumstances.
('54', 345, 1, 8, 778838) (6) All Congressmen and women are expected to use hand spun and handwoven khaddar to the exclusion of even cloth manufactured in indigenous mills.
('54', 345, 1, 9, 778985) (7) Picketing of liquor shops and foreign cloth shops should be vigorously conducted chiefly by women but always so as to ensure perfect non violence.
('54', 345, 1, 10, 779136) (8) Unlicensed manufacture and collection of salt should be resumed.
('54', 345, 1, 11, 779205) (9) If processions and demonstrations are organized, only those should join them who will stand lathi chrges or bullets without moving from their respectives places.
('54', 345, 1, 12, 779371) (10) Even in non violent war boycott of goods manufactured by the oppressor is perfectly lawful inasmuch as it is never the duty of the victim to promote or retian commercial relations with the oppressor.
('54', 345, 1, 13, 779576) Thereore, boycott of British goods and concerns should be resumed and vigorously prosecuted.
('54', 345, 1, 14, 779669) (11) Civil breach of non moral laws and of laws and orders injurious to the people wherever it is considered possible and advisable may be practised.
('54', 345, 1, 15, 779819) (12) All unjust orders issued under the Ordinances may be civilly disobeyed.

('54', 353, 4, 23, 791725) 211. TALK WITH WELFARE OF INDIA LEAGUE DEPUTATION 1
('54', 353, 5, 24, 791777) [BOMBAY,] January 2, 1932 My telegram 2 was in studiously courteous language and in the friendliest tone.
('54', 353, 5, 25, 791883) My friends objected to the word ‘guidance’, but I pleaded with them and got them to agree.
('54', 353, 5, 26, 791974) You will see that the Viceroy has placed himself completely in the wrong.
('54', 353, 5, 27, 792048) And arguing
('54', 353, 6, 28, 792060) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s article: “The Historic Week” 2 Vide “Telegram to Viceroy”, 29 12 1931
('54', 354, 0, 1, 792163) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 355
('54', 354, 1, 2, 792209) about the Ordinances was the wrong way of going about the thing.
('54', 354, 1, 3, 792274) He forgot that I had not approached him as an ordinary citizen, but one who had constant dealings with him and one with whom he had to discuss the future plans as to how best to help in the R.T.C. work.
('54', 354, 1, 4, 792477) It is irrelevant for him to say that I could not discuss the Ordinances.
('54', 354, 1, 5, 792550) The second condition is insulting, viz., that I must repudiate my collegues.
('54', 354, 1, 6, 792627) The fact is that Government has overreached itself.
('54', 354, 1, 7, 792679) It is not Lord Willingdon’s language.
('54', 354, 1, 8, 792717) It has been drafted for him.
('54', 354, 1, 9, 792746) It is a terrible affair that Government of India should act in this light hearted fashion though they know that any error may lead to a terrible situation arising in this country.
('54', 354, 1, 10, 792926) If you are convinced that Government of India have committed a grave error in repelling my advances and in banging the door on my face, then you should move heaven and earth to compel the Government of India to reconsider their decision and see me as a friend without putting any conditions.
('54', 354, 1, 11, 793218) But why should I have got the Working Committee to pass a tentative reso lution, you will ask.
('54', 354, 1, 12, 793313) Is it not that you want to go with a loaded pistol?
('54', 354, 1, 13, 793365) No, because the Government of India knew that the Congress was an institution with civil disobedience for its creed.
('54', 354, 1, 14, 793482) The Congress had done enough to lead the country and Government to believe that in connection with a movement for redress of wrongs the Congress would not advise an armed rebellion but a non violent dis obedience.
('54', 354, 1, 15, 793696) Evidently they overlook the fact that civil disobedience had become a permissible thing.
('54', 354, 1, 16, 793785) In the Delhi Pact, civil disobedience was not given up, it was only discontinued during the Truce.
('54', 354, 1, 17, 793884) In Simla, when our final letters were exchanged—letters which were published as part of the second Settlement— I said in my letter that, if all steps fail, we reserve to ourselves the right of civil disobedience.
('54', 354, 1, 18, 794097) Government’s reply finally banging the door is thus a direct breach of the Delhi Pact and of the Simla Pact to which Lord Willingdon was party.
('54', 354, 1, 19, 794241) You have thus got to see the enormity of the error in which the Government of India have been betrayed.
('54', 354, 1, 20, 794345) I therefore suggest to you that you follow your telegram by further action and go over to the side of the Congress if a simple thing like an interview cannot be granted.
('54', 354, 1, 21, 794515) It grieves me to find the suggestion being made that I was overborne by my extremist colleagues.
('54', 354, 1, 22, 794612) I am the arch extremist.
('54', 354, 1, 23, 794637) I have not found colleagues who have given more loyal allegiance than has been given me during the last four days.
('54', 354, 1, 24, 794752) There has been no goading on the part of my colleagues, and all resolutions and telegrams have
('54', 355, 0, 1, 794847) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 356
('54', 355, 1, 2, 794889) been drafted by me.
('54', 355, 1, 3, 794909) They have accepted me as an expert in these matters and left the whole field open to me.
('54', 355, 1, 4, 794998) We discussed for a long time and the sense was that we may pass the tentative resolution, but not publish it.
('54', 355, 1, 5, 795108) It was I who said “No”.
('54', 355, 1, 6, 795132) If I suppressed it, I would be unfair to the Viceroy and the nation.
('54', 355, 1, 7, 795201) Having passed the resolution, I said the Viceroy must be placed in possession of the full facts.
('54', 355, 1, 8, 795298) They agreed.
('54', 355, 1, 9, 795311) My colleagues are not wedded to civil disobedience nor to non violence in the sense that I am.
('54', 355, 1, 10, 795406) It is not a be all and end all with them as with me.
('54', 355, 1, 11, 795459) But there was no course open to me.
('54', 355, 1, 12, 795495) A man to whom it is open to declare an armed rebellion may parley, but a man who has no such alternative—how can he parley?
('54', 355, 1, 13, 795619) That is what has happened, for civil disobedience is my creed, how can I give it up?
('54', 355, 1, 14, 795704) That is why, though I am miserly in expending national money, I paid for the full text of the resolution being telegraphed along with my reply.
('54', 355, 1, 15, 795848) The way to follow out your telegram is not to send me to the Viceroy but to see the Viceroy yourselves.
('54', 355, 1, 16, 795952) All you have got to tell him is that when you are about to embark on a big constitutional advance it should be absurd for the head of a State to refuse to see a public man.
('54', 355, 2, 17, 796125) Young India, 7 1 1932
('54', 355, 3, 18, 796147) 212. MESSAGE TO KAIRA FARMERS 2
('54', 355, 4, 19, 796179) AHMEDABAD, [Before January 3, 1932] I had a great longing to peep into Gujarat to see the Ashramites and other companions and to console and sympathize with you in your difficulties, but I am afraid that this will not be possible.
('54', 355, 4, 20, 796410) A satyagrahi cannot even dream of a family or friend nor could he afford to wait to see them or bid farewell when the jail or the like invites him.
('54', 355, 4, 21, 796558) I believe such is my present condition.
('54', 355, 4, 22, 796598) If, therefore, it is not possible to see you, believe me it was due to the imperative demand of duty.
('54', 355, 4, 23, 796700) It seems war stares us in the face, and it would be more grim this time.
('54', 355, 5, 24, 796773) 1 The Deputation after hearing Gandhiji authorized their president to send another telegram assuring the Viceroy that Gandhiji had an entirely open mind and that it was all the more necessary that he should have an opportunity of fully discussing the situation with His Excellency.
('54', 355, 5, 25, 797055) 2 According to the source the message was in Gujarati.
('54', 356, 0, 1, 797110) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 357
('54', 356, 1, 2, 797156) Exhorting them to bear the brunt of the fight and not to flinch, Gandhiji asks them to cheerfully sacrifice their lands, goods and cattle and to suffer all sorts of privations and to bear all oppressions, including lathi and bullets.
('54', 356, 1, 3, 797390) But while enduring all these, Gandhiji appeals to them not to be excited in the least and to pity their persecutor and wish him well.
('54', 356, 2, 4, 797524) Quoting the famous Gujarati poet, Kavi Shamal Bhatt, that “he who returns
('54', 356, 3, 5, 797598) good for evil has only truly lived”, Gandhiji goes on: You have drunk at this fountain of love, and perceived the experiences of others.
('54', 356, 3, 6, 797735) You must therefore see that you do not offend even the farmer who does not stand by you or who is hostile to you.
('54', 356, 3, 7, 797849) Pity him too, for it is not his fault that he does not see eye to eye with you in matters of duty.
('54', 356, 4, 8, 797948) Gandhi says that they conferred upon Mr. Vallabhbhai the title of Sardar and continues: In your hands lies his honour and his strength.
('54', 356, 4, 9, 798084) Not only this, but the reputation and honour of the whole of India lies in your hands .
('54', 356, 4, 10, 798172) On the resumption of the struggle, the eyes of India and of the whole world are concentrated upon you.
('54', 356, 4, 11, 798275) Remember all these, and pray for strength befitting a satyagrahi.
('54', 356, 5, 12, 798341) Asking the peasants to live harmoniously with their Dharala brethren, Gandhiji concludes: Remember this, and console yourself.
('54', 356, 5, 13, 798468) Rest assured that all your confiscated lands will be restored to you.
('54', 356, 5, 14, 798538) This is not a bait.
('54', 356, 5, 15, 798558) Believe every word of it, when I say that this only is the true foundation of a satyagrahi.

('54', 356, 6, 17, 798670) 213. TEMPLE ENTRY SATYAGRAHA [On or before January 3, 1932] 1
('54', 356, 7, 18, 798732) Whilst the Working Committee was in session during the last week I had several conversations with representatives from Kerala and other Congress workers about many questions arising in connection with Temple entry Satyagraha.
('54', 356, 7, 19, 798958) Instead of correcting the report produced by the interviewers in the form of questions and answers.
('54', 356, 8, 20, 799058) 1 According to the source this article was dictated by Gandhiji under very heavy pressure of work in hourly expectation of arrest and handed over for publication just before his arrest on January 4.
('54', 357, 0, 1, 799257) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 357, 1, 2, 799299) am giving below what I think should be the answer to their questions.
('54', 357, 1, 3, 799369) The answers will be found so framed as to render unnecessary the questions being stated.
('54', 357, 1, 4, 799458) 1. It is necessary to bear in mind that the question of removal of untouchability, though it has a political significance of the greatest importance, is essentially and predominantly a religious question to be solved by the Hindus and as such for them it overshadows even the political aspect.
('54', 357, 1, 5, 799752) That is to say, the duty of touchables in respect of removal of untouchability can never be subordinated to any political exigencies, hence the present political situation must not in any way be allowed to postpone the endeavour to end untouchability.
('54', 357, 1, 6, 800004) 2. In a religious and righteous cause the reformer has to face all consequences and even take the risk of temporary alienation of the sym pathy of privileged classes.
('54', 357, 1, 7, 800171) Those, therefore, who believe untouchability is a curse to be removed at all costs will not abate their effort for fear of finding themselves in a hopeless minority.
('54', 357, 1, 8, 800337) 3. If the present pujaris 1 of temples strike work and refuse to perform the ceremonial required, they should be replaced promptly and, if the particular caste which has supplied the pujaris fail to furnish a substitute, I would not hesitate to find the priest from any other caste so long as he has the requisite qualifications and con viction.
('54', 357, 1, 9, 800683) The fact is that, so far as I am aware, the majority of the existing pujaris are too dependent on this service for their maintenance to continue the strike for any length of time.
('54', 357, 1, 10, 800863) That the right of performing puja is hereditary does not affect my opinion because, if the possessor himself of such a right, for any cause whatsoever, refuses to exercise the right, he has only himself to thank.
('54', 357, 1, 11, 801076) 4. If temple authorities offer to set apart a corner for untouchables, it should not be considered as sufficient.
('54', 357, 1, 12, 801190) No restriction against untouchables which is not applicable to other non Brahmin Hindus can be tolerated.
('54', 357, 1, 13, 801296) But a distant corner may be set apart for those who do not want to mix with the untouchables.
('54', 357, 1, 14, 801390) These people then become untouchables by choice.
('54', 357, 1, 15, 801439) 5. We may not force open barricades.
('54', 357, 1, 16, 801476) That would be a species of violence and it will not do that barricades are inanimate things, for the hands that put up the barricades were animate.
('54', 357, 2, 17, 801624) 1 Priests
('54', 358, 0, 1, 801634) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 359
('54', 358, 1, 2, 801680) 6. From the foregoing it will be clear that belief in temples should be a condition precedent to offering satyagraha regarding temple entry.
('54', 358, 1, 3, 801821) Temple entry is a religious right.
('54', 358, 1, 4, 801856) Entry, therefore, by any other person cannot be called satyagraha.
('54', 358, 1, 5, 801923) At the time of Vaikom Satyagraha, when Mr. George Joseph went to jail, I sent him word that he was wrong.
('54', 358, 1, 6, 802029) 1 He agreed with me, promptly apologized, and came out of jail.
('54', 358, 1, 7, 802093) Temple entry satyagraha is a penance on the part of the touchable Hindu.
('54', 358, 1, 8, 802166) He is the sinner and he has, therefore, to do the penance by inviting punishment on himself for endeavouring to take these untouchable co religionists with him to the temle.
('54', 358, 1, 9, 802340) Therefore, non Hindus can only offer help other than satyagraha.
('54', 358, 1, 10, 802405) For instance, whilst the other communities helped the Sikhs at the time of Gurudwara movement in various ways, satyagraha was and could be offered only by the Sikhs who believed in the akhanda path.
('54', 358, 2, 11, 802604) In my opinion, untouchables should not alone offer satyagraha.
('54', 358, 2, 12, 802667) It should be led by touchable reformers.
('54', 358, 2, 13, 802708) This is a matter of expedience.
('54', 358, 2, 14, 802740) There may come a time when untouchables may offer satyagraha by them selves.
('54', 358, 2, 15, 802817) The idea behind the opinion here expressed is that public opinion amongst touchable Hindus should be sufficiently alive and active before satyagraha is taken up at all.
('54', 358, 2, 16, 802986) It is a weapon whose use depends for success upon the gathering of public opinion.
('54', 358, 2, 17, 803069) Therefore, it use is invariably preceded by all the known orthodox remedies.
('54', 358, 2, 18, 803146) 7. There can be no entry demanded in temples on private bona fide property.
('54', 358, 2, 19, 803222) When a man allows free use to the public of a temple erected on a private property, but bars the entry of untouchables alone, it ceases to be a private temple.
('54', 358, 2, 20, 803382) 8. It has been suggested that temple entry through satyagraha should be postponed altogether and effected by legislative enactment.
('54', 358, 2, 21, 803514) I wholly dissent from the view.
('54', 358, 2, 22, 803546) Legislative enactment as a rule, and certainly always under democracy, follows the formation of public opinion, and for the formation of public opinion.
('54', 358, 2, 23, 803699) I know no swifter remedy than real satyagraha properly handled.
('54', 358, 2, 24, 803763) The question as to when time is ripe for offering satyagraha in a particular place is one primarily for local Congress Committees to decide.
('54', 358, 2, 25, 803904) 9. Those who contend that non Hindus can vote on questions
('54', 358, 3, 26, 803963) 1 Vide “Letter to George Joseph”, 6 4 1924 2 Non stop reading of the Granth Saheb
('54', 359, 0, 1, 804045) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 359, 1, 2, 804087) arising out of untouchability I would refer to the first resolution, since the new constituion passed at Nagpur in 1920. There it is clearly stated that the question of removal of untouchability is one specially and exclusively reserved for Hindus.
('54', 359, 1, 3, 804336) Therefore, a convention has grown up that Non Hindus should not interfere by their votes or otherwise with this religious question.
('54', 359, 1, 4, 804468) Young India, 14 1 1932

('54', 362, 7, 13, 809671) 218. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 2
('54', 362, 8, 14, 809717) January 3, 1932 It is a matter for deep regret to me to have received this telegram from H.E. the Viceroy and the Government.
('54', 362, 8, 15, 809843) I cannot help saying that it has heaped error upon error, instead of courageously acknowledging the first errror, in practically banging the door in my face by imposing for the coveted interview conditions which no self respecting man can possibly accept and reopen the door.
('54', 362, 8, 16, 810119) The telegram has added another error by deliberately and finally shutting the door, by telling me that he cannot see me under threat of resumption of civil disobedience and introducing in the telegram argument that is not germane to my repeated request for an interview.
('54', 362, 8, 17, 810390) The Viceroy and his Government have committed a flagrant breach of the Delhi Pact by using the so called threat of resumption of civil disobedience as an excuse for refusing to see me.
('54', 362, 8, 18, 810575) Surely he must know that the negotiations which resulted in the Settlement were being carried on although civil disobedience was still on, and under the Settlement it was never finally given you, but was only discontinued for the purpose of securing represen tation of the Congress at the
('54', 362, 9, 19, 810864) 1 Minister for external affairs of Italy, at whose invitation Ghandhiji had visited Rome for two days in December 1931 2 The message was dictated to the A.P.I. reporter on telephone at about 2 a.m.
('54', 363, 0, 1, 811062) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 363, 1, 2, 811104) Round Table Conference, it being understood that it was likely to be resumed if the Round Table Conference failed to do satisfaction in respect of the national demand.
('54', 363, 1, 3, 811272) To this I wish to add the Second Settlement that was arrived at in Simla immediately prior to my departure for London .
('54', 363, 1, 4, 811392) On examining the correspondence that has passed between myself and the Government, it would be seen that notwithstanding the Truce I had reserved to myself the right to take up civil disobedience by way of defensive action in connection with the grievances about which relief might be unattainable through milder methods.
('54', 363, 1, 5, 811714) Surely if civil disobedience was such a heinous crime, the Government could never have exchanged correspondence on that basis and sent me to London with Viceregal blessings; but I see that with the change of times manners have also changed.
('54', 363, 1, 6, 811955) The nation must now respond to the challenge of the Government.
('54', 363, 1, 7, 812019) It is to be hoped, however, that whilst people belonging to all classes and creeds will courageously and in all humility go through the fiery ordeal considerng no price too dear and no sufferings too great, they will observe the strictest non violence in thought, word and deed, no matter how great the provocation may be.
('54', 363, 1, 8, 812342) I would also urge them not to be angry with the administrators.
('54', 363, 1, 9, 812406) It is not easy for them to shed the habit handed down from generation to generation.
('54', 363, 1, 10, 812491) Our quarrel is not with men but with measures.
('54', 363, 1, 11, 812538) We have faith in ourselves and, therefore, in human nature, to feel that, if we suffer long enough and in the proper spirit, our sufferings must result in converting administrators.
('54', 363, 1, 12, 812720) After all, let us realize that the greater and the longer the sufferings the greater would be our fitness for swaraj, for which we are embarking upojn a fiery ordeal.
('54', 363, 1, 13, 812887) I would remind the nation of the pledge I gave to the Prime Minister towards the end of the Plenary Session of the Round Table Conference that there should be no malice in the struggle if it fell to our lot to resume it and that we would do nothing unworthy.
('54', 363, 1, 14, 813146) I shall trust every Indian to redeem the pledge.
('54', 363, 1, 15, 813195) To Englishmen I would say that they must beware of false reports that are often dished up for them from morning to morning and evening to evening as to the doings of the Congress in India.
('54', 363, 1, 16, 813384) This feeding on false information or starvation due to suppression of correct information is a greater barrier to heart to heart co operation.
('54', 363, 1, 17, 813527) The Hindu, 3 1 1932

('54', 364, 5, 8, 813918) 220. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('54', 364, 6, 9, 813950) [BOMBAY], January 3, 1932 You have been my companions in these prayers for some days, and now that the struggle is resumed again and I may be taken away any moment, I hope you will continue to have your prayers regularly morning and evening.
('54', 364, 6, 10, 814192) Let it become a daily obligatory ritual for you.
('54', 364, 6, 11, 814241) Prayer plays a large part in a self purificatory sacrifice and you will see that it will be a veritable cow of plenty for you, and will make your way clear.
('54', 364, 6, 12, 814398) The more you apply yourselves to it, the more fearlessness you will experience in daily life, for fearlessness is a sign and symbol of self purification.
('54', 364, 6, 13, 814552) I do not know a man or a woman who was on the path of self purification and was still obsessed by fear.
('54', 364, 6, 14, 814656) Generally there are two kinds of fear in man’s minds—fear of death and fear of loss of material possessions.
('54', 364, 6, 15, 814765) A man of prayer and self purification will shed the fear of death and embrace death as a boon companion and will regard all earthly possessions as fleeting and of no account.
('54', 364, 6, 16, 814940) He will see that he has no right to possess wealth when misery and pauperism stalk the land and when there are millions who have to go without a meal.
('54', 364, 6, 17, 815091) No power on earth can subdue a man who has shed these two fears.
('54', 364, 6, 18, 815156) But for that purpose the prayer should be a thing of the heart and not a thing of outward demonstration.
('54', 364, 6, 19, 815261) It must take us daily nearer to God, and a prayerful man is sure to have his

('54', 365, 1, 2, 815588) heart’s desire fulfilled, for the simple reason that he will never have an improper desire.
('54', 365, 1, 3, 815680) Continue this ritual and you will shed lustre not only on your city but on our country.
('54', 365, 1, 4, 815768) I hope this brief prayer of mine will find a lodgment in your hearts.

('54', 365, 2, 6, 815860) 221. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('54', 365, 3, 7, 815901) BOMBAY, January 3, 1932 What I would ask the nation to do after my arrest, is to wake up from its sleep; and 1. to discard at once all foreign cloth and take to khaddar; 2. to discard all drugs, narcotics, and intoxicating drinks; 3. to discard every trace of violence and give absolute protection to every Englishman, woman or child whether official or otherwise, no matter how provocative the action of officials may be; 4. to withdraw from Government every form of co operation that is possible for every individual; and 5. to study the resolution of the Working Committee and carry it out to the letter and in the spirit and in that process suffer all hardships that they may be put to, including loss of life and property.
('54', 365, 3, 8, 816629) It is difficult to lay down one rule for the whole of India.
('54', 365, 3, 9, 816690) But it seems to me that, since the Congress has adopted the method of self purification through non violence, I should begin by hartal, that is, voluntary suspension of all works for profit and undergo a prayerful fast and then begin simultaneously civil disobedience in such manner as may be possible in each locality such as (a) unlicensed manufacture of salt, (b) picketing of liquor and foreign cloth shops, (c) breach of orders under Section 144 and the like when there is no likelihood of breach of peace and where orders have been issued not out of any legal necessity, but manifestly for the sake of crushing the spirit of the people or, what is the same thing, or suppressing the Congress.
('54', 365, 4, 10, 817389) As to what particular items of programme Bombay should follow he left to Mr. K. F. Nariman and his council.
('54', 365, 5, 11, 817497) Questioned if the work of carrying on the behests of the Congress would not prove difficult if, as already contemplated, all listed Congress workers were removed from the field of action, Gandhiji commenced:
('54', 366, 0, 1, 817705) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 367
('54', 366, 1, 2, 817751) The resolution of the Working Committee was framed to cover the difficulty raised.
('54', 366, 1, 3, 817834) The situation will develop so suddenly that it is not possible to be more definite than the resolution is.
('54', 366, 1, 4, 817941) After experience of nearly 12 years of satyagraha in a more or less acute form, individuals are expected to know what the change in circumstances will require.
('54', 366, 1, 5, 818101) Last year’s experience shows that in spite of the imprisonment of almost all the leaders, the nation showed marvellous resourcefulness in the emergency as it arose, and kept up the spirit of civil defiance.
('54', 366, 2, 6, 818308) When his attention was drawn to the possibility of opposition to the Congress from certain classes of Indians, the Mahatma said that some handicap there naturally must be whenever there is internal opposition, but added: All these difficulties will dissolve in the fire of suffering without hatred whether towards the administrators or towards our own people, whether they oppose or are indifferent to the movement.
('54', 366, 2, 7, 818724) The Bombay Chronicle, 4 1 1932
('54', 366, 3, 8, 818755) 222. MESSAGE TO INDIAN CHRISTIANS 1
('54', 366, 4, 9, 818791) BOMBAY, January 3, 1932
('54', 366, 5, 10, 818815) DEAR CHRISTIAN FRIENDS AND FELLOW COUNTRYMEN, I have full trust that in the struggle on which the country is about to embark, Indian Christians, who tender their loyalty to the one whom they call the Prince of Peace, will not be found behind any community in our country in the struggle which is essentially based on peace.
('54', 366, 5, 11, 819139) I venture to suggest that service in this national struggle is an infinitely greater safeguard for the protection of a minority that has tendered such service than any paper security.
('54', 366, 5, 12, 819323) I would like to lay stress upon khaddar and prohibition.
('54', 366, 5, 13, 819380) When in my wanderings I have met thousands of poor Christian fellow countrymen.
('54', 366, 5, 14, 819460) I have realized the necessity for them of khaddar as much as for others.
('54', 366, 5, 15, 819533) I hope, therefore, that every Christian’s home will be adorned by the installation of the spinning wheel and every Christian body with khaddar, spun and woven by the hands of our poor countrymen and countrywomen.
('54', 366, 5, 16, 819746) And then there is the curse of drink.
('54', 366, 5, 17, 819784) I have never understood how a Christian can take intoxicating drink.
('54', 366, 5, 18, 819853) Did not Jesus say to Satan

('54', 367, 1, 3, 820099) How can a Christian serve both Satan and Christ?

('54', 367, 2, 5, 820179) 223. MESSAGE TO AMERICA 1
('54', 367, 3, 6, 820205) BOMBAY, January 3, 1932 On the eve of embarking on what promises to be a deadly struggle, I would expect numerous American friends to watch its career and use the influence of the great nation for the sake of oppressed humanity.
('54', 367, 3, 7, 820434) This Indian struggle is more than national.
('54', 367, 3, 8, 820478) It has international value and importance.
('54', 367, 3, 9, 820521) I am convinced that if my countrymen and women retain up to the last the spirit of non violence, they will have inaugurated a new era upon earth.

('54', 370, 7, 16, 824651) January 5, 1932
('54', 370, 8, 17, 824667) SHARDA, I have been writing to you regularly.
('54', 370, 8, 18, 824713) I am not sure if sometimes I forget about it.
('54', 370, 8, 19, 824759) But one who follows the path of non violence would not pay a person in the same coin.
('54', 370, 8, 20, 824845) He would do a good turn to someone who has done nothing for him or even to one who has done him harm.
('54', 370, 8, 21, 824947) Hence, even if I am lazy, you should not be.
('54', 370, 8, 22, 824992) If your yarn snapped 12 times in 47 turns, you could have done 36 more turns if it had not snapped at all.
('54', 370, 8, 23, 825099) It is my experience that if the yarn snaps once, re uniting it takes the time required for spinning three turns.

('54', 371, 6, 9, 825923) 232. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI January 11, 1932
('54', 371, 7, 10, 825971) CHI, NARANDAS,
('54', 371, 8, 11, 825986) If I wished to write to you at leisure, or write at all, I had no option but to go to jail.
('54', 371, 8, 12, 826078) I got today the permission to write letters and so I am writing my very first letter to you.
('54', 371, 8, 13, 826171) The Sardar’s being with me is a novel feature of my imprisonment this time.
('54', 371, 8, 14, 826247) I still feel tired and my hunger for sleep has not yet been fully satisfied, and so I do no work except a little reading and sacrificial spinning.
('54', 371, 8, 15, 826394) Both of us keep good health.
('54', 371, 8, 16, 826423) My diet is almost the same that it was when I was outside.
('54', 371, 8, 17, 826482) Instead of honey, I take jaggery mixed in hot water.
('54', 371, 8, 18, 826535) The Sardar’s diet consists mainly of tea, bread and vegetables.
('54', 371, 8, 19, 826599) He used to eat rice when outside, but doesn’t eat it here.
('54', 371, 8, 20, 826658) The rice cooked here may not agree with him.
('54', 371, 8, 21, 826703) He drinks some milk.
('54', 371, 8, 22, 826724) His throat complaint persists.
('54', 371, 8, 23, 826755) You should write to me regularly.
('54', 371, 8, 24, 826789) I have no precise information as to who have been arrested.
('54', 371, 8, 25, 826849) Please let me have this information, so that I may know to whom I should write.
('54', 371, 8, 26, 826929) I saw Jamna in Bombay.
('54', 371, 8, 27, 826952) I didn’t get time to talk much with anyone.
('54', 371, 8, 28, 826996) You should now write to me and give me news about her and about others, or those persons themselves should write.
('54', 371, 8, 29, 827110) I have not written to Kakasaheb, Chhaganlal Joshi, etc., thinking that they are already in jail.
('54', 371, 8, 30, 827207) It is surprising that leather for soles of sandals is not available there.
('54', 371, 8, 31, 827282) It must be available in the Ashram and at several other places.
('54', 371, 8, 32, 827346) Talk to Surendra about this and ask him to write to me.
('54', 372, 0, 1, 827402) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 373

('54', 372, 1, 3, 827492) I am glad.
('54', 372, 1, 4, 827503) If you are permitted to forward my letter to her, do so.
