('54', 373, 8, 10, 829198) 235. LETTER TO MAHALAKSHMI M. THAKKAR
('54', 373, 9, 11, 829236) January 12, 193[2] 1
('54', 373, 10, 12, 829257) MAHALAKSHMI,
('54', 373, 11, 13, 829270) I got your letter.
('54', 373, 11, 14, 829289) I often think about you all and also wish to write.
('54', 373, 11, 15, 829341) But I got no time at all while I was outside jail.
('54', 373, 11, 16, 829392) I see that I shall definitely be able to write from here.
('54', 373, 11, 17, 829450) The same diet does not suit all persons.
('54', 373, 11, 18, 829491) In the last resort, every person has to decide for himself the quantity and the type of food he should eat, having regard to his capacity.
('54', 373, 11, 19, 829630) I have discovered one thing at any rate from my own experience and that of others, namely, that ground nut does not agree with any person for long, and it must, therefore, be given up.
('54', 373, 11, 20, 829815) In any case, it should not be given to children to eat.
('54', 373, 11, 21, 829871) It will not matter if they eat it occasionally.
('54', 373, 11, 22, 829919) It will do them no harm if they never eat it.
('54', 373, 11, 23, 829965) Nor is it necessary to eat coconut.
('54', 373, 11, 24, 830001) Almonds are useful, of course.
('54', 373, 11, 25, 830032) But, in your case, I think the following diet will be good.
('54', 373, 11, 26, 830092) Milk, boiled or unboiled, to a maximum of three seers.
('54', 373, 11, 27, 830147) Dates and currants, two or three sour lemons to be taken either with soda, as I take them, or in warm water with honey or jaggery.
('54', 373, 11, 28, 830278) Once during the day raw carrots or radish (of the less pungent variety) or salad leaves or tender leaves of cabbage.
('54', 373, 11, 29, 830395) Two or three tolas of any of these items should be chewed thoroughly.
('54', 373, 11, 30, 830465) Eat them with a little salt.
('54', 373, 11, 31, 830494) If you eat carrots or these leaves, that will probably satisfy your sense of
('54', 373, 12, 32, 830571) 1 The source has “1931”, which is a slip for “1932”; vide “Diary, 1932”, the entry under “January 13”; also “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 13 1 1932
('54', 374, 0, 1, 830718) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 375
('54', 374, 1, 2, 830764) hunger.
('54', 374, 1, 3, 830772) The dates need not be soaked [in water].
('54', 374, 1, 4, 830813) They should be put in milk and eaten as they are.
('54', 374, 1, 5, 830863) If any of them are not clean, they should of course be washed.
('54', 374, 1, 6, 830926) If they are not soaked [in water] you will be required to chew them and that will probably give you a feeling of satisfaction.
('54', 374, 1, 7, 831053) Do not start eating almonds and pistachio nuts just now.
('54', 374, 1, 8, 831110) Try the diet I have suggested.
('54', 374, 1, 9, 831141) You will probably feel lighter with it and the menstrual flow will become regular.
('54', 374, 1, 10, 831224) There is no harm in taking curds instead of milk.
('54', 374, 1, 11, 831274) If the curds are sour you may add some soda according to how sour they are.
('54', 374, 1, 12, 831350) You should also eat raw tomatoes.
('54', 374, 1, 13, 831384) This diet will stop gas.
('54', 374, 1, 14, 831409) If unboiled milk does not agree with you, you should not consider itwrong to take boiled milk.
('54', 374, 1, 15, 831504) The addition of soda will most probably stop the gas.
('54', 374, 1, 16, 831558) I had seen the children in Bombay.
('54', 374, 1, 17, 831593) I saw them coughing and that had pained me.
('54', 374, 1, 18, 831637) They also may be given the diet suggested above.
('54', 374, 1, 19, 831686) Their weight ought to increase.
('54', 374, 1, 20, 831718) Just now they should not be given dry fruit at all.
('54', 374, 1, 21, 831770) You should give them more honey.
('54', 374, 1, 22, 831803) They may take it either with water or with tomatoes.
('54', 374, 1, 23, 831856) As for milk, it will be better if they drink it unboiled.
('54', 374, 1, 24, 831914) Ground nuts and honey never form a good combination.
('54', 374, 1, 25, 831967) I think I have now answered all your questions.
('54', 374, 1, 26, 832015) If any question is left out and if you are still free, you may ask it again.
('54', 374, 1, 27, 832092) My blessings to all the women.
('54', 374, 1, 28, 832123) I will write to all of them one after another.
('54', 374, 1, 29, 832170) Rama should write to me.
('54', 374, 1, 30, 832195) I now look upon all the women as mere guests.
('54', 374, 1, 31, 832241) Take care of your health and see that it does not suffer.
('54', 374, 1, 32, 832299) I had thought that your health was excellent.
('54', 374, 1, 33, 832345) Ask Madhavji to write to me.
('54', 374, 1, 34, 832374) If you think it necessary to send this letter to Calcutta for the sake of the children, you may do so.
('54', 374, 1, 35, 832477) The person there who looks after them should write to me.
('54', 374, 2, 36, 832535) Blessings from
('54', 374, 3, 37, 832550) BAPU [PS.] Since I got your letter late, this letter will be posted tomorrow though I have dated it today.

('54', 378, 1, 2, 836172) 241. LETTER TO SIR SAMUEL HOARE
('54', 378, 2, 3, 836204) January 15, 1932
('54', 378, 3, 4, 836221) DEAR SIR SAMUEL 1, I had not expected to write to you, at any rate not quite so soon from a prison.
('54', 378, 3, 5, 836321) I had promised to let you know before I took any serious step.
('54', 378, 3, 6, 836384) But the events came upon me with such a sudden rush that there was no time or choice left for me.
('54', 378, 3, 7, 836482) I have no doubt you have seen the telegrams exchanged between the Viceroy and me. 1 1932 I tried my best to keep up co operation but failed in my opinion through no fault of my own.
('54', 378, 3, 8, 836664) I cannot help feeling that the Viceroy was wholly in the wrong in refusing to see me except on impossible conditions.
('54', 378, 3, 9, 836782) I have just written a personal letter to Lord Willingdon urging him to reconsider his position.
('54', 378, 3, 10, 836878) I can assure you that I reached Bombay with every intention of co operating.
('54', 378, 3, 11, 836955) Your letter, for which pray accept my thanks, cleared one difficulty.
('54', 378, 3, 12, 837025) And I had hoped that a heart to heart talk with the Viceroy would clear up the difficulty about the ordinances and administration in the interim.
('54', 378, 3, 13, 837171) Indeed I had planned things about Hindu Muslim question and other matters with Sir Akbar Hydari who was on the same boat with me and in ignorance of what was happening in India.
('54', 378, 3, 14, 837349) I had given, as you might have seen, the day before landing, a hopeful message 2 to Reuter’s representative on board.
('54', 378, 3, 15, 837467) But the events I saw happening in India did startle me.
('54', 378, 3, 16, 837523) I at once sought an interview with the Viceroy with the result you know.
('54', 378, 3, 17, 837596) Let me add this: cruel suggestions have appeared in the Press that my colleagues forced me to the position I took up.There is no warrant whatsoever for them.
('54', 378, 3, 18, 837754) The initiative for every step was mine and it was a logical outcome of my creed of satyagraha.
('54', 378, 3, 19, 837849) I cannot wish for more loyal colleagues.
('54', 378, 3, 20, 837890) In matters of satyagraha they yield to my judgment as to an expert’s 3. I don’t expect you to reply to this letter.
('54', 378, 3, 21, 838006) I thought I should just tell you what I think about it all.
('54', 378, 3, 22, 838066) Whatever happens, I shall always retain happy recollections of our meetings.
('54', 378, 4, 23, 838143) Yours sincerely,
('54', 378, 5, 24, 838160) From a photostat: C.W. 9556. Courtesy: India Office Library
('54', 378, 6, 25, 838220) 1 Secretary of State for India 2 Vide “Interview to Reuter”, 27 12 1931
('54', 378, 7, 26, 838292) 3 The source has “as if an expert”.

('54', 379, 2, 3, 838401) YERAVDA PRISON, January 15, 1932
('54', 379, 3, 4, 838434) DEAR FRIEND,
('54', 379, 4, 5, 838447) Your wire in reply to mine was a painful surprise to me.
('54', 379, 4, 6, 838504) Your very cordial letters written by you after I had left for London had led me to expect a message from you awaiting me on my return to Bombay.
('54', 379, 4, 7, 838649) Such a message would have been in keeping with your past as you had let me see it.
('54', 379, 4, 8, 838732) Do you remember 1915 when I returned to India from self imposed exile?
('54', 379, 4, 9, 838803) You had sent me a message through the late Mr. Gokhale that I should see you before expressing my viewson Indian matters.
('54', 379, 4, 10, 838925) Your astounding wire therefore in reply to mine seeking interview and guidance I could not understand at all.
('54', 379, 4, 11, 839035) Nor do I understand it even now.
('54', 379, 4, 12, 839068) But I do not write this to blame you for your action for which no doubt, in your own opinion, you had the best of State reasons.
('54', 379, 4, 13, 839197) But I would like you as an Englishman to review the immediate past and see whether you did not commit a grave error of judgment in repelling my sincere and well meant advance.
('54', 379, 4, 14, 839373) I ask you to believe me when I tell you that I was desperately anxious to avoid resumption of struggle and to tender my whole hearted co operation if it was at all possible.
('54', 379, 4, 15, 839547) I am anxious to do so even now.
('54', 379, 4, 16, 839579) But the difficulties are obviously much greater than before, unless you retrace your steps or convince me that I was wholly in the wrong.
('54', 379, 4, 17, 839717) Will you not realize that it is impossible to crush the Congress spirit though you have in law killed the Congress organization?
('54', 379, 4, 18, 839846) Is it wrong for Indians to desire complete independence for their country?
('54', 379, 4, 19, 839921) Is it wrong to seek to do so through non violent direct action, when negotiation fails or becomes impossible?
('54', 379, 4, 20, 840031) Englishmen have negotiated with men whose hands were dyed red as in Ireland but after committing a series of inhumanities.
('54', 379, 4, 21, 840154) They negotiated with the Boers after trying the method of concentration for women.
('54', 379, 4, 22, 840237) Even in India the same thing was done last year after trying repressive measures of a particularly strong character against most women who never did the slightest violence.
('54', 379, 4, 23, 840410) Must such history be repeated again?
('54', 379, 4, 24, 840447) It seems to me that you invited trouble, so as to enable you to put the Congress out of your way.
('54', 379, 4, 25, 840545) Even if you succeed in producing a dead calm in India you must know that it can bring no lasting peace to the land.
('54', 379, 4, 26, 840661) I ask you
('54', 380, 0, 1, 840671) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 381
('54', 380, 1, 2, 840717) therefore to give me and my comrades the same credit for honesty of intention and action that you would claim for yourself and your colleagues and with such a mind reconsider your position and if you feel sure of its correctness try to convince me of the error of my way.
('54', 380, 1, 3, 840989) Why do you say I want to impose my views on the Government?
('54', 380, 1, 4, 841049) Argument is not an imposing.
('54', 380, 1, 5, 841078) The Congress does seek to convert the Government to its views by reason, negotiation and even by direct action, i.e., self suffering, so long as the Congress is sure of the correctness of its own position.
('54', 380, 1, 6, 841284) Is not this what every citizen or organization has done all the world over?
('54', 380, 1, 7, 841360) The congress has indeed struck a new path.
('54', 380, 1, 8, 841403) It has replaced the method of armed rebellion by self suffering.
('54', 380, 1, 9, 841468) If you believe in this profession of the Congress, surely you would welcome the coming in of a method that more becomes man’s dignity than the old law of the jungle.
('54', 380, 1, 10, 841634) But whether you feel with me as to the method or not I invite you still to try negotiation with the Congress and especially with me as its representative whom you gave no chance of even knowing the Government side of the case.
('54', 380, 1, 11, 841861) Remember the door was shut by you and not by me.
('54', 380, 1, 12, 841910) Open it in a gentlemanly manner and you will find me eager to enter in.
('54', 380, 1, 13, 841982) My regards to Lady Willingdon.
('54', 380, 1, 14, 842013) She must not be angry with me that I am causing worry to her husband.
('54', 380, 1, 15, 842083) I do not want to.
('54', 380, 1, 16, 842101) If at all, she must be angry with you in that in your anger or distrust, you banged the door in the face of a poor old man who knocked and was denied entrance.
('54', 380, 3, 17, 842261) Your sincere friend,
('54', 380, 4, 18, 842282) M. K. GANDHI
('54', 380, 5, 19, 842295) From a photostat: India Office Library and Records.
('54', 380, 5, 20, 842347) Courtesy: The British

('54', 387, 1, 2, 850866) 255. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('54', 387, 2, 3, 850897) January 21, 1932
('54', 387, 3, 4, 850914) NARANDAS, I got the post from the Ashram today, after I had waited for it for many days.
('54', 387, 3, 5, 851003) I was getting worried since I had received no reply.
('54', 387, 3, 6, 851056) As you posted the packet as a parcel, it was delayed.
('54', 387, 3, 7, 851110) On previous occasions, too, that is what happened.
('54', 387, 3, 8, 851161) I see, however, that posting things as parcel costs less.
('54', 387, 3, 9, 851219) You may, therefore, continue the practice if you wish to.
('54', 387, 3, 10, 851277) You can do this.
('54', 387, 3, 11, 851294) Send the many other letters as parcel and send yours separately, by ordinary post.
('54', 387, 3, 12, 851377) That will save expenditure and I will get one letter immediately.
('54', 387, 3, 13, 851443) Ordinarily you oranybody else will be able to write to me as often as necessary.
('54', 387, 3, 14, 851524) Most probably I will get the letters immediately.
('54', 387, 3, 15, 851574) You have done nothing wrong in reproducing in the “Ashram Samachar” 1 the extract from my letter.
('54', 387, 3, 16, 851672) Anyone from the Ashram will be permitted to visit us.
('54', 387, 3, 17, 851726) Others too, who have not become prominent in the political field, will be permitted; for instance, Pyare Ali 2, or Rama (Ranchhodbhai’s).
('54', 387, 3, 18, 851864) Three or four can come at a time.
('54', 387, 3, 19, 851898) We are permitted to receive visitors once a week.
('54', 387, 3, 20, 851948) But we don’t wish to waste money in this manner.
('54', 387, 3, 21, 851997) You may, therefore, permit people to come as and when you think proper.
('54', 387, 3, 22, 852069) I wish to tell you what is permissible and what my general view is, and leave the rest to you.
('54', 387, 3, 23, 852164) Don’t think that I am putting any restriction.
('54', 387, 3, 24, 852211) How can I judge what the circumstances there require, or measure the depth of people’s feelings or their foolish attachment to me?
('54', 387, 3, 25, 852342) Allow Krishnamaiyadevi and others to go to Darjeeling.
('54', 387, 3, 26, 852397) It will certainly mean expense, but that will be worth incurring.
('54', 387, 3, 27, 852463) I suppose in Darjeeling they will stay with some friends and we shall have to pay only the fare.
('54', 387, 3, 28, 852560) Give them the fare for the outward journey.
('54', 387, 3, 29, 852604) As for the return fare, tell them that you will send a note which they can show and get money from Bhai Jivanlal of the Birla Brothers.
('54', 387, 3, 30, 852740) That is, you can send them a letter of recommendation when they intend to return.
('54', 387, 3, 31, 852822) Will Mahavir also go with them?
('54', 387, 3, 32, 852854) If he does, let him stay there for five or six months.
('54', 387, 3, 33, 852909) After he has recovered, he can take up some public work in Darjeeling.
('54', 387, 3, 34, 852980) Similarly, send away the girls when they wish to go.
('54', 387, 4, 35, 853033) 1 A handwritten news bulletin of the Ashram 2 A business man from Bombay who, along with his wife Noorbanu, was an ardent follower of Gandhiji

('54', 388, 4, 18, 853898) 256. LETTER TO RAMANANDA CHATTERJEE
('54', 388, 5, 19, 853934) January 22, 1932

('54', 389, 1, 2, 854804) 257. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('54', 389, 2, 3, 854836) January 22, 1932
('54', 389, 3, 4, 854853) PREMA, I got your letter.
('54', 389, 3, 5, 854879) You did well in paying a visit to the women who are in prison.
('54', 389, 3, 6, 854942) There is no such thing as a miracle 1 in this world, or rather everything is a miracle.
('54', 389, 3, 7, 855030) That the earth is hanging in space withoutsupport and that we do not see the atman though we know that it dwells in our body—these are great miracles.
('54', 389, 3, 8, 855181) Compared to them, other miracles are as trivial as the conjuror’s mango tree.
('54', 389, 3, 9, 855259) “Keeping one’s eye single” 2 means that one should not see with a distorted vision, that one should keep one’s eyes pure and not cast lustful glances.
('54', 389, 3, 10, 855410) The statement has no other meaning.
('54', 389, 3, 11, 855446) Sarojinidevi’s case is a painful one.
('54', 389, 3, 12, 855484) If, however, we behave towards her in a spirit of non attachment, she will keep herself on the right path, no matter whether she continues to live there or lives in Prayag.
('54', 389, 4, 13, 855657) Blessings from

('54', 389, 7, 15, 855761) 258. LETTER TO SIR FREDERICK SYKES 3
('54', 389, 8, 16, 855798) January 23, 1932
('54', 389, 9, 17, 855815) DEAR FRIEND, The cordial conversations I had with you last year embolden me to write this to you.
('54', 389, 9, 18, 855913) If you would rather that, being a prisoner, I should not write to you, I shall cease to do so and this may be thrown away.
('54', 389, 9, 19, 856036) If however you don’t resent this letter, I may take the further liberty of writing again, should the occasion arise.
('54', 389, 9, 20, 856153) Whilst in my opinion all the ordinances are a tragic blunder and so utterly unnecessary, I can understand the Government taking a different view and trying to crush the Congress.
('54', 389, 9, 21, 856332) The organization may
('54', 389, 10, 22, 856353) 1 The addressee had asked Gandhiji what he thought of miracles.
('54', 389, 10, 23, 856417) 2 Vide St. Matthew, IV.
('54', 389, 11, 24, 856441) 3 Governor of Bombay
('54', 390, 0, 1, 856462) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 391
('54', 390, 1, 2, 856508) be put out of action for a time.
('54', 390, 1, 3, 856541) The spirit will never be crushed.
('54', 390, 1, 4, 856575) But this is another story.
('54', 390, 1, 5, 856602) What I want to draw your attention to is the excesses that are being committed under the ordinances.
('54', 390, 1, 6, 856703) The breaking up of a peaceful meeting in Ahmedabad by severe lathi charges and running horses through the meeting appears to have been a barbarous procedure, several young men were severely and some women were slightly hurt.
('54', 390, 1, 7, 856928) One young woman had her hair pulled.
('54', 390, 1, 8, 856965) This information I glean from the newspapers supplied to me.
('54', 390, 1, 9, 857026) In Nadiad the treatment is said to have been still more brutal and it isreported to have been the worst in Surat.
('54', 390, 1, 10, 857140) Boys in two boarding houses are said to have been hurriedly dragged out of them and the houses taken over by the authorities.
('54', 390, 1, 11, 857266) Such procedure brutalizes those who are engaged in carrying it out.
('54', 390, 1, 12, 857334) It should be borne in mind that all this treatment is being meted out to those who do not retaliate and have not been known to have done any previous violence.
('54', 390, 1, 13, 857494) The authorities have taken possession of the National University buildings in Ahmedabad.
('54', 390, 1, 14, 857583) The University has a rich collection of carefully selected books.
('54', 390, 1, 15, 857649) There is a religious section to the library.
('54', 390, 1, 16, 857694) It is admitted to be a unique library built up by devoted scholars.
('54', 390, 1, 17, 857762) It contains some rare and valuable manuscripts.
('54', 390, 1, 18, 857810) There is, too, a little museum which has an art collection.
('54', 390, 1, 19, 857870) The grounds have valuable trees planted on them.
('54', 390, 1, 20, 857919) The whole of this constructive effort—a fruit of ten years patient labour—is likely to be ruined without any just cause.
('54', 390, 1, 21, 858040) One of the most respectable Indians belonging to the celebrated Tyabji family, Mr. Abbas Tyabji who is 78 year old and who is an ex Chief Judge of the Baroda High Court is said to have been locked up in Nadiad along with other prisoners in what can only be described as a cage.
('54', 390, 1, 22, 858318) I ask you to investigate these statements.
('54', 390, 1, 23, 858361) Denials by the parties charged can be regarded as no investigation.
('54', 390, 1, 24, 858429) Often have such denials been proved to be worthless.
('54', 390, 1, 25, 858482) I have picked out but a few of what have appeared to me to be glaring instances of high handedness.
('54', 390, 1, 26, 858582) If past experience is any guide, probably the worst cases have not even been allowed to appear in the newspapers.
('54', 390, 1, 27, 858696) Nor do I get all the newspapers.
('54', 390, 1, 28, 858729) I write this as a friend wishing well to the English.
('54', 390, 1, 29, 858783) I am anxious that on both sides every avoidable cause of bitterness should be avoided.
('54', 390, 1, 30, 858870) I would like the fight to be conducted honourably on either
('54', 391, 0, 1, 858930) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 391, 1, 2, 858972) side so that at the end of it either party may be able to say of the other that there was no malice behind its actions.
('54', 391, 3, 3, 859092) Your sincere friend,

('54', 391, 6, 8, 859261) 259. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('54', 391, 7, 9, 859285) January 23, 1932
('54', 391, 8, 10, 859302) MIRA, The long awaited post came from the Ashram only yesterday.
('54', 391, 8, 11, 859367) I shall now get it regularly I expect.
('54', 391, 8, 12, 859406) Of course, you were right in going to Bombay.
('54', 391, 8, 13, 859452) You should be the sole judge finally as to where you would stay and what you would do.
('54', 391, 8, 14, 859539) When you write to the Privats, tell them they are constantly in my thoughts.
('54', 391, 8, 15, 859616) They must on no account impair their health.
('54', 391, 8, 16, 859661) They should write to me.
('54', 391, 8, 17, 859686) I have told you already not to bring or send the hanging bow.
('54', 391, 8, 18, 859748) 1 You have sent me so many slivers that I shall not need to card for some weeks yet.
('54', 391, 8, 19, 859833) And I am glad.
('54', 391, 8, 20, 859848) I have not yet regained my bodily strength.
('54', 391, 8, 21, 859892) I sleep at least thrice during the day in spite of full sleep between 9 p.m.
('54', 391, 8, 22, 859969) and 3.45 a.m.
('54', 391, 8, 23, 859983) I need sleep and rest as yet.
('54', 391, 8, 24, 860013) I do not spin 500 yards [like] 2 I did last year.
('54', 391, 8, 25, 860063) I am doing the amount in two days.
('54', 391, 8, 26, 860098) I am hoping however soon to be able to do 500 yards per day.
('54', 391, 8, 27, 860159) I will not strain myself to do it.
('54', 391, 8, 28, 860194) I shall try to conserve what energy there is still left in me.
('54', 391, 8, 29, 860257) This is no notice to you to bring or send me more slivers.
('54', 391, 8, 30, 860316) If I must have them I shall soon tell you.
('54', 391, 8, 31, 860359) My health is excellent and so is Sardar Vallabhbhai’s.
('54', 391, 8, 32, 860414) I have simply told you how much rest I still need.
('54', 391, 8, 33, 860465) The London wear and tear was terrific and I suppose the body now demands prolonged rest.
('54', 391, 8, 34, 860554) The Bombay rush on the top of London’s undid the good the voyage had undoubtedly done.
('54', 391, 8, 35, 860641) As to the visits, this time there is no difficulty.
('54', 391, 8, 36, 860693) They have

('54', 392, 3, 15, 861410) 260. LETTER TO KANTI GANDHI
('54', 392, 4, 16, 861438) January 23, 1932
('54', 392, 6, 17, 861455) I was glad to get your letter.
('54', 392, 6, 18, 861486) Personally I was very happy that all of you were given a taste of the Government’s kindness.
('54', 392, 6, 19, 861579) If the experience does not make us angry but, on the contrary, fills our heart with compassion for the other party, and if we are as ready as ever to welcome more such experience, we shall have realized the true aim of our life.
('54', 392, 6, 20, 861808) If anybody abused St. Francis, he would smile gently and thank God that He did not inspire that person to assault him, and if anybody assaulted him he would thank God that He did not inspire the latter to kill him outright.
('54', 392, 6, 21, 862032) If anybody attempted to kill him, St. Francis would say that after all he did not try to torture him.
('54', 392, 6, 22, 862134) The point is that he who has overcome love for his body and looks upon it only as an instrument will never be affected in his mind by anybody injuring his body.

('54', 393, 2, 3, 862432) January 23, 1932
('54', 393, 3, 4, 862449) BAL, I did get your letter, but I could find no time at all to reply.

('54', 393, 4, 11, 862948) Remember that none of us should get elated[with the service we are able to do].

('54', 393, 4, 13, 863082) We come into this world not to incur debts, but to pay them.
('54', 393, 4, 14, 863143) He who has no debts to discharge no longer needs to be burdened with a body.
('54', 393, 4, 15, 863220) Such a one is a free soul, and a debtor has no reason to feel elated even when he pays off his whole debt.
('54', 393, 4, 16, 863327) When he has done that, he only earns his rest.
('54', 393, 4, 17, 863374) To be free from one’s debts is to be free from bondage.

('54', 404, 1, 2, 879802) 280. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('54', 404, 2, 3, 879830) Silence Day, January 25, 1932
('54', 404, 3, 4, 879860) DEAR SISTERS, I hope you will understand that it is not possible for me to write to each of you separately.
('54', 404, 3, 5, 879968) Of course, whenever it is necessary, and I get time, I write to some of you individually.
('54', 404, 3, 6, 880058) But this time, too, I intend to write a joint letter to the women as I used to do formerly.
('54', 404, 3, 7, 880150) During these days, when all of us are passing through a testing time, I hope that all of you will derive great consolation from Draupadi’s prayer.
('54', 404, 3, 8, 880297) Really speaking, all of us are now in the same plight as she was.
('54', 404, 3, 9, 880363) No human being can save our honour, God alone can do that.
('54', 404, 3, 10, 880422) It is true that He often sends His help through men.
('54', 404, 3, 11, 880475) But such a man is only God’s tool or instrument.
('54', 404, 3, 12, 880524) This much in regard to the difficult time through which we are passing.
('54', 404, 3, 13, 880596) Now a little from my experiences in England.
('54', 404, 3, 14, 880641) I may say that in England, too, I received from women almost the same love that I have always received from Indian women.
('54', 404, 3, 15, 880763) Just as you have kept no secret from me, there in England also I came across women who opened their hearts to me.
('54', 404, 3, 16, 880877) They came from long distances to accompany me in my early morning walks and to talk to me.
('54', 404, 3, 17, 880968) The moral which I drew from this is that non violence is a very wide thing.
('54', 404, 3, 18, 881044) It includes absolute freedom from impure thoughts.
('54', 404, 3, 19, 881095) I also saw that Indian women were in no way inferior to European women.
('54', 404, 3, 20, 881167) Much of their strength lies suppressed and some of it has had no opportunity to reveal itself.
('54', 404, 3, 21, 881262) Whenever I observed the European women’s superiority, I could also see the causes of it.
('54', 404, 3, 22, 881351) If the same causes begin to operate in our country, the women here also would become like them.
('54', 404, 3, 23, 881447) However, we should certainly reflect over the superiority which weobserve in European women.
('54', 404, 3, 24, 881540) We should not feel elated thinking that that strength lies concealed in us; nor should we be complacent on that account.
('54', 404, 3, 25, 881661) They possess the power of organization and can unite and work very well like the men.
('54', 404, 3, 26, 881747) They don’t think themselves helpless, but fearlessly move about wherever they like.
('54', 404, 3, 27, 881831) In England, if a woman goes out alone either during day or at night, it is not thought necessary for anybody to accompany her.
('54', 404, 3, 28, 881958) Nursing in hospitals has become an exclusive province of women, and they do the work very well indeed.
('54', 404, 3, 29, 882061) The sacrifices made by some women are beyond praise.
('54', 404, 3, 30, 882114) Muriel Lester who came to stay with us at the Ashram is a daughter of rich parents.

('54', 406, 1, 2, 884607) children, and to that end she has been running a beautiful school for them.
('54', 406, 1, 3, 884683) It has no male teacher.

('54', 406, 1, 6, 884911) I liked one thing which I saw there.

('54', 414, 5, 6, 899786) 290. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('54', 414, 6, 7, 899815) Y.C.P. January 27, 1932
('54', 414, 7, 8, 899839) DEAR MR. EMERSON, After the receipt of your very frank and good letter received by me in London, I had not expected the turn the events took on my landing.
('54', 414, 7, 9, 899995) I suppose I am right in thinking that yours is the brain working behind this repression.

('54', 415, 1, 15, 902243) As Mrs. Gandhi is reported to have said justly at her trial, what is the use of women like her or men like Sardar Vallabhbhai and me being pampered prisoners when others who, being misled, as you would say by us, break laws and suffer lathi blows or worse?
('54', 415, 1, 16, 902500) I do really think that there is much in what The Daily Express says when it suggests that I as the author of “all this mischief” should be sent to the gallows.
('54', 415, 1, 17, 902660) Does it not strike you that there is something terribly wrong with a Government that has to declare a thousand associations unlawful?
('54', 415, 1, 18, 902794) How is it possible to crush a movement which has taken such deep root?
('54', 415, 1, 19, 902865) You have suppressed social and economic activities.
('54', 415, 1, 20, 902917) You have taken possession of school buildings, hospitals, khadi depots, a library that contains valuable research and religious works.
('54', 415, 1, 21, 903052) Is that what you meant by hitting hard?
('54', 415, 1, 22, 903092) I fear you have undone Lord Irwin’s work.
('54', 415, 1, 23, 903134) I had come with the fullest desire to tender co operation, if it was at all possible.
('54', 415, 1, 24, 903220) You should have seen me, reasoned with me and if you had found me wilfully obstinate, you might have taken such course as you had thought necessary.
('54', 415, 1, 25, 903369) As it is, I cannot help feeling that you took a course which I should not have thought you to be capable of taking.
('54', 415, 1, 26, 903485) I plead : retrace your steps.
('54', 415, 1, 27, 903515) Some day there is no doubt there will be negotiation if not between the present Government and the present Congressmen, then between our successors.
('54', 415, 1, 28, 903664) Let us not doanything that will make them meet with bitterness in their souls.
('54', 415, 1, 29, 903743) I can say for myself with the clearest possible conscience that I have done nothig to embitter the relations.
('54', 415, 1, 30, 903853) If you too can say likewise, I can only say let an impartial authority judge between us.
('54', 415, 1, 31, 903942) In any case,
('54', 416, 0, 1, 903955) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 417
('54', 416, 1, 2, 904001) breath in me I shall long for co operation even through my non co operation.
('54', 416, 1, 3, 904078) I do not believe in a make believe co operation.
('54', 416, 1, 4, 904127) You will please pardon me for this long letter.
('54', 416, 1, 5, 904175) If it is an infliction, you are to blame, for you allowed me to think that we had become good friends.
('54', 416, 1, 6, 904278) I have exercised the privilege of a friend.
('54', 416, 2, 7, 904322) Yours sincerely,
('54', 416, 3, 8, 904339) M. K. GANDHI

('54', 417, 0, 1, 905518) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 417, 1, 2, 905560) 292. A LETTER
('54', 417, 2, 3, 905574) January 28, 1932
('54', 417, 3, 4, 905591) MY DEAR, You are right about the repetition of the prayers by some without knowing the meaning.
('54', 417, 3, 5, 905687) Effort has been often made to remove the defect.
('54', 417, 3, 6, 905736) But in a place which has a floating population, the task is difficult.
('54', 417, 3, 7, 905807) A prayerful repetition is itself not a bad thing.
('54', 417, 3, 8, 905857) It is like music that has no words.
('54', 417, 3, 9, 905893) The music has its own distinct effect apart from words.
('54', 417, 3, 10, 905949) This defence is good only where there is no hypocrisy and the mind is properly attuned.
('54', 417, 3, 11, 906037) If I am not mistaken the remains of food is not given to the cattle because it is not good for their health.
('54', 417, 3, 12, 906146) They are scientifically fed.
('54', 417, 3, 13, 906175) Burial is not waste.
('54', 417, 3, 14, 906196) The food turns to manure.
('54', 417, 3, 15, 906222) The real remedy is that there is no waste.
('54', 417, 3, 16, 906265) We try to live the life of the poor and hence we should take in our dishes no more than we need.
('54', 417, 3, 17, 906362) I know there are many difficulties.
('54', 417, 6, 18, 906398) From Gujarati: C.W. 8920. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('54', 417, 7, 19, 906450) 293. A LETTER
('54', 417, 8, 20, 906464) January 28, 1932
('54', 417, 9, 21, 906481) BHAI, What further explanation do you want beyond what I have given in my writings on the Gita?
('54', 417, 9, 22, 906577) Thoughts occur only in a vikari mind.
('54', 417, 9, 23, 906615) The word vikar should be understood here in a very wide sense.
('54', 417, 9, 24, 906678) Vikar means change of state.
('54', 417, 9, 25, 906707) Even pure thoughts do not arise in a state of samadhi, and yet it is not a state of utter inertness.
('54', 417, 9, 26, 906808) God does not think, because he is nirvikar 1. Absence of thoughts does not mean a state of inertness, it means pure consciousness.
('54', 417, 9, 27, 906939) This is a state which cannot be described but can only be experienced.
('54', 417, 9, 28, 907010) I don’t mean to say, however, that I have experienced it.
('54', 417, 9, 29, 907068) I believe in it through faith.
('54', 417, 9, 30, 907099) I may even say that I have had a faint glimpse of it.
('54', 417, 11, 31, 907153) From Gujarati: C.W. 8907. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('54', 417, 12, 32, 907205) 1 Not subject to vikar

('54', 418, 1, 2, 907274) 294. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('54', 418, 2, 3, 907306) January 28, 1932
('54', 418, 3, 4, 907323) GANGABEHN, I got your letter.
('54', 418, 3, 5, 907353) I am not surprised at what is happening today.
('54', 418, 3, 6, 907400) I had expected it all.
('54', 418, 3, 7, 907423) Much worse will follow yet.
('54', 418, 3, 8, 907451) Didn’t Sudhanva have to jump into a pan of boiling oil to prove his faith?
('54', 418, 3, 9, 907526) Sita had to enter the flames, and Prahlad was forced to embrace a red hot pillar.
('54', 418, 3, 10, 907608) He whose faith in God is perfect has no limit to his endurance.
('54', 418, 3, 11, 907672) God provides sufficient food alike to the elephant and the ant according to the need of each.
('54', 418, 3, 12, 907766) There is a verse in the Gita 1 which says: “In whatever way men resort to Me, even so do I render to them.” This is what it means: “I give to the people in proportion to the faith with which they worship Me.” If you draw water from a well with a cup, you will get a cupful and, if you draw with a pitcher, you will draw a pitcherful.
('54', 418, 3, 13, 908100) Chanchalbehn has done good work indeed.
('54', 418, 3, 14, 908140) I am writing to her.
('54', 418, 3, 15, 908161) Go and give the letter to her or read it out to her.
('54', 418, 3, 16, 908214) It should not be published.

('54', 420, 7, 8, 910004) 300. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('54', 420, 8, 9, 910036) YERAVDA MANDIR, January 28, 1932
('54', 420, 9, 10, 910069) PRABHUDAS, I have your letter.
('54', 420, 9, 11, 910100) I like the views of Krishnadas.
('54', 420, 9, 12, 910132) I would like him to stay with you.
('54', 420, 9, 13, 910167) But the occasion is inopportune.
('54', 420, 9, 14, 910200) The dissociation of Krishnadas from Wardha is looked upon by official guests, viz., Jamnalal, Vinoba and others as a betrayal of trust.
('54', 420, 9, 15, 910336) I believe that he cannot give up the work he has undertaken unless he can do so in normal course.
('54', 420, 9, 16, 910434) Ultimately, his inner self will help him get peace of mind.
('54', 420, 9, 17, 910494) He would not get that by change of work.
('54', 420, 9, 18, 910535) My advice therefore is let Krishnadas stick to his views, but he should not put them in practice.
('54', 420, 9, 19, 910633) It seldom happens that what we like is also good for us.
('54', 420, 9, 20, 910690) I feel it is true in the case of Krishnadas but such opportunity should be welcomed when it comes in the normal course.
('54', 420, 9, 21, 910810) I am of the opinion that at present we cannot even ask Jamnalal and Vinoba and cause them inconvenience.
('54', 420, 9, 22, 910915) I have formed my opinion according to my understanding of the situation based on the facts you have put before me.
('54', 420, 9, 23, 911030) Let me know if there is a misunderstanding on my part or some facts are left out.
('54', 420, 9, 24, 911112) If there is no misunderstanding, send this reply to Krishnadas.
('54', 420, 9, 25, 911176) If the misunderstanding persists, ask me again.
('54', 420, 9, 26, 911224) We can ask Jamnalal or Mathuradas for the money for Almora.
('54', 420, 9, 27, 911284) We should wind it up if we can.
('54', 420, 9, 28, 911316) And if it is better to postpone it, you may do that.
('54', 420, 9, 29, 911369) I cannot give any definite decision from here.
('54', 420, 9, 30, 911416) You will have to run away when the summer comes.
('54', 420, 9, 31, 911465) We will incur expenses but that cannot be helped.
('54', 420, 9, 32, 911515) You are rendering whatever service you can.
('54', 420, 9, 33, 911559) We should put up with it when the public malign us but have to be very cautious when our own heart takes exception to it.

('54', 426, 12, 16, 919328) January 30, 1932
('54', 426, 13, 17, 919345) MAHALAKSHMI, I have your letter.
('54', 426, 13, 18, 919378) It is probable that the gas trouble is caused by milk.
('54', 426, 13, 19, 919433) Try the following.
('54', 426, 13, 20, 919452) Take curds instead of milk, but not more than half a seer at a time.
('54', 426, 13, 21, 919521) Add ten grains of soda bicarb to the curds.
('54', 426, 13, 22, 919565) You may take one and a half seers of curds during the whole day.
('54', 426, 13, 23, 919630) You can then take one and a half seers of dates.
('54', 426, 13, 24, 919679) But they also should not exceed half a seer at a time.
('54', 426, 13, 25, 919734) As the dates are likely to have been soiled, you should wash them before eating.
('54', 426, 13, 26, 919815) There is no harm in mixing them with the curds after washing and taking out their stones.
('54', 426, 13, 27, 919905) Remember that dates will need time to get softened in curds.
('54', 426, 13, 28, 919966) In addition, take also the raw vegetables I mentioned earlier, but very little of them.
('54', 426, 13, 29, 920054) You will certainly feel thirsty between meals.
('54', 426, 13, 30, 920101) You may then take water with
('54', 426, 14, 31, 920130) 1 A stick 2 A girl beloved by the family
('54', 427, 0, 1, 920171) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 427, 1, 2, 920213) soda bicarb and lemon juice added to it.
('54', 427, 1, 3, 920254) This will stop the gas and the body will feel light.
('54', 427, 1, 4, 920307) Dates never cause gas.
('54', 427, 1, 5, 920330) Probably it is caused by milk.
('54', 427, 1, 6, 920361) If the curds cause constipation, take milk once instead of curds.
('54', 427, 1, 7, 920427) If the milk is fresh and cold, you may soak datesin it also and eat them.
('54', 427, 1, 8, 920501) They will get soft only if you let them soak for some time.
('54', 427, 1, 9, 920561) If you eat them soon after putting them in cold milk, you will not find them soft.
('54', 427, 1, 10, 920644) Dates cannot help you to become fat, but the milk might.
('54', 427, 1, 11, 920701) One cannot live on dates alone for many days, if one wants to do physical labour.
('54', 427, 1, 12, 920783) In the letter to Madhavji I mentioned one seer of dates, and this letter is an amendment of that since here I have suggested one and a half seers of curds or milk in place of three seers of milk.

('54', 427, 6, 20, 921358) 313. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('54', 427, 7, 21, 921395) January 30, 1932
('54', 427, 8, 22, 921412) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, I could give to you some more reminiscences of Miss Doris’s school, about which I wrote to you last week.
('54', 427, 8, 23, 921539) But I will leave that subject today and write about [Madame] Montessori’s schoolchildren.
('54', 427, 8, 24, 921629) Montessori is an aged lady.
('54', 427, 8, 25, 921657) She has dedicated her life to children’s education.
('54', 427, 8, 26, 921709) She is an Italian lady.
('54', 427, 8, 27, 921733) Learn from your teachers where Italy is and how its government is run.
('54', 427, 8, 28, 921804) Keep the map of Europe before you.
('54', 427, 8, 29, 921839) In the map it looks like a fat leg which has separated from the rest of the body.
('54', 427, 8, 30, 921921) But let us leave that and return to the school of the learned Madame Montessori.
('54', 427, 8, 31, 922002) The lady happened to be in England, where they were holding a conference of all teachers who followed her method.
('54', 427, 8, 32, 922116) She invited me to it and explained to me how and what they taught the
('54', 428, 0, 1, 922186) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 429
('54', 428, 1, 2, 922232) children.
('54', 428, 1, 3, 922242) The most important thing was that the children felt no burden of learning as they learnt everything as they played.
('54', 428, 1, 4, 922358) Secondly, the aim is to develop all the senses and organs of the child, that is, its hands, feet, nose, ears, tongue, skin and the mind, and they have very carefully planned a teaching programme with that aim in view.In the programme very little place is given to memorizing.
('54', 428, 1, 5, 922634) Music has an important place, and it accompanies physical exercises also.
('54', 428, 1, 6, 922708) They teach dancing too, and it gives plenty of exercise to the body.
('54', 428, 1, 7, 922777) The children do most of the things by themselves and learn without effort to concentrate attention.
('54', 428, 1, 8, 922877) The thing I liked most in their method was that they trained children to observe silence and concentrate.
('54', 428, 1, 9, 922983) This is how they do it.
('54', 428, 1, 10, 923007) The children sit with closed eyes, the teacher speaks in a voice no louder than a whisper into one’s ear and children strain their ears to hear what she says.
('54', 428, 1, 11, 923166) As soon as any child hears it, it goes over on its toes and sits by the side of the teacher.
('54', 428, 1, 12, 923259) Till all the children have done this one after another, everyone is to remain sitting and keep silent.
('54', 428, 1, 13, 923362) You, too, should try this.
('54', 428, 2, 14, 923389) Blessings from
('54', 428, 4, 15, 923404) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('54', 428, 5, 16, 923448) 314. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('54', 428, 6, 17, 923480) January 30, 1932
('54', 428, 7, 18, 923497) PREMA, I got your letter.
('54', 428, 7, 19, 923523) Has the trunk of books which I brought with me arrived there?
('54', 428, 7, 20, 923585) Does anybody live in the Vidyapith?
('54', 428, 7, 21, 923621) Does anyone take care of the books or is everything falling into ruin?
('54', 428, 7, 22, 923692) Many of the monthlies too are worth preserving.
('54', 428, 7, 23, 923740) It is desirable that there should be one whole time person to look after the books assisted by two others.
('54', 428, 7, 24, 923847) If this is not possible, we should not have allowed the library to grow so large.
('54', 428, 7, 25, 923929) It is the duty of the Vidyapith to make this arrangement.
('54', 428, 7, 26, 923987) It is not our job.
('54', 428, 7, 27, 924006) It is because this was not our work that we started the Vidyapith, otherwise we would have turned the Ashram itself into a Vidyapith.
('54', 428, 7, 28, 924140) The work does not lie within the Ashram’s sphere of activities at all.
('54', 428, 7, 29, 924211) Its work is primarily internal, and the Vidyapith’s is primarily external, and so it ought to be.
('54', 428, 7, 30, 924309) The aims of both are the same but their activities are different.
('54', 428, 7, 31, 924375) In the Ashram, therefore, we should keep only such books as we require for our purpose.
('54', 429, 0, 1, 924463) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 429, 1, 2, 924505) books that we may need, we should borrow from the Vidyapith.
('54', 429, 1, 3, 924566) All this, however, when we settle down again to our normal activities.
('54', 429, 1, 4, 924637) Just now everything is being swept away by a flood, and that is all to the good.
('54', 429, 1, 5, 924718) When the flood has subsided, don’t we have a wide expanse of water, clear as crystal?
('54', 429, 1, 6, 924804) I remember the Nag Panchami festival, and I adhere to the reply which I gave on that occasion.
('54', 429, 1, 7, 924899) Haven’t I compared the breaking of heads to the explosion of crackers?
('54', 429, 1, 8, 924970) Anyone who knows the nature of the atman will believe that to be literally so.
('54', 429, 1, 9, 925049) If the atman never perishes, what does it matter that the houses it inhabits perish or that the garments which it puts on wear out and decay?
('54', 429, 1, 10, 925191) Moreover, the atman is eternally perfect and so it can never lack a house to inhabit.
('54', 429, 1, 11, 925277) If we but know the truth, it needs none.
('54', 429, 1, 12, 925318) But all this is true only with reference to oneself.
('54', 429, 1, 13, 925371) So long, therefore, as our own heads are being broken, we should think that crackers are exploding.
('54', 429, 1, 14, 925471) Don’t ask me how the atman can make a distinction between one’s own and another’s.
('54', 429, 1, 15, 925554) So long as the body endures, we must assume this distinction in all our actions.
('54', 429, 1, 16, 925635) As we die to ourselves, the distinction between one’s own and another’s loses its force for us, but so long as we go on killing others, the distinction becomes stronger.
('54', 429, 1, 17, 925805) As the children gradually understand this truth, they too, like the young men in the Ashram, will become wise.
('54', 429, 1, 18, 925916) But that requires patience on our part.
('54', 429, 1, 19, 925956) In this connection, read my letter 1 to the children.

('54', 430, 7, 12, 926475) 316. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('54', 430, 8, 13, 926503) January 30, 1932
('54', 430, 9, 14, 926520) DEAR SISTERS, I wish to write to you today about a lady.
('54', 430, 9, 15, 926577) Her name is Maude Royden.
('54', 430, 9, 16, 926603) She is an old woman.
('54', 430, 9, 17, 926624) She has remained unmarried.
('54', 430, 9, 18, 926652) She was the first woman in England to obtain the highest degree in theology.
('54', 430, 9, 19, 926729) Besides her, there has been only one other woman who has obtained that degree.
('54', 430, 9, 20, 926808) I am saying this not to show that theology is a very difficult subject, though it certainly is that.
('54', 430, 9, 21, 926909) My point is that few women have been attracted to it.
('54', 430, 9, 22, 926963) It does not help one to acquire status or importance in the world.
('54', 430, 9, 23, 927030) Not only has Maude Royden studied the subject so deeply, but she has also dedicated her life to the service of the poor.
('54', 430, 9, 24, 927151) Like Miss Muriel, she too makes no distinction between whites and non whites.
('54', 430, 9, 25, 927229) Through her own efforts she got a church built, which gives shelter to the poor and in which they hold their meetings.
('54', 430, 9, 26, 927348) These services have brought the lady great honour.
('54', 430, 9, 27, 927399) People valued her learning very little, but her services to the poor have made the lady very famous.
('54', 430, 9, 28, 927500) She is also a powerful speaker, and in her character she is above all reproach.
('54', 430, 9, 29, 927580) She relies on herself in all her activities and does not regard herself a weak and helpless woman.
('54', 430, 9, 30, 927679) She has travelled widely and gathered much experience.
('54', 430, 9, 31, 927734) Perhaps she may even come here to help us in our work.
('54', 430, 9, 32, 927789) The main question before her will be whether she can be free from her present work.

('54', 434, 1, 2, 930901) 323. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('54', 434, 2, 3, 930932) Night, January 28/February 1,1932
('54', 434, 3, 4, 930966) NARANDAS, I feel that my right hand will not give good service for long, and so I intend to use both hands.
('54', 434, 3, 5, 931074) It will take more time, of course.
('54', 434, 3, 6, 931109) But I should not want time here.
('54', 434, 3, 7, 931142) I will give less time to other work.
('54', 434, 3, 8, 931179) I have written a letter to Chanchalbehn whose son Visu died the other day.
('54', 434, 3, 9, 931254) That letter should not be published or talked about.
('54', 434, 3, 10, 931307) My actions are governed by mutual trust.
('54', 434, 3, 11, 931348) I do nothing without the knowledge of the authorities.
('54', 434, 3, 12, 931403) I will talk to them about this letter.
('54', 434, 3, 13, 931442) There seems nothing wrong to me in writing a letter of condolence.
('54', 434, 3, 14, 931509) But it would be wrong if such a letter were published.
('54', 434, 3, 15, 931564) That would be propaganda.
('54', 434, 3, 16, 931590) That is why I have asked Gangabehn 1 to show that letter to Chanchalbehn and then bring it back with her.
('54', 434, 3, 17, 931696) No letter of mine is intended for publication in newspapers.
('54', 434, 3, 18, 931757) There is nothing wrong, though, in your publishing in the “Ashram Samachar” extracts from them containing moral discussions or news about our health.
('54', 434, 3, 19, 931907) Parnerkar does not seem to have calmed down.
('54', 434, 3, 20, 931952) I believe that the problem before him is certainly a moral one.
('54', 434, 3, 21, 932016) Call him to you and comfort him.
('54', 434, 3, 22, 932049) Ultimately, of course, you will do what you think best.
('54', 434, 3, 23, 932105) I don’t look upon the orchard as a white elephant.
('54', 434, 3, 24, 932156) It is a useful investment.
('54', 434, 3, 25, 932183) The money that is spent on it will not, in the long run, have been wasted.
('54', 434, 3, 26, 932258) An orchard always increases the value of the land, helps the soil to retain moisture and cools the air.
('54', 434, 3, 27, 932362) This is a universal experience.
('54', 434, 3, 28, 932394) The choice of trees to be planted may of course require thinking.
('54', 434, 3, 29, 932460) I have only stated a general principle.
('54', 434, 3, 30, 932500) Obtain Prof.
('54', 434, 3, 31, 932513) Trivedi’s opinion.

('54', 442, 5, 13, 942463) February 5, 1932
('54', 442, 6, 14, 942480) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI 2, I observe that you have over two hundred civil resistance prisoners in the extension.
('54', 442, 6, 15, 942589) Many of these are intimate co workers.
('54', 442, 6, 16, 942628) I knew that you had already several from Poona but as they were important public men, I did not ask for meeting them.
('54', 442, 6, 17, 942746) But with regard to the large number now admitted, an occasional meeting with them is a human want I may not resist.
('54', 442, 6, 18, 942862) Exactly the same question occurred last year and after talks with Major Martin and then Major Doyle, permission was given to me to see these prisoners occasionally and in small batches of two or three.
('54', 442, 6, 19, 943064) I repeat the request and I hope that the authorities will have no objection to my seeing these fellow prisonersand workers, subject of course to the same restrictions as last year.

('54', 444, 5, 15, 946097) 338. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('54', 444, 6, 16, 946125) February 5, 1932
('54', 444, 7, 17, 946142) DEAR SISTERS, Only a few of you are now left there.
('54', 444, 7, 18, 946194) But there is an ebb and flow in all things in the world.
('54', 444, 7, 19, 946251) Mother Gita teaches us to remain unaffected by rise and fall, sunshine and cold, or happiness and misery.
('54', 444, 7, 20, 946357) We are at present getting an object lesson in the Mother’s teaching.
('54', 444, 7, 21, 946426) If all of you learn it well, our trust in the Gita will have borne fruit.I have observed that in certain respects people in Europe act according to the teaching of the Gita without knowing it.
('54', 444, 7, 22, 946619) Just now I remember only one thing, and I will describe it to you.
('54', 444, 7, 23, 946686) Whenever I went out of London I used to put up with friends, who may be said tobe well to do.
('54', 444, 7, 24, 946780) I saw that the servants at their places lived not as servants but as members of the family.
('54', 444, 7, 25, 946872) They did not put an excessive burden of work on the servants, but worked side by side with them.
('54', 444, 7, 26, 946969) If anybody had to get up early in the morning, he would not disturb the servant from his sleep but attend to the work himself.
('54', 444, 7, 27, 947096) At several places I found the servants to have been with the family for many years.
('54', 444, 7, 28, 947180) In almost every family they
('54', 445, 0, 1, 947208) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('54', 445, 1, 2, 947250) introduced me to their servants.
('54', 445, 1, 3, 947283) Their love of cleanliness was wonderful.
('54', 445, 1, 4, 947324) On seeing all this, my respect for the friends increased very much.

('54', 449, 1, 11, 954545) If therefore it is lawful to wage war at all, it makes no difference whether it is kinsmen who are concerned or strangers.
('54', 449, 1, 12, 954668) But this physical, outward war is merely a shadow of the war that is going on within—between God and Satan, forces of evil and good.
('54', 449, 1, 13, 954801) And do we not always have difficult and delicate problems of conscience arising within us?
('54', 449, 1, 14, 954892) The Gita says, “Surrender all to God, He will take care of you and your doubts; do not vex yourself about anything but simply perform the service that comes to you in the name of and for the sake of God.
('54', 449, 1, 15, 955096) Cultivate uttermost selflessness and all will be well.” The result of this selfless detachment must be uttermost truth and non violence.

('54', 457, 1, 6, 965925) I have some free time today and so I wish to describe a few details of the routine here.
('54', 457, 1, 7, 966014) Both of us get up at 3.40. After brushing, we pray.
('54', 457, 1, 8, 966066) After that, we take warm water with honey and lemon juice and then read till the stroke of five.
('54', 457, 1, 9, 966163) From five to six, we walk.
('54', 457, 1, 10, 966190) At six, if I feel the call of nature I answer it, and then sleep for about 20 minutes.
('54', 457, 1, 11, 966277) I get up at 6.45, when the bell for opening the cells is given, and read up to seven.
('54', 457, 1, 12, 966363) The Sardar, after answering the call of nature, walks about and sits down to breakfast when milk is brought.
('54', 457, 1, 13, 966472) As he eats the breakfast, he reads from the newspaper, which has arrived by then.
('54', 457, 1, 14, 966554) During the day, I read, write and spin.
('54', 457, 1, 15, 966594) In between I take a nap twice.
('54', 457, 1, 16, 966625) The Sardar walks about much longer than I do.
('54', 457, 1, 17, 966671) He generally reads from the newspapers which are supplied to us.
('54', 457, 1, 18, 966736) I have two meals a day.
('54', 457, 1, 19, 966760) The Sardar occasionally eats salad or something else like that at twelve.
('54', 457, 1, 20, 966834) I again take warm water and honey at that time.
('54', 457, 1, 21, 966882) When the honey isexhausted, I add jaggery and lemon juice.
('54', 457, 1, 22, 966941) I once happened to remark that Mirabehn or Pyarelal used to prepare fruit for me to eat.
('54', 457, 1, 23, 967030) Since then the Sardar has monopolized that duty.
('54', 457, 1, 24, 967079) It is he who prepares dates and tomatoes for me and does it with great love.
('54', 457, 1, 25, 967156) I have accepted this loving service without the slightest hesitation.
('54', 457, 1, 26, 967226) Having mentioned the service rendered by Mirabehn and Pyarelal, it would be a useless attempt on my part to decline the Sardar’s help.
('54', 457, 1, 27, 967361) He takes milk and bread in the morning.
('54', 457, 1, 28, 967401) At four in the afternoon, he takes bread, curds and some vegetables and, generally salad.
('54', 457, 1, 29, 967491) I used to take milk in the morning, with dates, tomatoes and, from the fruit sent by Lady Thackersey or Prof.
('54', 457, 1, 30, 967601) Trivedi, some oranges, chikus, etc.
('54', 457, 1, 31, 967637) At present, I eat dates and tomatoes and, in the morning, take half a pound of milk, and in the evening the same quantity of curds.
('54', 457, 1, 32, 967769) But I see that I shall have to reduce the quantity of milk still further.
('54', 457, 1, 33, 967843) My health is good, of course.
('54', 457, 1, 34, 967873) Do you know that my weight has increased?
('54', 457, 1, 35, 967915) I see that now I do not need very nourishing food, especially when I enjoy solitude and peace of mind.
('54', 457, 1, 36, 968018) This was my experience last year.
('54', 457, 1, 37, 968052) While in jail, I could live without milk and maintain my weight.
('54', 457, 1, 38, 968117) After my release, I lost weight in a short time for want of milk and, therefore, resumed it.
('54', 457, 1, 39, 968210) In England, it was only with that that I could keep up my strength.
('54', 457, 1, 40, 968278) Here I may not perhaps need milk.
('54', 457, 1, 41, 968312) On the contrary milk may even do me harm.
('54', 457, 1, 42, 968354) Of course I will do no violence to my body.

('54', 461, 2, 3, 972859) APPENDIX I ROMAIN ROLLAND’S LETTER TO AN AMERICAN FRIEND 1
('54', 461, 3, 4, 972918) December, 1931
('54', 461, 4, 5, 972933) How I should have liked to have you here during the visit of the Indians!
('54', 461, 4, 6, 973007) They stayed five days—from Sunday night until Friday afternoon, the eleventh—at the Villa Vionette.
('54', 461, 4, 7, 973107) The little man, bespectacled and toothless, was wrapped in his white burnoose, but his legs, thin as a heron’s stilts, were bare.
('54', 461, 4, 8, 973237) His shaven head with its few coarse hairs was uncovered and wet with rain.
('54', 461, 4, 9, 973312) He came to me with a dry laugh, his mouth open, like good dog panting, and flinging an arm around me leaned his cheek against my shoulder.
('54', 461, 4, 10, 973451) I felt his grizzled head against my cheek.
('54', 461, 4, 11, 973494) It was, I amuse myself thinking, the kiss of St. Dominic and St. Francis.
('54', 461, 5, 12, 973568) Then came Mira (Miss Slade), proud of figure and with the stately bearing of a
('54', 461, 6, 13, 973647) Demeter and finally three Indians, one young son of Gandhi, Devdas, with a round and
('54', 461, 7, 14, 973732) happy face.
('54', 461, 7, 15, 973744) He is gentle and but little aware of the grandeur of his name.
('54', 461, 7, 16, 973807) The others
('54', 461, 8, 17, 973818) were secretaries—disciples—two young men of rare qualities of heart and mind:
('54', 461, 9, 18, 973896) Mahadev Desai and Pyarelal.
('54', 461, 10, 19, 973924) As I had contrived shortly beforehand to get a severe cold on my chest, it was to my house and to the chamber on the second floor where I sleep at Villa Olga—you will remember it—that Gandhi came each morning for long conversations.
('54', 461, 10, 20, 974157) My sister interpreted with the assistance of Mira, and I had also a Russian friend and secretary, Miss Kondacheff, who took notes on our discussions.
('54', 461, 10, 21, 974307) Some good photographs by Schlemmer, our neighbour from Montreux, recorded the aspect of our interviews.
('54', 461, 11, 22, 974411) Evening at seven o’clock, prayers were held in the first floor salon.
('54', 461, 11, 23, 974481) With lights lowered, the Indians seated on the carpet, and a little assembly of the faithful grouped about, there was a suite of three beautiful chants—the first an extract form the Gita, the second an ancient hymn of the Sanskrit texts which Gandhi has
('54', 461, 12, 24, 974735) translated and the third a canticle of Rama and Siva, intoned by the warm, grave voice of Mira.
('54', 461, 13, 25, 974831) Gandhi held other prayers at three o’clock in the morning for which, in London, he used to wake his harassed staff, although he had not retired until one.
('54', 461, 13, 26, 974986) This little man, so frail in appearance, is tireless, and fatigue is a word which does not exist in his vocabulary.
('54', 461, 13, 27, 975102) He could calmly answer for hours the heckling of a crowd, as he did at Lausanne and Geneva, without a muscle of his face twitching.
('54', 461, 13, 28, 975234) Seated on a table, motionless, his voice always clear and calm, he replied to his adversaries open or masked—and they were not lacking at Geneva—giving them rude truths which left them silenced and suffocated.
('54', 461, 14, 29, 975444) 1 Vide “Discussion with Romain Rolland”, 6 12 1931
('54', 462, 0, 1, 975495) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 463
('54', 462, 1, 2, 975541) The Roman bourgeoisie, and nationalist, who had at first received him with crafty looks, quivered with rage when he left.
('54', 462, 1, 3, 975663) I believe that if his stay had lasted any longer the public meetings would have been forbidden.
('54', 462, 1, 4, 975759) He pronounced himself as unequivocally as possible on the double question of nationl armaments and the conflict between capital and labour.
('54', 462, 1, 5, 975899) I was largely responsible for steering him on this latter course.
('54', 462, 2, 6, 975965) His mind proceeds through successive experiments into action and he follows a straight line, but he never stops, and one would risk error in attempting to judge him by what he said ten years ago, because his thought is in constant evolution.
('54', 462, 2, 7, 976207) I will give you a little example of it that is characteristic.
('54', 462, 3, 8, 976270) He was asked at Lausanne to define what he understood by God.
('54', 462, 3, 9, 976332) He explained how, among the noblest attributes which the Hindu scriptures ascribed to God, he had in his youth chosen the word ‘truth’ as most truly defining the essential element.
('54', 462, 3, 10, 976513) He had then said, “God is Truth.” “But”, he added, “two years ago I advanced another step.
('54', 462, 3, 11, 976604) I now say,” Truth is God’.
('54', 462, 3, 12, 976631) For even the atheists do not doubt the necessity for the power of truth.
('54', 462, 3, 13, 976704) In their passion for discovering the truth, the atheists have not hesitated to deny the existence of God, and, from their point of view, they are right.” You will understand from this single trait the boldness and independence of this religious spirit from the Orient.
('54', 462, 3, 14, 976973) I noted in him traits similar to Vivekananda.
('54', 462, 4, 15, 977019) And yet not a single political ruse catches him unprepared.
('54', 462, 4, 16, 977079) And his own politics are to say everyting that he thinks to everybody, not concealing a thing.
('54', 462, 5, 17, 977174) On the last evening, after the prayers, Gandhi asked me to play him a little of Beethoven.
('54', 462, 5, 18, 977265) (He does not know Beethoven, but he knows that Beethoven has been the intermediary between Mira and me 1, and consequently between Mira and himself, and that, in the final count, it is to Beethoven that the gratitude of us all must go.) I played him the Andante of the Fifth Symphony.
('54', 462, 5, 19, 977550) To that I added “Les Champs Elyses” of Gluck—the page for the orchestra and the air for the flute.
('54', 462, 6, 20, 977649) He is very sensitive to the religious chants of his country, which somewhat resemble the most beautiful of our Gregorian melodies, and he has worked to assemble them.
('54', 462, 6, 21, 977816) We also exchanged our ideas on art, from which he does not separate his conception of truth, nor from his conception of truth that of joy, which he thinks truth should bring.
('54', 462, 6, 22, 977991) But it follows of itself that for this heroic nature joy does not come without effort, nor even life itself without hardship.
('54', 462, 6, 23, 978117) “The seeker after truth hath a heart tender as the lotus, and hard as granite.”
('54', 462, 7, 24, 978197) Here, my dear friend, are a few hints of those days of ours together on which I have taken much more detailed notes.
('54', 462, 7, 25, 978314) What I do not dwell on to you is the hurricane of intruders, loiterers and half wits which this visit loosed on our two villas.
('54', 462, 7, 26, 978442) No, the

('54', 463, 1, 3, 978675) The milkmen’s syndicate at Leman informed me that during all the time of this sojourn with me of the “King of India” they intended to assume complete responsibility for his “victualling”.
('54', 463, 1, 4, 978863) We received letters from “Sons of God”.

('54', 466, 26, 31, 985552) APPENDIX IV
('54', 466, 27, 32, 985564) VERRIER ELWIN ON GANDHIJI’S ARREST 1
('54', 466, 28, 33, 985601) Gandhi was staying in a house called Mani Bhuvan and he invited us to stay with him there.
('54', 466, 28, 34, 985692) There was great excitement in the city; the Viceroy had finally rejected the Congress offer of peace; Nehru was already in jail, and arrest of other national leaders was expected at any moment.
('54', 466, 29, 35, 985886) But when we reached Mani Bhuvan and climbed to the roof, we found a great serenity in astonishing contrast to the crowds and turmoil outside.
('54', 466, 29, 36, 986028) The roof was a very pleasant place.
('54', 466, 29, 37, 986064) Low tents had been erected, and there were palms and plants; at
('54', 466, 30, 38, 986128) 1 Vide “Letter to Varrier Elwin”, 4 1 1932
('54', 467, 0, 1, 986171) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 468
('54', 467, 1, 2, 986217) least 300 people could gather there.
('54', 467, 1, 3, 986254) It was cool and you could see the stars.
('54', 467, 1, 4, 986295) Bapu was sitting at the wheel quietly spinning.
('54', 467, 1, 5, 986343) He had already begun his weekly silence.
('54', 467, 1, 6, 986384) I carried on a one sided conversation with him, and he wrote down his questions and replied on a scrap of paper which I still have.
('54', 467, 1, 7, 986516) I must have begun by asking if there was anything I could do.
('54', 467, 1, 8, 986578) He wrote: “I have sent for you for that very purpose.
('54', 467, 1, 9, 986632) I have told Mahadev all I have been revolving in my mind.
('54', 467, 1, 10, 986690) When he comes he will tell you or I shall briefly write what is wanted.
('54', 467, 1, 11, 986762) How are you keeping in health?
('54', 467, 1, 12, 986793) He [Mahadev] 1 should be coming shortly.
('54', 467, 1, 13, 986834) If he does not during the time I finish this I shall write out what I want to say.
('54', 467, 1, 14, 986917) You are sleeping here?
('54', 467, 1, 15, 986940) If so is your bedding, etc., arranged?” Then Shamrao and I retired to the smaller tent and Bapu lay down about three yards from us, while some thirty others lay on the roof under the canvas shelter.
('54', 467, 1, 16, 987139) Mrs. Gandhi and Mirabehn gave us a surprisingly satisfying supper of dates, nuts and fruit.
('54', 467, 1, 17, 987231) But I could not sleep.
('54', 467, 1, 18, 987254) As I wrote at the time, ‘I felt I had to keep vigil, and for hours I was under those splendid stars that rose, tier upon tier above me, while beside me Bapu slept like a child committed to his Father’s hands.
('54', 467, 1, 19, 987463) I thought of Christ going up to Jerusalem, his eyes filled with determination and courage: and I seemed to see the Spirit of Christ travelling the centuries like a bright sword turned against all wrong and injustice.
('54', 467, 1, 20, 987680) Among these sleeping friends so dear to us, brave, pure hearted, sincere, the spirit of love was manifest and unconquerable.
('54', 467, 1, 21, 987805) At last I lay down between Shamrao and Bernard on my hastily improvised bed on the floor, just beside Bapu, and fell into a deep sleep, when suddenly like the coming of a dream there was a stir and a whisper: ‘The police have come.’ We started up and I saw what I shall never forget—a fully uniformed Commissioner of Police at the foot of Bapu’s bed, and Bapu just waking, a little bewildered, looking old, fragile and rather pathetic with the mists of sleep still on his face.
('54', 467, 1, 22, 988283) ‘Mr. Gandhi, it is my duty to arrest you.’ A beautiful smile of welcome broke out on Bapu’s face and now he looked young, strong and confident.
('54', 467, 1, 23, 988427) He made signs to show that he was keeping silence.
('54', 467, 1, 24, 988478) The Commissioner smiled and with great courtesy said, ‘I should like you to be ready in half an hour’s time.’ It was five minutes past three.
('54', 467, 1, 25, 988620) Bapu looked at his watch and the Commissioner said, ‘Ah, the famous watch!’ and they both laughed heartily.
('54', 467, 1, 26, 988728) Bapu took a pencil and wrote, ‘I will be ready to come with you in half an hour.’
('54', 467, 2, 27, 988810) 1 As given in the source.
('54', 468, 0, 1, 988836) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 469
('54', 468, 1, 2, 988882) The Commissioner laid his hand on Bapu’s shoulder with a gesture so full of
('54', 468, 2, 3, 988958) affection that I thought it was an embrace, until I realized that it was the formal token
('54', 468, 3, 4, 989048) of arrest.
('54', 468, 3, 5, 989059) Bapu then cleaned his teeth and retired for a moment.
('54', 468, 3, 6, 989113) The door was guarded,
('54', 468, 4, 7, 989135) and all of us who were on the roof sat round in a circle.
('54', 468, 4, 8, 989193) I looked out on to the road
('54', 468, 5, 9, 989221) where some had been keeping all night vigil and where a little crowd, very quiet and
('54', 468, 6, 10, 989306) orderly, had collected, but there were no special police precautions.
('54', 468, 7, 11, 989376) When he was ready, Bapu sat in the midst of us for the prayers and we sang
('54', 468, 8, 12, 989451) together the song of the true Vaishnava.
('54', 468, 8, 13, 989492) Then Bapu took pencil and paper and wrote a
('54', 468, 9, 14, 989536) few messages, some last instructions to his followers and a letter 1 to Sardar
('54', 468, 10, 15, 989615) Vallabhbhai, which was as follows: .
('54', 468, 11, 16, 989652) He then wrote a short note 2 and gave it to me: .
('54', 468, 12, 17, 989702) Then Bapu stood up to take farewell.
('54', 468, 12, 18, 989739) It was a strange sight: the police at the
('54', 468, 13, 19, 989781) door, Mirabehn and Devdas bustling to and fro with the baggage which was already
('54', 468, 14, 20, 989862) packed, Bapu surrounded by his friends, many of them weeping.
('54', 468, 14, 21, 989924) Mrs. Gandhi with
('54', 468, 15, 22, 989941) tears running down her cheeks said, “Can’t you take me with you?” Everyone in turn
('54', 468, 16, 23, 990024) touched his feet, and when I said goodbye he pulled my ear with a smile.
('54', 468, 16, 24, 990097) He was in
('54', 468, 17, 25, 990107) very good spirits: he might have been going to a festival rather than a jail.
('54', 468, 18, 26, 990185) Then, followed by the whole company, he went downstairs.
('54', 468, 18, 27, 990242) Shamrao and
('54', 468, 19, 28, 990254) I watched from the roof.
('54', 468, 19, 29, 990279) The tiny figure got into the car and the crowd surged round
('54', 468, 20, 30, 990339) It was a wonderful tribute to India’s non violence that there were only a few
('54', 468, 21, 31, 990417) policemen and they were able to be in the midst of the crowd without fear ofdanger.
('54', 468, 22, 32, 990501) Just at that moment a message came to say that Sardar Vallabhbhai, the Congress
('54', 468, 23, 33, 990581) President had also been arrested.
('54', 468, 23, 34, 990615) And then the crowd scattered as the car bearing the
('54', 468, 24, 35, 990667) very soul of India drove away through the dark and deserted streets.

('54', 469, 14, 12, 991173) I am directed to inform you that the Governor in Council has been pleased to issue the following orders with regard to the privileges to be allowed for the present to
('54', 469, 15, 13, 991340) the State Prisoners, Messrs Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Patel and
('54', 469, 16, 14, 991421) regarding the arrangements to be made for their periodical medical examination.
('54', 469, 17, 15, 991501) 2. PERIODICALS AND NEWSPAPERS: Both the prisoners should be allowed the following periodicals and newspapers: The Times of India, The Bombay Chronicle, The Leader (Allahabad), The Tribune (Lahore), The Hindu (Madras), The Indian Social Reformer, The Modern Review, Young India and Navajivan.
('54', 469, 18, 16, 991793) 3. LETTERS: Both the prisoners may, as requested by them, be allowed to write letters once a week; or oftener with the previous permission of the Superintendent of the Prison.
('54', 469, 18, 17, 991969) All correspondence to and from the prisoners should be censored by the Superintendent of the Prison.
('54', 469, 18, 18, 992070) Vernacular letters which cannot be translated in the Prison should be sent to the Oriental Translator to Government for translation unless the District Magistrate can arrange to have them translated in his office.
('54', 469, 18, 19, 992284) All objectionable correspondence should be withheld.
('54', 469, 18, 20, 992337) In doubtful cases areference should
('54', 469, 19, 21, 992373) 1 Vide “Letter to Ramananda Chatterjee”, 22 1 1932
('54', 470, 0, 1, 992424) VOL.54: 13 OCTOBER, 1931 8 FEBRUARY, 1932 471
('54', 470, 1, 2, 992470) be made to Government.
('54', 470, 1, 3, 992493) Any letters which the Superintendent considers should be seen by the Police should be forwarded by him to the Deputy Inspector General of Police, C.I.D., Poona.
('54', 470, 2, 4, 992654) 4. HEALTH AND PERIODICAL MEDICAL EXAMINATION: The two prisoners will
('54', 470, 3, 5, 992723) remain in the medical care of the Superintendent of the Prison, but arrangements
('54', 470, 4, 6, 992804) should be made in consultation with the Surgeon General with the Government of
('54', 470, 5, 7, 992883) Bombay for their full medical examination with as little delay as possible by the
('54', 470, 6, 8, 992965) Civil Surgeon, Poona, in conjunction with the Superintendent and for a report of the
('54', 470, 7, 9, 993050) examination to be submitted to Government at once.
('54', 470, 7, 10, 993101) Similar arrangements should be
('54', 470, 8, 11, 993132) made for subsequent medical examination by the same two officers of Mr. Gandhi once
('54', 470, 9, 12, 993216) a month and of Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel once in three months.
('54', 470, 9, 13, 993275) A copy of the report
('54', 470, 10, 14, 993296) should in each case be submitted to the Private Secretary to His Excellency the
('54', 470, 11, 15, 993376) Governor.
('54', 470, 11, 16, 993386) The Superintendent should also consult the Civil Surgeon, Poona, if at any
('54', 470, 12, 17, 993461) time either prisoner appears to be suffering in health or is attacked by any serious
('54', 470, 13, 18, 993546) illness.
('54', 470, 14, 19, 993555) I am to request that you will communicate to the prisoners, through the
('54', 470, 15, 20, 993627) Superintendent, the orders in paragraphs 2, 3 and 4 so far as they pertain to them
('54', 470, 16, 21, 993710) with the omission of the instructions regarding censorship of correspondence in
('54', 470, 17, 22, 993790) paragraph 3.
